text: Chapter One: Education as a Necessity of Life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Renewal of Life by Transmission. The most notable distinction between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: living and inanimate things is that the former maintain themselves by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: renewal. A stone when struck resists. If its resistance is greater than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the force of the blow struck, it remains outwardly unchanged. Otherwise,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is shattered into smaller bits. Never does the stone attempt to react
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in such a way that it may maintain itself against the blow, much less so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to render the blow a contributing factor to its own continued action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While the living thing may easily be crushed by superior force, it none
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the less tries to turn the energies which act upon it into means of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own further existence. If it cannot do so, it does not just split into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: smaller pieces (at least in the higher forms of life), but loses its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identity as a living thing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As long as it endures, it struggles to use surrounding energies in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own behalf. It uses light, air, moisture, and the material of soil. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: say that it uses them is to say that it turns them into means of its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conservation. As long as it is growing, the energy it expends in thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: turning the environment to account is more than compensated for by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the return it gets: it grows. Understanding the word "control" in this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense, it may be said that a living being is one that subjugates
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and controls for its own continued activity the energies that would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: otherwise use it up. Life is a self-renewing process through action upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In all the higher forms this process cannot be kept up indefinitely.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: After a while they succumb; they die. The creature is not equal to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: task of indefinite self-renewal. But continuity of the life process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not dependent upon the prolongation of the existence of any one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual. Reproduction of other forms of life goes on in continuous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sequence. And though, as the geological record shows, not merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals but also species die out, the life process continues in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increasingly complex forms. As some species die out, forms better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adapted to utilize the obstacles against which they struggled in vain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: come into being. Continuity of life means continual readaptation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment to the needs of living organisms.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We have been speaking of life in its lowest terms--as a physical thing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But we use the word "Life" to denote the whole range of experience,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual and racial. When we see a book called the Life of Lincoln
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we do not expect to find within its covers a treatise on physiology.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We look for an account of social antecedents; a description of early
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surroundings, of the conditions and occupation of the family; of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chief episodes in the development of character; of signal struggles and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achievements; of the individual's hopes, tastes, joys and sufferings. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely similar fashion we speak of the life of a savage tribe, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the Athenian people, of the American nation. "Life" covers customs,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions, beliefs, victories and defeats, recreations and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We employ the word "experience" in the same pregnant sense. And to it,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as well as to life in the bare physiological sense, the principle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of continuity through renewal applies. With the renewal of physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence goes, in the case of human beings, the recreation of beliefs,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals, hopes, happiness, misery, and practices. The continuity of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, through renewing of the social group, is a literal fact.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Education, in its broadest sense, is the means of this social continuity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life. Every one of the constituent elements of a social group, in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modern city as in a savage tribe, is born immature, helpless, without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language, beliefs, ideas, or social standards. Each individual, each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unit who is the carrier of the life-experience of his group, in time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: passes away. Yet the life of the group goes on.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The primary ineluctable facts of the birth and death of each one of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the constituent members in a social group determine the necessity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education. On one hand, there is the contrast between the immaturity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the new-born members of the group--its future sole representatives--and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the maturity of the adult members who possess the knowledge and customs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the group. On the other hand, there is the necessity that these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immature members be not merely physically preserved in adequate numbers,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but that they be initiated into the interests, purposes, information,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: skill, and practices of the mature members: otherwise the group will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cease its characteristic life. Even in a savage tribe, the achievements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of adults are far beyond what the immature members would be capable of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if left to themselves. With the growth of civilization, the gap between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the original capacities of the immature and the standards and customs of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the elders increases. Mere physical growing up, mere mastery of the bare
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessities of subsistence will not suffice to reproduce the life of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the group. Deliberate effort and the taking of thoughtful pains are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: required. Beings who are born not only unaware of, but quite indifferent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to, the aims and habits of the social group have to be rendered
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cognizant of them and actively interested. Education, and education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alone, spans the gap.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Society exists through a process of transmission quite as much as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: biological life. This transmission occurs by means of communication of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits of doing, thinking, and feeling from the older to the younger.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Without this communication of ideals, hopes, expectations, standards,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opinions, from those members of society who are passing out of the group
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life to those who are coming into it, social life could not survive.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If the members who compose a society lived on continuously, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: might educate the new-born members, but it would be a task directed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by personal interest rather than social need. Now it is a work of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If a plague carried off the members of a society all at once, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obvious that the group would be permanently done for. Yet the death of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each of its constituent members is as certain as if an epidemic took
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them all at once. But the graded difference in age, the fact that some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are born as some die, makes possible through transmission of ideas and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practices the constant reweaving of the social fabric. Yet this renewal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not automatic. Unless pains are taken to see that genuine and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thorough transmission takes place, the most civilized group will relapse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into barbarism and then into savagery. In fact, the human young are so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immature that if they were left to themselves without the guidance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and succor of others, they could not acquire the rudimentary abilities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessary for physical existence. The young of human beings compare
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so poorly in original efficiency with the young of many of the lower
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: animals, that even the powers needed for physical sustentation have to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be acquired under tuition. How much more, then, is this the case with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respect to all the technological, artistic, scientific, and moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achievements of humanity!
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Education and Communication. So obvious, indeed, is the necessity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching and learning for the continued existence of a society that we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may seem to be dwelling unduly on a truism. But justification is found
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the fact that such emphasis is a means of getting us away from an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unduly scholastic and formal notion of education. Schools are, indeed,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one important method of the transmission which forms the dispositions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the immature; but it is only one means, and, compared with other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: agencies, a relatively superficial means. Only as we have grasped the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessity of more fundamental and persistent modes of tuition can we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make sure of placing the scholastic methods in their true context.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Society not only continues to exist by transmission, by communication,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but it may fairly be said to exist in transmission, in communication.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is more than a verbal tie between the words common, community,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and communication. Men live in a community in virtue of the things which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have in common; and communication is the way in which they come to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possess things in common. What they must have in common in order to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form a community or society are aims, beliefs, aspirations, knowledge--a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: common understanding--like-mindedness as the sociologists say. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things cannot be passed physically from one to another, like bricks;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they cannot be shared as persons would share a pie by dividing it into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical pieces. The communication which insures participation in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: common understanding is one which secures similar emotional and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual dispositions--like ways of responding to expectations and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Persons do not become a society by living in physical proximity, any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more than a man ceases to be socially influenced by being so many feet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or miles removed from others. A book or a letter may institute a more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intimate association between human beings separated thousands of miles
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from each other than exists between dwellers under the same roof.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Individuals do not even compose a social group because they all work
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for a common end. The parts of a machine work with a maximum of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cooperativeness for a common result, but they do not form a community.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If, however, they were all cognizant of the common end and all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interested in it so that they regulated their specific activity in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: view of it, then they would form a community. But this would involve
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communication. Each would have to know what the other was about and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would have to have some way of keeping the other informed as to his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose and progress. Consensus demands communication.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We are thus compelled to recognize that within even the most social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group there are many relations which are not as yet social. A large
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of human relationships in any social group are still upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: machine-like plane. Individuals use one another so as to get desired
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results, without reference to the emotional and intellectual disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and consent of those used. Such uses express physical superiority, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superiority of position, skill, technical ability, and command of tools,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mechanical or fiscal. So far as the relations of parent and child,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teacher and pupil, employer and employee, governor and governed, remain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon this level, they form no true social group, no matter how closely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their respective activities touch one another. Giving and taking of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: orders modifies action and results, but does not of itself effect a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sharing of purposes, a communication of interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Not only is social life identical with communication, but all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communication (and hence all genuine social life) is educative. To be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a recipient of a communication is to have an enlarged and changed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. One shares in what another has thought and felt and in so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: far, meagerly or amply, has his own attitude modified. Nor is the one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who communicates left unaffected. Try the experiment of communicating,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with fullness and accuracy, some experience to another, especially if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be somewhat complicated, and you will find your own attitude toward
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: your experience changing; otherwise you resort to expletives and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ejaculations. The experience has to be formulated in order to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communicated. To formulate requires getting outside of it, seeing it as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another would see it, considering what points of contact it has with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the life of another so that it may be got into such form that he can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciate its meaning. Except in dealing with commonplaces and catch
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: phrases one has to assimilate, imaginatively, something of another's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience in order to tell him intelligently of one's own experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: All communication is like art. It may fairly be said, therefore, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any social arrangement that remains vitally social, or vitally shared,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is educative to those who participate in it. Only when it becomes cast
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in a mold and runs in a routine way does it lose its educative power.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In final account, then, not only does social life demand teaching and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning for its own permanence, but the very process of living together
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educates. It enlarges and enlightens experience; it stimulates and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enriches imagination; it creates responsibility for accuracy and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vividness of statement and thought. A man really living alone (alone
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mentally as well as physically) would have little or no occasion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to reflect upon his past experience to extract its net meaning. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inequality of achievement between the mature and the immature not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessitates teaching the young, but the necessity of this teaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gives an immense stimulus to reducing experience to that order and form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which will render it most easily communicable and hence most usable.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Place of Formal Education. There is, accordingly, a marked
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference between the education which every one gets from living
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with others, as long as he really lives instead of just continuing to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsist, and the deliberate educating of the young. In the former case
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the education is incidental; it is natural and important, but it is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the express reason of the association. While it may be said, without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exaggeration, that the measure of the worth of any social institution,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economic, domestic, political, legal, religious, is its effect in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlarging and improving experience; yet this effect is not a part of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its original motive, which is limited and more immediately practical.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Religious associations began, for example, in the desire to secure the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: favor of overruling powers and to ward off evil influences; family
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life in the desire to gratify appetites and secure family perpetuity;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systematic labor, for the most part, because of enslavement to others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc. Only gradually was the by-product of the institution, its effect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the quality and extent of conscious life, noted, and only more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradually still was this effect considered as a directive factor in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conduct of the institution. Even today, in our industrial life, apart
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from certain values of industriousness and thrift, the intellectual and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emotional reaction of the forms of human association under which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world's work is carried on receives little attention as compared with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical output.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But in dealing with the young, the fact of association itself as an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate human fact, gains in importance. While it is easy to ignore in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our contact with them the effect of our acts upon their disposition,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or to subordinate that educative effect to some external and tangible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result, it is not so easy as in dealing with adults. The need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training is too evident; the pressure to accomplish a change in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitude and habits is too urgent to leave these consequences wholly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out of account. Since our chief business with them is to enable them to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: share in a common life we cannot help considering whether or no we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forming the powers which will secure this ability. If humanity has made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some headway in realizing that the ultimate value of every institution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is its distinctively human effect--its effect upon conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience--we may well believe that this lesson has been learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: largely through dealings with the young.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We are thus led to distinguish, within the broad educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process which we have been so far considering, a more formal kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education--that of direct tuition or schooling. In undeveloped social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: groups, we find very little formal teaching and training. Savage groups
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mainly rely for instilling needed dispositions into the young upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same sort of association which keeps adults loyal to their group. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have no special devices, material, or institutions for teaching save in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with initiation ceremonies by which the youth are inducted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into full social membership. For the most part, they depend upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children learning the customs of the adults, acquiring their emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set and stock of ideas, by sharing in what the elders are doing. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part, this sharing is direct, taking part in the occupations of adults
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thus serving an apprenticeship; in part, it is indirect, through the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dramatic plays in which children reproduce the actions of grown-ups
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thus learn to know what they are like. To savages it would seem
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preposterous to seek out a place where nothing but learning was going on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in order that one might learn.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But as civilization advances, the gap between the capacities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: young and the concerns of adults widens. Learning by direct sharing in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the pursuits of grown-ups becomes increasingly difficult except in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: case of the less advanced occupations. Much of what adults do is so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remote in space and in meaning that playful imitation is less and less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequate to reproduce its spirit. Ability to share effectively in adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities thus depends upon a prior training given with this end in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: view. Intentional agencies--schools--and explicit material--studies--are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devised. The task of teaching certain things is delegated to a special
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group of persons.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Without such formal education, it is not possible to transmit all the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources and achievements of a complex society. It also opens a way to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a kind of experience which would not be accessible to the young, if they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were left to pick up their training in informal association with others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: since books and the symbols of knowledge are mastered.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But there are conspicuous dangers attendant upon the transition from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indirect to formal education. Sharing in actual pursuit, whether
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directly or vicariously in play, is at least personal and vital. These
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities compensate, in some measure, for the narrowness of available
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities. Formal instruction, on the contrary, easily becomes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remote and dead--abstract and bookish, to use the ordinary words of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depreciation. What accumulated knowledge exists in low grade societies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is at least put into practice; it is transmuted into character; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exists with the depth of meaning that attaches to its coming within
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: urgent daily interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But in an advanced culture much which has to be learned is stored in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: symbols. It is far from translation into familiar acts and objects. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material is relatively technical and superficial. Taking the ordinary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standard of reality as a measure, it is artificial. For this measure is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with practical concerns. Such material exists in a world by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself, unassimilated to ordinary customs of thought and expression.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is the standing danger that the material of formal instruction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will be merely the subject matter of the schools, isolated from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of life-experience. The permanent social interests are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: likely to be lost from view. Those which have not been carried over
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into the structure of social life, but which remain largely matters
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of technical information expressed in symbols, are made conspicuous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in schools. Thus we reach the ordinary notion of education: the notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which ignores its social necessity and its identity with all human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: association that affects conscious life, and which identifies it with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imparting information about remote matters and the conveying of learning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through verbal signs: the acquisition of literacy.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence one of the weightiest problems with which the philosophy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education has to cope is the method of keeping a proper balance between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the informal and the formal, the incidental and the intentional,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modes of education. When the acquiring of information and of technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual skill do not influence the formation of a social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition, ordinary vital experience fails to gain in meaning, while
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schooling, in so far, creates only "sharps" in learning--that is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: egoistic specialists. To avoid a split between what men consciously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: know because they are aware of having learned it by a specific job of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning, and what they unconsciously know because they have absorbed it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the formation of their characters by intercourse with others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes an increasingly delicate task with every development of special
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schooling.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. It is the very nature of life to strive to continue in being.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since this continuance can be secured only by constant renewals, life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is a self-renewing process. What nutrition and reproduction are to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physiological life, education is to social life. This education consists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: primarily in transmission through communication. Communication is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process of sharing experience till it becomes a common possession. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modifies the disposition of both the parties who partake in it. That
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ulterior significance of every mode of human association lies in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the contribution which it makes to the improvement of the quality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of experience is a fact most easily recognized in dealing with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immature. That is to say, while every social arrangement is educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in effect, the educative effect first becomes an important part of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose of the association in connection with the association of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: older with the younger. As societies become more complex in structure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and resources, the need of formal or intentional teaching and learning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increases. As formal teaching and training grow in extent, there is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: danger of creating an undesirable split between the experience gained in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more direct associations and what is acquired in school. This danger was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: never greater than at the present time, on account of the rapid growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the last few centuries of knowledge and technical modes of skill.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Two: Education as a Social Function
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Nature and Meaning of Environment. We have seen that a community
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or social group sustains itself through continuous self-renewal, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that this renewal takes place by means of the educational growth of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immature members of the group. By various agencies, unintentional and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: designed, a society transforms uninitiated and seemingly alien beings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into robust trustees of its own resources and ideals. Education is thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a fostering, a nurturing, a cultivating, process. All of these words
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mean that it implies attention to the conditions of growth. We also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speak of rearing, raising, bringing up--words which express the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference of level which education aims to cover. Etymologically, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: word education means just a process of leading or bringing up. When
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we have the outcome of the process in mind, we speak of education as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shaping, forming, molding activity--that is, a shaping into the standard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form of social activity. In this chapter we are concerned with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general features of the way in which a social group brings up its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immature members into its own social form.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since what is required is a transformation of the quality of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: till it partakes in the interests, purposes, and ideas current in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social group, the problem is evidently not one of mere physical forming.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Things can be physically transported in space; they may be bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conveyed. Beliefs and aspirations cannot be physically extracted and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inserted. How then are they communicated? Given the impossibility of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct contagion or literal inculcation, our problem is to discover the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method by which the young assimilate the point of view of the old, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the older bring the young into like-mindedness with themselves. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: answer, in general formulation, is: By means of the action of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment in calling out certain responses. The required beliefs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot be hammered in; the needed attitudes cannot be plastered on. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the particular medium in which an individual exists leads him to see and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: feel one thing rather than another; it leads him to have certain plans
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in order that he may act successfully with others; it strengthens some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beliefs and weakens others as a condition of winning the approval of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others. Thus it gradually produces in him a certain system of behavior,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a certain disposition of action. The words "environment," "medium"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: denote something more than surroundings which encompass an individual.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They denote the specific continuity of the surroundings with his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active tendencies. An inanimate being is, of course, continuous with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its surroundings; but the environing circumstances do not, save
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: metaphorically, constitute an environment. For the inorganic being is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not concerned in the influences which affect it. On the other hand,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some things which are remote in space and time from a living creature,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: especially a human creature, may form his environment even more truly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than some of the things close to him. The things with which a man varies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are his genuine environment. Thus the activities of the astronomer vary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the stars at which he gazes or about which he calculates. Of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his immediate surroundings, his telescope is most intimately his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment. The environment of an antiquarian, as an antiquarian,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consists of the remote epoch of human life with which he is concerned,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the relics, inscriptions, etc., by which he establishes connections
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with that period.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In brief, the environment consists of those conditions that promote or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hinder, stimulate or inhibit, the characteristic activities of a living
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being. Water is the environment of a fish because it is necessary to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fish's activities--to its life. The north pole is a significant element
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the environment of an arctic explorer, whether he succeeds in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reaching it or not, because it defines his activities, makes them what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they distinctively are. Just because life signifies not bare passive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence (supposing there is such a thing), but a way of acting,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment or medium signifies what enters into this activity as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sustaining or frustrating condition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Social Environment. A being whose activities are associated with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others has a social environment. What he does and what he can do depend
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the expectations, demands, approvals, and condemnations of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A being connected with other beings cannot perform his own activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without taking the activities of others into account. For they are the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indispensable conditions of the realization of his tendencies. When he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moves he stirs them and reciprocally. We might as well try to imagine a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: business man doing business, buying and selling, all by himself, as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceive it possible to define the activities of an individual in terms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of his isolated actions. The manufacturer moreover is as truly socially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: guided in his activities when he is laying plans in the privacy of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own counting house as when he is buying his raw material or selling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his finished goods. Thinking and feeling that have to do with action in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: association with others is as much a social mode of behavior as is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: most overt cooperative or hostile act.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What we have more especially to indicate is how the social medium
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nurtures its immature members. There is no great difficulty in seeing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: how it shapes the external habits of action. Even dogs and horses have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their actions modified by association with human beings; they form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different habits because human beings are concerned with what they do.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Human beings control animals by controlling the natural stimuli which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence them; by creating a certain environment in other words. Food,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bits and bridles, noises, vehicles, are used to direct the ways in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the natural or instinctive responses of horses occur. By operating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: steadily to call out certain acts, habits are formed which function with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same uniformity as the original stimuli. If a rat is put in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: maze and finds food only by making a given number of turns in a given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sequence, his activity is gradually modified till he habitually takes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that course rather than another when he is hungry.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Human actions are modified in a like fashion. A burnt child dreads the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fire; if a parent arranged conditions so that every time a child touched
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a certain toy he got burned, the child would learn to avoid that toy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as automatically as he avoids touching fire. So far, however, we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dealing with what may be called training in distinction from educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching. The changes considered are in outer action rather than in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental and emotional dispositions of behavior. The distinction is not,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, a sharp one. The child might conceivably generate in time a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: violent antipathy, not only to that particular toy, but to the class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of toys resembling it. The aversion might even persist after he had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forgotten about the original burns; later on he might even invent some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason to account for his seemingly irrational antipathy. In some cases,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: altering the external habit of action by changing the environment to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affect the stimuli to action will also alter the mental disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerned in the action. Yet this does not always happen; a person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trained to dodge a threatening blow, dodges automatically with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no corresponding thought or emotion. We have to find, then, some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: differentia of training from education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A clew may be found in the fact that the horse does not really share in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the social use to which his action is put. Some one else uses the horse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to secure a result which is advantageous by making it advantageous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the horse to perform the act--he gets food, etc. But the horse,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presumably, does not get any new interest. He remains interested in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: food, not in the service he is rendering. He is not a partner in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shared activity. Were he to become a copartner, he would, in engaging
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the conjoint activity, have the same interest in its accomplishment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which others have. He would share their ideas and emotions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Now in many cases--too many cases--the activity of the immature human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being is simply played upon to secure habits which are useful. He is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trained like an animal rather than educated like a human being. His
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instincts remain attached to their original objects of pain or pleasure.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But to get happiness or to avoid the pain of failure he has to act in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a way agreeable to others. In other cases, he really shares or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: participates in the common activity. In this case, his original impulse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is modified. He not merely acts in a way agreeing with the actions of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, but, in so acting, the same ideas and emotions are aroused
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in him that animate the others. A tribe, let us say, is warlike. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successes for which it strives, the achievements upon which it sets
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
