text: store, are connected with fighting and victory. The presence of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: medium incites bellicose exhibitions in a boy, first in games, then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in fact when he is strong enough. As he fights he wins approval and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advancement; as he refrains, he is disliked, ridiculed, shut out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from favorable recognition. It is not surprising that his original
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: belligerent tendencies and emotions are strengthened at the expense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, and that his ideas turn to things connected with war. Only in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this way can he become fully a recognized member of his group. Thus his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental habitudes are gradually assimilated to those of his group.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If we formulate the principle involved in this illustration, we shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceive that the social medium neither implants certain desires and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas directly, nor yet merely establishes certain purely muscular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits of action, like "instinctively" winking or dodging a blow.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Setting up conditions which stimulate certain visible and tangible ways
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of acting is the first step. Making the individual a sharer or partner
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the associated activity so that he feels its success as his success,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its failure as his failure, is the completing step. As soon as he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possessed by the emotional attitude of the group, he will be alert to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognize the special ends at which it aims and the means employed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: secure success. His beliefs and ideas, in other words, will take a form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: similar to those of others in the group. He will also achieve pretty
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much the same stock of knowledge since that knowledge is an ingredient
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of his habitual pursuits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The importance of language in gaining knowledge is doubtless the chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cause of the common notion that knowledge may be passed directly from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one to another. It almost seems as if all we have to do to convey an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea into the mind of another is to convey a sound into his ear. Thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imparting knowledge gets assimilated to a purely physical process. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning from language will be found, when analyzed, to confirm the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle just laid down. It would probably be admitted with little
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hesitation that a child gets the idea of, say, a hat by using it as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other persons do; by covering the head with it, giving it to others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to wear, having it put on by others when going out, etc. But it may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: asked how this principle of shared activity applies to getting through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speech or reading the idea of, say, a Greek helmet, where no direct use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of any kind enters in. What shared activity is there in learning from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: books about the discovery of America?
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since language tends to become the chief instrument of learning about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: many things, let us see how it works. The baby begins of course with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere sounds, noises, and tones having no meaning, expressing, that is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no idea. Sounds are just one kind of stimulus to direct response, some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having a soothing effect, others tending to make one jump, and so on.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The sound h-a-t would remain as meaningless as a sound in Choctaw, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seemingly inarticulate grunt, if it were not uttered in connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with an action which is participated in by a number of people. When the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mother is taking the infant out of doors, she says "hat" as she puts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something on the baby's head. Being taken out becomes an interest to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: child; mother and child not only go out with each other physically,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but both are concerned in the going out; they enjoy it in common. By
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conjunction with the other factors in activity the sound "hat" soon gets
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same meaning for the child that it has for the parent; it becomes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sign of the activity into which it enters. The bare fact that language
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consists of sounds which are mutually intelligible is enough of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself to show that its meaning depends upon connection with a shared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In short, the sound h-a-t gains meaning in precisely the same way that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the thing "hat" gains it, by being used in a given way. And they acquire
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same meaning with the child which they have with the adult because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are used in a common experience by both. The guarantee for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same manner of use is found in the fact that the thing and the sound are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first employed in a joint activity, as a means of setting up an active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection between the child and a grownup. Similar ideas or meanings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spring up because both persons are engaged as partners in an action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where what each does depends upon and influences what the other does. If
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: two savages were engaged in a joint hunt for game, and a certain signal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meant "move to the right" to the one who uttered it, and "move to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: left" to the one who heard it, they obviously could not successfully
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carry on their hunt together. Understanding one another means that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects, including sounds, have the same value for both with respect to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carrying on a common pursuit.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: After sounds have got meaning through connection with other things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed in a joint undertaking, they can be used in connection with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other like sounds to develop new meanings, precisely as the things for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they stand are combined. Thus the words in which a child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learns about, say, the Greek helmet originally got a meaning (or were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understood) by use in an action having a common interest and end. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: now arouse a new meaning by inciting the one who hears or reads to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rehearse imaginatively the activities in which the helmet has its use.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For the time being, the one who understands the words "Greek helmet"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes mentally a partner with those who used the helmet. He engages,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through his imagination, in a shared activity. It is not easy to get
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the full meaning of words. Most persons probably stop with the idea that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "helmet" denotes a queer kind of headgear a people called the Greeks
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: once wore. We conclude, accordingly, that the use of language to convey
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and acquire ideas is an extension and refinement of the principle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that things gain meaning by being used in a shared experience or joint
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action; in no sense does it contravene that principle. When words do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not enter as factors into a shared situation, either overtly or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imaginatively, they operate as pure physical stimuli, not as having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a meaning or intellectual value. They set activity running in a given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: groove, but there is no accompanying conscious purpose or meaning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Thus, for example, the plus sign may be a stimulus to perform the act of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: writing one number under another and adding the numbers, but the person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performing the act will operate much as an automaton would unless he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realizes the meaning of what he does.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Social Medium as Educative. Our net result thus far is that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social environment forms the mental and emotional disposition of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: behavior in individuals by engaging them in activities that arouse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and strengthen certain impulses, that have certain purposes and entail
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain consequences. A child growing up in a family of musicians will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inevitably have whatever capacities he has in music stimulated, and,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relatively, stimulated more than other impulses which might have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose.

author: Dewey, John

text: (constituting the indirect or incidental education of which we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spoken) furnishes almost the sole influence for rearing the young into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: the practices and beliefs of the group. Even in present-day societies,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: youth. In accord with the interests and occupations of the group,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: certain things become objects of high esteem; others of aversion.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Association does not create impulses or affection and dislike, but it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnishes the objects to which they attach themselves. The way our group
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or class does things tends to determine the proper objects of attention,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thus to prescribe the directions and limits of observation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and memory. What is strange or foreign (that is to say outside
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the activities of the groups) tends to be morally forbidden and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectually suspect. It seems almost incredible to us, for example,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that things which we know very well could have escaped recognition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in past ages. We incline to account for it by attributing congenital
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stupidity to our forerunners and by assuming superior native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence on our own part. But the explanation is that their modes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life did not call for attention to such facts, but held their minds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: riveted to other things. Just as the senses require sensible objects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to stimulate them, so our powers of observation, recollection, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imagination do not work spontaneously, but are set in motion by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: demands set up by current social occupations. The main texture of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition is formed, independently of schooling, by such influences.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What conscious, deliberate teaching can do is at most to free the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities thus formed for fuller exercise, to purge them of some of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their grossness, and to furnish objects which make their activity more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: productive of meaning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While this "unconscious influence of the environment" is so subtle and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pervasive that it affects every fiber of character and mind, it may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be worth while to specify a few directions in which its effect is most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: marked. First, the habits of language. Fundamental modes of speech, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bulk of the vocabulary, are formed in the ordinary intercourse of life,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carried on not as a set means of instruction but as a social necessity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The babe acquires, as we well say, the mother tongue. While speech
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits thus contracted may be corrected or even displaced by conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching, yet, in times of excitement, intentionally acquired modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speech often fall away, and individuals relapse into their really native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tongue. Secondly, manners. Example is notoriously more potent than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precept. Good manners come, as we say, from good breeding or rather are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good breeding; and breeding is acquired by habitual action, in response
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to habitual stimuli, not by conveying information. Despite the never
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ending play of conscious correction and instruction, the surrounding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: atmosphere and spirit is in the end the chief agent in forming manners.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And manners are but minor morals. Moreover, in major morals, conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction is likely to be efficacious only in the degree in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it falls in with the general "walk and conversation" of those who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitute the child's social environment. Thirdly, good taste and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: esthetic appreciation. If the eye is constantly greeted by harmonious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects, having elegance of form and color, a standard of taste
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: naturally grows up. The effect of a tawdry, unarranged, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: over-decorated environment works for the deterioration of taste, just as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meager and barren surroundings starve out the desire for beauty. Against
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such odds, conscious teaching can hardly do more than convey second-hand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information as to what others think. Such taste never becomes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spontaneous and personally engrained, but remains a labored reminder of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what those think to whom one has been taught to look up. To say that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deeper standards of judgments of value are framed by the situations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into which a person habitually enters is not so much to mention a fourth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point, as it is to point out a fusion of those already mentioned. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rarely recognize the extent in which our conscious estimates of what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: worth while and what is not, are due to standards of which we are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious at all. But in general it may be said that the things which we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take for granted without inquiry or reflection are just the things which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: determine our conscious thinking and decide our conclusions. And these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habitudes which lie below the level of reflection are just those which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been formed in the constant give and take of relationship with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others.

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: 4. The School as a Special Environment. The chief importance of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: foregoing statement of the educative process which goes on willy-nilly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to lead us to note that the only way in which adults consciously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control the kind of education which the immature get is by controlling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the environment in which they act, and hence think and feel. We never
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educate directly, but indirectly by means of the environment. Whether
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we permit chance environments to do the work, or whether we design
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environments for the purpose makes a great difference. And any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment is a chance environment so far as its educative influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is concerned unless it has been deliberately regulated with reference to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its educative effect. An intelligent home differs from an unintelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one chiefly in that the habits of life and intercourse which prevail are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chosen, or at least colored, by the thought of their bearing upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of children. But schools remain, of course, the typical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instance of environments framed with express reference to influencing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mental and moral disposition of their members.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Roughly speaking, they come into existence when social traditions are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so complex that a considerable part of the social store is committed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to writing and transmitted through written symbols. Written symbols are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: even more artificial or conventional than spoken; they cannot be picked
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up in accidental intercourse with others. In addition, the written form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tends to select and record matters which are comparatively foreign
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to everyday life. The achievements accumulated from generation to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generation are deposited in it even though some of them have fallen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: temporarily out of use. Consequently as soon as a community depends to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any considerable extent upon what lies beyond its own territory and its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own immediate generation, it must rely upon the set agency of schools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to insure adequate transmission of all its resources. To take an obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: illustration: The life of the ancient Greeks and Romans has profoundly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influenced our own, and yet the ways in which they affect us do not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present themselves on the surface of our ordinary experiences. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: similar fashion, peoples still existing, but remote in space, British,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Germans, Italians, directly concern our own social affairs, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the nature of the interaction cannot be understood without explicit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement and attention. In precisely similar fashion, our daily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: associations cannot be trusted to make clear to the young the part
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: played in our activities by remote physical energies, and by invisible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: structures. Hence a special mode of social intercourse is instituted,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the school, to care for such matters.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This mode of association has three functions sufficiently specific,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as compared with ordinary associations of life, to be noted. First, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complex civilization is too complex to be assimilated in toto. It has to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be broken up into portions, as it were, and assimilated piecemeal, in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradual and graded way. The relationships of our present social life are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so numerous and so interwoven that a child placed in the most favorable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: position could not readily share in many of the most important of them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Not sharing in them, their meaning would not be communicated to him,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would not become a part of his own mental disposition. There would be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no seeing the trees because of the forest. Business, politics, art,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science, religion, would make all at once a clamor for attention;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confusion would be the outcome. The first office of the social organ we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: call the school is to provide a simplified environment. It selects the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: features which are fairly fundamental and capable of being responded to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the young. Then it establishes a progressive order, using the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: factors first acquired as means of gaining insight into what is more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complicated.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the second place, it is the business of the school environment to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eliminate, so far as possible, the unworthy features of the existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment from influence upon mental habitudes. It establishes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purified medium of action. Selection aims not only at simplifying but at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weeding out what is undesirable. Every society gets encumbered with what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is trivial, with dead wood from the past, and with what is positively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perverse. The school has the duty of omitting such things from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment which it supplies, and thereby doing what it can to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: counteract their influence in the ordinary social environment. By
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: selecting the best for its exclusive use, it strives to reinforce the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: power of this best. As a society becomes more enlightened, it realizes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that it is responsible not to transmit and conserve the whole of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its existing achievements, but only such as make for a better future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society. The school is its chief agency for the accomplishment of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the third place, it is the office of the school environment to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: balance the various elements in the social environment, and to see to it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that each individual gets an opportunity to escape from the limitations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the social group in which he was born, and to come into living
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contact with a broader environment. Such words as "society" and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "community" are likely to be misleading, for they have a tendency to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make us think there is a single thing corresponding to the single word.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As a matter of fact, a modern society is many societies more or less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: loosely connected. Each household with its immediate extension of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: friends makes a society; the village or street group of playmates is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: community; each business group, each club, is another. Passing beyond
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these more intimate groups, there is in a country like our own a variety
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of races, religious affiliations, economic divisions. Inside the modern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: city, in spite of its nominal political unity, there are probably more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communities, more differing customs, traditions, aspirations, and forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of government or control, than existed in an entire continent at an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: earlier epoch.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Each such group exercises a formative influence on the active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dispositions of its members. A clique, a club, a gang, a Fagin's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: household of thieves, the prisoners in a jail, provide educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environments for those who enter into their collective or conjoint
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities, as truly as a church, a labor union, a business partnership,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or a political party. Each of them is a mode of associated or community
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life, quite as much as is a family, a town, or a state. There are also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communities whose members have little or no direct contact with one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another, like the guild of artists, the republic of letters, the members
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the professional learned class scattered over the face of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: earth. For they have aims in common, and the activity of each member is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directly modified by knowledge of what others are doing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the olden times, the diversity of groups was largely a geographical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter. There were many societies, but each, within its own territory,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was comparatively homogeneous. But with the development of commerce,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transportation, intercommunication, and emigration, countries like the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: United States are composed of a combination of different groups with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different traditional customs. It is this situation which has, perhaps
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more than any other one cause, forced the demand for an educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institution which shall provide something like a homogeneous and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: balanced environment for the young. Only in this way can the centrifugal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forces set up by juxtaposition of different groups within one and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same political unit be counteracted. The intermingling in the school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of youth of different races, differing religions, and unlike customs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: creates for all a new and broader environment. Common subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accustoms all to a unity of outlook upon a broader horizon than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is visible to the members of any group while it is isolated. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assimilative force of the American public school is eloquent testimony
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the efficacy of the common and balanced appeal.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The school has the function also of coordinating within the disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of each individual the diverse influences of the various social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environments into which he enters. One code prevails in the family;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: is in danger of being split into a being having different standards of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judgment and emotion for different occasions. This danger imposes upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the school a steadying and integrating office.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. The development within the young of the attitudes and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dispositions necessary to the continuous and progressive life of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society cannot take place by direct conveyance of beliefs, emotions, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge. It takes place through the intermediary of the environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The environment consists of the sum total of conditions which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerned in the execution of the activity characteristic of a living
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being. The social environment consists of all the activities of fellow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beings that are bound up in the carrying on of the activities of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one of its members. It is truly educative in its effect in the degree in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which an individual shares or participates in some conjoint activity. By
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing his share in the associated activity, the individual appropriates
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the purpose which actuates it, becomes familiar with its methods and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matters, acquires needed skill, and is saturated with its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emotional spirit.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The deeper and more intimate educative formation of disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comes, without conscious intent, as the young gradually partake of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities of the various groups to which they may belong. As a society
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes more complex, however, it is found necessary to provide a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: special social environment which shall especially look after nurturing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the capacities of the immature. Three of the more important functions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of this special environment are: simplifying and ordering the factors
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the disposition it is wished to develop; purifying and idealizing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the existing social customs; creating a wider and better balanced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment than that by which the young would be likely, if left to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves, to be influenced.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Three: Education as Direction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Environment as Directive.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We now pass to one of the special forms which the general function of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education assumes: namely, that of direction, control, or guidance.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Of these three words, direction, control, and guidance, the last best
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conveys the idea of assisting through cooperation the natural capacities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the individuals guided; control conveys rather the notion of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energy brought to bear from without and meeting some resistance from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one controlled; direction is a more neutral term and suggests the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that the active tendencies of those directed are led in a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuous course, instead of dispersing aimlessly. Direction expresses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the basic function, which tends at one extreme to become a guiding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assistance and at another, a regulation or ruling. But in any case, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must carefully avoid a meaning sometimes read into the term "control."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is sometimes assumed, explicitly or unconsciously, that an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual's tendencies are naturally purely individualistic or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: egoistic, and thus antisocial. Control then denotes the process by which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he is brought to subordinate his natural impulses to public or common
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ends. Since, by conception, his own nature is quite alien to this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process and opposes it rather than helps it, control has in this view
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a flavor of coercion or compulsion about it. Systems of government
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and theories of the state have been built upon this notion, and it has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seriously affected educational ideas and practices. But there is no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ground for any such view. Individuals are certainly interested, at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: times, in having their own way, and their own way may go contrary to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ways of others. But they are also interested, and chiefly interested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the whole, in entering into the activities of others and taking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part in conjoint and cooperative doings. Otherwise, no such thing as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a community would be possible. And there would not even be any one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interested in furnishing the policeman to keep a semblance of harmony
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unless he thought that thereby he could gain some personal advantage.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Control, in truth, means only an emphatic form of direction of powers,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and covers the regulation gained by an individual through his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efforts quite as much as that brought about when others take the lead.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In general, every stimulus directs activity. It does not simply excite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it or stir it up, but directs it toward an object. Put the other way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: around, a response is not just a re-action, a protest, as it were,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: against being disturbed; it is, as the word indicates, an answer. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meets the stimulus, and corresponds with it. There is an adaptation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the stimulus and response to each other. A light is the stimulus to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eye to see something, and the business of the eye is to see. If the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eyes are open and there is light, seeing occurs; the stimulus is but a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: condition of the fulfillment of the proper function of the organ, not an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outside interruption. To some extent, then, all direction or control is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a guiding of activity to its own end; it is an assistance in doing fully
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what some organ is already tending to do.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This general statement needs, however, to be qualified in two respects.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the first place, except in the case of a small number of instincts,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the stimuli to which an immature human being is subject are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sufficiently definite to call out, in the beginning, specific responses.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is always a great deal of superfluous energy aroused. This energy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be wasted, going aside from the point; it may also go against the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successful performance of an act. It does harm by getting in the way.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Compare the behavior of a beginner in riding a bicycle with that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expert. There is little axis of direction in the energies put forth;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are largely dispersive and centrifugal. Direction involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a focusing and fixating of action in order that it may be truly a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: response, and this requires an elimination of unnecessary and confusing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements. In the second place, although no activity can be produced in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the person does not cooperate to some extent, yet a response may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be of a kind which does not fit into the sequence and continuity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action. A person boxing may dodge a particular blow successfully, but in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such a way as to expose himself the next instant to a still harder
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: blow. Adequate control means that the successive acts are brought into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a continuous order; each act not only meets its immediate stimulus but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: helps the acts which follow.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In short, direction is both simultaneous and successive. At a given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time, it requires that, from all the tendencies that are partially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: called out, those be selected which center energy upon the point of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: need. Successively, it requires that each act be balanced with those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which precede and come after, so that order of activity is achieved.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Focusing and ordering are thus the two aspects of direction, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spatial, the other temporal. The first insures hitting the mark; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: second keeps the balance required for further action. Obviously, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not possible to separate them in practice as we have distinguished them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in idea. Activity must be centered at a given time in such a way as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prepare for what comes next. The problem of the immediate response is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complicated by one's having to be on the lookout for future occurrences.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Two conclusions emerge from these general statements. On the one hand,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purely external direction is impossible. The environment can at most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only supply stimuli to call out responses. These responses proceed from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies already possessed by the individual. Even when a person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is frightened by threats into doing something, the threats work only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because the person has an instinct of fear. If he has not, or if, though
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having it, it is under his own control, the threat has no more influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon him than light has in causing a person to see who has no eyes.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While the customs and rules of adults furnish stimuli which direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as well as evoke the activities of the young, the young, after all,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: participate in the direction which their actions finally take. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strict sense, nothing can be forced upon them or into them. To overlook
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this fact means to distort and pervert human nature. To take into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: account the contribution made by the existing instincts and habits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of those directed is to direct them economically and wisely. Speaking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accurately, all direction is but re-direction; it shifts the activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already going on into another channel. Unless one is cognizant of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energies which are already in operation, one's attempts at direction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will almost surely go amiss.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On the other hand, the control afforded by the customs and regulations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of others may be short-sighted. It may accomplish its immediate effect,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but at the expense of throwing the subsequent action of the person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out of balance. A threat may, for example, prevent a person from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing something to which he is naturally inclined by arousing fear of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disagreeable consequences if he persists. But he may be left in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: position which exposes him later on to influences which will lead him
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do even worse things. His instincts of cunning and slyness may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aroused, so that things henceforth appeal to him on the side of evasion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and trickery more than would otherwise have been the case. Those engaged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in directing the actions of others are always in danger of overlooking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the importance of the sequential development of those they direct.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Modes of Social Direction. Adults are naturally most conscious of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directing the conduct of others when they are immediately aiming so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do. As a rule, they have such an aim consciously when they find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves resisted; when others are doing things they do not wish them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do. But the more permanent and influential modes of control are those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which operate from moment to moment continuously without such deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intention on our part.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. When others are not doing what we would like them to or are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: threatening disobedience, we are most conscious of the need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlling them and of the influences by which they are controlled. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such cases, our control becomes most direct, and at this point we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: most likely to make the mistakes just spoken of. We are even likely to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take the influence of superior force for control, forgetting that while
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we may lead a horse to water we cannot make him drink; and that while we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can shut a man up in a penitentiary we cannot make him penitent. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all such cases of immediate action upon others, we need to discriminate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between physical results and moral results. A person may be in such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: condition that forcible feeding or enforced confinement is necessary for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his own good. A child may have to be snatched with roughness away from
