title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a fire so that he shall not be burnt. But no improvement of disposition,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no educative effect, need follow. A harsh and commanding tone may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effectual in keeping a child away from the fire, and the same desirable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical effect will follow as if he had been snatched away. But there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be no more obedience of a moral sort in one case than in the other.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A man can be prevented from breaking into other persons' houses by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shutting him up, but shutting him up may not alter his disposition to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commit burglary. When we confuse a physical with an educative result,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we always lose the chance of enlisting the person's own participating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition in getting the result desired, and thereby of developing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: within him an intrinsic and persisting direction in the right way.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In general, the occasion for the more conscious acts of control should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be limited to acts which are so instinctive or impulsive that the one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performing them has no means of foreseeing their outcome. If a person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot foresee the consequences of his act, and is not capable of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understanding what he is told about its outcome by those with more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, it is impossible for him to guide his act intelligently. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such a state, every act is alike to him. Whatever moves him does move
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: him, and that is all there is to it. In some cases, it is well to permit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: him to experiment, and to discover the consequences for himself in order
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that he may act intelligently next time under similar circumstances. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some courses of action are too discommoding and obnoxious to others to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: allow of this course being pursued. Direct disapproval is now resorted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to. Shaming, ridicule, disfavor, rebuke, and punishment are used. Or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contrary tendencies in the child are appealed to to divert him from his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: troublesome line of behavior. His sensitiveness to approbation, his hope
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of winning favor by an agreeable act, are made use of to induce action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in another direction.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. These methods of control are so obvious (because so intentionally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed) that it would hardly be worth while to mention them if it were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not that notice may now be taken, by way of contrast, of the other more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important and permanent mode of control. This other method resides in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ways in which persons, with whom the immature being is associated,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use things; the instrumentalities with which they accomplish their own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ends. The very existence of the social medium in which an individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lives, moves, and has his being is the standing effective agency of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directing his activity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This fact makes it necessary for us to examine in greater detail what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is meant by the social environment. We are given to separating from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each other the physical and social environments in which we live. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation is responsible on one hand for an exaggeration of the moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: importance of the more direct or personal modes of control of which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we have been speaking; and on the other hand for an exaggeration, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: current psychology and philosophy, of the intellectual possibilities of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contact with a purely physical environment. There is not, in fact, any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such thing as the direct influence of one human being on another apart
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from use of the physical environment as an intermediary. A smile, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: frown, a rebuke, a word of warning or encouragement, all involve some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical change. Otherwise, the attitude of one would not get over to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alter the attitude of another. Comparatively speaking, such modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence may be regarded as personal. The physical medium is reduced to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a mere means of personal contact. In contrast with such direct modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mutual influence, stand associations in common pursuits involving the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use of things as means and as measures of results. Even if the mother
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: never told her daughter to help her, or never rebuked her for not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: helping, the child would be subjected to direction in her activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the mere fact that she was engaged, along with the parent, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: household life. Imitation, emulation, the need of working together,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enforce control.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If the mother hands the child something needed, the latter must reach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the thing in order to get it. Where there is giving there must be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taking. The way the child handles the thing after it is got, the use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which it is put, is surely influenced by the fact that the child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has watched the mother. When the child sees the parent looking for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something, it is as natural for it also to look for the object and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: give it over when it finds it, as it was, under other circumstances, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: receive it. Multiply such an instance by the thousand details of daily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse, and one has a picture of the most permanent and enduring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method of giving direction to the activities of the young.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In saying this, we are only repeating what was said previously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about participating in a joint activity as the chief way of forming
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition. We have explicitly added, however, the recognition of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part played in the joint activity by the use of things. The philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of learning has been unduly dominated by a false psychology. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: frequently stated that a person learns by merely having the qualities of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things impressed upon his mind through the gateway of the senses. Having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: received a store of sensory impressions, association or some power of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental synthesis is supposed to combine them into ideas--into things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a meaning. An object, stone, orange, tree, chair, is supposed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: convey different impressions of color, shape, size, hardness, smell,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taste, etc., which aggregated together constitute the characteristic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning of each thing. But as matter of fact, it is the characteristic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use to which the thing is put, because of its specific qualities, which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplies the meaning with which it is identified. A chair is a thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is put to one use; a table, a thing which is employed for another
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose; an orange is a thing which costs so much, which is grown in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: warm climes, which is eaten, and when eaten has an agreeable odor and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: refreshing taste, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The difference between an adjustment to a physical stimulus and a mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: act is that the latter involves response to a thing in its meaning;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the former does not. A noise may make me jump without my mind being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implicated. When I hear a noise and run and get water and put out a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: blaze, I respond intelligently; the sound meant fire, and fire meant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: need of being extinguished. I bump into a stone, and kick it to one side
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purely physically. I put it to one side for fear some one will stumble
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon it, intelligently; I respond to a meaning which the thing has. I am
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: startled by a thunderclap whether I recognize it or not--more likely, if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: I do not recognize it. But if I say, either out loud or to myself, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is thunder, I respond to the disturbance as a meaning. My behavior has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a mental quality. When things have a meaning for us, we mean (intend,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: propose) what we do: when they do not, we act blindly, unconsciously,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unintelligently.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In both kinds of responsive adjustment, our activities are directed or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlled. But in the merely blind response, direction is also blind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There may be training, but there is no education. Repeated responses to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recurrent stimuli may fix a habit of acting in a certain way. All of us
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have many habits of whose import we are quite unaware, since they were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formed without our knowing what we were about. Consequently they possess
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: us, rather than we them. They move us; they control us. Unless we become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aware of what they accomplish, and pass judgment upon the worth of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result, we do not control them. A child might be made to bow every time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he met a certain person by pressure on his neck muscles, and bowing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would finally become automatic. It would not, however, be an act of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognition or deference on his part, till he did it with a certain end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in view--as having a certain meaning. And not till he knew what he was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about and performed the act for the sake of its meaning could he be said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be "brought up" or educated to act in a certain way. To have an idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a thing is thus not just to get certain sensations from it. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be able to respond to the thing in view of its place in an inclusive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scheme of action; it is to foresee the drift and probable consequence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the action of the thing upon us and of our action upon it. To have the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same ideas about things which others have, to be like-minded with them,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thus to be really members of a social group, is therefore to attach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same meanings to things and to acts which others attach. Otherwise,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is no common understanding, and no community life. But in a shared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity, each person refers what he is doing to what the other is doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vice-versa. That is, the activity of each is placed in the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inclusive situation. To pull at a rope at which others happen to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pulling is not a shared or conjoint activity, unless the pulling is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done with knowledge that others are pulling and for the sake of either
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: helping or hindering what they are doing. A pin may pass in the course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of its manufacture through the hands of many persons. But each may do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his part without knowledge of what others do or without any reference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what they do; each may operate simply for the sake of a separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result--his own pay. There is, in this case, no common consequence to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the several acts are referred, and hence no genuine intercourse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or association, in spite of juxtaposition, and in spite of the fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that their respective doings contribute to a single outcome. But if each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: views the consequences of his own acts as having a bearing upon what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others are doing and takes into account the consequences of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: behavior upon himself, then there is a common mind; a common intent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in behavior. There is an understanding set up between the different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contributors; and this common understanding controls the action of each.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Suppose that conditions were so arranged that one person automatically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: caught a ball and then threw it to another person who caught and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: automatically returned it; and that each so acted without knowing where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ball came from or went to. Clearly, such action would be without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point or meaning. It might be physically controlled, but it would not be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: socially directed. But suppose that each becomes aware of what the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other is doing, and becomes interested in the other's action and thereby
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interested in what he is doing himself as connected with the action of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other. The behavior of each would then be intelligent; and socially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligent and guided. Take one more example of a less imaginary kind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: An infant is hungry, and cries while food is prepared in his presence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If he does not connect his own state with what others are doing, nor
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what they are doing with his own satisfaction, he simply reacts with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increasing impatience to his own increasing discomfort. He is physically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlled by his own organic state. But when he makes a back and forth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reference, his whole attitude changes. He takes an interest, as we say;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he takes note and watches what others are doing. He no longer reacts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just to his own hunger, but behaves in the light of what others are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing for its prospective satisfaction. In that way, he also no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: longer just gives way to hunger without knowing it, but he notes, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognizes, or identifies his own state. It becomes an object for him.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: His attitude toward it becomes in some degree intelligent. And in such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noting of the meaning of the actions of others and of his own state, he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is socially directed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It will be recalled that our main proposition had two sides. One of them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has now been dealt with: namely, that physical things do not influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind (or form ideas and beliefs) except as they are implicated in action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for prospective consequences. The other point is persons modify one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another's dispositions only through the special use they make of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical conditions. Consider first the case of so-called expressive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements to which others are sensitive; blushing, smiling, frowning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clinching of fists, natural gestures of all kinds. In themselves, these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are not expressive. They are organic parts of a person's attitude. One
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not blush to show modesty or embarrassment to others, but because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the capillary circulation alters in response to stimuli. But others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use the blush, or a slightly perceptible tightening of the muscles of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a person with whom they are associated, as a sign of the state in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which that person finds himself, and as an indication of what course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to pursue. The frown signifies an imminent rebuke for which one must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prepare, or an uncertainty and hesitation which one must, if possible,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remove by saying or doing something to restore confidence. A man at some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distance is waving his arms wildly. One has only to preserve an attitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of detached indifference, and the motions of the other person will be on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the level of any remote physical change which we happen to note. If we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have no concern or interest, the waving of the arms is as meaningless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to us as the gyrations of the arms of a windmill. But if interest is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aroused, we begin to participate. We refer his action to something we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are doing ourselves or that we should do. We have to judge the meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of his act in order to decide what to do. Is he beckoning for help? Is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he warning us of an explosion to be set off, against which we should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: guard ourselves? In one case, his action means to run toward him; in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other case, to run away. In any case, it is the change he effects in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the physical environment which is a sign to us of how we should conduct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ourselves. Our action is socially controlled because we endeavor to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: refer what we are to do to the same situation in which he is acting.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Language is, as we have already seen (ante, p. 15) a case of this joint
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reference of our own action and that of another to a common situation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence its unrivaled significance as a means of social direction. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language would not be this efficacious instrument were it not that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it takes place upon a background of coarser and more tangible use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical means to accomplish results. A child sees persons with whom he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lives using chairs, hats, tables, spades, saws, plows, horses, money in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain ways. If he has any share at all in what they are doing, he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: led thereby to use things in the same way, or to use other things in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way which will fit in. If a chair is drawn up to a table, it is a sign
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that he is to sit in it; if a person extends his right hand, he is to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extend his; and so on in a never ending stream of detail. The prevailing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits of using the products of human art and the raw materials of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature constitute by all odds the deepest and most pervasive mode
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of social control. When children go to school, they already have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "minds"--they have knowledge and dispositions of judgment which may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be appealed to through the use of language. But these "minds" are the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organized habits of intelligent response which they have previously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: required by putting things to use in connection with the way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other persons use things. The control is inescapable; it saturates
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition. The net outcome of the discussion is that the fundamental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means of control is not personal but intellectual. It is not "moral" in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the sense that a person is moved by direct personal appeal from others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important as is this method at critical junctures. It consists in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the habits of understanding, which are set up in using objects in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: correspondence with others, whether by way of cooperation and assistance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or rivalry and competition. Mind as a concrete thing is precisely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the power to understand things in terms of the use made of them; a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: socialized mind is the power to understand them in terms of the use to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they are turned in joint or shared situations. And mind in this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense is the method of social control.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Imitation and Social Psychology. We have already noted the defects of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a psychology of learning which places the individual mind naked, as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it were, in contact with physical objects, and which believes that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge, ideas, and beliefs accrue from their interaction. Only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comparatively recently has the predominating influence of association
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with fellow beings in the formation of mental and moral disposition been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceived. Even now it is usually treated as a kind of adjunct to an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alleged method of learning by direct contact with things, and as merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplementing knowledge of the physical world with knowledge of persons.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The purport of our discussion is that such a view makes an absurd and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impossible separation between persons and things. Interaction with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things may form habits of external adjustment. But it leads to activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having a meaning and conscious intent only when things are used to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: produce a result. And the only way one person can modify the mind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another is by using physical conditions, crude or artificial, so as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to evoke some answering activity from him. Such are our two main
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusions. It is desirable to amplify and enforce them by placing them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in contrast with the theory which uses a psychology of supposed direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relationships of human beings to one another as an adjunct to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: psychology of the supposed direct relation of an individual to physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects. In substance, this so-called social psychology has been built
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the notion of imitation. Consequently, we shall discuss the nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and role of imitation in the formation of mental disposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: According to this theory, social control of individuals rests upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instinctive tendency of individuals to imitate or copy the actions of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others. The latter serve as models. The imitative instinct is so strong
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the young devote themselves to conforming to the patterns set by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others and reproducing them in their own scheme of behavior. According
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to our theory, what is here called imitation is a misleading name for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: partaking with others in a use of things which leads to consequences of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: common interest. The basic error in the current notion of imitation is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that it puts the cart before the horse. It takes an effect for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cause of the effect. There can be no doubt that individuals in forming a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social group are like-minded; they understand one another. They tend
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to act with the same controlling ideas, beliefs, and intentions, given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: similar circumstances. Looked at from without, they might be said to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be engaged in "imitating" one another. In the sense that they are doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much the same sort of thing in much the same sort of way, this would be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: true enough. But "imitation" throws no light upon why they so act; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: repeats the fact as an explanation of itself. It is an explanation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same order as the famous saying that opium puts men to sleep because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of its dormitive power.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Objective likeness of acts and the mental satisfaction found in being in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conformity with others are baptized by the name imitation. This social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact is then taken for a psychological force, which produced the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: likeness. A considerable portion of what is called imitation is simply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fact that persons being alike in structure respond in the same way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to like stimuli. Quite independently of imitation, men on being insulted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: get angry and attack the insulter. This statement may be met by citing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the undoubted fact that response to an insult takes place in different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ways in groups having different customs. In one group, it may be met by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recourse to fisticuffs, in another by a challenge to a duel, in a third
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by an exhibition of contemptuous disregard. This happens, so it is said,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because the model set for imitation is different. But there is no need
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to appeal to imitation. The mere fact that customs are different means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the actual stimuli to behavior are different. Conscious instruction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plays a part; prior approvals and disapprovals have a large influence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Still more effective is the fact that unless an individual acts in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way current in his group, he is literally out of it. He can associate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with others on intimate and equal terms only by behaving in the way in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they behave. The pressure that comes from the fact that one is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: let into the group action by acting in one way and shut out by acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in another way is unremitting. What is called the effect of imitation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is mainly the product of conscious instruction and of the selective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence exercised by the unconscious confirmations and ratifications
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of those with whom one associates.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Suppose that some one rolls a ball to a child; he catches it and rolls
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it back, and the game goes on. Here the stimulus is not just the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sight of the ball, or the sight of the other rolling it. It is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation--the game which is playing. The response is not merely rolling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ball back; it is rolling it back so that the other one may catch and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: return it,--that the game may continue. The "pattern" or model is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the action of the other person. The whole situation requires that each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should adapt his action in view of what the other person has done and is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do. Imitation may come in but its role is subordinate. The child has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an interest on his own account; he wants to keep it going. He may then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: note how the other person catches and holds the ball in order to improve
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his own acts. He imitates the means of doing, not the end or thing to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done. And he imitates the means because he wishes, on his own behalf, as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part of his own initiative, to take an effective part in the game. One
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has only to consider how completely the child is dependent from his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: earliest days for successful execution of his purposes upon fitting his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acts into those of others to see what a premium is put upon behaving as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others behave, and of developing an understanding of them in order that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he may so behave. The pressure for likemindedness in action from this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: source is so great that it is quite superfluous to appeal to imitation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As matter of fact, imitation of ends, as distinct from imitation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means which help to reach ends, is a superficial and transitory affair
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which leaves little effect upon disposition. Idiots are especially apt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at this kind of imitation; it affects outward acts but not the meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their performance. When we find children engaging in this sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mimicry, instead of encouraging them (as we would do if it were an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important means of social control) we are more likely to rebuke them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as apes, monkeys, parrots, or copy cats. Imitation of means of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplishment is, on the other hand, an intelligent act. It involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: close observation, and judicious selection of what will enable one to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: better something which he already is trying to do. Used for a purpose,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the imitative instinct may, like any other instinct, become a factor in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the development of effective action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This excursus should, accordingly, have the effect of reinforcing the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusion that genuine social control means the formation of a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental disposition; a way of understanding objects, events, and acts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which enables one to participate effectively in associated activities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Only the friction engendered by meeting resistance from others leads
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the view that it takes place by forcing a line of action contrary to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural inclinations. Only failure to take account of the situations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which persons are mutually concerned (or interested in acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsively to one another) leads to treating imitation as the chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: agent in promoting social control.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 4. Some Applications to Education. Why does a savage group perpetuate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: savagery, and a civilized group civilization? Doubtless the first answer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to occur to mind is because savages are savages; being of low-grade
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence and perhaps defective moral sense. But careful study
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has made it doubtful whether their native capacities are appreciably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inferior to those of civilized man. It has made it certain that native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: differences are not sufficient to account for the difference in culture.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In a sense the mind of savage peoples is an effect, rather than a cause,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their backward institutions. Their social activities are such as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: restrict their objects of attention and interest, and hence to limit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the stimuli to mental development. Even as regards the objects that come
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: within the scope of attention, primitive social customs tend to arrest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation and imagination upon qualities which do not fructify in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind. Lack of control of natural forces means that a scant number of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural objects enter into associated behavior. Only a small number of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural resources are utilized and they are not worked for what they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: worth. The advance of civilization means that a larger number of natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forces and objects have been transformed into instrumentalities of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action, into means for securing ends. We start not so much with superior
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities as with superior stimuli for evocation and direction of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our capacities. The savage deals largely with crude stimuli; we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weighted stimuli. Prior human efforts have made over natural conditions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As they originally existed they were indifferent to human endeavors.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Every domesticated plant and animal, every tool, every utensil, every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appliance, every manufactured article, every esthetic decoration,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: every work of art means a transformation of conditions once hostile
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or indifferent to characteristic human activities into friendly and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: favoring conditions. Because the activities of children today are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlled by these selected and charged stimuli, children are able to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: traverse in a short lifetime what the race has needed slow, tortured
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ages to attain. The dice have been loaded by all the successes which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have preceded.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Stimuli conducive to economical and effective response, such as our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: system of roads and means of transportation, our ready command of heat,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: light, and electricity, our ready-made machines and apparatus for every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose, do not, by themselves or in their aggregate, constitute a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: civilization. But the uses to which they are put are civilization,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and without the things the uses would be impossible. Time otherwise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessarily devoted to wresting a livelihood from a grudging environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and securing a precarious protection against its inclemencies is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freed. A body of knowledge is transmitted, the legitimacy of which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is guaranteed by the fact that the physical equipment in which it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: incarnated leads to results that square with the other facts of nature.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Thus these appliances of art supply a protection, perhaps our chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: protection, against a recrudescence of these superstitious beliefs,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: those fanciful myths and infertile imaginings about nature in which so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much of the best intellectual power of the past has been spent. If we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: add one other factor, namely, that such appliances be not only used,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but used in the interests of a truly shared or associated life, then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the appliances become the positive resources of civilization. If Greece,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a scant tithe of our material resources, achieved a worthy and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noble intellectual and artistic career, it is because Greece operated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for social ends such resources as it had. But whatever the situation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whether one of barbarism or civilization, whether one of stinted control
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of physical forces, or of partial enslavement to a mechanism not yet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made tributary to a shared experience, things as they enter into action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnish the educative conditions of daily life and direct the formation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mental and moral disposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Intentional education signifies, as we have already seen, a specially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: selected environment, the selection being made on the basis of materials
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and method specifically promoting growth in the desired direction. Since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language represents the physical conditions that have been subjected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the maximum transformation in the interests of social life--physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which have lost their original quality in becoming social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tools--it is appropriate that language should play a large part compared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with other appliances. By it we are led to share vicariously in past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human experience, thus widening and enriching the experience of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present. We are enabled, symbolically and imaginatively, to anticipate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations. In countless ways, language condenses meanings that record
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social outcomes and presage social outlooks. So significant is it of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a liberal share in what is worth while in life that unlettered and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uneducated have become almost synonymous.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The emphasis in school upon this particular tool has, however, its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dangers--dangers which are not theoretical but exhibited in practice.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Why is it, in spite of the fact that teaching by pouring in, learning by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a passive absorption, are universally condemned, that they are still so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: entrenched in practice? That education is not an affair of "telling"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and being told, but an active and constructive process, is a principle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: almost as generally violated in practice as conceded in theory. Is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this deplorable situation due to the fact that the doctrine is itself
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely told? It is preached; it is lectured; it is written about. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its enactment into practice requires that the school environment be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equipped with agencies for doing, with tools and physical materials, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an extent rarely attained. It requires that methods of instruction and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: administration be modified to allow and to secure direct and continuous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations with things. Not that the use of language as an educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resource should lessen; but that its use should be more vital and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitful by having its normal connection with shared activities. "These
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things ought ye to have done, and not to have left the others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undone." And for the school "these things" mean equipment with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumentalities of cooperative or joint activity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For when the schools depart from the educational conditions effective in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the out-of-school environment, they necessarily substitute a bookish, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pseudo-intellectual spirit for a social spirit. Children doubtless go to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school to learn, but it has yet to be proved that learning occurs most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequately when it is made a separate conscious business. When treating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it as a business of this sort tends to preclude the social sense which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comes from sharing in an activity of common concern and value, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effort at isolated intellectual learning contradicts its own aim. We may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: secure motor activity and sensory excitation by keeping an individual by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself, but we cannot thereby get him to understand the meaning which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things have in the life of which he is a part. We may secure technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialized ability in algebra, Latin, or botany, but not the kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence which directs ability to useful ends. Only by engaging in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a joint activity, where one person's use of material and tools is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously referred to the use other persons are making of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities and appliances, is a social direction of disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attained.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
