text: Summary. The natural or native impulses of the young do not agree with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the life-customs of the group into which they are born. Consequently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have to be directed or guided. This control is not the same thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as physical compulsion; it consists in centering the impulses acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at any one time upon some specific end and in introducing an order of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity into the sequence of acts. The action of others is always
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influenced by deciding what stimuli shall call out their actions. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in some cases as in commands, prohibitions, approvals, and disapprovals,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the stimuli proceed from persons with a direct view to influencing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action. Since in such cases we are most conscious of controlling the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action of others, we are likely to exaggerate the importance of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sort of control at the expense of a more permanent and effective method.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The basic control resides in the nature of the situations in which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: young take part. In social situations the young have to refer their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way of acting to what others are doing and make it fit in. This directs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their action to a common result, and gives an understanding common to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the participants. For all mean the same thing, even when performing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different acts. This common understanding of the means and ends of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action is the essence of social control. It is indirect, or emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and intellectual, not direct or personal. Moreover it is intrinsic to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the disposition of the person, not external and coercive. To achieve
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this internal control through identity of interest and understanding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the business of education. While books and conversation can do much,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these agencies are usually relied upon too exclusively. Schools require
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for their full efficiency more opportunity for conjoint activities in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which those instructed take part, so that they may acquire a social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense of their own powers and of the materials and appliances used.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Four: Education as Growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Conditions of Growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In directing the activities of the young, society determines its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future in determining that of the young. Since the young at a given time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will at some later date compose the society of that period, the latter's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature will largely turn upon the direction children's activities were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: given at an earlier period. This cumulative movement of action toward a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later result is what is meant by growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The primary condition of growth is immaturity. This may seem to be a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere truism--saying that a being can develop only in some point in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he is undeveloped. But the prefix "im" of the word immaturity means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something positive, not a mere void or lack. It is noteworthy that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms "capacity" and "potentiality" have a double meaning, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense being negative, the other positive. Capacity may denote mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: receptivity, like the capacity of a quart measure. We may mean by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: potentiality a merely dormant or quiescent state--a capacity to become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something different under external influences. But we also mean by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacity an ability, a power; and by potentiality potency, force. Now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when we say that immaturity means the possibility of growth, we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not referring to absence of powers which may exist at a later time; we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: express a force positively present--the ability to develop.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Our tendency to take immaturity as mere lack, and growth as something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which fills up the gap between the immature and the mature is due to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarding childhood comparatively, instead of intrinsically. We treat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it simply as a privation because we are measuring it by adulthood as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fixed standard. This fixes attention upon what the child has not, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will not have till he becomes a man. This comparative standpoint is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: legitimate enough for some purposes, but if we make it final, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: question arises whether we are not guilty of an overweening presumption.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Children, if they could express themselves articulately and sincerely,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would tell a different tale; and there is excellent adult authority for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the conviction that for certain moral and intellectual purposes adults
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must become as little children. The seriousness of the assumption of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: negative quality of the possibilities of immaturity is apparent when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we reflect that it sets up as an ideal and standard a static end. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fulfillment of growing is taken to mean an accomplished growth: that is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to say, an Ungrowth, something which is no longer growing. The futility
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the assumption is seen in the fact that every adult resents the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imputation of having no further possibilities of growth; and so far
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as he finds that they are closed to him mourns the fact as evidence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: loss, instead of falling back on the achieved as adequate manifestation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of power. Why an unequal measure for child and man?
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Taken absolutely, instead of comparatively, immaturity designates a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: positive force or ability,--the pouter to grow. We do not have to draw
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out or educe positive activities from a child, as some educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doctrines would have it. Where there is life, there are already eager
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and impassioned activities. Growth is not something done to them; it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something they do. The positive and constructive aspect of possibility
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gives the key to understanding the two chief traits of immaturity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dependence and plasticity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (1) It sounds absurd to hear dependence spoken of as something positive,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: still more absurd as a power. Yet if helplessness were all there were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in dependence, no development could ever take place. A merely impotent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being has to be carried, forever, by others. The fact that dependence is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accompanied by growth in ability, not by an ever increasing lapse into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parasitism, suggests that it is already something constructive. Being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely sheltered by others would not promote growth. For
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) it would only build a wall around impotence. With reference to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical world, the child is helpless. He lacks at birth and for a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: long time thereafter power to make his way physically, to make his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: living. If he had to do that by himself, he would hardly survive an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hour. On this side his helplessness is almost complete. The young of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the brutes are immeasurably his superiors. He is physically weak and not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: able to turn the strength which he possesses to coping with the physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The thoroughgoing character of this helplessness suggests, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some compensating power. The relative ability of the young of brute
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: animals to adapt themselves fairly well to physical conditions from an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: early period suggests the fact that their life is not intimately bound
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up with the life of those about them. They are compelled, so to speak,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to have physical gifts because they are lacking in social gifts. Human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: infants, on the other hand, can get along with physical incapacity just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because of their social capacity. We sometimes talk and think as if they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply happened to be physically in a social environment; as if social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forces exclusively existed in the adults who take care of them, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being passive recipients. If it were said that children are themselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: marvelously endowed with power to enlist the cooperative attention of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, this would be thought to be a backhanded way of saying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that others are marvelously attentive to the needs of children. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation shows that children are gifted with an equipment of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first order for social intercourse. Few grown-up persons retain all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the flexible and sensitive ability of children to vibrate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sympathetically with the attitudes and doings of those about them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Inattention to physical things (going with incapacity to control them)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is accompanied by a corresponding intensification of interest and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention as to the doings of people. The native mechanism of the child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and his impulses all tend to facile social responsiveness. The statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that children, before adolescence, are egotistically self-centered, even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if it were true, would not contradict the truth of this statement. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would simply indicate that their social responsiveness is employed on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own behalf, not that it does not exist. But the statement is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: true as matter of fact. The facts which are cited in support of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alleged pure egoism of children really show the intensity and directness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with which they go to their mark. If the ends which form the mark seem
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: narrow and selfish to adults, it is only because adults (by means of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: similar engrossment in their day) have mastered these ends, which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have consequently ceased to interest them. Most of the remainder of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children's alleged native egoism is simply an egoism which runs counter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to an adult's egoism. To a grown-up person who is too absorbed in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his own affairs to take an interest in children's affairs, children
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doubtless seem unreasonably engrossed in their own affairs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: From a social standpoint, dependence denotes a power rather than a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weakness; it involves interdependence. There is always a danger that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increased personal independence will decrease the social capacity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an individual. In making him more self-reliant, it may make him more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-sufficient; it may lead to aloofness and indifference. It often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes an individual so insensitive in his relations to others as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: develop an illusion of being really able to stand and act alone--an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unnamed form of insanity which is responsible for a large part of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remediable suffering of the world.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The specific adaptability of an immature creature for growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes his plasticity. This is something quite different from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plasticity of putty or wax. It is not a capacity to take on change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of form in accord with external pressure. It lies near the pliable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elasticity by which some persons take on the color of their surroundings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while retaining their own bent. But it is something deeper than this. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is essentially the ability to learn from experience; the power to retain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from one experience something which is of avail in coping with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulties of a later situation. This means power to modify actions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the basis of the results of prior experiences, the power to develop
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dispositions. Without it, the acquisition of habits is impossible.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is a familiar fact that the young of the higher animals, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: especially the human young, have to learn to utilize their instinctive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reactions. The human being is born with a greater number of instinctive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies than other animals. But the instincts of the lower animals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perfect themselves for appropriate action at an early period after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: birth, while most of those of the human infant are of little account
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just as they stand. An original specialized power of adjustment secures
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate efficiency, but, like a railway ticket, it is good for one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: route only. A being who, in order to use his eyes, ears, hands,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and legs, has to experiment in making varied combinations of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reactions, achieves a control that is flexible and varied. A chick,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for example, pecks accurately at a bit of food in a few hours after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hatching. This means that definite coordinations of activities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eyes in seeing and of the body and head in striking are perfected in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: few trials. An infant requires about six months to be able to gauge with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: approximate accuracy the action in reaching which will coordinate with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his visual activities; to be able, that is, to tell whether he can reach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a seen object and just how to execute the reaching. As a result, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chick is limited by the relative perfection of its original endowment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The infant has the advantage of the multitude of instinctive tentative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reactions and of the experiences that accompany them, even though he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at a temporary disadvantage because they cross one another. In learning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an action, instead of having it given ready-made, one of necessity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learns to vary its factors, to make varied combinations of them,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: according to change of circumstances. A possibility of continuing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progress is opened up by the fact that in learning one act, methods are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developed good for use in other situations. Still more important is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that the human being acquires a habit of learning. He learns to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learn.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The importance for human life of the two facts of dependence and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: variable control has been summed up in the doctrine of the significance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of prolonged infancy. 1 This prolongation is significant from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standpoint of the adult members of the group as well as from that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: young. The presence of dependent and learning beings is a stimulus to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nurture and affection. The need for constant continued care was probably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a chief means in transforming temporary cohabitations into permanent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unions. It certainly was a chief influence in forming habits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affectionate and sympathetic watchfulness; that constructive interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the well-being of others which is essential to associated life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Intellectually, this moral development meant the introduction of many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new objects of attention; it stimulated foresight and planning for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future. Thus there is a reciprocal influence. Increasing complexity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social life requires a longer period of infancy in which to acquire the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needed powers; this prolongation of dependence means prolongation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plasticity, or power of acquiring variable and novel modes of control.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence it provides a further push to social progress.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Habits as Expressions of Growth. We have already noted that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plasticity is the capacity to retain and carry over from prior
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience factors which modify subsequent activities. This signifies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the capacity to acquire habits, or develop definite dispositions. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have now to consider the salient features of habits. In the first place,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a habit is a form of executive skill, of efficiency in doing. A habit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means an ability to use natural conditions as means to ends. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an active control of the environment through control of the organs of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action. We are perhaps apt to emphasize the control of the body at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expense of control of the environment. We think of walking, talking,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: playing the piano, the specialized skills characteristic of the etcher,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the surgeon, the bridge-builder, as if they were simply ease, deftness,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and accuracy on the part of the organism. They are that, of course; but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the measure of the value of these qualities lies in the economical and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effective control of the environment which they secure. To be able to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: walk is to have certain properties of nature at our disposal--and so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with all other habits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Education is not infrequently defined as consisting in the acquisition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of those habits that effect an adjustment of an individual and his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment. The definition expresses an essential phase of growth. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is essential that adjustment be understood in its active sense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control of means for achieving ends. If we think of a habit simply as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a change wrought in the organism, ignoring the fact that this change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consists in ability to effect subsequent changes in the environment, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shall be led to think of "adjustment" as a conformity to environment as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wax conforms to the seal which impresses it. The environment is thought
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of as something fixed, providing in its fixity the end and standard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of changes taking place in the organism; adjustment is just fitting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ourselves to this fixity of external conditions. 2 Habit as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habituation is indeed something relatively passive; we get used to our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surroundings--to our clothing, our shoes, and gloves; to the atmosphere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as long as it is fairly equable; to our daily associates, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Conformity to the environment, a change wrought in the organism without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reference to ability to modify surroundings, is a marked trait of such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habituations. Aside from the fact that we are not entitled to carry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: over the traits of such adjustments (which might well be called
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accommodations, to mark them off from active adjustments) into habits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active use of our surroundings, two features of habituations are worth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: notice. In the first place, we get used to things by first using them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consider getting used to a strange city. At first, there is excessive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulation and excessive and ill-adapted response. Gradually certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimuli are selected because of their relevancy, and others are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degraded. We can say either that we do not respond to them any longer,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or more truly that we have effected a persistent response to them--an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equilibrium of adjustment. This means, in the second place, that this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enduring adjustment supplies the background upon which are made specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adjustments, as occasion arises. We are never interested in changing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the whole environment; there is much that we take for granted and accept
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just as it already is. Upon this background our activities focus at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain points in an endeavor to introduce needed changes. Habituation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is thus our adjustment to an environment which at the time we are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerned with modifying, and which supplies a leverage to our active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits. Adaptation, in fine, is quite as much adaptation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment to our own activities as of our activities to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment. A savage tribe manages to live on a desert plain. It adapts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself. But its adaptation involves a maximum of accepting, tolerating,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: putting up with things as they are, a maximum of passive acquiescence,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and a minimum of active control, of subjection to use. A civilized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: people enters upon the scene. It also adapts itself. It introduces
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irrigation; it searches the world for plants and animals that will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flourish under such conditions; it improves, by careful selection, those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are growing there. As a consequence, the wilderness blossoms as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a rose. The savage is merely habituated; the civilized man has habits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which transform the environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The significance of habit is not exhausted, however, in its executive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and motor phase. It means formation of intellectual and emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition as well as an increase in ease, economy, and efficiency of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action. Any habit marks an inclination--an active preference and choice
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the conditions involved in its exercise. A habit does not wait,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Micawber-like, for a stimulus to turn up so that it may get busy;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it actively seeks for occasions to pass into full operation. If its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expression is unduly blocked, inclination shows itself in uneasiness and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intense craving. A habit also marks an intellectual disposition. Where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is a habit, there is acquaintance with the materials and equipment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which action is applied. There is a definite way of understanding the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations in which the habit operates. Modes of thought, of observation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and reflection, enter as forms of skill and of desire into the habits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that make a man an engineer, an architect, a physician, or a merchant.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In unskilled forms of labor, the intellectual factors are at minimum
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely because the habits involved are not of a high grade. But there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are habits of judging and reasoning as truly as of handling a tool,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: painting a picture, or conducting an experiment. Such statements are,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, understatements. The habits of mind involved in habits of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eye and hand supply the latter with their significance. Above all,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the intellectual element in a habit fixes the relation of the habit to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied and elastic use, and hence to continued growth. We speak of fixed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits. Well, the phrase may mean powers so well established that their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possessor always has them as resources when needed. But the phrase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is also used to mean ruts, routine ways, with loss of freshness,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: open-mindedness, and originality. Fixity of habit may mean that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something has a fixed hold upon us, instead of our having a free hold
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon things. This fact explains two points in a common notion about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits: their identification with mechanical and external modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action to the neglect of mental and moral attitudes, and the tendency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to give them a bad meaning, an identification with "bad habits." Many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a person would feel surprised to have his aptitude in his chosen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: profession called a habit, and would naturally think of his use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tobacco, liquor, or profane language as typical of the meaning of habit.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A habit is to him something which has a hold on him, something not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: easily thrown off even though judgment condemn it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Habits reduce themselves to routine ways of acting, or degenerate into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ways of action to which we are enslaved just in the degree in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence is disconnected from them. Routine habits are unthinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits: "bad" habits are habits so severed from reason that they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opposed to the conclusions of conscious deliberation and decision. As we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have seen, the acquiring of habits is due to an original plasticity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of our natures: to our ability to vary responses till we find an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appropriate and efficient way of acting. Routine habits, and habits that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possess us instead of our possessing them, are habits which put an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to plasticity. They mark the close of power to vary. There can be no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doubt of the tendency of organic plasticity, of the physiological basis,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to lessen with growing years. The instinctively mobile and eagerly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varying action of childhood, the love of new stimuli and new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developments, too easily passes into a "settling down," which means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aversion to change and a resting on past achievements. Only an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment which secures the full use of intelligence in the process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of forming habits can counteract this tendency. Of course, the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hardening of the organic conditions affects the physiological structures
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are involved in thinking. But this fact only indicates the need
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of persistent care to see to it that the function of intelligence is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: invoked to its maximum possibility. The short-sighted method which falls
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: back on mechanical routine and repetition to secure external efficiency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of habit, motor skill without accompanying thought, marks a deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: closing in of surroundings upon growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Educational Bearings of the Conception of Development. We have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had so far but little to say in this chapter about education. We have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been occupied with the conditions and implications of growth. If our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusions are justified, they carry with them, however, definite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational consequences. When it is said that education is development,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everything depends upon how development is conceived. Our net conclusion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is that life is development, and that developing, growing, is life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Translated into its educational equivalents, that means (i) that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational process has no end beyond itself; it is its own end; and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that (ii) the educational process is one of continual reorganizing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reconstructing, transforming.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Development when it is interpreted in comparative terms, that is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with respect to the special traits of child and adult life, means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the direction of power into special channels: the formation of habits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involving executive skill, definiteness of interest, and specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects of observation and thought. But the comparative view is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: final. The child has specific powers; to ignore that fact is to stunt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or distort the organs upon which his growth depends. The adult uses his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers to transform his environment, thereby occasioning new stimuli
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which redirect his powers and keep them developing. Ignoring this fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means arrested development, a passive accommodation. Normal child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and normal adult alike, in other words, are engaged in growing. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference between them is not the difference between growth and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no growth, but between the modes of growth appropriate to different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions. With respect to the development of powers devoted to coping
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with specific scientific and economic problems we may say the child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be growing in manhood. With respect to sympathetic curiosity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unbiased responsiveness, and openness of mind, we may say that the adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be growing in childlikeness. One statement is as true as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Three ideas which have been criticized, namely, the merely privative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature of immaturity, static adjustment to a fixed environment, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rigidity of habit, are all connected with a false idea of growth or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development,--that it is a movement toward a fixed goal. Growth is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarded as having an end, instead of being an end. The educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: counterparts of the three fallacious ideas are first, failure to take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: account of the instinctive or native powers of the young; secondly,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: failure to develop initiative in coping with novel situations; thirdly,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an undue emphasis upon drill and other devices which secure automatic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: skill at the expense of personal perception. In all cases, the adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment is accepted as a standard for the child. He is to be brought
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up to it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Natural instincts are either disregarded or treated as nuisances--as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obnoxious traits to be suppressed, or at all events to be brought into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conformity with external standards. Since conformity is the aim, what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distinctively individual in a young person is brushed aside, or regarded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as a source of mischief or anarchy. Conformity is made equivalent to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uniformity. Consequently, there are induced lack of interest in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: novel, aversion to progress, and dread of the uncertain and the unknown.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since the end of growth is outside of and beyond the process of growing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external agents have to be resorted to to induce movement toward it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Whenever a method of education is stigmatized as mechanical, we may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sure that external pressure is brought to bear to reach an external end.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Since in reality there is nothing to which growth is relative save
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more growth, there is nothing to which education is subordinate save
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more education. It is a commonplace to say that education should not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cease when one leaves school. The point of this commonplace is that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose of school education is to insure the continuance of education by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organizing the powers that insure growth. The inclination to learn from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life itself and to make the conditions of life such that all will learn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the process of living is the finest product of schooling.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When we abandon the attempt to define immaturity by means of fixed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comparison with adult accomplishments, we are compelled to give up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking of it as denoting lack of desired traits. Abandoning this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: notion, we are also forced to surrender our habit of thinking of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction as a method of supplying this lack by pouring knowledge into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a mental and moral hole which awaits filling. Since life means growth,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a living creature lives as truly and positively at one stage as at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another, with the same intrinsic fullness and the same absolute claims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence education means the enterprise of supplying the conditions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insure growth, or adequacy of life, irrespective of age. We first look
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with impatience upon immaturity, regarding it as something to be got
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: over as rapidly as possible. Then the adult formed by such educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods looks back with impatient regret upon childhood and youth as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scene of lost opportunities and wasted powers. This ironical situation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will endure till it is recognized that living has its own intrinsic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality and that the business of education is with that quality.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Realization that life is growth protects us from that so-called
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idealizing of childhood which in effect is nothing but lazy indulgence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Life is not to be identified with every superficial act and interest.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Even though it is not always easy to tell whether what appears to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere surface fooling is a sign of some nascent as yet untrained power,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we must remember that manifestations are not to be accepted as ends in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves. They are signs of possible growth. They are to be turned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into means of development, of carrying power forward, not indulged or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultivated for their own sake. Excessive attention to surface phenomena
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (even in the way of rebuke as well as of encouragement) may lead to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their fixation and thus to arrested development. What impulses are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moving toward, not what they have been, is the important thing for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parent and teacher. The true principle of respect for immaturity cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be better put than in the words of Emerson: "Respect the child. Be not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: too much his parent. Trespass not on his solitude. But I hear the outcry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which replies to this suggestion: Would you verily throw up the reins
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of public and private discipline; would you leave the young child to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mad career of his own passions and whimsies, and call this anarchy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a respect for the child's nature? I answer,--Respect the child, respect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: him to the end, but also respect yourself.... The two points in a boy's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training are, to keep his naturel and train off all but that; to keep
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his naturel, but stop off his uproar, fooling, and horseplay; keep
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his nature and arm it with knowledge in the very direction in which it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: points." And as Emerson goes on to show this reverence for childhood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and youth instead of opening up an easy and easy-going path to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instructors, "involves at once, immense claims on the time, the thought,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the life of the teacher. It requires time, use, insight, event, all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the great lessons and assistances of God; and only to think of using it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implies character and profoundness."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Power to grow depends upon need for others and plasticity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Both of these conditions are at their height in childhood and youth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Plasticity or the power to learn from experience means the formation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits. Habits give control over the environment, power to utilize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it for human purposes. Habits take the form both of habituation, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a general and persistent balance of organic activities with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surroundings, and of active capacities to readjust activity to meet new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions. The former furnishes the background of growth; the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitute growing. Active habits involve thought, invention, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: initiative in applying capacities to new aims. They are opposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to routine which marks an arrest of growth. Since growth is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: characteristic of life, education is all one with growing; it has no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end beyond itself. The criterion of the value of school education is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extent in which it creates a desire for continued growth and supplies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means for making the desire effective in fact.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1 Intimations of its significance are found in a number of writers, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: John Fiske, in his Excursions of an Evolutionist, is accredited with its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first systematic exposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2 This conception is, of course, a logical correlate of the conceptions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
