author: Dewey, John

text: of the external relation of stimulus and response, considered in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the last chapter, and of the negative conceptions of immaturity and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plasticity noted in this chapter.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Five: Preparation, Unfolding, and Formal Discipline
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Education as Preparation. We have laid it down that the educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process is a continuous process of growth, having as its aim at every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stage an added capacity of growth. This conception contrasts sharply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with other ideas which have influenced practice. By making the contrast
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explicit, the meaning of the conception will be brought more clearly to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: light. The first contrast is with the idea that education is a process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of preparation or getting ready. What is to be prepared for is, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course, the responsibilities and privileges of adult life. Children are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not regarded as social members in full and regular standing. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: looked upon as candidates; they are placed on the waiting list. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception is only carried a little farther when the life of adults
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is considered as not having meaning on its own account, but as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preparatory probation for "another life." The idea is but another form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the notion of the negative and privative character of growth already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criticized; hence we shall not repeat the criticisms, but pass on to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evil consequences which flow from putting education on this basis.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the first place, it involves loss of impetus. Motive power is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utilized. Children proverbially live in the present; that is not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a fact not to be evaded, but it is an excellence. The future just as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future lacks urgency and body. To get ready for something, one knows not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what nor why, is to throw away the leverage that exists, and to seek for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motive power in a vague chance. Under such circumstances, there is, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the second place, a premium put on shilly-shallying and procrastination.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The future prepared for is a long way off; plenty of time will intervene
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: before it becomes a present. Why be in a hurry about getting ready for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it? The temptation to postpone is much increased because the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: offers so many wonderful opportunities and proffers such invitations to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adventure. Naturally attention and energy go to them; education accrues
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: naturally as an outcome, but a lesser education than if the full stress
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of effort had been put upon making conditions as educative as possible.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A third undesirable result is the substitution of a conventional average
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standard of expectation and requirement for a standard which concerns
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the specific powers of the individual under instruction. For a severe
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and definite judgment based upon the strong and weak points of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual is substituted a vague and wavering opinion concerning what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: youth may be expected, upon the average, to become in some more or less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remote future; say, at the end of the year, when promotions are to take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: place, or by the time they are ready to go to college or to enter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon what, in contrast with the probationary stage, is regarded as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: serious business of life. It is impossible to overestimate the loss
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which results from the deflection of attention from the strategic point
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to a comparatively unproductive point. It fails most just where it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinks it is succeeding--in getting a preparation for the future.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Finally, the principle of preparation makes necessary recourse on a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: large scale to the use of adventitious motives of pleasure and pain. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future having no stimulating and directing power when severed from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities of the present, something must be hitched on to it to make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it work. Promises of reward and threats of pain are employed. Healthy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work, done for present reasons and as a factor in living, is largely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unconscious. The stimulus resides in the situation with which one is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actually confronted. But when this situation is ignored, pupils have to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be told that if they do not follow the prescribed course penalties will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accrue; while if they do, they may expect, some time in the future,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rewards for their present sacrifices. Everybody knows how largely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systems of punishment have had to be resorted to by educational systems
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which neglect present possibilities in behalf of preparation for a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future. Then, in disgust with the harshness and impotency of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method, the pendulum swings to the opposite extreme, and the dose of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information required against some later day is sugar-coated, so that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pupils may be fooled into taking something which they do not care for.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is not of course a question whether education should prepare for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future. If education is growth, it must progressively realize present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities, and thus make individuals better fitted to cope with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later requirements. Growing is not something which is completed in odd
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moments; it is a continuous leading into the future. If the environment,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in school and out, supplies conditions which utilize adequately the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present capacities of the immature, the future which grows out of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the present is surely taken care of. The mistake is not in attaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: importance to preparation for future need, but in making it the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mainspring of present effort. Because the need of preparation for a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continually developing life is great, it is imperative that every energy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be bent to making the present experience as rich and significant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as possible. Then as the present merges insensibly into the future, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future is taken care of.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Education as Unfolding. There is a conception of education which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: professes to be based upon the idea of development. But it takes back
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with one hand what it proffers with the other. Development is conceived
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not as continuous growing, but as the unfolding of latent powers toward
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a definite goal. The goal is conceived of as completion,--perfection.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Life at any stage short of attainment of this goal is merely an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unfolding toward it. Logically the doctrine is only a variant of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preparation theory. Practically the two differ in that the adherents of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter make much of the practical and professional duties for which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one is preparing, while the developmental doctrine speaks of the ideal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and spiritual qualities of the principle which is unfolding.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The conception that growth and progress are just approximations to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a final unchanging goal is the last infirmity of the mind in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transition from a static to a dynamic understanding of life. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simulates the style of the latter. It pays the tribute of speaking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much of development, process, progress. But all of these operations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are conceived to be merely transitional; they lack meaning on their own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: account. They possess significance only as movements toward something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: away from what is now going on. Since growth is just a movement toward a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: completed being, the final ideal is immobile. An abstract and indefinite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future is in control with all which that connotes in depreciation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present power and opportunity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since the goal of perfection, the standard of development, is very far
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: away, it is so beyond us that, strictly speaking, it is unattainable.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently, in order to be available for present guidance it must be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: translated into something which stands for it. Otherwise we should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be compelled to regard any and every manifestation of the child as an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unfolding from within, and hence sacred. Unless we set up some definite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criterion representing the ideal end by which to judge whether a given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitude or act is approximating or moving away, our sole alternative is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to withdraw all influences of the environment lest they interfere with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proper development. Since that is not practicable, a working substitute
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is set up. Usually, of course, this is some idea which an adult would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like to have a child acquire. Consequently, by "suggestive questioning"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or some other pedagogical device, the teacher proceeds to "draw out"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the pupil what is desired. If what is desired is obtained, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is evidence that the child is unfolding properly. But as the pupil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generally has no initiative of his own in this direction, the result is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a random groping after what is wanted, and the formation of habits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dependence upon the cues furnished by others. Just because such methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simulate a true principle and claim to have its sanction they may do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more harm than would outright "telling," where, at least, it remains
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the child how much will stick.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Within the sphere of philosophic thought there have been two typical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attempts to provide a working representative of the absolute goal. Both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: start from the conception of a whole--an absolute--which is "immanent"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in human life. The perfect or complete ideal is not a mere ideal; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is operative here and now. But it is present only implicitly,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "potentially," or in an enfolded condition. What is termed development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the gradual making explicit and outward of what is thus wrapped up.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: referred to, have different ideas of the path by which the progressive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization of manifestation of the complete principle is effected.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: According to Hegel, it is worked out through a series of historical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions which embody the different factors in the Absolute.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: According to Froebel, the actuating force is the presentation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: symbols, largely mathematical, corresponding to the essential traits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the Absolute. When these are presented to the child, the Whole,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or perfection, sleeping within him, is awakened. A single example
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may indicate the method. Every one familiar with the kindergarten is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquainted with the circle in which the children gather. It is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enough that the circle is a convenient way of grouping the children. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be used "because it is a symbol of the collective life of mankind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in general." Froebel's recognition of the significance of the native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities of children, his loving attention to them, and his influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in inducing others to study them, represent perhaps the most effective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: single force in modern educational theory in effecting widespread
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acknowledgment of the idea of growth. But his formulation of the notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of development and his organization of devices for promoting it were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: badly hampered by the fact that he conceived development to be the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unfolding of a ready-made latent principle. He failed to see that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growing is growth, developing is development, and consequently placed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the emphasis upon the completed product. Thus he set up a goal which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meant the arrest of growth, and a criterion which is not applicable to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate guidance of powers, save through translation into abstract and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: symbolic formulae.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A remote goal of complete unfoldedness is, in technical philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language, transcendental. That is, it is something apart from direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience and perception. So far as experience is concerned, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: empty; it represents a vague sentimental aspiration rather than anything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which can be intelligently grasped and stated. This vagueness must be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: compensated for by some a priori formula. Froebel made the connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between the concrete facts of experience and the transcendental ideal of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development by regarding the former as symbols of the latter. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regard known things as symbols, according to some arbitrary a priori
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formula--and every a priori conception must be arbitrary--is an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: invitation to romantic fancy to seize upon any analogies which appeal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children. Adults being the formulators of the symbolism are naturally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the authors and controllers of the technique. The result was that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sympathetic insight; and there was substituted for development as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arbitrary and externally imposed a scheme of dictation as the history of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction has ever seen.

author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

text: With Hegel the necessity of finding some working concrete counterpart of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the inaccessible Absolute took an institutional, rather than symbolic,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form. His philosophy, like Froebel's, marks in one direction an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indispensable contribution to a valid conception of the process of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The weaknesses of an abstract individualistic philosophy were evident
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to him; he saw the impossibility of making a clean sweep of historical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions, of treating them as despotisms begot in artifice and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nurtured in fraud. In his philosophy of history and society culminated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the efforts of a whole series of German writers--Lessing, Herder, Kant,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Schiller, Goethe--to appreciate the nurturing influence of the great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: collective institutional products of humanity. For those who learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the lesson of this movement, it was henceforth impossible to conceive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of institutions or of culture as artificial. It destroyed completely--in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea, not in fact--the psychology that regarded "mind" as a ready-made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possession of a naked individual by showing the significance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "objective mind"--language, government, art, religion--in the formation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of individual minds. But since Hegel was haunted by the conception of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absolute goal, he was obliged to arrange institutions as they concretely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exist, on a stepladder of ascending approximations. Each in its time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and place is absolutely necessary, because a stage in the self-realizing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process of the absolute mind. Taken as such a step or stage, its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence is proof of its complete rationality, for it is an integral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: element in the total, which is Reason. Against institutions as they are,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals have no spiritual rights; personal development, and nurture,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consist in obedient assimilation of the spirit of existing institutions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Conformity, not transformation, is the essence of education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Institutions change as history shows; but their change, the rise and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fall of states, is the work of the "world-spirit." Individuals, save the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: great "heroes" who are the chosen organs of the world-spirit, have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no share or lot in it. In the later nineteenth century, this type of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idealism was amalgamated with the doctrine of biological evolution.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "Evolution" was a force working itself out to its own end. As against
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it, or as compared with it, the conscious ideas and preference of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals are impotent. Or, rather, they are but the means by which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it works itself out. Social progress is an "organic growth," not an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental selection. Reason is all powerful, but only Absolute Reason
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has any power.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The recognition (or rediscovery, for the idea was familiar to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Greeks) that great historic institutions are active factors in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual nurture of mind was a great contribution to educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy. It indicated a genuine advance beyond Rousseau, who had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: marred his assertion that education must be a natural development and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not something forced or grafted upon individuals from without, by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: notion that social conditions are not natural. But in its notion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a complete and all-inclusive end of development, the Hegelian theory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: swallowed up concrete individualities, though magnifying The Individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the abstract. Some of Hegel's followers sought to reconcile the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: claims of the Whole and of individuality by the conception of society as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an organic whole, or organism. That social organization is presupposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the adequate exercise of individual capacity is not to be doubted.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But the social organism, interpreted after the relation of the organs of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the body to each other and to the whole body, means that each individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has a certain limited place and function, requiring to be supplemented
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the place and functions of the other organs. As one portion of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bodily tissue is differentiated so that it can be the hand and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hand only, another, the eye, and so on, all taken together making the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organism, so one individual is supposed to be differentiated for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exercise of the mechanical operations of society, another for those of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a statesman, another for those of a scholar, and so on. The notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of "organism" is thus used to give a philosophic sanction to class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distinctions in social organization--a notion which in its educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: application again means external dictation instead of growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Education as Training of Faculties. A theory which has had great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vogue and which came into existence before the notion of growth had much
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence is known as the theory of "formal discipline." It has in view
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a correct ideal; one outcome of education should be the creation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specific powers of accomplishment. A trained person is one who can do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the chief things which it is important for him to do better than he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: could without training: "better" signifying greater ease, efficiency,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economy, promptness, etc. That this is an outcome of education was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indicated in what was said about habits as the product of educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development. But the theory in question takes, as it were, a short
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cut; it regards some powers (to be presently named) as the direct and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious aims of instruction, and not simply as the results of growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is a definite number of powers to be trained, as one might
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enumerate the kinds of strokes which a golfer has to master.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently education should get directly at the business of training
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. But this implies that they are already there in some untrained
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form; otherwise their creation would have to be an indirect product of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other activities and agencies. Being there already in some crude form,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all that remains is to exercise them in constant and graded repetitions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and they will inevitably be refined and perfected. In the phrase "formal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline" as applied to this conception, "discipline" refers both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the outcome of trained power and to the method of training through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: repeated exercise.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The forms of powers in question are such things as the faculties of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceiving, retaining, recalling, associating, attending, willing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: feeling, imagining, thinking, etc., which are then shaped by exercise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon material presented. In its classic form, this theory was expressed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by Locke. On the one hand, the outer world presents the material or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: content of knowledge through passively received sensations. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other hand, the mind has certain ready powers, attention, observation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: retention, comparison, abstraction, compounding, etc. Knowledge results
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if the mind discriminates and combines things as they are united and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: divided in nature itself. But the important thing for education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the exercise or practice of the faculties of the mind till they become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thoroughly established habitudes. The analogy constantly employed is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that of a billiard player or gymnast, who by repeated use of certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: muscles in a uniform way at last secures automatic skill. Even the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: faculty of thinking was to be formed into a trained habit by repeated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exercises in making and combining simple distinctions, for which, Locke
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought, mathematics affords unrivaled opportunity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Locke's statements fitted well into the dualism of his day. It seemed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do justice to both mind and matter, the individual and the world. One of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the two supplied the matter of knowledge and the object upon which mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should work. The other supplied definite mental powers, which were few
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in number and which might be trained by specific exercises. The scheme
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appeared to give due weight to the subject matter of knowledge, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: yet it insisted that the end of education is not the bare reception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and storage of information, but the formation of personal powers of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention, memory, observation, abstraction, and generalization. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was realistic in its emphatic assertion that all material whatever is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: received from without; it was idealistic in that final stress fell upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the formation of intellectual powers. It was objective and impersonal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in its assertion that the individual cannot possess or generate any true
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas on his own account; it was individualistic in placing the end of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education in the perfecting of certain faculties possessed at the outset
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the individual. This kind of distribution of values expressed with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nicety the state of opinion in the generations following upon Locke.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It became, without explicit reference to Locke, a common-place of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational theory and of psychology. Practically, it seemed to provide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the educator with definite, instead of vague, tasks. It made the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elaboration of a technique of instruction relatively easy. All that was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessary was to provide for sufficient practice of each of the powers.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This practice consists in repeated acts of attending, observing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: memorizing, etc. By grading the difficulty of the acts, making each set
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of repetitions somewhat more difficult than the set which preceded it,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a complete scheme of instruction is evolved. There are various ways,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equally conclusive, of criticizing this conception, in both its alleged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: foundations and in its educational application. (1) Perhaps the most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct mode of attack consists in pointing out that the supposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: original faculties of observation, recollection, willing, thinking,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc., are purely mythological. There are no such ready-made powers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: waiting to be exercised and thereby trained. There are, indeed, a great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of original native tendencies, instinctive modes of action, based
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the original connections of neurones in the central nervous system.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There are impulsive tendencies of the eyes to follow and fixate light;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the neck muscles to turn toward light and sound; of the hands to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reach and grasp; and turn and twist and thump; of the vocal apparatus to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make sounds; of the mouth to spew out unpleasant substances; to gag
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and to curl the lip, and so on in almost indefinite number. But these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies (a) instead of being a small number sharply marked off from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another, are of an indefinite variety, interweaving with one another
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in all kinds of subtle ways. (b) Instead of being latent intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers, requiring only exercise for their perfecting, they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies to respond in certain ways to changes in the environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so as to bring about other changes. Something in the throat makes one

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: (volition) upon them.

author: Dewey, John

text: (2) Consequently the training of our original impulsive activities is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: say, among the reactions of the body in general occur upon stimulation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

text: of oral or written reproduction. The scope of coordination (to use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed in other observations and recollections (or reproductions) are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of letters and words. Having been excluded, they cannot be restored when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

text: narrow and rigid, coordination. (4) Going to the root of the matter, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

text: matter involved in its exercise, is nonsense. Exercise may react
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon circulation, breathing, and nutrition so as to develop vigor or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in connection with the material means which accomplish them. Vigor will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of them; and expertness in one secures expertness in another only so far
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as it is either a sign of aptitude for fine muscular coordinations or as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same kind of coordination is involved in all of them. Moreover, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as context, affiliations of descent, etc., may be compared to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "develop" certain muscles, and a game or sport. The former is uniform
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and mechanical; it is rigidly specialized. The latter is varied from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moment to moment; no two acts are quite alike; novel emergencies have to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be met; the coordinations forming have to be kept flexible and elastic.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently, the training is much more "general"; that is to say, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A monotonously uniform exercise may by practice give great skill in one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: calculations in logarithms or experiments in hydrocarbons. One may be

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: special field has been of a kind to ramify into the subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the other fields. (5) Consequently, such powers as observation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recollection, judgment, esthetic taste, represent organized results of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the occupation of native active tendencies with certain subject matters.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A man does not observe closely and fully by pressing a button for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the observing faculty to get to work (in other words by "willing"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successfully only through intensive and extensive use of eye and hand,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he naturally observes. Observation is an outcome, a consequence, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the interaction of sense organ and subject matter. It will vary,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accordingly, with the subject matter employed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is consequently futile to set up even the ulterior development of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: faculties of observation, memory, etc., unless we have first determined
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what sort of subject matter we wish the pupil to become expert in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observing and recalling and for what purpose. And it is only repeating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in another form what has already been said, to declare that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criterion here must be social. We want the person to note and recall and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judge those things which make him an effective competent member of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group in which he is associated with others. Otherwise we might as well
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set the pupil to observing carefully cracks on the wall and set him to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
