title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline. If the observing habits of a botanist or chemist or engineer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are better habits than those which are thus formed, it is because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they deal with subject matter which is more significant in life. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concluding this portion of the discussion, we note that the distinction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between special and general education has nothing to do with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transferability of function or power. In the literal sense, any transfer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is miraculous and impossible. But some activities are broad; they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involve a coordination of many factors. Their development demands
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuous alternation and readjustment. As conditions change, certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: factors are subordinated, and others which had been of minor importance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: come to the front. There is constant redistribution of the focus of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action, as is seen in the illustration of a game as over against pulling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a fixed weight by a series of uniform motions. Thus there is practice in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prompt making of new combinations with the focus of activity shifted to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meet change in subject matter. Wherever an activity is broad in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scope (that is, involves the coordinating of a large variety of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sub-activities), and is constantly and unexpectedly obliged to change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direction in its progressive development, general education is bound
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to result. For this is what "general" means; broad and flexible. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practice, education meets these conditions, and hence is general, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degree in which it takes account of social relationships. A person may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: become expert in technical philosophy, or philology, or mathematics or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engineering or financiering, and be inept and ill-advised in his action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and judgment outside of his specialty. If however his concern with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these technical subject matters has been connected with human activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having social breadth, the range of active responses called into play
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and flexibly integrated is much wider. Isolation of subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from a social context is the chief obstruction in current practice to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: securing a general training of mind. Literature, art, religion, when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thus dissociated, are just as narrowing as the technical things which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the professional upholders of general education strenuously oppose.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. The conception that the result of the educative process is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacity for further education stands in contrast with some other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas which have profoundly influenced practice. The first contrasting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception considered is that of preparing or getting ready for some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future duty or privilege. Specific evil effects were pointed out which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result from the fact that this aim diverts attention of both teacher
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and taught from the only point to which it may be fruitfully
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directed--namely, taking advantage of the needs and possibilities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate present. Consequently it defeats its own professed purpose.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The notion that education is an unfolding from within appears to have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more likeness to the conception of growth which has been set forth. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as worked out in the theories of Froebel and Hegel, it involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ignoring the interaction of present organic tendencies with the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment, just as much as the notion of preparation. Some implicit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whole is regarded as given ready-made and the significance of growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is merely transitory; it is not an end in itself, but simply a means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of making explicit what is already implicit. Since that which is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explicit cannot be made definite use of, something has to be found to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent it. According to Froebel, the mystic symbolic value of certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects and acts (largely mathematical) stand for the Absolute
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Whole which is in process of unfolding. According to Hegel, existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions are its effective actual representatives. Emphasis upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: symbols and institutions tends to divert perception from the direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growth of experience in richness of meaning. Another influential but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: defective theory is that which conceives that mind has, at birth,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain mental faculties or powers, such as perceiving, remembering,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: willing, judging, generalizing, attending, etc., and that education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the training of these faculties through repeated exercise. This theory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: treats subject matter as comparatively external and indifferent, its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value residing simply in the fact that it may occasion exercise of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the general powers. Criticism was directed upon this separation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alleged powers from one another and from the material upon which they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: act. The outcome of the theory in practice was shown to be an undue
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emphasis upon the training of narrow specialized modes of skill at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expense of initiative, inventiveness, and readaptability--qualities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which depend upon the broad and consecutive interaction of specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities with one another. 1 As matter of fact, the interconnection is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so great, there are so many paths of construction, that every stimulus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brings about some change in all of the organs of response. We are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accustomed however to ignore most of these modifications of the total
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organic activity, concentrating upon that one which is most specifically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adapted to the most urgent stimulus of the moment. 2 This statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be compared with what was said earlier about the sequential
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ordering of responses (p. 25). It is merely a more explicit statement of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the way in which that consecutive arrangement occurs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
