text: Chapter Six: Education as Conservative and Progressive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Education as Formation. We now come to a type of theory which denies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the existence of faculties and emphasizes the unique role of subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter in the development of mental and moral disposition. According to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it, education is neither a process of unfolding from within nor is it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a training of faculties resident in mind itself. It is rather the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formation of mind by setting up certain associations or connections of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: content by means of a subject matter presented from without. Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proceeds by instruction taken in a strictly literal sense, a building
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into the mind from without. That education is formative of mind is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questioned; it is the conception already propounded. But formation here
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has a technical meaning dependent upon the idea of something operating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from without. Herbart is the best historical representative of this type
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of theory. He denies absolutely the existence of innate faculties. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind is simply endowed with the power of producing various qualities in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reaction to the various realities which act upon it. These qualitatively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different reactions are called presentations (Vorstellungen). Every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presentation once called into being persists; it may be driven below the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "threshold" of consciousness by new and stronger presentations, produced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the reaction of the soul to new material, but its activity continues
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by its own inherent momentum, below the surface of consciousness. What
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are termed faculties--attention, memory, thinking, perception, even the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sentiments, are arrangements, associations, and complications, formed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the interaction of these submerged presentations with one another and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with new presentations. Perception, for example, is the complication of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presentations which result from the rise of old presentations to greet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and combine with new ones; memory is the evoking of an old presentation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: above the threshold of consciousness by getting entangled with another
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presentation, etc. Pleasure is the result of reinforcement among the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: independent activities of presentations; pain of their pulling different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ways, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The concrete character of mind consists, then, wholly of the various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrangements formed by the various presentations in their different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities. The "furniture" of the mind is the mind. Mind is wholly a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of "contents." The educational implications of this doctrine are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: threefold.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (1) This or that kind of mind is formed by the use of objects which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evoke this or that kind of reaction and which produce this or that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrangement among the reactions called out. The formation of mind is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wholly a matter of the presentation of the proper educational materials.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) Since the earlier presentations constitute the "apperceiving organs"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which control the assimilation of new presentations, their character is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all important. The effect of new presentations is to reinforce groupings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: previously formed. The business of the educator is, first, to select the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proper material in order to fix the nature of the original reactions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and, secondly, to arrange the sequence of subsequent presentations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the basis of the store of ideas secured by prior transactions. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control is from behind, from the past, instead of, as in the unfolding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception, in the ultimate goal.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (3) Certain formal steps of all method in teaching may be laid down.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Presentation of new subject matter is obviously the central thing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but since knowing consists in the way in which this interacts with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contents already submerged below consciousness, the first thing is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the step of "preparation,"--that is, calling into special activity and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting above the floor of consciousness those older presentations which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are to assimilate the new one. Then after the presentation, follow the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: processes of interaction of new and old; then comes the application of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the newly formed content to the performance of some task. Everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must go through this course; consequently there is a perfectly uniform
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method in instruction in all subjects for all pupils of all ages.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Herbart's great service lay in taking the work of teaching out of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the region of routine and accident. He brought it into the sphere of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious method; it became a conscious business with a definite aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and procedure, instead of being a compound of casual inspiration
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and subservience to tradition. Moreover, everything in teaching and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline could be specified, instead of our having to be content with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vague and more or less mystic generalities about ultimate ideals and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speculative spiritual symbols. He abolished the notion of ready-made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: faculties, which might be trained by exercise upon any sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material, and made attention to concrete subject matter, to the content,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all-important. Herbart undoubtedly has had a greater influence in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bringing to the front questions connected with the material of study
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than any other educational philosopher. He stated problems of method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the standpoint of their connection with subject matter: method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having to do with the manner and sequence of presenting new subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter to insure its proper interaction with old.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The fundamental theoretical defect of this view lies in ignoring the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence in a living being of active and specific functions which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developed in the redirection and combination which occur as they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupied with their environment. The theory represents the Schoolmaster
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: come to his own. This fact expresses at once its strength and its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weakness. The conception that the mind consists of what has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taught, and that the importance of what has been taught consists in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its availability for further teaching, reflects the pedagogue's view
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life. The philosophy is eloquent about the duty of the teacher in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instructing pupils; it is almost silent regarding his privilege of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning. It emphasizes the influence of intellectual environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the mind; it slurs over the fact that the environment involves a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal sharing in common experiences. It exaggerates beyond reason
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the possibilities of consciously formulated and used methods, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: underestimates the role of vital, unconscious, attitudes. It insists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the old, the past, and passes lightly over the operation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: genuinely novel and unforeseeable. It takes, in brief, everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational into account save its essence,--vital energy seeking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunity for effective exercise. All education forms character,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental and moral, but formation consists in the selection and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coordination of native activities so that they may utilize the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of the social environment. Moreover, the formation is not only a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formation of native activities, but it takes place through them. It is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process of reconstruction, reorganization.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Education as Recapitulation and Retrospection. A peculiar combination
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the ideas of development and formation from without has given rise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the recapitulation theory of education, biological and cultural. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual develops, but his proper development consists in repeating in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: orderly stages the past evolution of animal life and human history. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: former recapitulation occurs physiologically; the latter should be made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to occur by means of education. The alleged biological truth that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual in his growth from the simple embryo to maturity repeats the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history of the evolution of animal life in the progress of forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the simplest to the most complex (or expressed technically, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ontogenesis parallels phylogenesis) does not concern us, save as it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supposed to afford scientific foundation for cultural recapitulation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the past. Cultural recapitulation says, first, that children at a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain age are in the mental and moral condition of savagery; their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instincts are vagrant and predatory because their ancestors at one time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lived such a life. Consequently (so it is concluded) the proper subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of their education at this time is the material--especially the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literary material of myths, folk-tale, and song--produced by humanity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the analogous stage. Then the child passes on to something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: corresponding, say, to the pastoral stage, and so on till at the time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when he is ready to take part in contemporary life, he arrives at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present epoch of culture.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In this detailed and consistent form, the theory, outside of a small
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school in Germany (followers of Herbart for the most part), has had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: little currency. But the idea which underlies it is that education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is essentially retrospective; that it looks primarily to the past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and especially to the literary products of the past, and that mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is adequately formed in the degree in which it is patterned upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spiritual heritage of the past. This idea has had such immense influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon higher instruction especially, that it is worth examination in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extreme formulation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the first place, its biological basis is fallacious. Embyronic growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the human infant preserves, without doubt, some of the traits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lower forms of life. But in no respect is it a strict traversing of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past stages. If there were any strict "law" of repetition, evolutionary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development would clearly not have taken place. Each new generation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would simply have repeated its predecessors' existence. Development, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: short, has taken place by the entrance of shortcuts and alterations in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the prior scheme of growth. And this suggests that the aim of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to facilitate such short-circuited growth. The great advantage of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immaturity, educationally speaking, is that it enables us to emancipate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the young from the need of dwelling in an outgrown past. The business of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education is rather to liberate the young from reviving and retraversing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the past than to lead them to a recapitulation of it. The social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment of the young is constituted by the presence and action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the habits of thinking and feeling of civilized men. To ignore the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directive influence of this present environment upon the young is simply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to abdicate the educational function. A biologist has said: "The history
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of development in different animals. . . offers to us. . . a series of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ingenious, determined, varied but more or less unsuccessful efforts to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: escape from the necessity of recapitulating, and to substitute for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ancestral method a more direct method." Surely it would be foolish if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education did not deliberately attempt to facilitate similar efforts in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious experience so that they become increasingly successful.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The two factors of truth in the conception may easily be disentangled
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from association with the false context which perverts them. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: biological side we have simply the fact that any infant starts with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely the assortment of impulsive activities with which he does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: start, they being blind, and many of them conflicting with one another,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: casual, sporadic, and unadapted to their immediate environment. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other point is that it is a part of wisdom to utilize the products
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of past history so far as they are of help for the future. Since they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent the results of prior experience, their value for future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience may, of course, be indefinitely great. Literatures produced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the past are, so far as men are now in possession and use of them, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part of the present environment of individuals; but there is an enormous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference between availing ourselves of them as present resources and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taking them as standards and patterns in their retrospective character.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (1) The distortion of the first point usually comes about through misuse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the idea of heredity. It is assumed that heredity means that past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life has somehow predetermined the main traits of an individual, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they are so fixed that little serious change can be introduced into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. Thus taken, the influence of heredity is opposed to that of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the environment, and the efficacy of the latter belittled. But for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational purposes heredity means neither more nor less than the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: original endowment of an individual. Education must take the being as he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is; that a particular individual has just such and such an equipment of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: native activities is a basic fact. That they were produced in such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and such a way, or that they are derived from one's ancestry, is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: especially important for the educator, however it may be with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: biologist, as compared with the fact that they now exist. Suppose one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had to advise or direct a person regarding his inheritance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: property. The fallacy of assuming that the fact it is an inheritance,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: predetermines its future use, is obvious. The advisor is concerned with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making the best use of what is there--putting it at work under the most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: favorable conditions. Obviously he cannot utilize what is not there;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: neither can the educator. In this sense, heredity is a limit of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education. Recognition of this fact prevents the waste of energy and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irritation that ensue from the too prevalent habit of trying to make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by instruction something out of an individual which he is not naturally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fitted to become. But the doctrine does not determine what use shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be made of the capacities which exist. And, except in the case of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imbecile, these original capacities are much more varied and potential,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: even in the case of the more stupid, than we as yet know properly how to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utilize. Consequently, while a careful study of the native aptitudes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and deficiencies of an individual is always a preliminary necessity, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsequent and important step is to furnish an environment which will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequately function whatever activities are present. The relation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heredity and environment is well expressed in the case of language. If a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being had no vocal organs from which issue articulate sounds, if he had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no auditory or other sense-receptors and no connections between the two
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sets of apparatus, it would be a sheer waste of time to try to teach him
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to converse. He is born short in that respect, and education must accept
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the limitation. But if he has this native equipment, its possession in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no way guarantees that he will ever talk any language or what language
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he will talk. The environment in which his activities occur and by which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are carried into execution settles these things. If he lived in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dumb unsocial environment where men refused to talk to one another and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: used only that minimum of gestures without which they could not get
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: along, vocal language would be as unachieved by him as if he had no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocal organs. If the sounds which he makes occur in a medium of persons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speaking the Chinese language, the activities which make like sounds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will be selected and coordinated. This illustration may be applied to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the entire range of the educability of any individual. It places the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heritage from the past in its right connection with the demands and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities of the present.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) The theory that the proper subject matter of instruction is found
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the culture-products of past ages (either in general, or more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specifically in the particular literatures which were produced in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the culture epoch which is supposed to correspond with the stage of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of those taught) affords another instance of that divorce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between the process and product of growth which has been criticized. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: keep the process alive, to keep it alive in ways which make it easier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to keep it alive in the future, is the function of educational subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter. But an individual can live only in the present. The present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not just something which comes after the past; much less something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: produced by it. It is what life is in leaving the past behind it. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: study of past products will not help us understand the present, because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the present is not due to the products, but to the life of which they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were the products. A knowledge of the past and its heritage is of great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance when it enters into the present, but not otherwise. And the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mistake of making the records and remains of the past the main material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of education is that it cuts the vital connection of present and past,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and tends to make the past a rival of the present and the present a more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or less futile imitation of the past. Under such circumstances, culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes an ornament and solace; a refuge and an asylum. Men escape
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the crudities of the present to live in its imagined refinements,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instead of using what the past offers as an agency for ripening these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: crudities. The present, in short, generates the problems which lead us
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to search the past for suggestion, and which supplies meaning to what we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: find when we search. The past is the past precisely because it does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not include what is characteristic in the present. The moving present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: includes the past on condition that it uses the past to direct its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movement. The past is a great resource for the imagination; it adds a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new dimension to life, but OD condition that it be seen as the past of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the present, and not as another and disconnected world. The principle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which makes little of the present act of living and operation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growing, the only thing always present, naturally looks to the past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because the future goal which it sets up is remote and empty. But having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: turned its back upon the present, it has no way of returning to it laden
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the spoils of the past. A mind that is adequately sensitive to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needs and occasions of the present actuality will have the liveliest of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motives for interest in the background of the present, and will never
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have to hunt for a way back because it will never have lost connection.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Education as Reconstruction. In its contrast with the ideas both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of unfolding of latent powers from within, and of the formation from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without, whether by physical nature or by the cultural products of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past, the ideal of growth results in the conception that education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a constant reorganizing or reconstructing of experience. It has all the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time an immediate end, and so far as activity is educative, it reaches
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that end--the direct transformation of the quality of experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Infancy, youth, adult life,--all stand on the same educative level
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the sense that what is really learned at any and every stage of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience constitutes the value of that experience, and in the sense
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that it is the chief business of life at every point to make living thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contribute to an enrichment of its own perceptible meaning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We thus reach a technical definition of education: It is that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reconstruction or reorganization of experience which adds to the meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of experience, and which increases ability to direct the course of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsequent experience. (1) The increment of meaning corresponds to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the increased perception of the connections and continuities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities in which we are engaged. The activity begins in an impulsive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form; that is, it is blind. It does not know what it is about; that is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to say, what are its interactions with other activities. An activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which brings education or instruction with it makes one aware of some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the connections which had been imperceptible. To recur to our simple
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: example, a child who reaches for a bright light gets burned. Henceforth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he knows that a certain act of touching in connection with a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: act of vision (and vice-versa) means heat and pain; or, a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: light means a source of heat. The acts by which a scientific man in his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: laboratory learns more about flame differ no whit in principle. By doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain things, he makes perceptible certain connections of heat with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other things, which had been previously ignored. Thus his acts in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relation to these things get more meaning; he knows better what he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is doing or "is about" when he has to do with them; he can intend
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences instead of just letting them happen--all synonymous ways
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of saying the same thing. At the same stroke, the flame has gained in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning; all that is known about combustion, oxidation, about light and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: temperature, may become an intrinsic part of its intellectual content.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) The other side of an educative experience is an added power of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsequent direction or control. To say that one knows what he is about,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or can intend certain consequences, is to say, of course, that he can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: better anticipate what is going to happen; that he can, therefore, get
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ready or prepare in advance so as to secure beneficial consequences and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: avert undesirable ones. A genuinely educative experience, then, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which instruction is conveyed and ability increased, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contradistinguished from a routine activity on one hand, and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capricious activity on the other. (a) In the latter one "does not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: care what happens"; one just lets himself go and avoids connecting the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences of one's act (the evidences of its connections with other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things) with the act. It is customary to frown upon such aimless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: random activity, treating it as willful mischief or carelessness or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lawlessness. But there is a tendency to seek the cause of such aimless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities in the youth's own disposition, isolated from everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: else. But in fact such activity is explosive, and due to maladjustment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with surroundings. Individuals act capriciously whenever they act under
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external dictation, or from being told, without having a purpose of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own or perceiving the bearing of the deed upon other acts. One may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learn by doing something which he does not understand; even in the most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligent action, we do much which we do not mean, because the largest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: portion of the connections of the act we consciously intend are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceived or anticipated. But we learn only because after the act is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performed we note results which we had not noted before. But much work
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in school consists in setting up rules by which pupils are to act of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such a sort that even after pupils have acted, they are not led to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: see the connection between the result--say the answer--and the method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursued. So far as they are concerned, the whole thing is a trick and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a kind of miracle. Such action is essentially capricious, and leads to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capricious habits. (b) Routine action, action which is automatic, may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increase skill to do a particular thing. In so far, it might be said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to have an educative effect. But it does not lead to new perceptions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of bearings and connections; it limits rather than widens the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning-horizon. And since the environment changes and our way of acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has to be modified in order successfully to keep a balanced connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with things, an isolated uniform way of acting becomes disastrous at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some critical moment. The vaunted "skill" turns out gross ineptitude.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The essential contrast of the idea of education as continuous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reconstruction with the other one-sided conceptions which have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criticized in this and the previous chapter is that it identifies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end (the result) and the process. This is verbally self-contradictory,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but only verbally. It means that experience as an active process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupies time and that its later period completes its earlier portion;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it brings to light connections involved, but hitherto unperceived.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The later outcome thus reveals the meaning of the earlier, while the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience as a whole establishes a bent or disposition toward the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things possessing this meaning. Every such continuous experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or activity is educative, and all education resides in having such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It remains only to point out (what will receive more ample attention
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later) that the reconstruction of experience may be social as well as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal. For purposes of simplification we have spoken in the earlier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chapters somewhat as if the education of the immature which fills them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the spirit of the social group to which they belong, were a sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: catching up of the child with the aptitudes and resources of the adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group. In static societies, societies which make the maintenance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: established custom their measure of value, this conception applies in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the main. But not in progressive communities. They endeavor to shape the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences of the young so that instead of reproducing current habits,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: better habits shall be formed, and thus the future adult society be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an improvement on their own. Men have long had some intimation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extent to which education may be consciously used to eliminate obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social evils through starting the young on paths which shall not produce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these ills, and some idea of the extent in which education may be made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an instrument of realizing the better hopes of men. But we are doubtless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: far from realizing the potential efficacy of education as a constructive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: agency of improving society, from realizing that it represents not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a development of children and youth but also of the future society of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they will be the constituents.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Education may be conceived either retrospectively or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prospectively. That is to say, it may be treated as process of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accommodating the future to the past, or as an utilization of the past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for a resource in a developing future. The former finds its standards
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and patterns in what has gone before. The mind may be regarded as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group of contents resulting from having certain things presented. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this case, the earlier presentations constitute the material to which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the later are to be assimilated. Emphasis upon the value of the early
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences of immature beings is most important, especially because of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the tendency to regard them as of little account. But these experiences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do not consist of externally presented material, but of interaction of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: native activities with the environment which progressively modifies both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the activities and the environment. The defect of the Herbartian theory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of formation through presentations consists in slighting this constant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interaction and change. The same principle of criticism applies to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theories which find the primary subject matter of study in the cultural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: products--especially the literary products--of man's history. Isolated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from their connection with the present environment in which individuals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have to act, they become a kind of rival and distracting environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Their value lies in their use to increase the meaning of the things with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which we have actively to do at the present time. The idea of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advanced in these chapters is formally summed up in the idea of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuous reconstruction of experience, an idea which is marked off
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from education as preparation for a remote future, as unfolding, as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external formation, and as recapitulation of the past.

author: Dewey, John
