author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For the most part, save incidentally, we have hitherto been concerned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with education as it may exist in any social group. We have now to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make explicit the differences in the spirit, material, and method of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education as it operates in different types of community life. To say
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that education is a social function, securing direction and development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the immature through their participation in the life of the group to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they belong, is to say in effect that education will vary with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality of life which prevails in a group. Particularly is it true that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a society which not only changes but-which has the ideal of such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: change as will improve it, will have different standards and methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of education from one which aims simply at the perpetuation of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own customs. To make the general ideas set forth applicable to our own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational practice, it is, therefore, necessary to come to closer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quarters with the nature of present social life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Implications of Human Association. Society is one word, but many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things. Men associate together in all kinds of ways and for all kinds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of purposes. One man is concerned in a multitude of diverse groups, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which his associates may be quite different. It often seems as if they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had nothing in common except that they are modes of associated life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Within every larger social organization there are numerous minor groups:
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not only political subdivisions, but industrial, scientific, religious,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: associations. There are political parties with differing aims, social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sets, cliques, gangs, corporations, partnerships, groups bound closely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: together by ties of blood, and so on in endless variety. In many modern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: states and in some ancient, there is great diversity of populations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of varying languages, religions, moral codes, and traditions. From this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standpoint, many a minor political unit, one of our large cities, for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: example, is a congeries of loosely associated societies, rather than an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inclusive and permeating community of action and thought. (See ante, p.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The terms society, community, are thus ambiguous. They have both a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eulogistic or normative sense, and a descriptive sense; a meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: de jure and a meaning de facto. In social philosophy, the former
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connotation is almost always uppermost. Society is conceived as one by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its very nature. The qualities which accompany this unity, praiseworthy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: community of purpose and welfare, loyalty to public ends, mutuality of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sympathy, are emphasized. But when we look at the facts which the term
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: denotes instead of confining our attention to its intrinsic connotation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we find not unity, but a plurality of societies, good and bad. Men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: banded together in a criminal conspiracy, business aggregations that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prey upon the public while serving it, political machines held together
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the interest of plunder, are included. If it is said that such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organizations are not societies because they do not meet the ideal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements of the notion of society, the answer, in part, is that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception of society is then made so "ideal" as to be of no use, having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no reference to facts; and in part, that each of these organizations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no matter how opposed to the interests of other groups, has something of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the praiseworthy qualities of "Society" which hold it together. There
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is honor among thieves, and a band of robbers has a common interest as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respects its members. Gangs are marked by fraternal feeling, and narrow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cliques by intense loyalty to their own codes. Family life may be marked
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by exclusiveness, suspicion, and jealousy as to those without, and yet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be a model of amity and mutual aid within. Any education given by a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: group tends to socialize its members, but the quality and value of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: socialization depends upon the habits and aims of the group. Hence, once
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more, the need of a measure for the worth of any given mode of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. In seeking this measure, we have to avoid two extremes. We cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set up, out of our heads, something we regard as an ideal society. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must base our conception upon societies which actually exist, in order
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to have any assurance that our ideal is a practicable one. But, as we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have just seen, the ideal cannot simply repeat the traits which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actually found. The problem is to extract the desirable traits of forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of community life which actually exist, and employ them to criticize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undesirable features and suggest improvement. Now in any social group
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whatever, even in a gang of thieves, we find some interest held in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: common, and we find a certain amount of interaction and cooperative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse with other groups. From these two traits we derive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our standard. How numerous and varied are the interests which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously shared? How full and free is the interplay with other forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of association? If we apply these considerations to, say, a criminal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: band, we find that the ties which consciously hold the members together
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are few in number, reducible almost to a common interest in plunder; and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they are of such a nature as to isolate the group from other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: groups with respect to give and take of the values of life. Hence, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education such a society gives is partial and distorted. If we take, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other hand, the kind of family life which illustrates the standard,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we find that there are material, intellectual, aesthetic interests in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which all participate and that the progress of one member has worth for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the experience of other members--it is readily communicable--and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the family is not an isolated whole, but enters intimately into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relationships with business groups, with schools, with all the agencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of culture, as well as with other similar groups, and that it plays a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: due part in the political organization and in return receives support
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from it. In short, there are many interests consciously communicated and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shared; and there are varied and free points of contact with other modes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of association.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: I. Let us apply the first element in this criterion to a despotically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: governed state. It is not true there is no common interest in such an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organization between governed and governors. The authorities in command
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must make some appeal to the native activities of the subjects, must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: call some of their powers into play. Talleyrand said that a government
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: could do everything with bayonets except sit on them. This cynical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: declaration is at least a recognition that the bond of union is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not merely one of coercive force. It may be said, however, that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities appealed to are themselves unworthy and degrading--that such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a government calls into functioning activity simply capacity for fear.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In a way, this statement is true. But it overlooks the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fear need not be an undesirable factor in experience. Caution,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: circumspection, prudence, desire to foresee future events so as to avert
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is harmful, these desirable traits are as much a product of calling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the impulse of fear into play as is cowardice and abject submission. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: real difficulty is that the appeal to fear is isolated. In evoking dread
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and hope of specific tangible reward--say comfort and ease--many other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities are left untouched. Or rather, they are affected, but in such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a way as to pervert them. Instead of operating on their own account they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are reduced to mere servants of attaining pleasure and avoiding pain.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This is equivalent to saying that there is no extensive number of common
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests; there is no free play back and forth among the members of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the social group. Stimulation and response are exceedingly one-sided. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: order to have a large number of values in common, all the members of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the group must have an equable opportunity to receive and to take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from others. There must be a large variety of shared undertakings and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences. Otherwise, the influences which educate some into masters,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educate others into slaves. And the experience of each party loses in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning, when the free interchange of varying modes of life-experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is arrested. A separation into a privileged and a subject-class prevents
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social endosmosis. The evils thereby affecting the superior class are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: less material and less perceptible, but equally real. Their culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tends to be sterile, to be turned back to feed on itself; their art
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes a showy display and artificial; their wealth luxurious; their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge overspecialized; their manners fastidious rather than humane.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Lack of the free and equitable intercourse which springs from a variety
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of shared interests makes intellectual stimulation unbalanced. Diversity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of stimulation means novelty, and novelty means challenge to thought.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The more activity is restricted to a few definite lines--as it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when there are rigid class lines preventing adequate interplay of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences--the more action tends to become routine on the part of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class at a disadvantage, and capricious, aimless, and explosive on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the part of the class having the materially fortunate position. Plato
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: defined a slave as one who accepts from another the purposes which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control his conduct. This condition obtains even where there is no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: slavery in the legal sense. It is found wherever men are engaged in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity which is socially serviceable, but whose service they do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not understand and have no personal interest in. Much is said about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific management of work. It is a narrow view which restricts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the science which secures efficiency of operation to movements of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: muscles. The chief opportunity for science is the discovery of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relations of a man to his work--including his relations to others who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take part--which will enlist his intelligent interest in what he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing. Efficiency in production often demands division of labor. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is reduced to a mechanical routine unless workers see the technical,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual, and social relationships involved in what they do,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and engage in their work because of the motivation furnished by such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceptions. The tendency to reduce such things as efficiency of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity and scientific management to purely technical externals is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evidence of the one-sided stimulation of thought given to those in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control of industry--those who supply its aims. Because of their lack
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of all-round and well-balanced social interest, there is not sufficient
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulus for attention to the human factors and relationships in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industry. Intelligence is narrowed to the factors concerned with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical production and marketing of goods. No doubt, a very acute and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intense intelligence in these narrow lines can be developed, but the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: failure to take into account the significant social factors means none
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the less an absence of mind, and a corresponding distortion of emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. II. This illustration (whose point is to be extended to all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: associations lacking reciprocity of interest) brings us to our second
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point. The isolation and exclusiveness of a gang or clique brings its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: antisocial spirit into relief. But this same spirit is found wherever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one group has interests "of its own" which shut it out from full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interaction with other groups, so that its prevailing purpose is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: protection of what it has got, instead of reorganization and progress
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through wider relationships. It marks nations in their isolation from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another; families which seclude their domestic concerns as if they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had no connection with a larger life; schools when separated from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest of home and community; the divisions of rich and poor; learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and unlearned. The essential point is that isolation makes for rigidity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and formal institutionalizing of life, for static and selfish ideals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: within the group. That savage tribes regard aliens and enemies as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: synonymous is not accidental. It springs from the fact that they have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identified their experience with rigid adherence to their past customs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On such a basis it is wholly logical to fear intercourse with others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for such contact might dissolve custom. It would certainly occasion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reconstruction. It is a commonplace that an alert and expanding mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life depends upon an enlarging range of contact with the physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment. But the principle applies even more significantly to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: field where we are apt to ignore it--the sphere of social contacts.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Every expansive era in the history of mankind has coincided with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operation of factors which have tended to eliminate distance between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: peoples and classes previously hemmed off from one another. Even the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alleged benefits of war, so far as more than alleged, spring from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that conflict of peoples at least enforces intercourse between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them and thus accidentally enables them to learn from one another,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thereby to expand their horizons. Travel, economic and commercial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies, have at present gone far to break down external barriers;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to bring peoples and classes into closer and more perceptible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with one another. It remains for the most part to secure the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual and emotional significance of this physical annihilation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: space.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Democratic Ideal. The two elements in our criterion both point
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to democracy. The first signifies not only more numerous and more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied points of shared common interest, but greater reliance upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the recognition of mutual interests as a factor in social control. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: second means not only freer interaction between social groups (once
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated so far as intention could keep up a separation) but change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in social habit--its continuous readjustment through meeting the new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations produced by varied intercourse. And these two traits are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely what characterize the democratically constituted society.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Upon the educational side, we note first that the realization of a form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of social life in which interests are mutually interpenetrating, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where progress, or readjustment, is an important consideration, makes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: democratic community more interested than other communities have cause
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to education is a familiar fact. The superficial explanation is that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic society repudiates the principle of external authority, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must find a substitute in voluntary disposition and interest; these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can be created only by education. But there is a deeper explanation. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democracy is more than a form of government; it is primarily a mode of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: associated living, of conjoint communicated experience. The extension
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in space of the number of individuals who participate in an interest so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that each has to refer his own action to that of others, and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consider the action of others to give point and direction to his own,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is equivalent to the breaking down of those barriers of class, race,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and national territory which kept men from perceiving the full import
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their activity. These more numerous and more varied points of contact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: denote a greater diversity of stimuli to which an individual has to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respond; they consequently put a premium on variation in his action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They secure a liberation of powers which remain suppressed as long as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the incitations to action are partial, as they must be in a group which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in its exclusiveness shuts out many interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The widening of the area of shared concerns, and the liberation of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater diversity of personal capacities which characterize a democracy,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are not of course the product of deliberation and conscious effort.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On the contrary, they were caused by the development of modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manufacture and commerce, travel, migration, and intercommunication
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which flowed from the command of science over natural energy. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: after greater individualization on one hand, and a broader community
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of interest on the other have come into existence, it is a matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate effort to sustain and extend them. Obviously a society to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which stratification into separate classes would be fatal, must see to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it that intellectual opportunities are accessible to all on equable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and easy terms. A society marked off into classes need he specially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attentive only to the education of its ruling elements. A society which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is mobile, which is full of channels for the distribution of a change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occurring anywhere, must see to it that its members are educated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to personal initiative and adaptability. Otherwise, they will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be overwhelmed by the changes in which they are caught and whose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance or connections they do not perceive. The result will be a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confusion in which a few will appropriate to themselves the results of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the blind and externally directed activities of others.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Platonic Educational Philosophy. Subsequent chapters will be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devoted to making explicit the implications of the democratic ideas in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education. In the remaining portions of this chapter, we shall consider
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the educational theories which have been evolved in three epochs when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the social import of education was especially conspicuous. The first one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be considered is that of Plato. No one could better express than did
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he the fact that a society is stably organized when each individual is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing that for which he has aptitude by nature in such a way as to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: useful to others (or to contribute to the whole to which he belongs);
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and that it is the business of education to discover these aptitudes and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progressively to train them for social use. Much which has been said so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: far is borrowed from what Plato first consciously taught the world. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions which he could not intellectually control led him to restrict
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these ideas in their application. He never got any conception of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indefinite plurality of activities which may characterize an individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and a social group, and consequently limited his view to a limited
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of classes of capacities and of social arrangements. Plato's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: starting point is that the organization of society depends ultimately
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon knowledge of the end of existence. If we do not know its end, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shall be at the mercy of accident and caprice. Unless we know the end,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the good, we shall have no criterion for rationally deciding what the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities are which should be promoted, nor how social arrangements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are to be ordered. We shall have no conception of the proper limits and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distribution of activities--what he called justice--as a trait of both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual and social organization. But how is the knowledge of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: final and permanent good to be achieved? In dealing with this question
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we come upon the seemingly insuperable obstacle that such knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not possible save in a just and harmonious social order. Everywhere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: else the mind is distracted and misled by false valuations and false
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perspectives. A disorganized and factional society sets up a number of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different models and standards. Under such conditions it is impossible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the individual to attain consistency of mind. Only a complete whole
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is fully self-consistent. A society which rests upon the supremacy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some factor over another irrespective of its rational or proportionate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: claims, inevitably leads thought astray. It puts a premium on certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things and slurs over others, and creates a mind whose seeming unity is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forced and distorted. Education proceeds ultimately from the patterns
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnished by institutions, customs, and laws. Only in a just state will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these be such as to give the right education; and only those who have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rightly trained minds will be able to recognize the end, and ordering
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle of things. We seem to be caught in a hopeless circle.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: However, Plato suggested a way out. A few men, philosophers or lovers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of wisdom--or truth--may by study learn at least in outline the proper
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: patterns of true existence. If a powerful ruler should form a state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: after these patterns, then its regulations could be preserved. An
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education could be given which would sift individuals, discovering what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they were good for, and supplying a method of assigning each to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work in life for which his nature fits him. Each doing his own part,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and never transgressing, the order and unity of the whole would be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: maintained.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It would be impossible to find in any scheme of philosophic thought a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more adequate recognition on one hand of the educational significance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of social arrangements and, on the other, of the dependence of those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrangements upon the means used to educate the young. It would be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impossible to find a deeper sense of the function of education in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovering and developing personal capacities, and training them so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they would connect with the activities of others. Yet the society
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which the theory was propounded was so undemocratic that Plato could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not work out a solution for the problem whose terms he clearly saw.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While he affirmed with emphasis that the place of the individual in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society should not be determined by birth or wealth or any conventional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: status, but by his own nature as discovered in the process of education,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he had no perception of the uniqueness of individuals. For him they fall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by nature into classes, and into a very small number of classes at that.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently the testing and sifting function of education only shows
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which one of three classes an individual belongs. There being no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognition that each individual constitutes his own class, there could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be no recognition of the infinite diversity of active tendencies and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: combinations of tendencies of which an individual is capable. There
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were only three types of faculties or powers in the individual's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitution. Hence education would soon reach a static limit in each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class, for only diversity makes change and progress.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In some individuals, appetites naturally dominate; they are assigned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the laboring and trading class, which expresses and supplies human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wants. Others reveal, upon education, that over and above appetites,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have a generous, outgoing, assertively courageous disposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They become the citizen-subjects of the state; its defenders in war; its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: internal guardians in peace. But their limit is fixed by their lack of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason, which is a capacity to grasp the universal. Those who possess
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this are capable of the highest kind of education, and become in time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the legislators of the state--for laws are the universals which control
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the particulars of experience. Thus it is not true that in intent, Plato
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinated the individual to the social whole. But it is true that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lacking the perception of the uniqueness of every individual, his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: incommensurability with others, and consequently not recognizing that a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society might change and yet be stable, his doctrine of limited powers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and classes came in net effect to the idea of the subordination of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuality. We cannot better Plato's conviction that an individual is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happy and society well organized when each individual engages in those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities for which he has a natural equipment, nor his conviction that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is the primary office of education to discover this equipment to its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possessor and train him for its effective use. But progress in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge has made us aware of the superficiality of Plato's lumping
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of individuals and their original powers into a few sharply marked-off
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: classes; it has taught us that original capacities are indefinitely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: numerous and variable. It is but the other side of this fact to say
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that in the degree in which society has become democratic, social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organization means utilization of the specific and variable qualities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of individuals, not stratification by classes. Although his educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy was revolutionary, it was none the less in bondage to static
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals. He thought that change or alteration was evidence of lawless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flux; that true reality was unchangeable. Hence while he would radically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: change the existing state of society, his aim was to construct a state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which change would subsequently have no place. The final end of life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is fixed; given a state framed with this end in view, not even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: minor details are to be altered. Though they might not be inherently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important, yet if permitted they would inure the minds of men to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea of change, and hence be dissolving and anarchic. The breakdown of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his philosophy is made apparent in the fact that he could not trust to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradual improvements in education to bring about a better society which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should then improve education, and so on indefinitely. Correct education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: could not come into existence until an ideal state existed, and after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that education would be devoted simply to its conservation. For the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence of this state he was obliged to trust to some happy accident
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by which philosophic wisdom should happen to coincide with possession of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ruling power in the state.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 4. The "Individualistic" Ideal of the Eighteenth Century. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eighteenth-century philosophy we find ourselves in a very different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: circle of ideas. "Nature" still means something antithetical to existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social organization; Plato exercised a great influence upon Rousseau.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But the voice of nature now speaks for the diversity of individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: talent and for the need of free development of individuality in all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its variety. Education in accord with nature furnishes the goal and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method of instruction and discipline. Moreover, the native or original
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: endowment was conceived, in extreme cases, as nonsocial or even as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: antisocial. Social arrangements were thought of as mere external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expedients by which these nonsocial individuals might secure a greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: amount of private happiness for themselves. Nevertheless, these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statements convey only an inadequate idea of the true significance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the movement. In reality its chief interest was in progress and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in social progress. The seeming antisocial philosophy was a somewhat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transparent mask for an impetus toward a wider and freer society--toward
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cosmopolitanism. The positive ideal was humanity. In membership in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanity, as distinct from a state, man's capacities would be liberated;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while in existing political organizations his powers were hampered and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distorted to meet the requirements and selfish interests of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rulers of the state. The doctrine of extreme individualism was but the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: counterpart, the obverse, of ideals of the indefinite perfectibility of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man and of a social organization having a scope as wide as humanity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The emancipated individual was to become the organ and agent of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comprehensive and progressive society.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The heralds of this gospel were acutely conscious of the evils of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social estate in which they found themselves. They attributed these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evils to the limitations imposed upon the free powers of man. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limitation was both distorting and corrupting. Their impassioned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devotion to emancipation of life from external restrictions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operated to the exclusive advantage of the class to whom a past feudal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: system consigned power, found intellectual formulation in a worship
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of nature. To give "nature" full swing was to replace an artificial,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: corrupt, and inequitable social order by a new and better kingdom of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanity. Unrestrained faith in Nature as both a model and a working
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: power was strengthened by the advances of natural science. Inquiry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freed from prejudice and artificial restraints of church and state had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: revealed that the world is a scene of law. The Newtonian solar system,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which expressed the reign of natural law, was a scene of wonderful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: harmony, where every force balanced with every other. Natural law would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplish the same result in human relations, if men would only get rid
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the artificial man-imposed coercive restrictions.
