text: Education in accord with nature was thought to be the first step in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insuring this more social society. It was plainly seen that economic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and political limitations were ultimately dependent upon limitations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought and feeling. The first step in freeing men from external chains
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was to emancipate them from the internal chains of false beliefs and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals. What was called social life, existing institutions, were too
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: false and corrupt to be intrusted with this work. How could it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be expected to undertake it when the undertaking meant its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: destruction? "Nature" must then be the power to which the enterprise was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be left. Even the extreme sensationalistic theory of knowledge which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was current derived itself from this conception. To insist that mind is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: originally passive and empty was one way of glorifying the possibilities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of education. If the mind was a wax tablet to be written upon by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects, there were no limits to the possibility of education by means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the natural environment. And since the natural world of objects is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a scene of harmonious "truth," this education would infallibly produce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: minds filled with the truth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 5. Education as National and as Social. As soon as the first enthusiasm
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for freedom waned, the weakness of the theory upon the constructive side
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: became obvious. Merely to leave everything to nature was, after all, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to negate the very idea of education; it was to trust to the accidents
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of circumstance. Not only was some method required but also some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: positive organ, some administrative agency for carrying on the process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of instruction. The "complete and harmonious development of all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers," having as its social counterpart an enlightened and progressive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanity, required definite organization for its realization. Private
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals here and there could proclaim the gospel; they could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not execute the work. A Pestalozzi could try experiments and exhort
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philanthropically inclined persons having wealth and power to follow his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: example. But even Pestalozzi saw that any effective pursuit of the new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational ideal required the support of the state. The realization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the new education destined to produce a new society was, after all,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dependent upon the activities of existing states. The movement for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic idea inevitably became a movement for publicly conducted and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: administered schools.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So far as Europe was concerned, the historic situation identified the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movement for a state-supported education with the nationalistic movement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in political life--a fact of incalculable significance for subsequent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements. Under the influence of German thought in particular,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education became a civic function and the civic function was identified
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the realization of the ideal of the national state. The "state" was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: substituted for humanity; cosmopolitanism gave way to nationalism. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form the citizen, not the "man," became the aim of education. 1 The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: historic situation to which reference is made is the after-effects of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the Napoleonic conquests, especially in Germany. The German states felt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (and subsequent events demonstrate the correctness of the belief) that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systematic attention to education was the best means of recovering and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: maintaining their political integrity and power. Externally they were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weak and divided. Under the leadership of Prussian statesmen they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made this condition a stimulus to the development of an extensive and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thoroughly grounded system of public education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This change in practice necessarily brought about a change in theory.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The individualistic theory receded into the background. The state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnished not only the instrumentalities of public education but also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its goal. When the actual practice was such that the school system, from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the elementary grades through the university faculties, supplied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the patriotic citizen and soldier and the future state official and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: administrator and furnished the means for military, industrial, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: political defense and expansion, it was impossible for theory not to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emphasize the aim of social efficiency. And with the immense importance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attached to the nationalistic state, surrounded by other competing and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more or less hostile states, it was equally impossible to interpret
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social efficiency in terms of a vague cosmopolitan humanitarianism.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since the maintenance of a particular national sovereignty required
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordination of individuals to the superior interests of the state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: both in military defense and in struggles for international supremacy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in commerce, social efficiency was understood to imply a like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordination. The educational process was taken to be one of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disciplinary training rather than of personal development. Since,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, the ideal of culture as complete development of personality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persisted, educational philosophy attempted a reconciliation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: two ideas. The reconciliation took the form of the conception of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "organic" character of the state. The individual in his isolation is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nothing; only in and through an absorption of the aims and meaning of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organized institutions does he attain true personality. What appears to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be his subordination to political authority and the demand for sacrifice
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of himself to the commands of his superiors is in reality but making his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own the objective reason manifested in the state--the only way in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he can become truly rational. The notion of development which we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seen to be characteristic of institutional idealism (as in the Hegelian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy) was just such a deliberate effort to combine the two ideas
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of complete realization of personality and thoroughgoing "disciplinary"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordination to existing institutions. The extent of the transformation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of educational philosophy which occurred in Germany in the generation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupied by the struggle against Napoleon for national independence,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be gathered from Kant, who well expresses the earlier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual-cosmopolitan ideal. In his treatise on Pedagogics, consisting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of lectures given in the later years of the eighteenth century, he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: defines education as the process by which man becomes man. Mankind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: begins its history submerged in nature--not as Man who is a creature of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason, while nature furnishes only instinct and appetite. Nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: offers simply the germs which education is to develop and perfect. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: peculiarity of truly human life is that man has to create himself by his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own voluntary efforts; he has to make himself a truly moral, rational,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and free being. This creative effort is carried on by the educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities of slow generations. Its acceleration depends upon men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously striving to educate their successors not for the existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: state of affairs but so as to make possible a future better humanity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But there is the great difficulty. Each generation is inclined to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educate its young so as to get along in the present world instead of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a view to the proper end of education: the promotion of the best
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible realization of humanity as humanity. Parents educate their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children so that they may get on; princes educate their subjects as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruments of their own purposes.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Who, then, shall conduct education so that humanity may improve? We must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depend upon the efforts of enlightened men in their private capacity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "All culture begins with private men and spreads outward from them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Simply through the efforts of persons of enlarged inclinations, who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are capable of grasping the ideal of a future better condition, is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradual approximation of human nature to its end possible. Rulers are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply interested in such training as will make their subjects better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tools for their own intentions." Even the subsidy by rulers of privately
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conducted schools must be carefully safeguarded. For the rulers'
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest in the welfare of their own nation instead of in what is best
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for humanity, will make them, if they give money for the schools, wish
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to draw their plans. We have in this view an express statement of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the points characteristic of the eighteenth century individualistic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cosmopolitanism. The full development of private personality is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identified with the aims of humanity as a whole and with the idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of progress. In addition we have an explicit fear of the hampering
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence of a state-conducted and state-regulated education upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attainment of these ideas. But in less than two decades after this time,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Kant's philosophic successors, Fichte and Hegel, elaborated the idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the chief function of the state is educational; that in particular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the regeneration of Germany is to be accomplished by an education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carried on in the interests of the state, and that the private
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual is of necessity an egoistic, irrational being, enslaved to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his appetites and to circumstances unless he submits voluntarily to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educative discipline of state institutions and laws. In this spirit,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Germany was the first country to undertake a public, universal, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: compulsory system of education extending from the primary school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through the university, and to submit to jealous state regulation and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supervision all private educational enterprises. Two results should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stand out from this brief historical survey. The first is that such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms as the individual and the social conceptions of education are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quite meaningless taken at large, or apart from their context. Plato had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ideal of an education which should equate individual realization and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social coherency and stability. His situation forced his ideal into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the notion of a society organized in stratified classes, losing the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual in the class. The eighteenth century educational philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was highly individualistic in form, but this form was inspired by a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noble and generous social ideal: that of a society organized to include
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanity, and providing for the indefinite perfectibility of mankind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The idealistic philosophy of Germany in the early nineteenth century
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: endeavored again to equate the ideals of a free and complete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of cultured personality with social discipline and political
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordination. It made the national state an intermediary between the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization of private personality on one side and of humanity on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other. Consequently, it is equally possible to state its animating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle with equal truth either in the classic terms of "harmonious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of all the powers of personality" or in the more recent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terminology of "social efficiency." All this reinforces the statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which opens this chapter: The conception of education as a social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process and function has no definite meaning until we define the kind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of society we have in mind. These considerations pave the way for our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: second conclusion. One of the fundamental problems of education in and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for a democratic society is set by the conflict of a nationalistic and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wider social aim. The earlier cosmopolitan and "humanitarian" conception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suffered both from vagueness and from lack of definite organs of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: execution and agencies of administration. In Europe, in the Continental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: states particularly, the new idea of the importance of education for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human welfare and progress was captured by national interests and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: harnessed to do a work whose social aim was definitely narrow and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exclusive. The social aim of education and its national aim were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identified, and the result was a marked obscuring of the meaning of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social aim.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This confusion corresponds to the existing situation of human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse. On the one hand, science, commerce, and art transcend
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: national boundaries. They are largely international in quality and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method. They involve interdependencies and cooperation among the peoples
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inhabiting different countries. At the same time, the idea of national
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sovereignty has never been as accentuated in politics as it is at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present time. Each nation lives in a state of suppressed hostility and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: incipient war with its neighbors. Each is supposed to be the supreme
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judge of its own interests, and it is assumed as matter of course that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each has interests which are exclusively its own. To question this is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to question the very idea of national sovereignty which is assumed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be basic to political practice and political science. This contradiction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (for it is nothing less) between the wider sphere of associated and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mutually helpful social life and the narrower sphere of exclusive and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hence potentially hostile pursuits and purposes, exacts of educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory a clearer conception of the meaning of "social" as a function
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and test of education than has yet been attained. Is it possible for an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational system to be conducted by a national state and yet the full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social ends of the educative process not be restricted, constrained, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: corrupted? Internally, the question has to face the tendencies, due to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present economic conditions, which split society into classes some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of which are made merely tools for the higher culture of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Externally, the question is concerned with the reconciliation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: national loyalty, of patriotism, with superior devotion to the things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which unite men in common ends, irrespective of national political
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: boundaries. Neither phase of the problem can be worked out by merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: negative means. It is not enough to see to it that education is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actively used as an instrument to make easier the exploitation of one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class by another. School facilities must be secured of such amplitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and efficiency as will in fact and not simply in name discount the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effects of economic inequalities, and secure to all the wards of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nation equality of equipment for their future careers. Accomplishment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of this end demands not only adequate administrative provision of school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facilities, and such supplementation of family resources as will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enable youth to take advantage of them, but also such modification
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of traditional ideals of culture, traditional subjects of study and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: traditional methods of teaching and discipline as will retain all the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: youth under educational influences until they are equipped to be masters

author: Dewey, John

text: of their own economic and social careers. The ideal may seem remote
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of execution, but the democratic ideal of education is a farcical yet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tragic delusion except as the ideal more and more dominates our public
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: system of education. The same principle has application on the side of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the considerations which concern the relations of one nation to another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is not enough to teach the horrors of war and to avoid everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which would stimulate international jealousy and animosity. The emphasis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be put upon whatever binds people together in cooperative human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursuits and results, apart from geographical limitations. The secondary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and provisional character of national sovereignty in respect to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fuller, freer, and more fruitful association and intercourse of all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human beings with one another must be instilled as a working disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind. If these applications seem to be remote from a consideration
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the philosophy of education, the impression shows that the meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the idea of education previously developed has not been adequately
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: grasped. This conclusion is bound up with the very idea of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as a freeing of individual capacity in a progressive growth directed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social aims. Otherwise a democratic criterion of education can only be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inconsistently applied.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Since education is a social process, and there are many kinds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of societies, a criterion for educational criticism and construction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implies a particular social ideal. The two points selected by which to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: measure the worth of a form of social life are the extent in which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests of a group are shared by all its members, and the fullness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and freedom with which it interacts with other groups. An undesirable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society, in other words, is one which internally and externally sets up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: barriers to free intercourse and communication of experience. A society
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which makes provision for participation in its good of all its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: members on equal terms and which secures flexible readjustment of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions through interaction of the different forms of associated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life is in so far democratic. Such a society must have a type of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education which gives individuals a personal interest in social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relationships and control, and the habits of mind which secure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social changes without introducing disorder. Three typical historic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophies of education were considered from this point of view.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The Platonic was found to have an ideal formally quite similar to that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stated, but which was compromised in its working out by making a class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rather than an individual the social unit. The so-called individualism
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the eighteenth-century enlightenment was found to involve the notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a society as broad as humanity, of whose progress the individual was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be the organ. But it lacked any agency for securing the development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of its ideal as was evidenced in its falling back upon Nature. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutional idealistic philosophies of the nineteenth century supplied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this lack by making the national state the agency, but in so doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: narrowed the conception of the social aim to those who were members of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same political unit, and reintroduced the idea of the subordination
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the individual to the institution. 1 There is a much neglected strain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in Rousseau tending intellectually in this direction. He opposed the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existing state of affairs on the ground that it formed neither the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: citizen nor the man. Under existing conditions, he preferred to try for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter rather than for the former. But there are many sayings of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which point to the formation of the citizen as ideally the higher, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which indicate that his own endeavor, as embodied in the Emile, was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply the best makeshift the corruption of the times permitted him to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sketch.
