text: Chapter Eight: Aims in Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Nature of an Aim.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The account of education given in our earlier chapters virtually
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anticipated the results reached in a discussion of the purport of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education in a democratic community. For it assumed that the aim of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education is to enable individuals to continue their education--or that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the object and reward of learning is continued capacity for growth. Now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this idea cannot be applied to all the members of a society except
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where intercourse of man with man is mutual, and except where there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is adequate provision for the reconstruction of social habits and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions by means of wide stimulation arising from equitably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distributed interests. And this means a democratic society. In our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: search for aims in education, we are not concerned, therefore, with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: finding an end outside of the educative process to which education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinate. Our whole conception forbids. We are rather concerned with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the contrast which exists when aims belong within the process in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they operate and when they are set up from without. And the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: state of affairs must obtain when social relationships are not equitably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: balanced. For in that case, some portions of the whole social group will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: find their aims determined by an external dictation; their aims will not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arise from the free growth of their own experience, and their nominal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aims will be means to more ulterior ends of others rather than truly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Our first question is to define the nature of an aim so far as it falls
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: within an activity, instead of being furnished from without. We approach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the definition by a contrast of mere results with ends. Any exhibition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of energy has results. The wind blows about the sands of the desert; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: position of the grains is changed. Here is a result, an effect, but not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an end. For there is nothing in the outcome which completes or fulfills
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what went before it. There is mere spatial redistribution. One state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of affairs is just as good as any other. Consequently there is no basis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon which to select an earlier state of affairs as a beginning, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later as an end, and to consider what intervenes as a process of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transformation and realization.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consider for example the activities of bees in contrast with the changes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the sands when the wind blows them about. The results of the bees'
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actions may be called ends not because they are designed or consciously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intended, but because they are true terminations or completions of what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has preceded. When the bees gather pollen and make wax and build cells,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each step prepares the way for the next. When cells are built, the queen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lays eggs in them; when eggs are laid, they are sealed and bees brood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them and keep them at a temperature required to hatch them. When they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are hatched, bees feed the young till they can take care of themselves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Now we are so familiar with such facts, that we are apt to dismiss them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the ground that life and instinct are a kind of miraculous thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anyway. Thus we fail to note what the essential characteristic of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: event is; namely, the significance of the temporal place and order of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each element; the way each prior event leads into its successor while
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the successor takes up what is furnished and utilizes it for some other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stage, until we arrive at the end, which, as it were, summarizes and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: finishes off the process. Since aims relate always to results, the first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing to look to when it is a question of aims, is whether the work
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assigned possesses intrinsic continuity. Or is it a mere serial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aggregate of acts, first doing one thing and then another? To talk about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an educational aim when approximately each act of a pupil is dictated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the teacher, when the only order in the sequence of his acts is that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which comes from the assignment of lessons and the giving of directions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by another, is to talk nonsense. It is equally fatal to an aim to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: permit capricious or discontinuous action in the name of spontaneous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-expression. An aim implies an orderly and ordered activity, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which the order consists in the progressive completing of a process.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Given an activity having a time span and cumulative growth within
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the time succession, an aim means foresight in advance of the end or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible termination. If bees anticipated the consequences of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity, if they perceived their end in imaginative foresight, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would have the primary element in an aim. Hence it is nonsense to talk
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the aim of education--or any other undertaking--where conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do not permit of foresight of results, and do not stimulate a person to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: look ahead to see what the outcome of a given activity is to be. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: next place the aim as a foreseen end gives direction to the activity; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not an idle view of a mere spectator, but influences the steps taken
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to reach the end. The foresight functions in three ways. In the first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: place, it involves careful observation of the given conditions to see
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what are the means available for reaching the end, and to discover the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hindrances in the way. In the second place, it suggests the proper order
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or sequence in the use of means. It facilitates an economical selection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and arrangement. In the third place, it makes choice of alternatives
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible. If we can predict the outcome of acting this way or that, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can then compare the value of the two courses of action; we can pass
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judgment upon their relative desirability. If we know that stagnant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: water breeds mosquitoes and that they are likely to carry disease, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can, disliking that anticipated result, take steps to avert it. Since we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do not anticipate results as mere intellectual onlookers, but as persons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerned in the outcome, we are partakers in the process which produces
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the result. We intervene to bring about this result or that.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Of course these three points are closely connected with one another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We can definitely foresee results only as we make careful scrutiny
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of present conditions, and the importance of the outcome supplies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motive for observations. The more adequate our observations, the more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied is the scene of conditions and obstructions that presents itself,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the more numerous are the alternatives between which choice may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made. In turn, the more numerous the recognized possibilities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation, or alternatives of action, the more meaning does the chosen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity possess, and the more flexibly controllable is it. Where only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a single outcome has been thought of, the mind has nothing else to think
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of; the meaning attaching to the act is limited. One only steams ahead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: toward the mark. Sometimes such a narrow course may be effective. But if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unexpected difficulties offer themselves, one has not as many resources
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at command as if he had chosen the same line of action after a broader
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: survey of the possibilities of the field. He cannot make needed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: readjustments readily.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The net conclusion is that acting with an aim is all one with acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligently. To foresee a terminus of an act is to have a basis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon which to observe, to select, and to order objects and our own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities. To do these things means to have a mind--for mind is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely intentional purposeful activity controlled by perception of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts and their relationships to one another. To have a mind to do a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing is to foresee a future possibility; it is to have a plan for its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplishment; it is to note the means which make the plan capable of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: execution and the obstructions in the way,--or, if it is really a mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do the thing and not a vague aspiration--it is to have a plan which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: takes account of resources and difficulties. Mind is capacity to refer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present conditions to future results, and future consequences to present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions. And these traits are just what is meant by having an aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or a purpose. A man is stupid or blind or unintelligent--lacking in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind--just in the degree in which in any activity he does not know what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he is about, namely, the probable consequences of his acts. A man is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imperfectly intelligent when he contents himself with looser guesses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the outcome than is needful, just taking a chance with his luck,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or when he forms plans apart from study of the actual conditions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: including his own capacities. Such relative absence of mind means to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make our feelings the measure of what is to happen. To be intelligent we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must "stop, look, listen" in making the plan of an activity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To identify acting with an aim and intelligent activity is enough to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: show its value--its function in experience. We are only too given to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making an entity out of the abstract noun "consciousness." We forget
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that it comes from the adjective "conscious." To be conscious is to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be aware of what we are about; conscious signifies the deliberate,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observant, planning traits of activity. Consciousness is nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which we have which gazes idly on the scene around one or which has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impressions made upon it by physical things; it is a name for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposeful quality of an activity, for the fact that it is directed by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an aim. Put the other way about, to have an aim is to act with meaning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not like an automatic machine; it is to mean to do something and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceive the meaning of things in the light of that intent.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Criteria of Good Aims. We may apply the results of our discussion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to a consideration of the criteria involved in a correct establishing of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aims. (1) The aim set up must be an outgrowth of existing conditions. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be based upon a consideration of what is already going on; upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources and difficulties of the situation. Theories about the proper
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end of our activities--educational and moral theories--often violate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this principle. They assume ends lying outside our activities; ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: foreign to the concrete makeup of the situation; ends which issue from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some outside source. Then the problem is to bring our activities to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bear upon the realization of these externally supplied ends. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something for which we ought to act. In any case such "aims" limit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence; they are not the expression of mind in foresight,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation, and choice of the better among alternative possibilities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They limit intelligence because, given ready-made, they must be imposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by some authority external to intelligence, leaving to the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nothing but a mechanical choice of means.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) We have spoken as if aims could be completely formed prior to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attempt to realize them. This impression must now be qualified. The aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as it first emerges is a mere tentative sketch. The act of striving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to realize it tests its worth. If it suffices to direct activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successfully, nothing more is required, since its whole function is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to set a mark in advance; and at times a mere hint may suffice. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: usually--at least in complicated situations--acting upon it brings to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: light conditions which had been overlooked. This calls for revision
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the original aim; it has to be added to and subtracted from. An
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aim must, then, be flexible; it must be capable of alteration to meet
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: circumstances. An end established externally to the process of action is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: always rigid. Being inserted or imposed from without, it is not supposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to have a working relationship to the concrete conditions of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation. What happens in the course of action neither confirms,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: refutes, nor alters it. Such an end can only be insisted upon. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: failure that results from its lack of adaptation is attributed simply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the perverseness of conditions, not to the fact that the end is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasonable under the circumstances. The value of a legitimate aim, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the contrary, lies in the fact that we can use it to change conditions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is a method for dealing with conditions so as to effect desirable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alterations in them. A farmer who should passively accept things just as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he finds them would make as great a mistake as he who framed his plans
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in complete disregard of what soil, climate, etc., permit. One of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evils of an abstract or remote external aim in education is that its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: very inapplicability in practice is likely to react into a haphazard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: snatching at immediate conditions. A good aim surveys the present state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of experience of pupils, and forming a tentative plan of treatment,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: keeps the plan constantly in view and yet modifies it as conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: develop. The aim, in short, is experimental, and hence constantly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growing as it is tested in action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (3) The aim must always represent a freeing of activities. The term end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in view is suggestive, for it puts before the mind the termination
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or conclusion of some process. The only way in which we can define
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an activity is by putting before ourselves the objects in which it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terminates--as one's aim in shooting is the target. But we must remember
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the object is only a mark or sign by which the mind specifies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity one desires to carry out. Strictly speaking, not the target
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but hitting the target is the end in view; one takes aim by means of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: target, but also by the sight on the gun. The different objects which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are thought of are means of directing the activity. Thus one aims at,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: say, a rabbit; what he wants is to shoot straight: a certain kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity. Or, if it is the rabbit he wants, it is not rabbit apart from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his activity, but as a factor in activity; he wants to eat the rabbit,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or to show it as evidence of his marksmanship--he wants to do something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with it. The doing with the thing, not the thing in isolation, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his end. The object is but a phase of the active end,--continuing the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity successfully. This is what is meant by the phrase, used above,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "freeing activity."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In contrast with fulfilling some process in order that activity may go
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on, stands the static character of an end which is imposed from without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the activity. It is always conceived of as fixed; it is something to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attained and possessed. When one has such a notion, activity is a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unavoidable means to something else; it is not significant or important
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on its own account. As compared with the end it is but a necessary evil;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something which must be gone through before one can reach the object
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is alone worth while. In other words, the external idea of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aim leads to a separation of means from end, while an end which grows
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up within an activity as plan for its direction is always both ends and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means, the distinction being only one of convenience. Every means is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: temporary end until we have attained it. Every end becomes a means of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carrying activity further as soon as it is achieved. We call it end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when it marks off the future direction of the activity in which we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engaged; means when it marks off the present direction. Every divorce of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end from means diminishes by that much the significance of the activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and tends to reduce it to a drudgery from which one would escape if he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: could. A farmer has to use plants and animals to carry on his farming
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities. It certainly makes a great difference to his life whether he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is fond of them, or whether he regards them merely as means which he has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to employ to get something else in which alone he is interested. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: former case, his entire course of activity is significant; each phase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of it has its own value. He has the experience of realizing his end at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: every stage; the postponed aim, or end in view, being merely a sight
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ahead by which to keep his activity going fully and freely. For if he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not look ahead, he is more likely to find himself blocked. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aim is as definitely a means of action as is any other portion of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Applications in Education. There is nothing peculiar about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational aims. They are just like aims in any directed occupation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The educator, like the farmer, has certain things to do, certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources with which to do, and certain obstacles with which to contend.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The conditions with which the farmer deals, whether as obstacles or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources, have their own structure and operation independently of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any purpose of his. Seeds sprout, rain falls, the sun shines, insects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devour, blight comes, the seasons change. His aim is simply to utilize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these various conditions; to make his activities and their energies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work together, instead of against one another. It would be absurd if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the farmer set up a purpose of farming, without any reference to these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions of soil, climate, characteristic of plant growth, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: His purpose is simply a foresight of the consequences of his energies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connected with those of the things about him, a foresight used to direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his movements from day to day. Foresight of possible consequences leads
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to more careful and extensive observation of the nature and performances
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the things he had to do with, and to laying out a plan--that is, of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain order in the acts to be performed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is the same with the educator, whether parent or teacher. It is as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absurd for the latter to set up his "own" aims as the proper objects of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the growth of the children as it would be for the farmer to set up an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideal of farming irrespective of conditions. Aims mean acceptance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility for the observations, anticipations, and arrangements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: required in carrying on a function--whether farming or educating. Any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aim is of value so far as it assists observation, choice, and planning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in carrying on activity from moment to moment and hour to hour; if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gets in the way of the individual's own common sense (as it will surely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do if imposed from without or accepted on authority) it does harm.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And it is well to remind ourselves that education as such has no aims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Only persons, parents, and teachers, etc., have aims, not an abstract
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea like education. And consequently their purposes are indefinitely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied, differing with different children, changing as children grow and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the growth of experience on the part of the one who teaches. Even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the most valid aims which can be put in words will, as words, do more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: harm than good unless one recognizes that they are not aims, but rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggestions to educators as to how to observe, how to look ahead, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: how to choose in liberating and directing the energies of the concrete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations in which they find themselves. As a recent writer has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: said: "To lead this boy to read Scott's novels instead of old Sleuth's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stories; to teach this girl to sew; to root out the habit of bullying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from John's make-up; to prepare this class to study medicine,--these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are samples of the millions of aims we have actually before us in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concrete work of education." Bearing these qualifications in mind, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shall proceed to state some of the characteristics found in all good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational aims. (1) An educational aim must be founded upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intrinsic activities and needs (including original instincts and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquired habits) of the given individual to be educated. The tendency of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such an aim as preparation is, as we have seen, to omit existing powers,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and find the aim in some remote accomplishment or responsibility. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general, there is a disposition to take considerations which are dear
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the hearts of adults and set them up as ends irrespective of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities of those educated. There is also an inclination to propound
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aims which are so uniform as to neglect the specific powers and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements of an individual, forgetting that all learning is something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which happens to an individual at a given time and place. The larger
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: range of perception of the adult is of great value in observing the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abilities and weaknesses of the young, in deciding what they may amount
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to. Thus the artistic capacities of the adult exhibit what certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies of the child are capable of; if we did not have the adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achievements we should be without assurance as to the significance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the drawing, reproducing, modeling, coloring activities of childhood.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So if it were not for adult language, we should not be able to see the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: import of the babbling impulses of infancy. But it is one thing to use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adult accomplishments as a context in which to place and survey the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doings of childhood and youth; it is quite another to set them up as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fixed aim without regard to the concrete activities of those educated.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) An aim must be capable of translation into a method of cooperating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the activities of those undergoing instruction. It must suggest the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kind of environment needed to liberate and to organize their capacities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Unless it lends itself to the construction of specific procedures, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unless these procedures test, correct, and amplify the aim, the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is worthless. Instead of helping the specific task of teaching, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prevents the use of ordinary judgment in observing and sizing up the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation. It operates to exclude recognition of everything except what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: squares up with the fixed end in view. Every rigid aim just because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is rigidly given seems to render it unnecessary to give careful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention to concrete conditions. Since it must apply anyhow, what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the use of noting details which do not count?
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The vice of externally imposed ends has deep roots. Teachers receive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them from superior authorities; these authorities accept them from what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is current in the community. The teachers impose them upon children. As
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a first consequence, the intelligence of the teacher is not free; it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confined to receiving the aims laid down from above. Too rarely is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the individual teacher so free from the dictation of authoritative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supervisor, textbook on methods, prescribed course of study, etc., that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he can let his mind come to close quarters with the pupil's mind and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the subject matter. This distrust of the teacher's experience is then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflected in lack of confidence in the responses of pupils. The latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: receive their aims through a double or treble external imposition,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and are constantly confused by the conflict between the aims which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural to their own experience at the time and those in which they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taught to acquiesce. Until the democratic criterion of the intrinsic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance of every growing experience is recognized, we shall be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectually confused by the demand for adaptation to external aims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (3) Educators have to be on their guard against ends that are alleged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be general and ultimate. Every activity, however specific, is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of course, general in its ramified connections, for it leads out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indefinitely into other things. So far as a general idea makes us more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alive to these connections, it cannot be too general. But "general"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also means "abstract," or detached from all specific context. And such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abstractness means remoteness, and throws us back, once more, upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching and learning as mere means of getting ready for an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disconnected from the means. That education is literally and all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the time its own reward means that no alleged study or discipline is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educative unless it is worth while in its own immediate having. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: truly general aim broadens the outlook; it stimulates one to take more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences (connections) into account. This means a wider and more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flexible observation of means. The more interacting forces, for example,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the farmer takes into account, the more varied will be his immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources. He will see a greater number of possible starting places, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a greater number of ways of getting at what he wants to do. The fuller
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one's conception of possible future achievements, the less his present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity is tied down to a small number of alternatives. If one knew
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enough, one could start almost anywhere and sustain his activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuously and fruitfully.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Understanding then the term general or comprehensive aim simply in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense of a broad survey of the field of present activities, we shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take up some of the larger ends which have currency in the educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theories of the day, and consider what light they throw upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate concrete and diversified aims which are always the educator's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: real concern. We premise (as indeed immediately follows from what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has been said) that there is no need of making a choice among them or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarding them as competitors. When we come to act in a tangible way we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have to select or choose a particular act at a particular time, but any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of comprehensive ends may exist without competition, since they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mean simply different ways of looking at the same scene. One cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: climb a number of different mountains simultaneously, but the views had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when different mountains are ascended supplement one another: they do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not set up incompatible, competing worlds. Or, putting the matter in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a slightly different way, one statement of an end may suggest certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questions and observations, and another statement another set of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questions, calling for other observations. Then the more general ends we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have, the better. One statement will emphasize what another slurs over.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What a plurality of hypotheses does for the scientific investigator, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plurality of stated aims may do for the instructor.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. An aim denotes the result of any natural process brought to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciousness and made a factor in determining present observation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and choice of ways of acting. It signifies that an activity has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: become intelligent. Specifically it means foresight of the alternative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences attendant upon acting in a given situation in different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ways, and the use of what is anticipated to direct observation and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiment. A true aim is thus opposed at every point to an aim which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imposed upon a process of action from without. The latter is fixed and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rigid; it is not a stimulus to intelligence in the given situation, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is an externally dictated order to do such and such things. Instead of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connecting directly with present activities, it is remote, divorced from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the means by which it is to be reached. Instead of suggesting a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freer and better balanced activity, it is a limit set to activity. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education, the currency of these externally imposed aims is responsible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the emphasis put upon the notion of preparation for a remote future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and for rendering the work of both teacher and pupil mechanical and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: slavish.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: Chapter Nine: Natural Development and Social Efficiency as Aims
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Nature as Supplying the Aim. We have just pointed out the futility
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of trying to establish the aim of education--some one final aim which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinates all others to itself. We have indicated that since general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aims are but prospective points of view from which to survey the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existing conditions and estimate their possibilities, we might have any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of them, all consistent with one another. As matter of fact, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: large number have been stated at different times, all having great local
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value. For the statement of aim is a matter of emphasis at a given time.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And we do not emphasize things which do not require emphasis--that is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such things as are taking care of themselves fairly well. We tend rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to frame our statement on the basis of the defects and needs of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contemporary situation; we take for granted, without explicit statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which would be of no use, whatever is right or approximately so. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: frame our explicit aims in terms of some alteration to be brought about.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is, then, DO paradox requiring explanation that a given epoch or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generation tends to emphasize in its conscious projections just the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which it has least of in actual fact. A time of domination by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authority will call out as response the desirability of great individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freedom; one of disorganized individual activities the need of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control as an educational aim.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The actual and implicit practice and the conscious or stated aim thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: balance each other. At different times such aims as complete living,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: better methods of language study, substitution of things for words,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social efficiency, personal culture, social service, complete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of personality, encyclopedic knowledge, discipline, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: esthetic contemplation, utility, etc., have served. The following
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discussion takes up three statements of recent influence; certain others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been incidentally discussed in the previous chapters, and others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will be considered later in a discussion of knowledge and of the values
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of studies. We begin with a consideration that education is a process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of development in accordance with nature, taking Rousseau's statement,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which opposed natural to social (See ante, p. 91); and then pass over
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the antithetical conception of social efficiency, which often opposes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social to natural.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (1) Educational reformers disgusted with the conventionality and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: artificiality of the scholastic methods they find about them are prone
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to resort to nature as a standard. Nature is supposed to furnish the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: law and the end of development; ours it is to follow and conform to her
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ways. The positive value of this conception lies in the forcible way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which it calls attention to the wrongness of aims which do not have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regard to the natural endowment of those educated. Its weakness is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ease with which natural in the sense of normal is confused with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical. The constructive use of intelligence in foresight, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contriving, is then discounted; we are just to get out of the way and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: allow nature to do the work. Since no one has stated in the doctrine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: both its truth and falsity better than Rousseau, we shall turn to him.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "Education," he says, "we receive from three sources--Nature, men,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and things. The spontaneous development of our organs and capacities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes the education of Nature. The use to which we are taught to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: put this development constitutes that education given us by Men. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquirement of personal experience from surrounding objects constitutes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that of things. Only when these three kinds of education are consonant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and make for the same end, does a man tend towards his true goal. If we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are asked what is this end, the answer is that of Nature. For since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the concurrence of the three kinds of education is necessary to their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: completeness, the kind which is entirely independent of our control must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessarily regulate us in determining the other two." Then he defines
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Nature to mean the capacities and dispositions which are inborn, "as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they exist prior to the modification due to constraining habits and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence of the opinion of others."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The wording of Rousseau will repay careful study. It contains as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fundamental truths as have been uttered about education in conjunction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a curious twist. It would be impossible to say better what is said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
