text: in the first sentences. The three factors of educative development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are (a) the native structure of our bodily organs and their functional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities; (b) the uses to which the activities of these organs are put
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: under the influence of other persons; (c) their direct interaction with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the environment. This statement certainly covers the ground. His other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: two propositions are equally sound; namely, (a) that only when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: three factors of education are consonant and cooperative does adequate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of the individual occur, and (b) that the native activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the organs, being original, are basic in conceiving consonance. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it requires but little reading between the lines, supplemented by other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statements of Rousseau, to perceive that instead of regarding these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: three things as factors which must work together to some extent in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: order that any one of them may proceed educatively, he regards them as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separate and independent operations. Especially does he believe that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is an independent and, as he says, "spontaneous" development of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the native organs and faculties. He thinks that this development can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: go on irrespective of the use to which they are put. And it is to this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separate development that education coming from social contact is to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinated. Now there is an immense difference between a use of native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities in accord with those activities themselves--as distinct from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forcing them and perverting them--and supposing that they have a normal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development apart from any use, which development furnishes the standard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and norm of all learning by use. To recur to our previous illustration,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the process of acquiring language is a practically perfect model of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proper educative growth. The start is from native activities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocal apparatus, organs of hearing, etc. But it is absurd to suppose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that these have an independent growth of their own, which left to itself
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would evolve a perfect speech. Taken literally, Rousseau's principle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would mean that adults should accept and repeat the babblings and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noises of children not merely as the beginnings of the development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of articulate speech--which they are--but as furnishing language
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself--the standard for all teaching of language.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The point may be summarized by saying that Rousseau was right,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: introducing a much-needed reform into education, in holding that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: structure and activities of the organs furnish the conditions of all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching of the use of the organs; but profoundly wrong in intimating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they supply not only the conditions but also the ends of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development. As matter of fact, the native activities develop, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contrast with random and capricious exercise, through the uses to which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are put. And the office of the social medium is, as we have seen,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to direct growth through putting powers to the best possible use. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instinctive activities may be called, metaphorically, spontaneous,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the sense that the organs give a strong bias for a certain sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operation,--a bias so strong that we cannot go contrary to it, though by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trying to go contrary we may pervert, stunt, and corrupt them. But the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: notion of a spontaneous normal development of these activities is pure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mythology. The natural, or native, powers furnish the initiating and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limiting forces in all education; they do not furnish its ends or aims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is no learning except from a beginning in unlearned powers, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning is not a matter of the spontaneous overflow of the unlearned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers. Rousseau's contrary opinion is doubtless due to the fact that he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identified God with Nature; to him the original powers are wholly good,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coming directly from a wise and good creator. To paraphrase the old
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: saying about the country and the town, God made the original human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organs and faculties, man makes the uses to which they are put.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently the development of the former furnishes the standard to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the latter must be subordinated. When men attempt to determine the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uses to which the original activities shall be put, they interfere with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a divine plan. The interference by social arrangements with Nature,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: God's work, is the primary source of corruption in individuals.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Rousseau's passionate assertion of the intrinsic goodness of all natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies was a reaction against the prevalent notion of the total
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depravity of innate human nature, and has had a powerful influence in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modifying the attitude towards children's interests. But it is hardly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessary to say that primitive impulses are of themselves neither good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nor evil, but become one or the other according to the objects for which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are employed. That neglect, suppression, and premature forcing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of some instincts at the expense of others, are responsible for many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: avoidable ills, there can be no doubt. But the moral is not to leave
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them alone to follow their own "spontaneous development," but to provide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an environment which shall organize them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Returning to the elements of truth contained in Rousseau's statements,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we find that natural development, as an aim, enables him to point the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means of correcting many evils in current practices, and to indicate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a number of desirable specific aims. (1) Natural development as an aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fixes attention upon the bodily organs and the need of health and vigor.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The aim of natural development says to parents and teachers: Make health
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an aim; normal development cannot be had without regard to the vigor of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the body--an obvious enough fact and yet one whose due recognition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in practice would almost automatically revolutionize many of our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational practices. "Nature" is indeed a vague and metaphorical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: term, but one thing that "Nature" may be said to utter is that there are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions of educational efficiency, and that till we have learned what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these conditions are and have learned to make our practices accord with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them, the noblest and most ideal of our aims are doomed to suffer--are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: verbal and sentimental rather than efficacious.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) The aim of natural development translates into the aim of respect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for physical mobility. In Rousseau's words: "Children are always in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motion; a sedentary life is injurious." When he says that "Nature's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intention is to strengthen the body before exercising the mind"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he hardly states the fact fairly. But if he had said that nature's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "intention" (to adopt his poetical form of speech) is to develop the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind especially by exercise of the muscles of the body he would have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stated a positive fact. In other words, the aim of following nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means, in the concrete, regard for the actual part played by use of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bodily organs in explorations, in handling of materials, in plays
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and games. (3) The general aim translates into the aim of regard for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual differences among children. Nobody can take the principle of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consideration of native powers into account without being struck by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that these powers differ in different individuals. The difference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: applies not merely to their intensity, but even more to their quality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and arrangement. As Rouseau said: "Each individual is born with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a distinctive temperament. We indiscriminately employ children of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different bents on the same exercises; their education destroys the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: special bent and leaves a dull uniformity. Therefore after we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wasted our efforts in stunting the true gifts of nature we see the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: short-lived and illusory brilliance we have substituted die away, while
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the natural abilities we have crushed do not revive."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Lastly, the aim of following nature means to note the origin, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: waxing, and waning, of preferences and interests. Capacities bud and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bloom irregularly; there is no even four-abreast development. We must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strike while the iron is hot. Especially precious are the first dawnings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of power. More than we imagine, the ways in which the tendencies of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: early childhood are treated fix fundamental dispositions and condition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the turn taken by powers that show themselves later. Educational concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the early years of life--as distinct from inculcation of useful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arts--dates almost entirely from the time of the emphasis by Pestalozzi
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and Froebel, following Rousseau, of natural principles of growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The irregularity of growth and its significance is indicated in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following passage of a student of the growth of the nervous system.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "While growth continues, things bodily and mental are lopsided, for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growth is never general, but is accentuated now at one spot, now at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another. The methods which shall recognize in the presence of these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enormous differences of endowment the dynamic values of natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inequalities of growth, and utilize them, preferring irregularity to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rounding out gained by pruning will most closely follow that which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: takes place in the body and thus prove most effective." 1 Observation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural tendencies is difficult under conditions of restraint. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: show themselves most readily in a child's spontaneous sayings and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doings,--that is, in those he engages in when not put at set tasks and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when not aware of being under observation. It does not follow that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these tendencies are all desirable because they are natural; but it does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: follow that since they are there, they are operative and must be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taken account of. We must see to it that the desirable ones have an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment which keeps them active, and that their activity shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control the direction the others take and thereby induce the disuse of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter because they lead to nothing. Many tendencies that trouble
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parents when they appear are likely to be transitory, and sometimes too
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much direct attention to them only fixes a child's attention upon them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At all events, adults too easily assume their own habits and wishes as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standards, and regard all deviations of children's impulses as evils
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be eliminated. That artificiality against which the conception of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following nature is so largely a protest, is the outcome of attempts to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: force children directly into the mold of grown-up standards.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In conclusion, we note that the early history of the idea of following
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature combined two factors which had no inherent connection with one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another. Before the time of Rousseau educational reformers had been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inclined to urge the importance of education by ascribing practically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unlimited power to it. All the differences between peoples and between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: classes and persons among the same people were said to be due to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: differences of training, of exercise, and practice. Originally, mind,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason, understanding is, for all practical purposes, the same in all.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This essential identity of mind means the essential equality of all and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the possibility of bringing them all to the same level. As a protest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: against this view, the doctrine of accord with nature meant a much less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formal and abstract view of mind and its powers. It substituted specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instincts and impulses and physiological capacities, differing from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual to individual (just as they differ, as Rousseau pointed out,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: even in dogs of the same litter), for abstract faculties of discernment,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: memory, and generalization. Upon this side, the doctrine of educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accord with nature has been reinforced by the development of modern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: biology, physiology, and psychology. It means, in effect, that great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as is the significance of nurture, of modification, and transformation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through direct educational effort, nature, or unlearned capacities,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affords the foundation and ultimate resources for such nurture. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other hand, the doctrine of following nature was a political dogma. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meant a rebellion against existing social institutions, customs, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals (See ante, p. 91). Rousseau's statement that everything is good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as it comes from the hands of the Creator has its signification only in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its contrast with the concluding part of the same sentence: "Everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degenerates in the hands of man." And again he says: "Natural man has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an absolute value; he is a numerical unit, a complete integer and has no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relation save to himself and to his fellow man. Civilized man is only a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relative unit, the numerator of a fraction whose value depends upon its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dominator, its relation to the integral body of society. Good political
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions are those which make a man unnatural." It is upon this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception of the artificial and harmful character of organized social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life as it now exists 2 that he rested the notion that nature not merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnishes prime forces which initiate growth but also its plan and goal.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: That evil institutions and customs work almost automatically to give a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wrong education which the most careful schooling cannot offset is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: true enough; but the conclusion is not to education apart from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment, but to provide an environment in which native powers will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be put to better uses.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Social Efficiency as Aim. A conception which made nature supply the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end of a true education and society the end of an evil one, could hardly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fail to call out a protest. The opposing emphasis took the form of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doctrine that the business of education is to supply precisely what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature fails to secure; namely, habituation of an individual to social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control; subordination of natural powers to social rules. It is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surprising to find that the value in the idea of social efficiency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resides largely in its protest against the points at which the doctrine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of natural development went astray; while its misuse comes when it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed to slur over the truth in that conception. It is a fact that we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must look to the activities and achievements of associated life to find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what the development of power--that is to say, efficiency--means. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: error is in implying that we must adopt measures of subordination rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than of utilization to secure efficiency. The doctrine is rendered
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequate when we recognize that social efficiency is attained not by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: negative constraint but by positive use of native individual capacities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in occupations having a social meaning. (1) Translated into specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aims, social efficiency indicates the importance of industrial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: competency. Persons cannot live without means of subsistence; the ways
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which these means are employed and consumed have a profound influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon all the relationships of persons to one another. If an individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not able to earn his own living and that of the children dependent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon him, he is a drag or parasite upon the activities of others. He
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: misses for himself one of the most educative experiences of life. If he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not trained in the right use of the products of industry, there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is grave danger that he may deprave himself and injure others in his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possession of wealth. No scheme of education can afford to neglect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such basic considerations. Yet in the name of higher and more spiritual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals, the arrangements for higher education have often not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: neglected them, but looked at them with scorn as beneath the level of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educative concern. With the change from an oligarchical to a democratic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society, it is natural that the significance of an education which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should have as a result ability to make one's way economically in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world, and to manage economic resources usefully instead of for mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: display and luxury, should receive emphasis.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is, however, grave danger that in insisting upon this end,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existing economic conditions and standards will be accepted as final.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A democratic criterion requires us to develop capacity to the point of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: competency to choose and make its own career. This principle is violated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when the attempt is made to fit individuals in advance for definite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial callings, selected not on the basis of trained original
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacities, but on that of the wealth or social status of parents. As a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of fact, industry at the present time undergoes rapid and abrupt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: changes through the evolution of new inventions. New industries spring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up, and old ones are revolutionized. Consequently an attempt to train
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for too specific a mode of efficiency defeats its own purpose. When the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupation changes its methods, such individuals are left behind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with even less ability to readjust themselves than if they had a less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definite training. But, most of all, the present industrial constitution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of society is, like every society which has ever existed, full of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inequities. It is the aim of progressive education to take part in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: correcting unfair privilege and unfair deprivation, not to perpetuate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. Wherever social control means subordination of individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities to class authority, there is danger that industrial education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will be dominated by acceptance of the status quo. Differences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of economic opportunity then dictate what the future callings of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals are to be. We have an unconscious revival of the defects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the Platonic scheme (ante, p. 89) without its enlightened method of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: selection.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) Civic efficiency, or good citizenship. It is, of course, arbitrary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to separate industrial competency from capacity in good citizenship. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter term may be used to indicate a number of qualifications which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are vaguer than vocational ability. These traits run from whatever make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an individual a more agreeable companion to citizenship in the political
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense: it denotes ability to judge men and measures wisely and to take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a determining part in making as well as obeying laws. The aim of civic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efficiency has at least the merit of protecting us from the notion of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training of mental power at large. It calls attention to the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: power must be relative to doing something, and to the fact that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which most need to be done are things which involve one's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relationships with others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Here again we have to be on guard against understanding the aim too
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: narrowly. An over-definite interpretation would at certain periods have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: excluded scientific discoveries, in spite of the fact that in the last
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: analysis security of social progress depends upon them. For scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: men would have been thought to be mere theoretical dreamers, totally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lacking in social efficiency. It must be borne in mind that ultimately
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social efficiency means neither more nor less than capacity to share
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in a give and take of experience. It covers all that makes one's own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience more worth while to others, and all that enables one to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: participate more richly in the worthwhile experiences of others. Ability
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to produce and to enjoy art, capacity for recreation, the significant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utilization of leisure, are more important elements in it than elements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conventionally associated oftentimes with citizenship. In the broadest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense, social efficiency is nothing less than that socialization of mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is actively concerned in making experiences more communicable;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in breaking down the barriers of social stratification which make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individuals impervious to the interests of others. When social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efficiency is confined to the service rendered by overt acts, its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chief constituent (because its only guarantee) is omitted,--intelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sympathy or good will. For sympathy as a desirable quality is something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more than mere feeling; it is a cultivated imagination for what men have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in common and a rebellion at whatever unnecessarily divides them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What is sometimes called a benevolent interest in others may be but an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unwitting mask for an attempt to dictate to them what their good shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be, instead of an endeavor to free them so that they may seek and find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the good of their own choice. Social efficiency, even social service,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are hard and metallic things when severed from an active acknowledgment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the diversity of goods which life may afford to different persons,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and from faith in the social utility of encouraging every individual to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make his own choice intelligent.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Culture as Aim. Whether or not social efficiency is an aim which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consistent with culture turns upon these considerations. Culture means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at least something cultivated, something ripened; it is opposed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the raw and crude. When the "natural" is identified with this rawness,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture is opposed to what is called natural development. Culture is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also something personal; it is cultivation with respect to appreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of ideas and art and broad human interests. When efficiency is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identified with a narrow range of acts, instead of with the spirit and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning of activity, culture is opposed to efficiency. Whether called
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture or complete development of personality, the outcome is identical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the true meaning of social efficiency whenever attention is given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what is unique in an individual--and he would not be an individual if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there were not something incommensurable about him. Its opposite is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mediocre, the average. Whenever distinctive quality is developed,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distinction of personality results, and with it greater promise for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a social service which goes beyond the supply in quantity of material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commodities. For how can there be a society really worth serving unless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is constituted of individuals of significant personal qualities?
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The fact is that the opposition of high worth of personality to social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efficiency is a product of a feudally organized society with its rigid
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: division of inferior and superior. The latter are supposed to have time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and opportunity to develop themselves as human beings; the former are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confined to providing external products. When social efficiency as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: measured by product or output is urged as an ideal in a would-be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic society, it means that the depreciatory estimate of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: masses characteristic of an aristocratic community is accepted and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carried over. But if democracy has a moral and ideal meaning, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that a social return be demanded from all and that opportunity for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of distinctive capacities be afforded all. The separation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the two aims in education is fatal to democracy; the adoption of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the narrower meaning of efficiency deprives it of its essential
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: justification.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The aim of efficiency (like any educational aim) must be included within
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the process of experience. When it is measured by tangible external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: products, and not by the achieving of a distinctively valuable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, it becomes materialistic. Results in the way of commodities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which may be the outgrowth of an efficient personality are, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strictest sense, by-products of education: by-products which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inevitable and important, but nevertheless by-products. To set up an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external aim strengthens by reaction the false conception of culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which identifies it with something purely "inner." And the idea of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perfecting an "inner" personality is a sure sign of social divisions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What is called inner is simply that which does not connect with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others--which is not capable of free and full communication. What is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: termed spiritual culture has usually been futile, with something rotten
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about it, just because it has been conceived as a thing which a man
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: might have internally--and therefore exclusively. What one is as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: person is what one is as associated with others, in a free give and take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of intercourse. This transcends both the efficiency which consists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in supplying products to others and the culture which is an exclusive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: refinement and polish.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Any individual has missed his calling, farmer, physician, teacher,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: student, who does not find that the accomplishments of results of value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to others is an accompaniment of a process of experience inherently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: worth while. Why then should it be thought that one must take his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: choice between sacrificing himself to doing useful things for others,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or sacrificing them to pursuit of his own exclusive ends, whether the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: saving of his own soul or the building of an inner spiritual life and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personality? What happens is that since neither of these things is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persistently possible, we get a compromise and an alternation. One tries
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each course by turns. There is no greater tragedy than that so much
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the professedly spiritual and religious thought of the world
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has emphasized the two ideals of self-sacrifice and spiritual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-perfecting instead of throwing its weight against this dualism of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. The dualism is too deeply established to be easily overthrown; for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that reason, it is the particular task of education at the present time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to struggle in behalf of an aim in which social efficiency and personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture are synonyms instead of antagonists.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. General or comprehensive aims are points of view for surveying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the specific problems of education. Consequently it is a test of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value of the manner in which any large end is stated to see if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will translate readily and consistently into the procedures which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggested by another. We have applied this test to three general aims:
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Development according to nature, social efficiency, and culture or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal mental enrichment. In each case we have seen that the aims
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when partially stated come into conflict with each other. The partial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement of natural development takes the primitive powers in an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alleged spontaneous development as the end-all. From this point of view
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training which renders them useful to others is an abnormal constraint;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one which profoundly modifies them through deliberate nurture is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: corrupting. But when we recognize that natural activities mean native
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities which develop only through the uses in which they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nurtured, the conflict disappears. Similarly a social efficiency which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is defined in terms of rendering external service to others is of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessity opposed to the aim of enriching the meaning of experience,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while a culture which is taken to consist in an internal refinement of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind is opposed to a socialized disposition. But social efficiency as an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational purpose should mean cultivation of power to join freely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and fully in shared or common activities. This is impossible without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture, while it brings a reward in culture, because one cannot share
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in intercourse with others without learning--without getting a broader
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point of view and perceiving things of which one would otherwise be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ignorant. And there is perhaps no better definition of culture than that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is the capacity for constantly expanding the range and accuracy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one's perception of meanings.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1 Donaldson, Growth of Brain, p. 356.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2 We must not forget that Rousseau had the idea of a radically different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sort of society, a fraternal society whose end should be identical with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the good of all its members, which he thought to be as much better than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existing states as these are worse than the state of nature.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
