text: Chapter Ten: Interest and Discipline
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Meaning of the Terms. We have already noticed the difference in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the attitude of a spectator and of an agent or participant. The former
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is indifferent to what is going on; one result is just as good as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another, since each is just something to look at. The latter is bound
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up with what is going on; its outcome makes a difference to him. His
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fortunes are more or less at stake in the issue of events. Consequently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he does whatever he can to influence the direction present occurrences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take. One is like a man in a prison cell watching the rain out of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: window; it is all the same to him. The other is like a man who has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: planned an outing for the next day which continuing rain will frustrate.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He cannot, to be sure, by his present reactions affect to-morrow's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: weather, but he may take some steps which will influence future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happenings, if only to postpone the proposed picnic. If a man sees a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carriage coming which may run over him, if he cannot stop its movement,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he can at least get out of the way if he foresees the consequence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in time. In many instances, he can intervene even more directly. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitude of a participant in the course of affairs is thus a double
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one: there is solicitude, anxiety concerning future consequences, and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendency to act to assure better, and avert worse, consequences. There
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are words which denote this attitude: concern, interest. These words
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggest that a person is bound up with the possibilities inhering in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects; that he is accordingly on the lookout for what they are likely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do to him; and that, on the basis of his expectation or foresight,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he is eager to act so as to give things one turn rather than another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Interest and aims, concern and purpose, are necessarily connected. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: words as aim, intent, end, emphasize the results which are wanted and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: striven for; they take for granted the personal attitude of solicitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and attentive eagerness. Such words as interest, affection, concern,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motivation, emphasize the bearing of what is foreseen upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual's fortunes, and his active desire to act to secure a possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result. They take for granted the objective changes. But the difference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is but one of emphasis; the meaning that is shaded in one set of words
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is illuminated in the other. What is anticipated is objective and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impersonal; to-morrow's rain; the possibility of being run over. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for an active being, a being who partakes of the consequences instead of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standing aloof from them, there is at the same time a personal response.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The difference imaginatively foreseen makes a present difference,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which finds expression in solicitude and effort. While such words
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as affection, concern, and motive indicate an attitude of personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preference, they are always attitudes toward objects--toward what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: foreseen. We may call the phase of objective foresight intellectual, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the phase of personal concern emotional and volitional, but there is no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation in the facts of the situation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Such a separation could exist only if the personal attitudes ran their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course in a world by themselves. But they are always responses to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is going on in the situation of which they are a part, and their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successful or unsuccessful expression depends upon their interaction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with other changes. Life activities flourish and fail only in connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with changes of the environment. They are literally bound up with these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: changes; our desires, emotions, and affections are but various ways in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which our doings are tied up with the doings of things and persons about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: us. Instead of marking a purely personal or subjective realm, separated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the objective and impersonal, they indicate the non-existence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such a separate world. They afford convincing evidence that changes in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things are not alien to the activities of a self, and that the career
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and welfare of the self are bound up with the movement of persons and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things. Interest, concern, mean that self and world are engaged with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each other in a developing situation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The word interest, in its ordinary usage, expresses (i) the whole state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of active development, (ii) the objective results that are foreseen and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wanted, and (iii) the personal emotional inclination.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (I) An occupation, employment, pursuit, business is often referred to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as an interest. Thus we say that a man's interest is politics, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: journalism, or philanthropy, or archaeology, or collecting Japanese
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prints, or banking.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) By an interest we also mean the point at which an object touches
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or engages a man; the point where it influences him. In some legal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transactions a man has to prove "interest" in order to have a standing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at court. He has to show that some proposed step concerns his affairs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A silent partner has an interest in a business, although he takes no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active part in its conduct because its prosperity or decline affects his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: profits and liabilities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iii) When we speak of a man as interested in this or that the emphasis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: falls directly upon his personal attitude. To be interested is to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absorbed in, wrapped up in, carried away by, some object. To take an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest is to be on the alert, to care about, to be attentive. We say
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of an interested person both that he has lost himself in some affair and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that he has found himself in it. Both terms express the engrossment of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the self in an object.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When the place of interest in education is spoken of in a depreciatory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way, it will be found that the second of the meanings mentioned is first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exaggerated and then isolated. Interest is taken to mean merely the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effect of an object upon personal advantage or disadvantage, success or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: failure. Separated from any objective development of affairs, these are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reduced to mere personal states of pleasure or pain. Educationally, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then follows that to attach importance to interest means to attach some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: feature of seductiveness to material otherwise indifferent; to secure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention and effort by offering a bribe of pleasure. This procedure is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: properly stigmatized as "soft" pedagogy; as a "soup-kitchen" theory of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But the objection is based upon the fact--or assumption--that the forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of skill to be acquired and the subject matter to be appropriated have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no interest on their own account: in other words, they are supposed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be irrelevant to the normal activities of the pupils. The remedy is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in finding fault with the doctrine of interest, any more than it is to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: search for some pleasant bait that may be hitched to the alien material.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is to discover objects and modes of action, which are connected with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present powers. The function of this material in engaging activity and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carrying it on consistently and continuously is its interest. If the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material operates in this way, there is no call either to hunt for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devices which will make it interesting or to appeal to arbitrary,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: semi-coerced effort.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The word interest suggests, etymologically, what is between,--that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which connects two things otherwise distant. In education, the distance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: covered may be looked at as temporal. The fact that a process takes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time to mature is so obvious a fact that we rarely make it explicit. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: overlook the fact that in growth there is ground to be covered between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an initial stage of process and the completing period; that there is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something intervening. In learning, the present powers of the pupil are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the initial stage; the aim of the teacher represents the remote limit.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Between the two lie means--that is middle conditions:--acts to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performed; difficulties to be overcome; appliances to be used. Only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through them, in the literal time sense, will the initial activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reach a satisfactory consummation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: These intermediate conditions are of interest precisely because the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of existing activities into the foreseen and desired end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depends upon them. To be means for the achieving of present tendencies,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be "between" the agent and his end, to be of interest, are different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: names for the same thing. When material has to be made interesting,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it signifies that as presented, it lacks connection with purposes and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present power: or that if the connection be there, it is not perceived.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To make it interesting by leading one to realize the connection that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exists is simply good sense; to make it interesting by extraneous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and artificial inducements deserves all the bad names which have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: applied to the doctrine of interest in education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So much for the meaning of the term interest. Now for that of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline. Where an activity takes time, where many means and obstacles
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lie between its initiation and completion, deliberation and persistence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are required. It is obvious that a very large part of the everyday
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning of will is precisely the deliberate or conscious disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to persist and endure in a planned course of action in spite of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulties and contrary solicitations. A man of strong will, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the popular usage of the words, is a man who is neither fickle nor
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: half-hearted in achieving chosen ends. His ability is executive; that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, he persistently and energetically strives to execute or carry out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his aims. A weak will is unstable as water.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Clearly there are two factors in will. One has to do with the foresight
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of results, the other with the depth of hold the foreseen outcome has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the person.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (I) Obstinacy is persistence but it is not strength of volition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Obstinacy may be mere animal inertia and insensitiveness. A man keeps
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on doing a thing just because he has got started, not because of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clearly thought-out purpose. In fact, the obstinate man generally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: declines (although he may not be quite aware of his refusal) to make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clear to himself what his proposed end is; he has a feeling that if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he allowed himself to get a clear and full idea of it, it might not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be worth while. Stubbornness shows itself even more in reluctance to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criticize ends which present themselves than it does in persistence and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energy in use of means to achieve the end. The really executive man is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a man who ponders his ends, who makes his ideas of the results of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actions as clear and full as possible. The people we called weak-willed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or self-indulgent always deceive themselves as to the consequences of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their acts. They pick out some feature which is agreeable and neglect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all attendant circumstances. When they begin to act, the disagreeable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results they ignored begin to show themselves. They are discouraged,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or complain of being thwarted in their good purpose by a hard fate, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shift to some other line of action. That the primary difference between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strong and feeble volition is intellectual, consisting in the degree
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of persistent firmness and fullness with which consequences are thought
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out, cannot be over-emphasized.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) There is, of course, such a thing as a speculative tracing out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of results. Ends are then foreseen, but they do not lay deep hold of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a person. They are something to look at and for curiosity to play
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with rather than something to achieve. There is no such thing as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: over-intellectuality, but there is such a thing as a one-sided
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectuality. A person "takes it out" as we say in considering the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences of proposed lines of action. A certain flabbiness of fiber
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prevents the contemplated object from gripping him and engaging him in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action. And most persons are naturally diverted from a proposed course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of action by unusual, unforeseen obstacles, or by presentation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inducements to an action that is directly more agreeable.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A person who is trained to consider his actions, to undertake them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberately, is in so far forth disciplined. Add to this ability
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a power to endure in an intelligently chosen course in face of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distraction, confusion, and difficulty, and you have the essence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline. Discipline means power at command; mastery of the resources
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: available for carrying through the action undertaken. To know what one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to do and to move to do it promptly and by use of the requisite means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to be disciplined, whether we are thinking of an army or a mind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Discipline is positive. To cow the spirit, to subdue inclination, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: compel obedience, to mortify the flesh, to make a subordinate perform an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uncongenial task--these things are or are not disciplinary according as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they do or do not tend to the development of power to recognize what one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is about and to persistence in accomplishment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is hardly necessary to press the point that interest and discipline
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are connected, not opposed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (i) Even the more purely intellectual phase of trained
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: power--apprehension of what one is doing as exhibited in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences--is not possible without interest. Deliberation will be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perfunctory and superficial where there is no interest. Parents and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teachers often complain--and correctly--that children "do not want
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to hear, or want to understand." Their minds are not upon the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precisely because it does not touch them; it does not enter into their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerns. This is a state of things that needs to be remedied, but the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remedy is not in the use of methods which increase indifference and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aversion. Even punishing a child for inattention is one way of trying to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make him realize that the matter is not a thing of complete unconcern;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is one way of arousing "interest," or bringing about a sense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection. In the long run, its value is measured by whether it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplies a mere physical excitation to act in the way desired by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adult or whether it leads the child "to think"--that is, to reflect upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his acts and impregnate them with aims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) That interest is requisite for executive persistence is even more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obvious. Employers do not advertise for workmen who are not interested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in what they are doing. If one were engaging a lawyer or a doctor, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would never occur to one to reason that the person engaged would stick
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to his work more conscientiously if it was so uncongenial to him that he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: did it merely from a sense of obligation. Interest measures--or rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is--the depth of the grip which the foreseen end has upon one, moving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one to act for its realization.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Importance of the Idea of Interest in Education. Interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represents the moving force of objects--whether perceived or presented
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in imagination--in any experience having a purpose. In the concrete,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the value of recognizing the dynamic place of interest in an educative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development is that it leads to considering individual children in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specific capabilities, needs, and preferences. One who recognizes the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: importance of interest will not assume that all minds work in the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way because they happen to have the same teacher and textbook. Attitudes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and methods of approach and response vary with the specific appeal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same material makes, this appeal itself varying with difference of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural aptitude, of past experience, of plan of life, and so on. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the facts of interest also supply considerations of general value to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy of education. Rightly understood, they put us on our guard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: against certain conceptions of mind and of subject matter which have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had great vogue in philosophic thought in the past, and which exercise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a serious hampering influence upon the conduct of instruction and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline. Too frequently mind is set over the world of things and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts to be known; it is regarded as something existing in isolation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with mental states and operations that exist independently. Knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then regarded as an external application of purely mental existences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the things to be known, or else as a result of the impressions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this outside subject matter makes on mind, or as a combination of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: two. Subject matter is then regarded as something complete in itself;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is just something to be learned or known, either by the voluntary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: application of mind to it or through the impressions it makes on mind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The facts of interest show that these conceptions are mythical. Mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appears in experience as ability to respond to present stimuli on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: basis of anticipation of future possible consequences, and with a view
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to controlling the kind of consequences that are to take place. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things, the subject matter known, consist of whatever is recognized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as having a bearing upon the anticipated course of events, whether
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assisting or retarding it. These statements are too formal to be very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligible. An illustration may clear up their significance. You are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engaged in a certain occupation, say writing with a typewriter. If you
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are an expert, your formed habits take care of the physical movements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and leave your thoughts free to consider your topic. Suppose, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: you are not skilled, or that, even if you are, the machine does not work
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: well. You then have to use intelligence. You do not wish to strike the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: keys at random and let the consequences be what they may; you wish to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: record certain words in a given order so as to make sense. You attend to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the keys, to what you have written, to your movements, to the ribbon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or the mechanism of the machine. Your attention is not distributed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indifferently and miscellaneously to any and every detail. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: centered upon whatever has a bearing upon the effective pursuit of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: your occupation. Your look is ahead, and you are concerned to note
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the existing facts because and in so far as they are factors in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achievement of the result intended. You have to find out what your
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources are, what conditions are at command, and what the difficulties
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and obstacles are. This foresight and this survey with reference to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is foreseen constitute mind. Action that does not involve such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forecast of results and such an examination of means and hindrances
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is either a matter of habit or else it is blind. In neither case is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it intelligent. To be vague and uncertain as to what is intended and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: careless in observation of conditions of its realization is to be, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that degree, stupid or partially intelligent.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If we recur to the case where mind is not concerned with the physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manipulation of the instruments but with what one intends to write, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: case is the same. There is an activity in process; one is taken up with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the development of a theme. Unless one writes as a phonograph talks,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this means intelligence; namely, alertness in foreseeing the various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusions to which present data and considerations are tending,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: together with continually renewed observation and recollection to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: get hold of the subject matter which bears upon the conclusions to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reached. The whole attitude is one of concern with what is to be, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with what is so far as the latter enters into the movement toward the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end. Leave out the direction which depends upon foresight of possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future results, and there is no intelligence in present behavior. Let
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there be imaginative forecast but no attention to the conditions upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which its attainment depends, and there is self-deception or idle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dreaming--abortive intelligence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If this illustration is typical, mind is not a name for something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complete by itself; it is a name for a course of action in so far as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that is intelligently directed; in so far, that is to say, as aims,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ends, enter into it, with selection of means to further the attainment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of aims. Intelligence is not a peculiar possession which a person owns;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but a person is intelligent in so far as the activities in which he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: plays a part have the qualities mentioned. Nor are the activities

text: from the notion that mind and mental states are something complete in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves, which then happen to be applied to some ready-made objects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and topics so that knowledge results. It shows that mind and intelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or purposeful engagement in a course of action into which things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enter are identical. Hence to develop and train mind is to provide an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment which induces such activity. On the other side, it protects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: us from the notion that subject matter on its side is something isolated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and independent. It shows that subject matter of learning is identical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with all the objects, ideas, and principles which enter as resources or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obstacles into the continuous intentional pursuit of a course of action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The developing course of action, whose end and conditions are perceived,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the unity which holds together what are often divided into an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: independent mind on one side and an independent world of objects and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts on the other.

text: Chapter Eleven: Experience and Thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Nature of Experience. The nature of experience can be understood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only by noting that it includes an active and a passive element
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: peculiarly combined. On the active hand, experience is trying--a meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is made explicit in the connected term experiment. On the passive,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is undergoing. When we experience something we act upon it, we do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something with it; then we suffer or undergo the consequences. We do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something to the thing and then it does something to us in return:
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such is the peculiar combination. The connection of these two phases of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience measures the fruitfulness or value of the experience. Mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity does not constitute experience. It is dispersive, centrifugal,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dissipating. Experience as trying involves change, but change is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaningless transition unless it is consciously connected with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: return wave of consequences which flow from it. When an activity is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continued into the undergoing of consequences, when the change made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by action is reflected back into a change made in us, the mere flux is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: loaded with significance. We learn something. It is not experience when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a child merely sticks his finger into a flame; it is experience when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movement is connected with the pain which he undergoes in consequence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Henceforth the sticking of the finger into flame means a burn. Being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: burned is a mere physical change, like the burning of a stick of wood,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if it is not perceived as a consequence of some other action. Blind and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capricious impulses hurry us on heedlessly from one thing to another. So
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: far as this happens, everything is writ in water. There is none of that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cumulative growth which makes an experience in any vital sense of that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: term. On the other hand, many things happen to us in the way of pleasure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and pain which we do not connect with any prior activity of our own.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They are mere accidents so far as we are concerned. There is no before
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or after to such experience; no retrospect nor outlook, and consequently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no meaning. We get nothing which may be carried over to foresee what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is likely to happen next, and no gain in ability to adjust ourselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what is coming--no added control. Only by courtesy can such an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience be called experience. To "learn from experience" is to make a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: backward and forward connection between what we do to things and what we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enjoy or suffer from things in consequence. Under such conditions, doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: becomes a trying; an experiment with the world to find out what it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like; the undergoing becomes instruction--discovery of the connection of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Two conclusions important for education follow. (1) Experience is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: primarily an active-passive affair; it is not primarily cognitive. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (2) the measure of the value of an experience lies in the perception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of relationships or continuities to which it leads up. It includes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cognition in the degree in which it is cumulative or amounts to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something, or has meaning. In schools, those under instruction are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: too customarily looked upon as acquiring knowledge as theoretical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spectators, minds which appropriate knowledge by direct energy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellect. The very word pupil has almost come to mean one who is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engaged not in having fruitful experiences but in absorbing knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directly. Something which is called mind or consciousness is severed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the physical organs of activity. The former is then thought to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purely intellectual and cognitive; the latter to be an irrelevant and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intruding physical factor. The intimate union of activity and undergoing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its consequences which leads to recognition of meaning is broken;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instead we have two fragments: mere bodily action on one side, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning directly grasped by "spiritual" activity on the other.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It would be impossible to state adequately the evil results which have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flowed from this dualism of mind and body, much less to exaggerate them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Some of the more striking effects, may, however, be enumerated. (a)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In part bodily activity becomes an intruder. Having nothing, so it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought, to do with mental activity, it becomes a distraction, an evil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be contended with. For the pupil has a body, and brings it to school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: along with his mind. And the body is, of necessity, a wellspring of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energy; it has to do something. But its activities, not being utilized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in occupation with things which yield significant results, have to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: frowned upon. They lead the pupil away from the lesson with which his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "mind" ought to be occupied; they are sources of mischief. The chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: source of the "problem of discipline" in schools is that the teacher
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has often to spend the larger part of the time in suppressing the bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities which take the mind away from its material. A premium is put
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on physical quietude; on silence, on rigid uniformity of posture and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movement; upon a machine-like simulation of the attitudes of intelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest. The teachers' business is to hold the pupils up to these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements and to punish the inevitable deviations which occur.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The nervous strain and fatigue which result with both teacher and pupil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are a necessary consequence of the abnormality of the situation in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bodily activity is divorced from the perception of meaning. Callous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indifference and explosions from strain alternate. The neglected body,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having no organized fruitful channels of activity, breaks forth, without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowing why or how, into meaningless boisterousness, or settles into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equally meaningless fooling--both very different from the normal play
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of children. Physically active children become restless and unruly; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more quiescent, so-called conscientious ones spend what energy they have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the negative task of keeping their instincts and active tendencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suppressed, instead of in a positive one of constructive planning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and execution; they are thus educated not into responsibility for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significant and graceful use of bodily powers, but into an enforced duty
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not to give them free play. It may be seriously asserted that a chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cause for the remarkable achievements of Greek education was that it was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: never misled by false notions into an attempted separation of mind and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: body.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (b) Even, however, with respect to the lessons which have to be learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the application of "mind," some bodily activities have to be used.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The senses--especially the eye and ear--have to be employed to take in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what the book, the map, the blackboard, and the teacher say. The lips
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vocal organs, and the hands, have to be used to reproduce in speech
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and writing what has been stowed away. The senses are then regarded as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a kind of mysterious conduit through which information is conducted from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the external world into the mind; they are spoken of as gateways and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: avenues of knowledge. To keep the eyes on the book and the ears open
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the teacher's words is a mysterious source of intellectual grace.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Moreover, reading, writing, and figuring--important school arts--demand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: muscular or motor training. The muscles of eye, hand, and vocal organs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accordingly have to be trained to act as pipes for carrying knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: back out of the mind into external action. For it happens that using the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: muscles repeatedly in the same way fixes in them an automatic tendency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to repeat.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The obvious result is a mechanical use of the bodily activities which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (in spite of the generally obtrusive and interfering character of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: body in mental action) have to be employed more or less. For the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: senses and muscles are used not as organic participants in having an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instructive experience, but as external inlets and outlets of mind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Before the child goes to school, he learns with his hand, eye, and ear,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because they are organs of the process of doing something from which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning results. The boy flying a kite has to keep his eye on the kite,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and has to note the various pressures of the string on his hand. His
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: senses are avenues of knowledge not because external facts are somehow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "conveyed" to the brain, but because they are used in doing something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a purpose. The qualities of seen and touched things have a bearing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on what is done, and are alertly perceived; they have a meaning. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when pupils are expected to use their eyes to note the form of words,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irrespective of their meaning, in order to reproduce them in spelling or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reading, the resulting training is simply of isolated sense organs and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: muscles. It is such isolation of an act from a purpose which makes it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mechanical. It is customary for teachers to urge children to read with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expression, so as to bring out the meaning. But if they originally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learned the sensory-motor technique of reading--the ability to identify
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forms and to reproduce the sounds they stand for--by methods which did
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not call for attention to meaning, a mechanical habit was established
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which makes it difficult to read subsequently with intelligence. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocal organs have been trained to go their own way automatically in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolation; and meaning cannot be tied on at will. Drawing, singing, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: writing may be taught in the same mechanical way; for, we repeat, any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way is mechanical which narrows down the bodily activity so that a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation of body from mind--that is, from recognition of meaning--is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set up. Mathematics, even in its higher branches, when undue emphasis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is put upon the technique of calculation, and science, when laboratory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exercises are given for their own sake, suffer from the same evil.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (c) On the intellectual side, the separation of "mind" from direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupation with things throws emphasis on things at the expense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relations or connections. It is altogether too common to separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceptions and even ideas from judgments. The latter are thought to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: come after the former in order to compare them. It is alleged that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind perceives things apart from relations; that it forms ideas of them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in isolation from their connections--with what goes before and comes
