title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: after. Then judgment or thought is called upon to combine the separated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: items of "knowledge" so that their resemblance or causal connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shall be brought out. As matter of fact, every perception and every idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is a sense of the bearings, use, and cause, of a thing. We do not really
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: know a chair or have an idea of it by inventorying and enumerating its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: various isolated qualities, but only by bringing these qualities into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with something else--the purpose which makes it a chair and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not a table; or its difference from the kind of chair we are accustomed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to, or the "period" which it represents, and so on. A wagon is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceived when all its parts are summed up; it is the characteristic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection of the parts which makes it a wagon. And these connections
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are not those of mere physical juxtaposition; they involve connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the animals that draw it, the things that are carried on it, and so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on. Judgment is employed in the perception; otherwise the perception is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere sensory excitation or else a recognition of the result of a prior
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judgment, as in the case of familiar objects.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Words, the counters for ideals, are, however, easily taken for ideas.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And in just the degree in which mental activity is separated from active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concern with the world, from doing something and connecting the doing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with what is undergone, words, symbols, come to take the place of ideas.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The substitution is the more subtle because some meaning is recognized.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But we are very easily trained to be content with a minimum of meaning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and to fail to note how restricted is our perception of the relations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which confer significance. We get so thoroughly used to a kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pseudo-idea, a half perception, that we are not aware how half-dead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our mental action is, and how much keener and more extensive our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observations and ideas would be if we formed them under conditions of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a vital experience which required us to use judgment: to hunt for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections of the thing dealt with. There is no difference of opinion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to the theory of the matter. All authorities agree that that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discernment of relationships is the genuinely intellectual matter;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hence, the educative matter. The failure arises in supposing that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relationships can become perceptible without experience--without that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conjoint trying and undergoing of which we have spoken. It is assumed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that "mind" can grasp them if it will only give attention, and that this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention may be given at will irrespective of the situation. Hence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the deluge of half-observations, of verbal ideas, and unassimilated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "knowledge" which afflicts the world. An ounce of experience is better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than a ton of theory simply because it is only in experience that any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory has vital and verifiable significance. An experience, a very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humble experience, is capable of generating and carrying any amount of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory (or intellectual content), but a theory apart from an experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot be definitely grasped even as theory. It tends to become a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: verbal formula, a set of catchwords used to render thinking, or genuine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theorizing, unnecessary and impossible. Because of our education we use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: words, thinking they are ideas, to dispose of questions, the disposal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being in reality simply such an obscuring of perception as prevents us
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from seeing any longer the difficulty.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Reflection in Experience. Thought or reflection, as we have already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seen virtually if not explicitly, is the discernment of the relation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between what we try to do and what happens in consequence. No experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having a meaning is possible without some element of thought. But we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may contrast two types of experience according to the proportion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflection found in them. All our experiences have a phase of "cut and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: try" in them--what psychologists call the method of trial and error. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply do something, and when it fails, we do something else, and keep
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on trying till we hit upon something which works, and then we adopt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that method as a rule of thumb measure in subsequent procedure. Some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences have very little else in them than this hit and miss or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: succeed process. We see that a certain way of acting and a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequence are connected, but we do not see how they are. We do not see
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the details of the connection; the links are missing. Our discernment is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: very gross. In other cases we push our observation farther. We analyze
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to see just what lies between so as to bind together cause and effect,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity and consequence. This extension of our insight makes foresight
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more accurate and comprehensive. The action which rests simply upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trial and error method is at the mercy of circumstances; they may change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so that the act performed does not operate in the way it was expected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to. But if we know in detail upon what the result depends, we can look
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to see whether the required conditions are there. The method extends our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practical control. For if some of the conditions are missing, we may,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if we know what the needed antecedents for an effect are, set to work to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supply them; or, if they are such as to produce undesirable effects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as well, we may eliminate some of the superfluous causes and economize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effort.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In discovery of the detailed connections of our activities and what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happens in consequence, the thought implied in cut and try experience is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made explicit. Its quantity increases so that its proportionate value is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: very different. Hence the quality of the experience changes; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: change is so significant that we may call this type of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflective--that is, reflective par excellence. The deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultivation of this phase of thought constitutes thinking as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distinctive experience. Thinking, in other words, is the intentional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: endeavor to discover specific connections between something which we do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the consequences which result, so that the two become continuous.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Their isolation, and consequently their purely arbitrary going together,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is canceled; a unified developing situation takes its place. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occurrence is now understood; it is explained; it is reasonable, as we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: say, that the thing should happen as it does.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Thinking is thus equivalent to an explicit rendering of the intelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: element in our experience. It makes it possible to act with an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in view. It is the condition of our having aims. As soon as an infant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: begins to expect he begins to use something which is now going on as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a sign of something to follow; he is, in however simple a fashion,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judging. For he takes one thing as evidence of something else, and so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognizes a relationship. Any future development, however elaborate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it may be, is only an extending and a refining of this simple act of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inference. All that the wisest man can do is to observe what is going on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more widely and more minutely and then select more carefully from what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is noted just those factors which point to something to happen. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opposites, once more, to thoughtful action are routine and capricious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: behavior. The former accepts what has been customary as a full measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of possibility and omits to take into account the connections of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particular things done. The latter makes the momentary act a measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of value, and ignores the connections of our personal action with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energies of the environment. It says, virtually, "things are to be just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as I happen to like them at this instant," as routine says in effect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "let things continue just as I have found them in the past." Both refuse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to acknowledge responsibility for the future consequences which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flow from present action. Reflection is the acceptance of such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The starting point of any process of thinking is something going on,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something which just as it stands is incomplete or unfulfilled. Its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point, its meaning lies literally in what it is going to be, in how it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is going to turn out. As this is written, the world is filled with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clang of contending armies. For an active participant in the war, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clear that the momentous thing is the issue, the future consequences, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this and that happening. He is identified, for the time at least, with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the issue; his fate hangs upon the course things are taking. But even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for an onlooker in a neutral country, the significance of every move
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made, of every advance here and retreat there, lies in what it portends.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To think upon the news as it comes to us is to attempt to see what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indicated as probable or possible regarding an outcome. To fill our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heads, like a scrapbook, with this and that item as a finished and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done-for thing, is not to think. It is to turn ourselves into a piece
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of registering apparatus. To consider the bearing of the occurrence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon what may be, but is not yet, is to think. Nor will the reflective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience be different in kind if we substitute distance in time for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation in space. Imagine the war done with, and a future historian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: giving an account of it. The episode is, by assumption, past. But he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot give a thoughtful account of the war save as he preserves the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time sequence; the meaning of each occurrence, as he deals with it, lies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in what was future for it, though not for the historian. To take it by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself as a complete existence is to take it unreflectively.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Reflection also implies concern with the issue--a certain sympathetic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identification of our own destiny, if only dramatic, with the outcome of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the course of events. For the general in the war, or a common soldier,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or a citizen of one of the contending nations, the stimulus to thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is direct and urgent. For neutrals, it is indirect and dependent upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imagination. But the flagrant partisanship of human nature is evidence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the intensity of the tendency to identify ourselves with one possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course of events, and to reject the other as foreign. If we cannot take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sides in overt action, and throw in our little weight to help determine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the final balance, we take sides emotionally and imaginatively. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desire this or that outcome. One wholly indifferent to the outcome does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not follow or think about what is happening at all. From this dependence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the act of thinking upon a sense of sharing in the consequences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of what goes on, flows one of the chief paradoxes of thought. Born in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: partiality, in order to accomplish its tasks it must achieve a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: detached impartiality. The general who allows his hopes and desires to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affect his observations and interpretations of the existing situation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will surely make a mistake in calculation. While hopes and fears may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the chief motive for a thoughtful following of the war on the part of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an onlooker in a neutral country, he too will think ineffectively in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degree in which his preferences modify the stuff of his observations and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasonings. There is, however, no incompatibility between the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the occasion of reflection lies in a personal sharing in what is going
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on and the fact that the value of the reflection lies upon keeping one's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self out of the data. The almost insurmountable difficulty of achieving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this detachment is evidence that thinking originates in situations where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the course of thinking is an actual part of the course of events and is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: designed to influence the result. Only gradually and with a widening of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the area of vision through a growth of social sympathies does thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: develop to include what lies beyond our direct interests: a fact of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: great significance for education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To say that thinking occurs with reference to situations which are still
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: going on, and incomplete, is to say that thinking occurs when things are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uncertain or doubtful or problematic. Only what is finished, completed,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is wholly assured. Where there is reflection there is suspense. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: object of thinking is to help reach a conclusion, to project a possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: termination on the basis of what is already given. Certain other facts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about thinking accompany this feature. Since the situation in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking occurs is a doubtful one, thinking is a process of inquiry, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: looking into things, of investigating. Acquiring is always secondary,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and instrumental to the act of inquiring. It is seeking, a quest,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for something that is not at hand. We sometimes talk as if "original
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: research" were a peculiar prerogative of scientists or at least of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advanced students. But all thinking is research, and all research is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: native, original, with him who carries it on, even if everybody else in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the world already is sure of what he is still looking for.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It also follows that all thinking involves a risk. Certainty cannot be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: guaranteed in advance. The invasion of the unknown is of the nature of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an adventure; we cannot be sure in advance. The conclusions of thinking,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: till confirmed by the event, are, accordingly, more or less tentative or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hypothetical. Their dogmatic assertion as final is unwarranted, short of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the issue, in fact. The Greeks acutely raised the question: How can we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learn? For either we know already what we are after, or else we do not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: know. In neither case is learning possible; on the first alternative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because we know already; on the second, because we do not know what to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: look for, nor if, by chance, we find it can we tell that it is what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we were after. The dilemma makes no provision for coming to know, for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning; it assumes either complete knowledge or complete ignorance.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Nevertheless the twilight zone of inquiry, of thinking, exists. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibility of hypothetical conclusions, of tentative results, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fact which the Greek dilemma overlooked. The perplexities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation suggest certain ways out. We try these ways, and either push
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our way out, in which case we know we have found what we were looking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for, or the situation gets darker and more confused--in which case, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: know we are still ignorant. Tentative means trying out, feeling one's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: way along provisionally. Taken by itself, the Greek argument is a nice
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: piece of formal logic. But it is also true that as long as men kept a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sharp disjunction between knowledge and ignorance, science made only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: slow and accidental advance. Systematic advance in invention and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovery began when men recognized that they could utilize doubt for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposes of inquiry by forming conjectures to guide action in tentative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explorations, whose development would confirm, refute, or modify the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: guiding conjecture. While the Greeks made knowledge more than learning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modern science makes conserved knowledge only a means to learning, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovery. To recur to our illustration. A commanding general cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: base his actions upon either absolute certainty or absolute ignorance.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He has a certain amount of information at hand which is, we will assume,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasonably trustworthy. He then infers certain prospective movements,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thus assigning meaning to the bare facts of the given situation. His
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inference is more or less dubious and hypothetical. But he acts upon it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He develops a plan of procedure, a method of dealing with the situation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The consequences which directly follow from his acting this way rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than that test and reveal the worth of his reflections. What he already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knows functions and has value in what he learns. But will this account
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apply in the case of the one in a neutral country who is thoughtfully
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following as best he can the progress of events? In form, yes, though
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not of course in content. It is self-evident that his guesses about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the future indicated by present facts, guesses by which he attempts to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supply meaning to a multitude of disconnected data, cannot be the basis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a method which shall take effect in the campaign. That is not his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problem. But in the degree in which he is actively thinking, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not merely passively following the course of events, his tentative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inferences will take effect in a method of procedure appropriate to his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation. He will anticipate certain future moves, and will be on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alert to see whether they happen or not. In the degree in which he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectually concerned, or thoughtful, he will be actively on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lookout; he will take steps which although they do not affect the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: campaign, modify in some degree his subsequent actions. Otherwise his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later "I told you so" has no intellectual quality at all; it does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not mark any testing or verification of prior thinking, but only a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coincidence that yields emotional satisfaction--and includes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: large factor of self-deception. The case is comparable to that of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: astronomer who from given data has been led to foresee (infer) a future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eclipse. No matter how great the mathematical probability, the inference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is hypothetical--a matter of probability. 1 The hypothesis as to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: date and position of the anticipated eclipse becomes the material of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forming a method of future conduct. Apparatus is arranged; possibly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an expedition is made to some far part of the globe. In any case, some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active steps are taken which actually change some physical conditions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And apart from such steps and the consequent modification of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation, there is no completion of the act of thinking. It remains
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suspended. Knowledge, already attained knowledge, controls thinking and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes it fruitful.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So much for the general features of a reflective experience. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (i) perplexity, confusion, doubt, due to the fact that one is implicated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in an incomplete situation whose full character is not yet determined;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) a conjectural anticipation--a tentative interpretation of the given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elements, attributing to them a tendency to effect certain consequences;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iii) a careful survey (examination, inspection, exploration, analysis)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of all attainable consideration which will define and clarify the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problem in hand; (iv) a consequent elaboration of the tentative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hypothesis to make it more precise and more consistent, because squaring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a wider range of facts; (v) taking one stand upon the projected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hypothesis as a plan of action which is applied to the existing state of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affairs: doing something overtly to bring about the anticipated result,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thereby testing the hypothesis. It is the extent and accuracy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: steps three and four which mark off a distinctive reflective experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from one on the trial and error plane. They make thinking itself into an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. Nevertheless, we never get wholly beyond the trial and error
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation. Our most elaborate and rationally consistent thought has to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be tried in the world and thereby tried out. And since it can never
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take into account all the connections, it can never cover with perfect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accuracy all the consequences. Yet a thoughtful survey of conditions is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so careful, and the guessing at results so controlled, that we have a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: right to mark off the reflective experience from the grosser trial and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: error forms of action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. In determining the place of thinking in experience we first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noted that experience involves a connection of doing or trying with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something which is undergone in consequence. A separation of the active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing phase from the passive undergoing phase destroys the vital meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of an experience. Thinking is the accurate and deliberate instituting of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections between what is done and its consequences. It notes not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they are connected, but the details of the connection. It makes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connecting links explicit in the form of relationships. The stimulus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to thinking is found when we wish to determine the significance of some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: act, performed or to be performed. Then we anticipate consequences. This
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implies that the situation as it stands is, either in fact or to us,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: incomplete and hence indeterminate. The projection of consequences means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a proposed or tentative solution. To perfect this hypothesis, existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions have to be carefully scrutinized and the implications of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hypothesis developed--an operation called reasoning. Then the suggested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: solution--the idea or theory--has to be tested by acting upon it. If it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brings about certain consequences, certain determinate changes, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world, it is accepted as valid. Otherwise it is modified, and another
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trial made. Thinking includes all of these steps,--the sense of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problem, the observation of conditions, the formation and rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elaboration of a suggested conclusion, and the active experimental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: testing. While all thinking results in knowledge, ultimately the value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowledge is subordinate to its use in thinking. For we live not in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: settled and finished world, but in one which is going on, and where our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: main task is prospective, and where retrospect--and all knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as distinct from thought is retrospect--is of value in the solidity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: security, and fertility it affords our dealings with the future.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1 It is most important for the practice of science that men in many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cases can calculate the degree of probability and the amount of probable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: error involved, but that does alter the features of the situation as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: described. It refines them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Twelve: Thinking in Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Essentials of Method. No one doubts, theoretically, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: importance of fostering in school good habits of thinking. But apart
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the fact that the acknowledgment is not so great in practice as in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory, there is not adequate theoretical recognition that all which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school can or need do for pupils, so far as their minds are concerned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (that is, leaving out certain specialized muscular abilities), is to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: develop their ability to think. The parceling out of instruction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: among various ends such as acquisition of skill (in reading, spelling,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: writing, drawing, reciting); acquiring information (in history and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: geography), and training of thinking is a measure of the ineffective way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which we accomplish all three. Thinking which is not connected with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increase of efficiency in action, and with learning more about ourselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the world in which we live, has something the matter with it just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as thought (See ante, p. 147). And skill obtained apart from thinking is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not connected with any sense of the purposes for which it is to be used.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It consequently leaves a man at the mercy of his routine habits and of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the authoritative control of others, who know what they are about and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who are not especially scrupulous as to their means of achievement.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And information severed from thoughtful action is dead, a mind-crushing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: load. Since it simulates knowledge and thereby develops the poison of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceit, it is a most powerful obstacle to further growth in the grace
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of intelligence. The sole direct path to enduring improvement in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods of instruction and learning consists in centering upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions which exact, promote, and test thinking. Thinking is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method of intelligent learning, of learning that employs and rewards
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind. We speak, legitimately enough, about the method of thinking, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the important thing to bear in mind about method is that thinking is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method, the method of intelligent experience in the course which it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: takes.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: I. The initial stage of that developing experience which is called
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking is experience. This remark may sound like a silly truism. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ought to be one; but unfortunately it is not. On the contrary, thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is often regarded both in philosophic theory and in educational practice
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as something cut off from experience, and capable of being cultivated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in isolation. In fact, the inherent limitations of experience are often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: urged as the sufficient ground for attention to thinking. Experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is then thought to be confined to the senses and appetites; to a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material world, while thinking proceeds from a higher faculty (of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason), and is occupied with spiritual or at least literary things. So,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: oftentimes, a sharp distinction is made between pure mathematics as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: peculiarly fit subject matter of thought (since it has nothing to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with physical existences) and applied mathematics, which has utilitarian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but not mental value.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Speaking generally, the fundamental fallacy in methods of instruction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lies in supposing that experience on the part of pupils may be assumed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What is here insisted upon is the necessity of an actual empirical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation as the initiating phase of thought. Experience is here taken
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as previously defined: trying to do something and having the thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceptibly do something to one in return. The fallacy consists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in supposing that we can begin with ready-made subject matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arithmetic, or geography, or whatever, irrespective of some direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal experience of a situation. Even the kindergarten and Montessori
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: techniques are so anxious to get at intellectual distinctions, without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "waste of time," that they tend to ignore--or reduce--the immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: crude handling of the familiar material of experience, and to introduce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pupils at once to material which expresses the intellectual distinctions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which adults have made. But the first stage of contact with any new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material, at whatever age of maturity, must inevitably be of the trial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and error sort. An individual must actually try, in play or work, to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something with material in carrying out his own impulsive activity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and then note the interaction of his energy and that of the material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed. This is what happens when a child at first begins to build
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with blocks, and it is equally what happens when a scientific man in his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: laboratory begins to experiment with unfamiliar objects.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence the first approach to any subject in school, if thought is to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aroused and not words acquired, should be as unscholastic as possible.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To realize what an experience, or empirical situation, means, we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to call to mind the sort of situation that presents itself outside of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school; the sort of occupations that interest and engage activity in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ordinary life. And careful inspection of methods which are permanently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successful in formal education, whether in arithmetic or learning to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: read, or studying geography, or learning physics or a foreign language,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will reveal that they depend for their efficiency upon the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they go back to the type of the situation which causes reflection out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of school in ordinary life. They give the pupils something to do, not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something to learn; and the doing is of such a nature as to demand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking, or the intentional noting of connections; learning naturally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: That the situation should be of such a nature as to arouse thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means of course that it should suggest something to do which is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: either routine or capricious--something, in other words, presenting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is new (and hence uncertain or problematic) and yet sufficiently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connected with existing habits to call out an effective response. An
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effective response means one which accomplishes a perceptible result,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in distinction from a purely haphazard activity, where the consequences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot be mentally connected with what is done. The most significant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: question which can be asked, accordingly, about any situation or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience proposed to induce learning is what quality of problem it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At first thought, it might seem as if usual school methods measured
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: well up to the standard here set. The giving of problems, the putting of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questions, the assigning of tasks, the magnifying of difficulties, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a large part of school work. But it is indispensable to discriminate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between genuine and simulated or mock problems. The following questions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may aid in making such discrimination. (a) Is there anything but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a problem? Does the question naturally suggest itself within some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation or personal experience? Or is it an aloof thing, a problem
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only for the purposes of conveying instruction in some school topic?
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Is it the sort of trying that would arouse observation and engage
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimentation outside of school? (b) Is it the pupil's own problem, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is it the teacher's or textbook's problem, made a problem for the pupil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only because he cannot get the required mark or be promoted or win
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the teacher's approval, unless he deals with it? Obviously, these two
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questions overlap. They are two ways of getting at the same point:
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Is the experience a personal thing of such a nature as inherently to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulate and direct observation of the connections involved, and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lead to inference and its testing? Or is it imposed from without, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the pupil's problem simply to meet the external requirement? Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: questions may give us pause in deciding upon the extent to which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: current practices are adapted to develop reflective habits. The physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equipment and arrangements of the average schoolroom are hostile to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence of real situations of experience. What is there similar to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the conditions of everyday life which will generate difficulties? Almost
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everything testifies to the great premium put upon listening, reading,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the reproduction of what is told and read. It is hardly possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to overstate the contrast between such conditions and the situations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active contact with things and persons in the home, on the playground,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in fulfilling of ordinary responsibilities of life. Much of it is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: even comparable with the questions which may arise in the mind of a boy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or girl in conversing with others or in reading books outside of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school. No one has ever explained why children are so full of questions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outside of the school (so that they pester grown-up persons if they get
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any encouragement), and the conspicuous absence of display of curiosity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the subject matter of school lessons. Reflection on this striking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contrast will throw light upon the question of how far customary school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions supply a context of experience in which problems naturally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggest themselves. No amount of improvement in the personal technique
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the instructor will wholly remedy this state of things. There must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be more actual material, more stuff, more appliances, and more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities for doing things, before the gap can be overcome. And
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where children are engaged in doing things and in discussing what arises
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the course of their doing, it is found, even with comparatively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indifferent modes of instruction, that children's inquiries are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spontaneous and numerous, and the proposals of solution advanced,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied, and ingenious.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As a consequence of the absence of the materials and occupations which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generate real problems, the pupil's problems are not his; or, rather,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are his only as a pupil, not as a human being. Hence the lamentable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: waste in carrying over such expertness as is achieved in dealing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with them to the affairs of life beyond the schoolroom. A pupil has a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problem, but it is the problem of meeting the peculiar requirements set
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the teacher. His problem becomes that of finding out what the teacher
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wants, what will satisfy the teacher in recitation and examination and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outward deportment. Relationship to subject matter is no longer direct.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
