text: The occasions and material of thought are not found in the arithmetic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or the history or geography itself, but in skillfully adapting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that material to the teacher's requirements. The pupil studies, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unconsciously to himself the objects of his study are the conventions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and standards of the school system and school authority, not the nominal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "studies." The thinking thus evoked is artificially one-sided at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: best. At its worst, the problem of the pupil is not how to meet the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements of school life, but how to seem to meet them--or, how to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: come near enough to meeting them to slide along without an undue amount
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of friction. The type of judgment formed by these devices is not a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desirable addition to character. If these statements give too highly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: colored a picture of usual school methods, the exaggeration may at least
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: serve to illustrate the point: the need of active pursuits, involving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the use of material to accomplish purposes, if there are to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations which normally generate problems occasioning thoughtful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inquiry.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: II. There must be data at command to supply the considerations required
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in dealing with the specific difficulty which has presented itself.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Teachers following a "developing" method sometimes tell children to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: think things out for themselves as if they could spin them out of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own heads. The material of thinking is not thoughts, but actions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts, events, and the relations of things. In other words, to think
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effectively one must have had, or now have, experiences which will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: furnish him resources for coping with the difficulty at hand. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulty is an indispensable stimulus to thinking, but not all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulties call out thinking. Sometimes they overwhelm and submerge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and discourage. The perplexing situation must be sufficiently like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations which have already been dealt with so that pupils will have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some control of the meanings of handling it. A large part of the art of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction lies in making the difficulty of new problems large enough
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to challenge thought, and small enough so that, in addition to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confusion naturally attending the novel elements, there shall be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: luminous familiar spots from which helpful suggestions may spring.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In one sense, it is a matter of indifference by what psychological means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the subject matter for reflection is provided. Memory, observation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reading, communication, are all avenues for supplying data. The relative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proportion to be obtained from each is a matter of the specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: features of the particular problem in hand. It is foolish to insist
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon observation of objects presented to the senses if the student is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so familiar with the objects that he could just as well recall the facts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: independently. It is possible to induce undue and crippling dependence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon sense-presentations. No one can carry around with him a museum of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all the things whose properties will assist the conduct of thought. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: well-trained mind is one that has a maximum of resources behind it, so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to speak, and that is accustomed to go over its past experiences to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: see what they yield. On the other hand, a quality or relation of even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a familiar object may previously have been passed over, and be just the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that is helpful in dealing with the question. In this case direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation is called for. The same principle applies to the use to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be made of observation on one hand and of reading and "telling" on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other. Direct observation is naturally more vivid and vital. But it has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its limitations; and in any case it is a necessary part of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that one should acquire the ability to supplement the narrowness of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately personal experiences by utilizing the experiences of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Excessive reliance upon others for data (whether got from reading
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or listening) is to be depreciated. Most objectionable of all is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: probability that others, the book or the teacher, will supply solutions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ready-made, instead of giving material that the student has to adapt and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apply to the question in hand for himself.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is no inconsistency in saying that in schools there is usually
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: both too much and too little information supplied by others. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accumulation and acquisition of information for purposes of reproduction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in recitation and examination is made too much of. "Knowledge," in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the sense of information, means the working capital, the indispensable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources, of further inquiry; of finding out, or learning, more things.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Frequently it is treated as an end itself, and then the goal becomes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to heap it up and display it when called for. This static, cold-storage
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideal of knowledge is inimical to educative development. It not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lets occasions for thinking go unused, but it swamps thinking. No one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: could construct a house on ground cluttered with miscellaneous junk.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Pupils who have stored their "minds" with all kinds of material which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have never put to intellectual uses are sure to be hampered
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when they try to think. They have no practice in selecting what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appropriate, and no criterion to go by; everything is on the same dead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: static level. On the other hand, it is quite open to question whether,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if information actually functioned in experience through use in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: application to the student's own purposes, there would not be need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more varied resources in books, pictures, and talks than are usually at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: command.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: III. The correlate in thinking of facts, data, knowledge already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquired, is suggestions, inferences, conjectured meanings,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suppositions, tentative explanations:--ideas, in short. Careful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation and recollection determine what is given, what is already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there, and hence assured. They cannot furnish what is lacking. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: define, clarify, and locate the question; they cannot supply its answer.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Projection, invention, ingenuity, devising come in for that purpose. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: data arouse suggestions, and only by reference to the specific data can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we pass upon the appropriateness of the suggestions. But the suggestions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: run beyond what is, as yet, actually given in experience. They forecast
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible results, things to do, not facts (things already done).
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Inference is always an invasion of the unknown, a leap from the known.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In this sense, a thought (what a thing suggests but is not as it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presented) is creative,--an incursion into the novel. It involves some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inventiveness. What is suggested must, indeed, be familiar in some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: context; the novelty, the inventive devising, clings to the new light
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which it is seen, the different use to which it is put. When Newton
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought of his theory of gravitation, the creative aspect of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought was not found in its materials. They were familiar; many of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them commonplaces--sun, moon, planets, weight, distance, mass, square of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: numbers. These were not original ideas; they were established facts. His
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: originality lay in the use to which these familiar acquaintances were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: put by introduction into an unfamiliar context. The same is true of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: every striking scientific discovery, every great invention, every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: admirable artistic production. Only silly folk identify creative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: originality with the extraordinary and fanciful; others recognize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that its measure lies in putting everyday things to uses which had not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occurred to others. The operation is novel, not the materials out of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which it is constructed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The educational conclusion which follows is that all thinking is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: original in a projection of considerations which have not been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: previously apprehended. The child of three who discovers what can be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done with blocks, or of six who finds out what he can make by putting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: five cents and five cents together, is really a discoverer, even though
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everybody else in the world knows it. There is a genuine increment of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience; not another item mechanically added on, but enrichment by a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new quality. The charm which the spontaneity of little children has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for sympathetic observers is due to perception of this intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: originality. The joy which children themselves experience is the joy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual constructiveness--of creativeness, if the word may be used
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without misunderstanding. The educational moral I am chiefly concerned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to draw is not, however, that teachers would find their own work less of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a grind and strain if school conditions favored learning in the sense
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of discovery and not in that of storing away what others pour into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them; nor that it would be possible to give even children and youth the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: delights of personal intellectual productiveness--true and important
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as are these things. It is that no thought, no idea, can possibly be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conveyed as an idea from one person to another. When it is told, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, to the one to whom it is told, another given fact, not an idea. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communication may stimulate the other person to realize the question for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself and to think out a like idea, or it may smother his intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest and suppress his dawning effort at thought. But what he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directly gets cannot be an idea. Only by wrestling with the conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the problem at first hand, seeking and finding his own way out, does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he think. When the parent or teacher has provided the conditions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulate thinking and has taken a sympathetic attitude toward the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities of the learner by entering into a common or conjoint
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, all has been done which a second party can do to instigate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning. The rest lies with the one directly concerned. If he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot devise his own solution (not of course in isolation, but in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: correspondence with the teacher and other pupils) and find his own way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out he will not learn, not even if he can recite some correct answer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with one hundred per cent accuracy. We can and do supply ready-made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "ideas" by the thousand; we do not usually take much pains to see
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the one learning engages in significant situations where his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities generate, support, and clinch ideas--that is, perceived
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meanings or connections. This does not mean that the teacher is to stand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: off and look on; the alternative to furnishing ready-made subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter and listening to the accuracy with which it is reproduced is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quiescence, but participation, sharing, in an activity. In such shared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity, the teacher is a learner, and the learner is, without knowing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it, a teacher--and upon the whole, the less consciousness there is, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: either side, of either giving or receiving instruction, the better.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: IV. Ideas, as we have seen, whether they be humble guesses or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dignified theories, are anticipations of possible solutions. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anticipations of some continuity or connection of an activity and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequence which has not as yet shown itself. They are therefore tested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the operation of acting upon them. They are to guide and organize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: further observations, recollections, and experiments. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intermediate in learning, not final. All educational reformers, as we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have had occasion to remark, are given to attacking the passivity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: traditional education. They have opposed pouring in from without, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absorbing like a sponge; they have attacked drilling in material as into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hard and resisting rock. But it is not easy to secure conditions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will make the getting of an idea identical with having an experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which widens and makes more precise our contact with the environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Activity, even self-activity, is too easily thought of as something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely mental, cooped up within the head, or finding expression only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through the vocal organs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While the need of application of ideas gained in study is acknowledged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by all the more successful methods of instruction, the exercises in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: application are sometimes treated as devices for fixing what has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already been learned and for getting greater practical skill in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manipulation. These results are genuine and not to be despised. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practice in applying what has been gained in study ought primarily to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have an intellectual quality. As we have already seen, thoughts just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as thoughts are incomplete. At best they are tentative; they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggestions, indications. They are standpoints and methods for dealing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with situations of experience. Till they are applied in these situations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they lack full point and reality. Only application tests them, and only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: testing confers full meaning and a sense of their reality. Short of use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made of them, they tend to segregate into a peculiar world of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own. It may be seriously questioned whether the philosophies (to which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reference has been made in section 2 of chapter X) which isolate mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and set it over against the world did not have their origin in the fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the reflective or theoretical class of men elaborated a large stock
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of ideas which social conditions did not allow them to act upon and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: test. Consequently men were thrown back into their own thoughts as ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in themselves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: However this may be, there can be no doubt that a peculiar artificiality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attaches to much of what is learned in schools. It can hardly be said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that many students consciously think of the subject matter as unreal;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but it assuredly does not possess for them the kind of reality which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of their vital experiences possesses. They learn not to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expect that sort of reality of it; they become habituated to treating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it as having reality for the purposes of recitations, lessons, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: examinations. That it should remain inert for the experiences of daily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life is more or less a matter of course. The bad effects are twofold.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Ordinary experience does not receive the enrichment which it should;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is not fertilized by school learning. And the attitudes which spring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from getting used to and accepting half-understood and ill-digested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material weaken vigor and efficiency of thought.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If we have dwelt especially on the negative side, it is for the sake
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of suggesting positive measures adapted to the effectual development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of thought. Where schools are equipped with laboratories, shops,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and gardens, where dramatizations, plays, and games are freely used,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities exist for reproducing situations of life, and for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquiring and applying information and ideas in the carrying forward of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progressive experiences. Ideas are not segregated, they do not form an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated island. They animate and enrich the ordinary course of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Information is vitalized by its function; by the place it occupies in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direction of action. The phrase "opportunities exist" is used purposely.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They may not be taken advantage of; it is possible to employ manual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and constructive activities in a physical way, as means of getting just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bodily skill; or they may be used almost exclusively for "utilitarian,"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: i.e., pecuniary, ends. But the disposition on the part of upholders of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "cultural" education to assume that such activities are merely physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or professional in quality, is itself a product of the philosophies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which isolate mind from direction of the course of experience and hence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from action upon and with things. When the "mental" is regarded as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a self-contained separate realm, a counterpart fate befalls bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity and movements. They are regarded as at the best mere external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: annexes to mind. They may be necessary for the satisfaction of bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needs and the attainment of external decency and comfort, but they do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not occupy a necessary place in mind nor enact an indispensable role
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the completion of thought. Hence they have no place in a liberal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education--i.e., one which is concerned with the interests of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence. If they come in at all, it is as a concession to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material needs of the masses. That they should be allowed to invade
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the education of the elite is unspeakable. This conclusion follows
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irresistibly from the isolated conception of mind, but by the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: logic it disappears when we perceive what mind really is--namely, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposive and directive factor in the development of experience. While
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is desirable that all educational institutions should be equipped so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to give students an opportunity for acquiring and testing ideas and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information in active pursuits typifying important social situations, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will, doubtless, be a long time before all of them are thus furnished.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But this state of affairs does not afford instructors an excuse for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: folding their hands and persisting in methods which segregate school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge. Every recitation in every subject gives an opportunity for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: establishing cross connections between the subject matter of the lesson
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the wider and more direct experiences of everyday life. Classroom
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction falls into three kinds. The least desirable treats each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lesson as an independent whole. It does not put upon the student the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility of finding points of contact between it and other lessons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the same subject, or other subjects of study. Wiser teachers see to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it that the student is systematically led to utilize his earlier lessons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to help understand the present one, and also to use the present to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: throw additional light upon what has already been acquired. Results are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: better, but school subject matter is still isolated. Save by accident,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out-of-school experience is left in its crude and comparatively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irreflective state. It is not subject to the refining and expanding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influences of the more accurate and comprehensive material of direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction. The latter is not motivated and impregnated with a sense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reality by being intermingled with the realities of everyday life. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: best type of teaching bears in mind the desirability of affecting this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interconnection. It puts the student in the habitual attitude of finding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: points of contact and mutual bearings.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Processes of instruction are unified in the degree in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they center in the production of good habits of thinking. While we may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speak, without error, of the method of thought, the important thing is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that thinking is the method of an educative experience. The essentials
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of method are therefore identical with the essentials of reflection.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They are first that the pupil have a genuine situation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience--that there be a continuous activity in which he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interested for its own sake; secondly, that a genuine problem develop
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: within this situation as a stimulus to thought; third, that he possess
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the information and make the observations needed to deal with it;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fourth, that suggested solutions occur to him which he shall be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsible for developing in an orderly way; fifth, that he have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunity and occasion to test his ideas by application, to make their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning clear and to discover for himself their validity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Thirteen: The Nature of Method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Unity of Subject Matter and Method.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The trinity of school topics is subject matter, methods, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: administration or government. We have been concerned with the two former
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in recent chapters. It remains to disentangle them from the context in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they have been referred to, and discuss explicitly their nature.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We shall begin with the topic of method, since that lies closest to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerations of the last chapter. Before taking it up, it may be well,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, to call express attention to one implication of our theory; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection of subject matter and method with each other. The idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that mind and the world of things and persons are two separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and independent realms--a theory which philosophically is known as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dualism--carries with it the conclusion that method and subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of instruction are separate affairs. Subject matter then becomes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ready-made systematized classification of the facts and principles
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the world of nature and man. Method then has for its province a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consideration of the ways in which this antecedent subject matter may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be best presented to and impressed upon the mind; or, a consideration
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the ways in which the mind may be externally brought to bear upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter so as to facilitate its acquisition and possession. In theory, at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: least, one might deduce from a science of the mind as something existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by itself a complete theory of methods of learning, with no knowledge of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the subjects to which the methods are to be applied. Since many who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are actually most proficient in various branches of subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are wholly innocent of these methods, this state of affairs gives
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunity for the retort that pedagogy, as an alleged science
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of methods of the mind in learning, is futile;--a mere screen for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concealing the necessity a teacher is under of profound and accurate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquaintance with the subject in hand.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But since thinking is a directed movement of subject matter to a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: completing issue, and since mind is the deliberate and intentional phase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the process, the notion of any such split is radically false. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that the material of a science is organized is evidence that it has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already been subjected to intelligence; it has been methodized, so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to say. Zoology as a systematic branch of knowledge represents crude,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scattered facts of our ordinary acquaintance with animals after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have been subjected to careful examination, to deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplementation, and to arrangement to bring out connections which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assist observation, memory, and further inquiry. Instead of furnishing a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: starting point for learning, they mark out a consummation. Method means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that arrangement of subject matter which makes it most effective in use.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Never is method something outside of the material.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: How about method from the standpoint of an individual who is dealing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with subject matter? Again, it is not something external. It is simply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an effective treatment of material--efficiency meaning such treatment as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utilizes the material (puts it to a purpose) with a minimum of waste of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time and energy. We can distinguish a way of acting, and discuss it by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself; but the way exists only as way-of-dealing-with-material. Method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not antithetical to subject matter; it is the effective direction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of subject matter to desired results. It is antithetical to random and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ill-considered action,--ill-considered signifying ill-adapted.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The statement that method means directed movement of subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: towards ends is formal. An illustration may give it content. Every
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: artist must have a method, a technique, in doing his work. Piano playing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not hitting the keys at random. It is an orderly way of using them,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the order is not something which exists ready-made in the musician's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hands or brain prior to an activity dealing with the piano. Order is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: found in the disposition of acts which use the piano and the hands and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brain so as to achieve the result intended. It is the action of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: piano directed to accomplish the purpose of the piano as a musical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrument. It is the same with "pedagogical" method. The only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference is that the piano is a mechanism constructed in advance for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a single end; while the material of study is capable of indefinite uses.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But even in this regard the illustration may apply if we consider the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: infinite variety of kinds of music which a piano may produce, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the variations in technique required in the different musical results
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: secured. Method in any case is but an effective way of employing some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material for some end.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: These considerations may be generalized by going back to the conception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of experience. Experience as the perception of the connection between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something tried and something undergone in consequence is a process.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Apart from effort to control the course which the process takes, there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is no distinction of subject matter and method. There is simply an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity which includes both what an individual does and what the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment does. A piano player who had perfect mastery of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrument would have no occasion to distinguish between his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contribution and that of the piano. In well-formed, smooth-running
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: functions of any sort,--skating, conversing, hearing music, enjoying a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: landscape,--there is no consciousness of separation of the method of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: person and of the subject matter. In whole-hearted play and work there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the same phenomenon.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When we reflect upon an experience instead of just having it, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inevitably distinguish between our own attitude and the objects toward
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which we sustain the attitude. When a man is eating, he is eating food.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He does not divide his act into eating and food. But if he makes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific investigation of the act, such a discrimination is the first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing he would effect. He would examine on the one hand the properties
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the nutritive material, and on the other hand the acts of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organism in appropriating and digesting. Such reflection upon experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gives rise to a distinction of what we experience (the experienced) and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the experiencing--the how. When we give names to this distinction we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have subject matter and method as our terms. There is the thing seen,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heard, loved, hated, imagined, and there is the act of seeing, hearing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: loving, hating, imagining, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This distinction is so natural and so important for certain purposes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that we are only too apt to regard it as a separation in existence and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not as a distinction in thought. Then we make a division between a self
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the environment or world. This separation is the root of the dualism
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of method and subject matter. That is, we assume that knowing, feeling,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: willing, etc., are things which belong to the self or mind in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolation, and which then may be brought to bear upon an independent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter. We assume that the things which belong in isolation to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the self or mind have their own laws of operation irrespective of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modes of active energy of the object. These laws are supposed to furnish
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method. It would be no less absurd to suppose that men can eat without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eating something, or that the structure and movements of the jaws,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: throat muscles, the digestive activities of stomach, etc., are not what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are because of the material with which their activity is engaged.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Just as the organs of the organism are a continuous part of the very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world in which food materials exist, so the capacities of seeing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hearing, loving, imagining are intrinsically connected with the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of the world. They are more truly ways in which the environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enters into experience and functions there than they are independent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acts brought to bear upon things. Experience, in short, is not a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: combination of mind and world, subject and object, method and subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter, but is a single continuous interaction of a great diversity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (literally countless in number) of energies.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For the purpose of controlling the course or direction which the moving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unity of experience takes we draw a mental distinction between the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: how and the what. While there is no way of walking or of eating or of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning over and above the actual walking, eating, and studying, there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are certain elements in the act which give the key to its more effective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control. Special attention to these elements makes them more obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to perception (letting other factors recede for the time being from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conspicuous recognition). Getting an idea of how the experience proceeds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indicates to us what factors must be secured or modified in order that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it may go on more successfully. This is only a somewhat elaborate way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of saying that if a man watches carefully the growth of several plants,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some of which do well and some of which amount to little or nothing, he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be able to detect the special conditions upon which the prosperous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of a plant depends. These conditions, stated in an orderly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sequence, would constitute the method or way or manner of its growth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is no difference between the growth of a plant and the prosperous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of an experience. It is not easy, in either case, to seize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon just the factors which make for its best movement. But study of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cases of success and failure and minute and extensive comparison, helps
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to seize upon causes. When we have arranged these causes in order, we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have a method of procedure or a technique.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A consideration of some evils in education that flow from the isolation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of method from subject matter will make the point more definite.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (I) In the first place, there is the neglect (of which we have spoken)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of concrete situations of experience. There can be no discovery of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a method without cases to be studied. The method is derived from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observation of what actually happens, with a view to seeing that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happen better next time. But in instruction and discipline, there is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rarely sufficient opportunity for children and youth to have the direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: normal experiences from which educators might derive an idea of method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or order of best development. Experiences are had under conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of such constraint that they throw little or no light upon the normal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course of an experience to its fruition. "Methods" have then to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authoritatively recommended to teachers, instead of being an expression
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their own intelligent observations. Under such circumstances, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have a mechanical uniformity, assumed to be alike for all minds. Where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flexible personal experiences are promoted by providing an environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which calls out directed occupations in work and play, the methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ascertained will vary with individuals--for it is certain that each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual has something characteristic in his way of going at things.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) In the second place, the notion of methods isolated from subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter is responsible for the false conceptions of discipline and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest already noted. When the effective way of managing material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is treated as something ready-made apart from material, there are just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: three possible ways in which to establish a relationship lacking by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assumption. One is to utilize excitement, shock of pleasure, tickling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the palate. Another is to make the consequences of not attending
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: painful; we may use the menace of harm to motivate concern with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alien subject matter. Or a direct appeal may be made to the person to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: put forth effort without any reason. We may rely upon immediate strain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of "will." In practice, however, the latter method is effectual only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when instigated by fear of unpleasant results. (iii) In the third place,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the act of learning is made a direct and conscious end in itself. Under
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: normal conditions, learning is a product and reward of occupation with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter. Children do not set out, consciously, to learn walking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or talking. One sets out to give his impulses for communication and for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fuller intercourse with others a show. He learns in consequence of his
