title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct activities. The better methods of teaching a child, say, to read,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: follow the same road. They do not fix his attention upon the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he has to learn something and so make his attitude self-conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and constrained. They engage his activities, and in the process of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engagement he learns: the same is true of the more successful methods in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dealing with number or whatever. But when the subject matter is not used
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in carrying forward impulses and habits to significant results, it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just something to be learned. The pupil's attitude to it is just that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of having to learn it. Conditions more unfavorable to an alert and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concentrated response would be hard to devise. Frontal attacks are even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more wasteful in learning than in war. This does not mean, however, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: students are to be seduced unaware into preoccupation with lessons. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means that they shall be occupied with them for real reasons or ends,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and not just as something to be learned. This is accomplished whenever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the pupil perceives the place occupied by the subject matter in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fulfilling of some experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iv) In the fourth place, under the influence of the conception of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation of mind and material, method tends to be reduced to a cut and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dried routine, to following mechanically prescribed steps. No one can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tell in how many schoolrooms children reciting in arithmetic or grammar
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are compelled to go through, under the alleged sanction of method,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain preordained verbal formulae. Instead of being encouraged to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attack their topics directly, experimenting with methods that seem
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: promising and learning to discriminate by the consequences that accrue,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is assumed that there is one fixed method to be followed. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also naively assumed that if the pupils make their statements and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explanations in a certain form of "analysis," their mental habits will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in time conform. Nothing has brought pedagogical theory into greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disrepute than the belief that it is identified with handing out to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teachers recipes and models to be followed in teaching. Flexibility and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: initiative in dealing with problems are characteristic of any conception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which method is a way of managing material to develop a conclusion.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Mechanical rigid woodenness is an inevitable corollary of any theory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which separates mind from activity motivated by a purpose.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Method as General and as Individual. In brief, the method of teaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the method of an art, of action intelligently directed by ends. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the practice of a fine art is far from being a matter of extemporized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inspirations. Study of the operations and results of those in the past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who have greatly succeeded is essential. There is always a tradition, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schools of art, definite enough to impress beginners, and often to take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them captive. Methods of artists in every branch depend upon thorough
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquaintance with materials and tools; the painter must know canvas,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pigments, brushes, and the technique of manipulation of all his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appliances. Attainment of this knowledge requires persistent and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concentrated attention to objective materials. The artist studies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progress of his own attempts to see what succeeds and what fails. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assumption that there are no alternatives between following ready-made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rules and trusting to native gifts, the inspiration of the moment and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undirected "hard work," is contradicted by the procedures of every art.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Such matters as knowledge of the past, of current technique, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: materials, of the ways in which one's own best results are assured,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supply the material for what may be called general method. There exists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a cumulative body of fairly stable methods for reaching results, a body
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authorized by past experience and by intellectual analysis, which an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual ignores at his peril. As was pointed out in the discussion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habit-forming (ante, p. 49), there is always a danger that these methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will become mechanized and rigid, mastering an agent instead of being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers at command for his own ends. But it is also true that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: innovator who achieves anything enduring, whose work is more than a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: passing sensation, utilizes classic methods more than may appear to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself or to his critics. He devotes them to new uses, and in so far
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transforms them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Education also has its general methods. And if the application of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remark is more obvious in the case of the teacher than of the pupil, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is equally real in the case of the latter. Part of his learning, a very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important part, consists in becoming master of the methods which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience of others has shown to be more efficient in like cases of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting knowledge. 1 These general methods are in no way opposed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual initiative and originality--to personal ways of doing things.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On the contrary they are reinforcements of them. For there is radical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference between even the most general method and a prescribed rule.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The latter is a direct guide to action; the former operates indirectly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through the enlightenment it supplies as to ends and means. It operates,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that is to say, through intelligence, and not through conformity to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: orders externally imposed. Ability to use even in a masterly way an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: established technique gives no warranty of artistic work, for the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also depends upon an animating idea.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: If knowledge of methods used by others does not directly tell us what to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do, or furnish ready-made models, how does it operate? What is meant by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: calling a method intellectual? Take the case of a physician. No mode
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of behavior more imperiously demands knowledge of established modes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: diagnosis and treatment than does his. But after all, cases are like,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not identical. To be used intelligently, existing practices, however
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authorized they may be, have to be adapted to the exigencies of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particular cases. Accordingly, recognized procedures indicate to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physician what inquiries to set on foot for himself, what measures to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: try. They are standpoints from which to carry on investigations; they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economize a survey of the features of the particular case by suggesting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the things to be especially looked into. The physician's own personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitudes, his own ways (individual methods) of dealing with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation in which he is concerned, are not subordinated to the general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principles of procedure, but are facilitated and directed by the latter.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The instance may serve to point out the value to the teacher of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge of the psychological methods and the empirical devices found
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: useful in the past. When they get in the way of his own common sense,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when they come between him and the situation in which he has to act,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are worse than useless. But if he has acquired them as intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aids in sizing up the needs, resources, and difficulties of the unique
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences in which he engages, they are of constructive value. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: last resort, just because everything depends upon his own methods of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: response, much depends upon how far he can utilize, in making his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: response, the knowledge which has accrued in the experience of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As already intimated, every word of this account is directly applicable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also to the method of the pupil, the way of learning. To suppose that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: students, whether in the primary school or in the university, can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be supplied with models of method to be followed in acquiring and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expounding a subject is to fall into a self-deception that has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lamentable consequences. (See ante, p. 169.) One must make his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reaction in any case. Indications of the standardized or general methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: used in like cases by others--particularly by those who are already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experts--are of worth or of harm according as they make his personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reaction more intelligent or as they induce a person to dispense with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exercise of his own judgment. If what was said earlier (See p. 159)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about originality of thought seemed overstrained, demanding more of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education than the capacities of average human nature permit, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulty is that we lie under the incubus of a superstition. We have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set up the notion of mind at large, of intellectual method that is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same for all. Then we regard individuals as differing in the quantity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind with which they are charged. Ordinary persons are then expected to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be ordinary. Only the exceptional are allowed to have originality. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: measure of difference between the average student and the genius is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: measure of the absence of originality in the former. But this notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind in general is a fiction. How one person's abilities compare in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quantity with those of another is none of the teacher's business. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irrelevant to his work. What is required is that every individual shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have opportunities to employ his own powers in activities that have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning. Mind, individual method, originality (these are convertible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms) signify the quality of purposive or directed action. If we act
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon this conviction, we shall secure more originality even by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conventional standard than now develops. Imposing an alleged uniform
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general method upon everybody breeds mediocrity in all but the very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exceptional. And measuring originality by deviation from the mass breeds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eccentricity in them. Thus we stifle the distinctive quality of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: many, and save in rare instances (like, say, that of Darwin) infect the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rare geniuses with an unwholesome quality.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Traits of Individual Method. The most general features of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method of knowing have been given in our chapter on thinking. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are the features of the reflective situation: Problem, collection and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: analysis of data, projection and elaboration of suggestions or ideas,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental application and testing; the resulting conclusion or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judgment. The specific elements of an individual's method or way of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attack upon a problem are found ultimately in his native tendencies and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his acquired habits and interests. The method of one will vary from that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of another (and properly vary) as his original instinctive capacities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vary, as his past experiences and his preferences vary. Those who have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already studied these matters are in possession of information which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will help teachers in understanding the responses different pupils
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make, and help them in guiding these responses to greater efficiency.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Child-study, psychology, and a knowledge of social environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplement the personal acquaintance gained by the teacher. But methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remain the personal concern, approach, and attack of an individual, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no catalogue can ever exhaust their diversity of form and tint.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Some attitudes may be named, however,-which are central in effective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual ways of dealing with subject matter. Among the most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important are directness, open-mindedness, single-mindedness (or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whole-heartedness), and responsibility.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. It is easier to indicate what is meant by directness through negative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms than in positive ones. Self-consciousness, embarrassment, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constraint are its menacing foes. They indicate that a person is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately concerned with subject matter. Something has come between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which deflects concern to side issues. A self-conscious person is partly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking about his problem and partly about what others think of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performances. Diverted energy means loss of power and confusion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas. Taking an attitude is by no means identical with being conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of one's attitude. The former is spontaneous, naive, and simple. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a sign of whole-souled relationship between a person and what he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dealing with. The latter is not of necessity abnormal. It is sometimes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the easiest way of correcting a false method of approach, and of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: improving the effectiveness of the means one is employing,--as golf
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: players, piano players, public speakers, etc., have occasionally to give
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: especial attention to their position and movements. But this need
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is occasional and temporary. When it is effectual a person thinks of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself in terms of what is to be done, as one means among others of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization of an end--as in the case of a tennis player practicing to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: get the "feel" of a stroke. In abnormal cases, one thinks of himself not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as part of the agencies of execution, but as a separate object--as when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the player strikes an attitude thinking of the impression it will make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon spectators, or is worried because of the impression he fears his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements give rise to.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Confidence is a good name for what is intended by the term directness.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It should not be confused, however, with self-confidence which may be a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form of self-consciousness--or of "cheek." Confidence is not a name for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what one thinks or feels about his attitude it is not reflex. It denotes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the straightforwardness with which one goes at what he has to do.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It denotes not conscious trust in the efficacy of one's powers but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unconscious faith in the possibilities of the situation. It signifies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rising to the needs of the situation. We have already pointed out (See
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: p. 169) the objections to making students emphatically aware of the fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they are studying or learning. Just in the degree in which they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are induced by the conditions to be so aware, they are not studying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and learning. They are in a divided and complicated attitude. Whatever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods of a teacher call a pupil's attention off from what he has to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do and transfer it to his own attitude towards what he is doing impair
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directness of concern and action. Persisted in, the pupil acquires a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: permanent tendency to fumble, to gaze about aimlessly, to look for some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clew of action beside that which the subject matter supplies. Dependence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon extraneous suggestions and directions, a state of foggy confusion,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take the place of that sureness with which children (and grown-up people
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who have not been sophisticated by "education") confront the situations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Open-mindedness. Partiality is, as we have seen, an accompaniment of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the existence of interest, since this means sharing, partaking, taking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sides in some movement. All the more reason, therefore, for an attitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind which actively welcomes suggestions and relevant information
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from all sides. In the chapter on Aims it was shown that foreseen ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are factors in the development of a changing situation. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the means by which the direction of action is controlled. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinate to the situation, therefore, not the situation to them. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are not ends in the sense of finalities to which everything must be bent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and sacrificed. They are, as foreseen, means of guiding the development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a situation. A target is not the future goal of shooting; it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the centering factor in a present shooting. Openness of mind means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accessibility of mind to any and every consideration that will throw
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: light upon the situation that needs to be cleared up, and that will help
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: determine the consequences of acting this way or that. Efficiency in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplishing ends which have been settled upon as unalterable can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coexist with a narrowly opened mind. But intellectual growth means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constant expansion of horizons and consequent formation of new purposes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and new responses. These are impossible without an active disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to welcome points of view hitherto alien; an active desire to entertain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerations which modify existing purposes. Retention of capacity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to grow is the reward of such intellectual hospitality. The worst
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing about stubbornness of mind, about prejudices, is that they arrest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development; they shut the mind off from new stimuli. Open-mindedness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means retention of the childlike attitude; closed-mindedness means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: premature intellectual old age.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Exorbitant desire for uniformity of procedure and for prompt external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results are the chief foes which the open-minded attitude meets in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school. The teacher who does not permit and encourage diversity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operation in dealing with questions is imposing intellectual blinders
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon pupils--restricting their vision to the one path the teacher's mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happens to approve. Probably the chief cause of devotion to rigidity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of method is, however, that it seems to promise speedy, accurately
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: measurable, correct results. The zeal for "answers" is the explanation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of much of the zeal for rigid and mechanical methods. Forcing and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: overpressure have the same origin, and the same result upon alert and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: varied intellectual interest.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Open-mindedness is not the same as empty-mindedness. To hang out a sign
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: saying "Come right in; there is no one at home" is not the equivalent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of hospitality. But there is a kind of passivity, willingness to let
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences accumulate and sink in and ripen, which is an essential of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development. Results (external answers or solutions) may be hurried;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: processes may not be forced. They take their own time to mature. Were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all instructors to realize that the quality of mental process, not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the production of correct answers, is the measure of educative growth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something hardly less than a revolution in teaching would be worked.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Single-mindedness. So far as the word is concerned, much that was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: said under the head of "directness" is applicable. But what the word is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: here intended to convey is completeness of interest, unity of purpose;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the absence of suppressed but effectual ulterior aims for which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: professed aim is but a mask. It is equivalent to mental integrity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Absorption, engrossment, full concern with subject matter for its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sake, nurture it. Divided interest and evasion destroy it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Intellectual integrity, honesty, and sincerity are at bottom not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matters of conscious purpose but of quality of active response.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Their acquisition is fostered of course by conscious intent, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-deception is very easy. Desires are urgent. When the demands and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wishes of others forbid their direct expression they are easily driven
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into subterranean and deep channels. Entire surrender, and wholehearted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adoption of the course of action demanded by others are almost
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impossible. Deliberate revolt or deliberate attempts to deceive others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may result. But the more frequent outcome is a confused and divided
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: state of interest in which one is fooled as to one's own real intent.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: One tries to serve two masters at once. Social instincts, the strong
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desire to please others and get their approval, social training, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general sense of duty and of authority, apprehension of penalty, all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lead to a half-hearted effort to conform, to "pay attention to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lesson," or whatever the requirement is. Amiable individuals want to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what they are expected to do. Consciously the pupil thinks he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing this. But his own desires are not abolished. Only their evident
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exhibition is suppressed. Strain of attention to what is hostile to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desire is irksome; in spite of one's conscious wish, the underlying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desires determine the main course of thought, the deeper emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responses. The mind wanders from the nominal subject and devotes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself to what is intrinsically more desirable. A systematized divided
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention expressing the duplicity of the state of desire is the result.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: One has only to recall his own experiences in school or at the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time when outwardly employed in actions which do not engage one's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desires and purposes, to realize how prevalent is this attitude of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: divided attention--double-mindedness. We are so used to it that we take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it for granted that a considerable amount of it is necessary. It may be;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if so, it is the more important to face its bad intellectual effects.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Obvious is the loss of energy of thought immediately available when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one is consciously trying (or trying to seem to try) to attend to one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter, while unconsciously one's imagination is spontaneously going out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to more congenial affairs. More subtle and more permanently crippling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to efficiency of intellectual activity is a fostering of habitual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-deception, with the confused sense of reality which accompanies it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A double standard of reality, one for our own private and more or less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concealed interests, and another for public and acknowledged concerns,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hampers, in most of us, integrity and completeness of mental action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Equally serious is the fact that a split is set up between conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought and attention and impulsive blind affection and desire.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Reflective dealings with the material of instruction is constrained
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and half-hearted; attention wanders. The topics to which it wanders are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unavowed and hence intellectually illicit; transactions with them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are furtive. The discipline that comes from regulating response by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate inquiry having a purpose fails; worse than that, the deepest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concern and most congenial enterprises of the imagination (since they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: center about the things dearest to desire) are casual, concealed. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enter into action in ways which are unacknowledged. Not subject to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rectification by consideration of consequences, they are demoralizing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: School conditions favorable to this division of mind between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: avowed, public, and socially responsible undertakings, and private,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ill-regulated, and suppressed indulgences of thought are not hard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to find. What is sometimes called "stern discipline," i.e., external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coercive pressure, has this tendency. Motivation through rewards
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extraneous to the thing to be done has a like effect. Everything that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes schooling merely preparatory (See ante, p. 55) works in this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direction. Ends being beyond the pupil's present grasp, other agencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have to be found to procure immediate attention to assigned tasks. Some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responses are secured, but desires and affections not enlisted must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: find other outlets. Not less serious is exaggerated emphasis upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: drill exercises designed to produce skill in action, independent of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engagement of thought--exercises have no purpose but the production of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: automatic skill. Nature abhors a mental vacuum. What do teachers imagine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is happening to thought and emotion when the latter get no outlet in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the things of immediate activity? Were they merely kept in temporary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abeyance, or even only calloused, it would not be a matter of so much
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moment. But they are not abolished; they are not suspended; they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not suppressed--save with reference to the task in question. They follow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own chaotic and undisciplined course. What is native, spontaneous,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vital in mental reaction goes unused and untested, and the habits
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formed are such that these qualities become less and less available for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: public and avowed ends.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 4. Responsibility. By responsibility as an element in intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitude is meant the disposition to consider in advance the probable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences of any projected step and deliberately to accept them: to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accept them in the sense of taking them into account, acknowledging them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in action, not yielding a mere verbal assent. Ideas, as we have seen,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are intrinsically standpoints and methods for bringing about a solution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a perplexing situation; forecasts calculated to influence responses.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is only too easy to think that one accepts a statement or believes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggested truth when one has not considered its implications; when one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has made but a cursory and superficial survey of what further things one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is committed to by acceptance. Observation and recognition, belief and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assent, then become names for lazy acquiescence in what is externally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presented.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It would be much better to have fewer facts and truths in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction--that is, fewer things supposedly accepted,--if a smaller
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of situations could be intellectually worked out to the point
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where conviction meant something real--some identification of the self
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the type of conduct demanded by facts and foresight of results. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: most permanent bad results of undue complication of school subjects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and congestion of school studies and lessons are not the worry, nervous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strain, and superficial acquaintance that follow (serious as these are),
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but the failure to make clear what is involved in really knowing and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: believing a thing. Intellectual responsibility means severe standards
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in this regard. These standards can be built up only through practice in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following up and acting upon the meaning of what is acquired.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Intellectual thoroughness is thus another name for the attitude we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considering. There is a kind of thoroughness which is almost purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical: the kind that signifies mechanical and exhausting drill upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all the details of a subject. Intellectual thoroughness is seeing a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing through. It depends upon a unity of purpose to which details are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinated, not upon presenting a multitude of disconnected details.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is manifested in the firmness with which the full meaning of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose is developed, not in attention, however "conscientious" it may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be, to the steps of action externally imposed and directed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Method is a statement of the way the subject matter of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience develops most effectively and fruitfully. It is derived,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accordingly, from observation of the course of experiences where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is no conscious distinction of personal attitude and manner from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material dealt with. The assumption that method is something separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is connected with the notion of the isolation of mind and self from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world of things. It makes instruction and learning formal, mechanical,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constrained. While methods are individualized, certain features of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: normal course of an experience to its fruition may be discriminated,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because of the fund of wisdom derived from prior experiences and because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of general similarities in the materials dealt with from time to time.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Expressed in terms of the attitude of the individual the traits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good method are straightforwardness, flexible intellectual interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or open-minded will to learn, integrity of purpose, and acceptance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility for the consequences of one's activity including thought.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1 This point is developed below in a discussion of what are termed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: psychological and logical methods respectively. See p. 219.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
