text: Chapter Fourteen: The Nature of Subject Matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Subject Matter of Educator and of Learner. So far as the nature of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter in principle is concerned, there is nothing to add
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what has been said (See ante, p. 134). It consists of the facts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observed, recalled, read, and talked about, and the ideas suggested, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course of a development of a situation having a purpose. This statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needs to be rendered more specific by connecting it with the materials
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of school instruction, the studies which make up the curriculum. What is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the significance of our definition in application to reading, writing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mathematics, history, nature study, drawing, singing, physics,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chemistry, modern and foreign languages, and so on? Let us recur to two
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the points made earlier in our discussion. The educator's part in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enterprise of education is to furnish the environment which stimulates
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responses and directs the learner's course. In last analysis, all that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the educator can do is modify stimuli so that response will as surely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as is possible result in the formation of desirable intellectual and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emotional dispositions. Obviously studies or the subject matter of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum have intimately to do with this business of supplying an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment. The other point is the necessity of a social environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to give meaning to habits formed. In what we have termed informal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education, subject matter is carried directly in the matrix of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse. It is what the persons with whom an individual associates
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do and say. This fact gives a clew to the understanding of the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of formal or deliberate instruction. A connecting link is found
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the stories, traditions, songs, and liturgies which accompany the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doings and rites of a primitive social group. They represent the stock
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of meanings which have been precipitated out of previous experience,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are so prized by the group as to be identified with their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception of their own collective life. Not being obviously a part of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the skill exhibited in the daily occupations of eating, hunting, making
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: war and peace, constructing rugs, pottery, and baskets, etc., they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are consciously impressed upon the young; often, as in the initiation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ceremonies, with intense emotional fervor. Even more pains are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously taken to perpetuate the myths, legends, and sacred verbal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulae of the group than to transmit the directly useful customs of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the group just because they cannot be picked up, as the latter can be in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ordinary processes of association.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As the social group grows more complex, involving a greater number of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquired skills which are dependent, either in fact or in the belief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the group, upon standard ideas deposited from past experience, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: content of social life gets more definitely formulated for purposes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction. As we have previously noted, probably the chief motive for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously dwelling upon the group life, extracting the meanings which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are regarded as most important and systematizing them in a coherent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrangement, is just the need of instructing the young so as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perpetuate group life. Once started on this road of selection,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulation, and organization, no definite limit exists. The invention
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of writing and of printing gives the operation an immense impetus.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Finally, the bonds which connect the subject matter of school study with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the habits and ideals of the social group are disguised and covered up.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The ties are so loosened that it often appears as if there were none;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as if subject matter existed simply as knowledge on its own independent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: behoof, and as if study were the mere act of mastering it for its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sake, irrespective of any social values. Since it is highly important
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for practical reasons to counter-act this tendency (See ante, p. 8)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the chief purposes of our theoretical discussion are to make clear the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection which is so readily lost from sight, and to show in some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: detail the social content and function of the chief constituents of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course of study.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The points need to be considered from the standpoint of instructor and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of student. To the former, the significance of a knowledge of subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter, going far beyond the present knowledge of pupils, is to supply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definite standards and to reveal to him the possibilities of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: crude activities of the immature. (i) The material of school studies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: translates into concrete and detailed terms the meanings of current
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social life which it is desirable to transmit. It puts clearly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: before the instructor the essential ingredients of the culture to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be perpetuated, in such an organized form as to protect him from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: haphazard efforts he would be likely to indulge in if the meanings had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not been standardized. (ii) A knowledge of the ideas which have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achieved in the past as the outcome of activity places the educator in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a position to perceive the meaning of the seeming impulsive and aimless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reactions of the young, and to provide the stimuli needed to direct them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so that they will amount to something. The more the educator knows of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: music the more he can perceive the possibilities of the inchoate musical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impulses of a child. Organized subject matter represents the ripe
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitage of experiences like theirs, experiences involving the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world, and powers and needs similar to theirs. It does not represent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perfection or infallible wisdom; but it is the best at command to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: further new experiences which may, in some respects at least, surpass
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the achievements embodied in existing knowledge and works of art.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: From the standpoint of the educator, in other words, the various studies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent working resources, available capital. Their remoteness from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the experience of the young is not, however, seeming; it is real. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of the learner is not, therefore, it cannot be, identical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the formulated, the crystallized, and systematized subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the adult; the material as found in books and in works of art, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The latter represents the possibilities of the former; not its existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: state. It enters directly into the activities of the expert and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educator, not into that of the beginner, the learner. Failure to bear in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind the difference in subject matter from the respective standpoints of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teacher and student is responsible for most of the mistakes made in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use of texts and other expressions of preexistent knowledge.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The need for a knowledge of the constitution and functions, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concrete, of human nature is great just because the teacher's attitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to subject matter is so different from that of the pupil. The teacher
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presents in actuality what the pupil represents only in posse. That is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the teacher already knows the things which the student is only learning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence the problem of the two is radically unlike. When engaged in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct act of teaching, the instructor needs to have subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at his fingers' ends; his attention should be upon the attitude and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: response of the pupil. To understand the latter in its interplay with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter is his task, while the pupil's mind, naturally, should be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not on itself but on the topic in hand. Or to state the same point in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a somewhat different manner: the teacher should be occupied not with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter in itself but in its interaction with the pupils' present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needs and capacities. Hence simple scholarship is not enough. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact, there are certain features of scholarship or mastered subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter--taken by itself--which get in the way of effective teaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unless the instructor's habitual attitude is one of concern with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its interplay in the pupil's own experience. In the first place,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his knowledge extends indefinitely beyond the range of the pupil's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquaintance. It involves principles which are beyond the immature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pupil's understanding and interest. In and of itself, it may no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more represent the living world of the pupil's experience than the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: astronomer's knowledge of Mars represents a baby's acquaintance with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: room in which he stays. In the second place, the method of organization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the material of achieved scholarship differs from that of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the beginner. It is not true that the experience of the young is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unorganized--that it consists of isolated scraps. But it is organized in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with direct practical centers of interest. The child's home
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, for example, the organizing center of his geographical knowledge.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: His own movements about the locality, his journeys abroad, the tales of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his friends, give the ties which hold his items of information together.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But the geography of the geographer, of the one who has already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developed the implications of these smaller experiences, is organized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on the basis of the relationship which the various facts bear to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another--not the relations which they bear to his house, bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements, and friends. To the one who is learned, subject matter is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extensive, accurately defined, and logically interrelated. To the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one who is learning, it is fluid, partial, and connected through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his personal occupations. 1 The problem of teaching is to keep the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience of the student moving in the direction of what the expert
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already knows. Hence the need that the teacher know both subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the characteristic needs and capacities of the student.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Development of Subject Matter in the Learner. It is possible,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without doing violence to the facts, to mark off three fairly typical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stages in the growth of subject matter in the experience of the learner.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In its first estate, knowledge exists as the content of intelligent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ability--power to do. This kind of subject matter, or known material, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expressed in familiarity or acquaintance with things. Then this material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradually is surcharged and deepened through communicated knowledge or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information. Finally, it is enlarged and worked over into rationally or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: logically organized material--that of the one who, relatively speaking,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: experience--a quality of aloofness that is popularly designated by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: Science has been defined in terms of method of inquiry and testing. At
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first sight, this definition may seem opposed to the current conception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that science is organized or systematized knowledge. The opposition,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, is only seeming, and disappears when the ordinary definition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is completed. Not organization but the kind of organization effected by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequate methods of tested discovery marks off science. The knowledge of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a farmer is systematized in the degree in which he is competent. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is organized on the basis of relation of means to ends--practically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organized. Its organization as knowledge (that is, in the eulogistic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense of adequately tested and confirmed) is incidental to its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organization with reference to securing crops, live-stock, etc. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific subject matter is organized with specific reference to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successful conduct of the enterprise of discovery, to knowing as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialized undertaking. Reference to the kind of assurance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attending science will shed light upon this statement. It is rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assurance,--logical warranty. The ideal of scientific organization is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: therefore, that every conception and statement shall be of such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kind as to follow from others and to lead to others. Conceptions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and propositions mutually imply and support one another. This double
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relation of "leading to and confirming" is what is meant by the terms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: logical and rational. The everyday conception of water is more available
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for ordinary uses of drinking, washing, irrigation, etc., than the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chemist's notion of it. The latter's description of it as H20 is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superior from the standpoint of place and use in inquiry. It states
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the nature of water in a way which connects it with knowledge of other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things, indicating to one who understands it how the knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrived at and its bearings upon other portions of knowledge of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: structure of things. Strictly speaking, it does not indicate the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objective relations of water any more than does a statement that water
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is transparent, fluid, without taste or odor, satisfying to thirst,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc. It is just as true that water has these relations as that it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constituted by two molecules of hydrogen in combination with one of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: oxygen. But for the particular purpose of conducting discovery with a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: view to ascertainment of fact, the latter relations are fundamental. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more one emphasizes organization as a mark of science, then, the more he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is committed to a recognition of the primacy of method in the definition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of science. For method defines the kind of organization in virtue of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which science is science.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 4. Subject Matter as Social. Our next chapters will take up various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school activities and studies and discuss them as successive stages
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in that evolution of knowledge which we have just been discussing. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remains to say a few words upon subject matter as social, since our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prior remarks have been mainly concerned with its intellectual aspect. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference in breadth and depth exists even in vital knowledge; even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the data and ideas which are relevant to real problems and which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motivated by purposes. For there is a difference in the social scope of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposes and the social importance of problems. With the wide range
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of possible material to select from, it is important that education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (especially in all its phases short of the most specialized) should use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a criterion of social worth. All information and systematized scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter have been worked out under the conditions of social life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and have been transmitted by social means. But this does not prove that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all is of equal value for the purposes of forming the disposition and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supplying the equipment of members of present society. The scheme of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum must take account of the adaptation of studies to the needs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the existing community life; it must select with the intention of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: improving the life we live in common so that the future shall be better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than the past. Moreover, the curriculum must be planned with reference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to placing essentials first, and refinements second. The things which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are socially most fundamental, that is, which have to do with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences in which the widest groups share, are the essentials. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which represent the needs of specialized groups and technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursuits are secondary. There is truth in the saying that education must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first be human and only after that professional. But those who utter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the saying frequently have in mind in the term human only a highly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialized class: the class of learned men who preserve the classic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: traditions of the past. They forget that material is humanized in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degree in which it connects with the common interests of men as men.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Democratic society is peculiarly dependent for its maintenance upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use in forming a course of study of criteria which are broadly human.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Democracy cannot flourish where the chief influences in selecting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of instruction are utilitarian ends narrowly conceived
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the masses, and, for the higher education of the few, the traditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a specialized cultivated class. The notion that the "essentials" of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elementary education are the three R's mechanically treated, is based
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon ignorance of the essentials needed for realization of democratic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideals. Unconsciously it assumes that these ideals are unrealizable;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it assumes that in the future, as in the past, getting a livelihood,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "making a living," must signify for most men and women doing things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are not significant, freely chosen, and ennobling to those who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do them; doing things which serve ends unrecognized by those engaged in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them, carried on under the direction of others for the sake of pecuniary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reward. For preparation of large numbers for a life of this sort, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only for this purpose, are mechanical efficiency in reading, writing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spelling and figuring, together with attainment of a certain amount
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of muscular dexterity, "essentials." Such conditions also infect the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education called liberal, with illiberality. They imply a somewhat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parasitic cultivation bought at the expense of not having the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlightenment and discipline which come from concern with the deepest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problems of common humanity. A curriculum which acknowledges the social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibilities of education must present situations where problems are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relevant to the problems of living together, and where observation and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information are calculated to develop social insight and interest.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. The subject matter of education consists primarily of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meanings which supply content to existing social life. The continuity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social life means that many of these meanings are contributed to present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity by past collective experience. As social life grows more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complex, these factors increase in number and import. There is need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: special selection, formulation, and organization in order that they may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be adequately transmitted to the new generation. But this very process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tends to set up subject matter as something of value just by itself,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apart from its function in promoting the realization of the meanings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implied in the present experience of the immature. Especially is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educator exposed to the temptation to conceive his task in terms of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pupil's ability to appropriate and reproduce the subject matter in set
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statements, irrespective of its organization into his activities as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developing social member. The positive principle is maintained when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: young begin with active occupations having a social origin and use,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and proceed to a scientific insight in the materials and laws involved,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through assimilating into their more direct experience the ideas and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts communicated by others who have had a larger experience. 1 Since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the learned man should also still be a learner, it will be understood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that these contrasts are relative, not absolute. But in the earlier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stages of learning at least they are practically all-important.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: 1. The Place of Active Occupations in Education. In consequence partly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the efforts of educational reformers, partly of increased interest in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: child-psychology, and partly of the direct experience of the schoolroom,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the course of study has in the past generation undergone considerable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modification. The desirability of starting from and with the experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and capacities of learners, a lesson enforced from all three quarters,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has led to the introduction of forms of activity, in play and work,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: similar to those in which children and youth engage outside of school.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Modern psychology has substituted for the general, ready-made faculties
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of older theory a complex group of instinctive and impulsive tendencies.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Experience has shown that when children have a chance at physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities which bring their natural impulses into play, going to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school is a joy, management is less of a burden, and learning is easier.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Sometimes, perhaps, plays, games, and constructive occupations are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resorted to only for these reasons, with emphasis upon relief from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tedium and strain of "regular" school work. There is no reason, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for using them merely as agreeable diversions. Study of mental life has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made evident the fundamental worth of native tendencies to explore,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to manipulate tools and materials, to construct, to give expression
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to joyous emotion, etc. When exercises which are prompted by these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instincts are a part of the regular school program, the whole pupil is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engaged, the artificial gap between life in school and out is reduced,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motives are afforded for attention to a large variety of materials and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: processes distinctly educative in effect, and cooperative associations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which give information in a social setting are provided. In short, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: grounds for assigning to play and active work a definite place in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the curriculum are intellectual and social, not matters of temporary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expediency and momentary agreeableness. Without something of the kind,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is not possible to secure the normal estate of effective learning;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: namely, that knowledge-getting be an outgrowth of activities having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own end, instead of a school task. More specifically, play and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work correspond, point for point, with the traits of the initial stage
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowing, which consists, as we saw in the last chapter, in learning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: how to do things and in acquaintance with things and processes gained
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the doing. It is suggestive that among the Greeks, till the rise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of conscious philosophy, the same word, techne, was used for art and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science. Plato gave his account of knowledge on the basis of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: analysis of the knowledge of cobblers, carpenters, players of musical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruments, etc., pointing out that their art (so far as it was not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere routine) involved an end, mastery of material or stuff worked upon,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control of appliances, and a definite order of procedure--all of which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had to be known in order that there be intelligent skill or art.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Doubtless the fact that children normally engage in play and work out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of school has seemed to many educators a reason why they should concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves in school with things radically different. School time seemed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: too precious to spend in doing over again what children were sure to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any way. In some social conditions, this reason has weight. In pioneer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: times, for example, outside occupations gave a definite and valuable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual and moral training. Books and everything concerned with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them were, on the other hand, rare and difficult of access; they were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the only means of outlet from a narrow and crude environment. Wherever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such conditions obtain, much may be said in favor of concentrating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school activity upon books. The situation is very different, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in most communities to-day. The kinds of work in which the young
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can engage, especially in cities, are largely anti-educational. That
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: prevention of child labor is a social duty is evidence on this point.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On the other hand, printed matter has been so cheapened and is in such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: universal circulation, and all the opportunities of intellectual culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been so multiplied, that the older type of book work is far from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having the force it used to possess.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But it must not be forgotten that an educational result is a by-product
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of play and work in most out-of-school conditions. It is incidental,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not primary. Consequently the educative growth secured is more or less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accidental. Much work shares in the defects of existing industrial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society--defects next to fatal to right development. Play tends to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reproduce and affirm the crudities, as well as the excellencies, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surrounding adult life. It is the business of the school to set up an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment in which play and work shall be conducted with reference to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facilitating desirable mental and moral growth. It is not enough just
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to introduce plays and games, hand work and manual exercises. Everything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depends upon the way in which they are employed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Available Occupations. A bare catalogue of the list of activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which have already found their way into schools indicates what a rich
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: field is at hand. There is work with paper, cardboard, wood, leather,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cloth, yarns, clay and sand, and the metals, with and without tools.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Processes employed are folding, cutting, pricking, measuring, molding,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
