author: Dewey, John

text: principles--almost out of their heads--by logical reasons. It seems
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as absurd that learning should come from action on and with physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things, like dropping acid on a stone to see what would happen, as that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it should come from sticking an awl with waxed thread through a piece of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leather. But the rise of experimental methods proved that, given control
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of conditions, the latter operation is more typical of the right way of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge than isolated logical reasonings. Experiment developed in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seventeenth and succeeding centuries and became the authorized way of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowing when men's interests were centered in the question of control
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of nature for human uses. The active occupations in which appliances
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are brought to bear upon physical things with the intention of effecting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: useful changes is the most vital introduction to the experimental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Work and Play. What has been termed active occupation includes both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: play and work. In their intrinsic meaning, play and industry are by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no means so antithetical to one another as is often assumed, any sharp
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contrast being due to undesirable social conditions. Both involve ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously entertained and the selection and adaptations of materials
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and processes designed to effect the desired ends. The difference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between them is largely one of time-span, influencing the directness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the connection of means and ends. In play, the interest is more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct--a fact frequently indicated by saying that in play the activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is its own end, instead of its having an ulterior result. The statement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is correct, but it is falsely taken, if supposed to mean that play
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity is momentary, having no element of looking ahead and none of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursuit. Hunting, for example, is one of the commonest forms of adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: play, but the existence of foresight and the direction of present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity by what one is watching for are obvious. When an activity is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its own end in the sense that the action of the moment is complete in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself, it is purely physical; it has no meaning (See p. 77). The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: person is either going through motions quite blindly, perhaps purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imitatively, or else is in a state of excitement which is exhausting to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind and nerves. Both results may be seen in some types of kindergarten
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: games where the idea of play is so highly symbolic that only the adult
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is conscious of it. Unless the children succeed in reading in some quite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different idea of their own, they move about either as if in a hypnotic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: daze, or they respond to a direct excitation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The point of these remarks is that play has an end in the sense of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directing idea which gives point to the successive acts. Persons who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: play are not just doing something (pure physical movement); they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trying to do or effect something, an attitude that involves anticipatory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forecasts which stimulate their present responses. The anticipated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result, however, is rather a subsequent action than the production of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a specific change in things. Consequently play is free, plastic. Where
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some definite external outcome is wanted, the end has to be held to with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some persistence, which increases as the contemplated result is complex
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and requires a fairly long series of intermediate adaptations. When the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intended act is another activity, it is not necessary to look far ahead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and it is possible to alter it easily and frequently. If a child
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is making a toy boat, he must hold on to a single end and direct a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerable number of acts by that one idea. If he is just "playing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: boat" he may change the material that serves as a boat almost at will,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and introduce new factors as fancy suggests. The imagination makes what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it will of chairs, blocks, leaves, chips, if they serve the purpose of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: carrying activity forward.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: From a very early age, however, there is no distinction of exclusive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: periods of play activity and work activity, but only one of emphasis.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There are definite results which even young children desire, and try
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to bring to pass. Their eager interest in sharing the occupations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, if nothing else, accomplishes this. Children want to "help";
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are anxious to engage in the pursuits of adults which effect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external changes: setting the table, washing dishes, helping care for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: animals, etc. In their plays, they like to construct their own toys and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appliances. With increasing maturity, activity which does not give back
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results of tangible and visible achievement loses its interest. Play
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then changes to fooling and if habitually indulged in is demoralizing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Observable results are necessary to enable persons to get a sense and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a measure of their own powers. When make-believe is recognized to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make-believe, the device of making objects in fancy alone is too easy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to stimulate intense action. One has only to observe the countenance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children really playing to note that their attitude is one of serious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absorption; this attitude cannot be maintained when things cease to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: afford adequate stimulation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When fairly remote results of a definite character are foreseen and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlist persistent effort for their accomplishment, play passes into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work. Like play, it signifies purposeful activity and differs not in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that activity is subordinated to an external result, but in the fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that a longer course of activity is occasioned by the idea of a result.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The demand for continuous attention is greater, and more intelligence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be shown in selecting and shaping means. To extend this account
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would be to repeat what has been said under the caption of aim,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest, and thinking. It is pertinent, however, to inquire why the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea is so current that work involves subordination of an activity to an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ulterior material result. The extreme form of this subordination,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: namely drudgery, offers a clew. Activity carried on under conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of external pressure or coercion is not carried on for any significance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attached to the doing. The course of action is not intrinsically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: satisfying; it is a mere means for avoiding some penalty, or for gaining
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some reward at its conclusion. What is inherently repulsive is endured
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the sake of averting something still more repulsive or of securing a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gain hitched on by others. Under unfree economic conditions, this state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of affairs is bound to exist. Work or industry offers little to engage
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the emotions and the imagination; it is a more or less mechanical series
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of strains. Only the hold which the completion of the work has upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a person will keep him going. But the end should be intrinsic to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action; it should be its end--a part of its own course. Then it affords
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a stimulus to effort very different from that arising from the thought
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of results which have nothing to do with the intervening action. As
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already mentioned, the absence of economic pressure in schools supplies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an opportunity for reproducing industrial situations of mature life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: under conditions where the occupation can be carried on for its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sake. If in some cases, pecuniary recognition is also a result of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action, though not the chief motive for it, that fact may well increase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the significance of the occupation. Where something approaching drudgery
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or the need of fulfilling externally imposed tasks exists, the demand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for play persists, but tends to be perverted. The ordinary course of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action fails to give adequate stimulus to emotion and imagination. So in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leisure time, there is an imperious demand for their stimulation by any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kind of means; gambling, drink, etc., may be resorted to. Or, in less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extreme cases, there is recourse to idle amusement; to anything which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: passes time with immediate agreeableness. Recreation, as the word
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indicates, is recuperation of energy. No demand of human nature is more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: urgent or less to be escaped. The idea that the need can be suppressed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is absolutely fallacious, and the Puritanic tradition which disallows
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the need has entailed an enormous crop of evils. If education does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not afford opportunity for wholesome recreation and train capacity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for seeking and finding it, the suppressed instincts find all sorts of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: illicit outlets, sometimes overt, sometimes confined to indulgence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the imagination. Education has no more serious responsibility than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making adequate provision for enjoyment of recreative leisure; not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the sake of immediate health, but still more if possible for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sake of its lasting effect upon habits of mind. Art is again the answer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to this demand.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. In the previous chapter we found that the primary subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of knowing is that contained in learning how to do things of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fairly direct sort. The educational equivalent of this principle is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consistent use of simple occupations which appeal to the powers of youth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and which typify general modes of social activity. Skill and information
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about materials, tools, and laws of energy are acquired while activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are carried on for their own sake. The fact that they are socially
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: representative gives a quality to the skill and knowledge gained which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes them transferable to out-of-school situations. It is important not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to confuse the psychological distinction between play and work with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economic distinction. Psychologically, the defining characteristic of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: play is not amusement nor aimlessness. It is the fact that the aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is thought of as more activity in the same line, without defining
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity of action in reference to results produced. Activities as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they grow more complicated gain added meaning by greater attention to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specific results achieved. Thus they pass gradually into work. Both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are equally free and intrinsically motivated, apart from false economic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions which tend to make play into idle excitement for the well
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do, and work into uncongenial labor for the poor. Work is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: psychologically simply an activity which consciously includes regard for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences as a part of itself; it becomes constrained labor when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences are outside of the activity as an end to which activity is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely a means. Work which remains permeated with the play attitude is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: art--in quality if not in conventional designation.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Sixteen: The Significance of Geography and History
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Extension of Meaning of Primary Activities. Nothing is more striking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than the difference between an activity as merely physical and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wealth of meanings which the same activity may assume. From the outside,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an astronomer gazing through a telescope is like a small boy looking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through the same tube. In each case, there is an arrangement of glass
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and metal, an eye, and a little speck of light in the distance. Yet at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a critical moment, the activity of an astronomer might be concerned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the birth of a world, and have whatever is known about the starry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heavens as its significant content. Physically speaking, what man has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effected on this globe in his progress from savagery is a mere scratch
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on its surface, not perceptible at a distance which is slight in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comparison with the reaches even of the solar system. Yet in meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what has been accomplished measures just the difference of civilization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from savagery. Although the activities, physically viewed, have changed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: somewhat, this change is slight in comparison with the development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the meanings attaching to the activities. There is no limit to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning which an action may come to possess. It all depends upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: context of perceived connections in which it is placed; the reach of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imagination in realizing connections is inexhaustible. The advantage
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the activity of man has in appropriating and finding meanings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes his education something else than the manufacture of a tool or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the training of an animal. The latter increase efficiency; they do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not develop significance. The final educational importance of such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations in play and work as were considered in the last chapter is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they afford the most direct instrumentalities for such extension
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of meaning. Set going under adequate conditions they are magnets for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gathering and retaining an indefinitely wide scope of intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerations. They provide vital centers for the reception and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assimilation of information. When information is purveyed in chunks
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply as information to be retained for its own sake, it tends to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stratify over vital experience. Entering as a factor into an activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursued for its own sake--whether as a means or as a widening of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: content of the aim--it is informing. The insight directly gained fuses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with what is told. Individual experience is then capable of taking up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and holding in solution the net results of the experience of the group
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which he belongs--including the results of sufferings and trials over
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: long stretches of time. And such media have no fixed saturation point
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where further absorption is impossible. The more that is taken in, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater capacity there is for further assimilation. New receptiveness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: follows upon new curiosity, and new curiosity upon information gained.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The meanings with which activities become charged, concern nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and man. This is an obvious truism, which however gains meaning when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: translated into educational equivalents. So translated, it signifies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that geography and history supply subject matter which gives background
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and outlook, intellectual perspective, to what might otherwise be narrow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal actions or mere forms of technical skill. With every increase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of ability to place our own doings in their time and space connections,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our doings gain in significant content. We realize that we are citizens
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of no mean city in discovering the scene in space of which we are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: denizens, and the continuous manifestation of endeavor in time of which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we are heirs and continuers. Thus our ordinary daily experiences cease
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be things of the moment and gain enduring substance. Of course if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: geography and history are taught as ready-made studies which a person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies simply because he is sent to school, it easily happens that a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: large number of statements about things remote and alien to everyday
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience are learned. Activity is divided, and two separate worlds are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: built up, occupying activity at divided periods. No transmutation takes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: place; ordinary experience is not enlarged in meaning by getting its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections; what is studied is not animated and made real by entering
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into immediate activity. Ordinary experience is not even left as it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was, narrow but vital. Rather, it loses something of its mobility and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sensitiveness to suggestions. It is weighed down and pushed into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a corner by a load of unassimilated information. It parts with its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flexible responsiveness and alert eagerness for additional meaning. Mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: amassing of information apart from the direct interests of life makes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind wooden; elasticity disappears.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Normally every activity engaged in for its own sake reaches out beyond
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its immediate self. It does not passively wait for information to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bestowed which will increase its meaning; it seeks it out. Curiosity is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not an accidental isolated possession; it is a necessary consequence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fact that an experience is a moving, changing thing, involving all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kinds of connections with other things. Curiosity is but the tendency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to make these conditions perceptible. It is the business of educators to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supply an environment so that this reaching out of an experience may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitfully rewarded and kept continuously active. Within a certain kind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of environment, an activity may be checked so that the only meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which accrues is of its direct and tangible isolated outcome. One may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cook, or hammer, or walk, and the resulting consequences may not take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mind any farther than the consequences of cooking, hammering,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and walking in the literal--or physical--sense. But nevertheless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the consequences of the act remain far-reaching. To walk involves a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: displacement and reaction of the resisting earth, whose thrill is felt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wherever there is matter. It involves the structure of the limbs and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nervous system; the principles of mechanics. To cook is to utilize heat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and moisture to change the chemical relations of food materials; it has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a bearing upon the assimilation of food and the growth of the body. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utmost that the most learned men of science know in physics, chemistry,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physiology is not enough to make all these consequences and connections
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceptible. The task of education, once more, is to see to it that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such activities are performed in such ways and under such conditions as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: render these conditions as perceptible as possible. To "learn geography"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to gain in power to perceive the spatial, the natural, connections of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an ordinary act; to "learn history" is essentially to gain in power
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to recognize its human connections. For what is called geography as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulated study is simply the body of facts and principles which have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been discovered in other men's experience about the natural medium in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which we live, and in connection with which the particular acts of our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life have an explanation. So history as a formulated study is but the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: body of known facts about the activities and sufferings of the social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: groups with which our own lives are continuous, and through reference to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which our own customs and institutions are illuminated.

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: looked upon as a vain fancy, or as supplying a high-sounding phraseology
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in support of what is already done. The words "history" and "geography"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggest simply the matter which has been traditionally sanctioned in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The function of historical and geographical subject matter has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stated; it is to enrich and liberate the more direct and personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contacts of life by furnishing their context, their background and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outlook. While geography emphasizes the physical side and history
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the social, these are only emphases in a common topic, namely, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its ways and means, its achievements and failures, does not go on in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sky nor yet in a vacuum. It takes place on the earth. This setting of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimuli; it supplies obstacles and resources. Civilization is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Geography, of course, has its educative influence in a counterpart
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection of natural facts with social events and their consequences.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this definition than it is to present specific geographical subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter in its vital human bearings. The residence, pursuits, successes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and failures of men are the things that give the geographic data their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a state. The earth as the home of man is humanizing and unified; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inert. Geography is a topic that originally appeals to imagination--even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulation. The mind is moved from the monotony of the customary.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. History and Present Social Life. The segregation which kills the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: is one-sided. It means equally that past events cannot be separated

author: Dewey, John

text: from the living present and retain meaning. The true starting point of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history is always some present situation with its problems.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This general principle may be briefly applied to a consideration of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bearing upon a number of points. The biographical method is generally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recommended as the natural mode of approach to historical study. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lives of great men, of heroes and leaders, make concrete and vital
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: historic episodes otherwise abstract and incomprehensible. They condense
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into vivid pictures complicated and tangled series of events spread over
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so much space and time that only a highly trained mind can follow and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unravel them. There can be no doubt of the psychological soundness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of this principle. But it is misused when employed to throw into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exaggerated relief the doings of a few individuals without reference to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the social situations which they represent. When a biography is related
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just as an account of the doings of a man isolated from the conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that aroused him and to which his activities were a response, we do not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have a study of history, for we have no study of social life, which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an affair of individuals in association. We get only a sugar coating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which makes it easier to swallow certain fragments of information. Much
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention has been given of late to primitive life as an introduction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to learning history. Here also there is a right and a wrong way of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceiving its value. The seemingly ready-made character and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complexity of present conditions, their apparently hard and fast
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: character, is an almost insuperable obstacle to gaining insight into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their nature. Recourse to the primitive may furnish the fundamental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elements of the present situation in immensely simplified form. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like unraveling a cloth so complex and so close to the eyes that its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scheme cannot be seen, until the larger coarser features of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pattern appear. We cannot simplify the present situations by deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiment, but resort to primitive life presents us with the sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results we should desire from an experiment. Social relationships and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modes of organized action are reduced to their lowest terms. When this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social aim is overlooked, however, the study of primitive life becomes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply a rehearsing of sensational and exciting features of savagery.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Primitive history suggests industrial history. For one of the chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasons for going to more primitive conditions to resolve the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into more easily perceived factors is that we may realize how the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fundamental problems of procuring subsistence, shelter, and protection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been met; and by seeing how these were solved in the earlier days
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the human race, form some conception of the long road which has had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be traveled, and of the successive inventions by which the race has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been brought forward in culture. We do not need to go into disputes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarding the economic interpretation of history to realize that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial history of mankind gives insight into two important phases of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social life in a way which no other phase of history can possibly do.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It presents us with knowledge of the successive inventions by which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theoretical science has been applied to the control of nature in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests of security and prosperity of social life. It thus reveals the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successive causes of social progress. Its other service is to put
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: before us the things that fundamentally concern all men in common--the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations and values connected with getting a living. Economic history
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deals with the activities, the career, and fortunes of the common man as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does no other branch of history. The one thing every individual must do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to live; the one thing that society must do is to secure from each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual his fair contribution to the general well being and see to it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that a just return is made to him.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Economic history is more human, more democratic, and hence more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: liberalizing than political history. It deals not with the rise and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fall of principalities and powers, but with the growth of the effective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: liberties, through command of nature, of the common man for whom powers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and principalities exist.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Industrial history also offers a more direct avenue of approach to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization of the intimate connection of man's struggles, successes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and failures with nature than does political history--to say nothing of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the military history into which political history so easily runs when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reduced to the level of youthful comprehension. For industrial history
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is essentially an account of the way in which man has learned to utilize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural energy from the time when men mostly exploited the muscular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energies of other men to the time when, in promise if not in actuality,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the resources of nature are so under command as to enable men to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extend a common dominion over her. When the history of work, when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the conditions of using the soil, forest, mine, of domesticating and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultivating grains and animals, of manufacture and distribution,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are left out of account, history tends to become merely literary--a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systematized romance of a mythical humanity living upon itself instead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of upon the earth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Perhaps the most neglected branch of history in general education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual history. We are only just beginning to realize that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: great heroes who have advanced human destiny are not its politicians,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generals, and diplomatists, but the scientific discoverers and inventors
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who have put into man's hands the instrumentalities of an expanding and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlled experience, and the artists and poets who have celebrated his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: struggles, triumphs, and defeats in such language, pictorial, plastic,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or written, that their meaning is rendered universally accessible to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others. One of the advantages of industrial history as a history of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man's progressive adaptation of natural forces to social uses is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunity which it affords for consideration of advance in the methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and results of knowledge. At present men are accustomed to eulogize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence and reason in general terms; their fundamental importance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is urged. But pupils often come away from the conventional study of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history, and think either that the human intellect is a static quantity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which has not progressed by the invention of better methods, or else
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that intelligence, save as a display of personal shrewdness, is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: negligible historic factor. Surely no better way could be devised of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instilling a genuine sense of the part which mind has to play in life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than a study of history which makes plain how the entire advance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of humanity from savagery to civilization has been dependent upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual discoveries and inventions, and the extent to which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which ordinarily figure most largely in historical writings have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been side issues, or even obstructions for intelligence to overcome.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Pursued in this fashion, history would most naturally become of ethical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value in teaching. Intelligent insight into present forms of associated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life is necessary for a character whose morality is more than colorless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: innocence. Historical knowledge helps provide such insight. It is an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organ for analysis of the warp and woof of the present social fabric, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making known the forces which have woven the pattern. The use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history for cultivating a socialized intelligence constitutes its moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance. It is possible to employ it as a kind of reservoir of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anecdotes to be drawn on to inculcate special moral lessons on this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: virtue or that vice. But such teaching is not so much an ethical use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history as it is an effort to create moral impressions by means of more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or less authentic material. At best, it produces a temporary emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: glow; at worst, callous indifference to moralizing. The assistance which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be given by history to a more intelligent sympathetic understanding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the social situations of the present in which individuals share is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: permanent and constructive moral asset.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. It is the nature of an experience to have implications which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: go far beyond what is at first consciously noted in it. Bringing these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections or implications to consciousness enhances the meaning of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. Any experience, however trivial in its first appearance, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capable of assuming an indefinite richness of significance by extending
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its range of perceived connections. Normal communication with others is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the readiest way of effecting this development, for it links up the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: net results of the experience of the group and even the race with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate experience of an individual. By normal communication is meant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that in which there is a joint interest, a common interest, so that one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is eager to give and the other to take. It contrasts with telling or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stating things simply for the sake of impressing them upon another,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely in order to test him to see how much he has retained and can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literally reproduce.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Geography and history are the two great school resources for bringing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the enlargement of the significance of a direct personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. The active occupations described in the previous chapter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reach out in space and time with respect to both nature and man. Unless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are taught for external reasons or as mere modes of skill their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: chief educational value is that they provide the most direct and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interesting roads out into the larger world of meanings stated in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history and geography. While history makes human implications explicit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and geography natural connections, these subjects are two phases of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the same living whole, since the life of men in association goes on in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature, not as an accidental setting, but as the material and medium of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development.
