text: Chapter Seventeen: Science in the Course of Study
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Logical and the Psychological. By science is meant, as already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stated, that knowledge which is the outcome of methods of observation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflection, and testing which are deliberately adopted to secure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a settled, assured subject matter. It involves an intelligent and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persistent endeavor to revise current beliefs so as to weed out what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: erroneous, to add to their accuracy, and, above all, to give them such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shape that the dependencies of the various facts upon one another may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be as obvious as possible. It is, like all knowledge, an outcome of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity bringing about certain changes in the environment. But in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: case, the quality of the resulting knowledge is the controlling factor
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and not an incident of the activity. Both logically and educationally,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science is the perfecting of knowing, its last stage.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Science, in short, signifies a realization of the logical implications
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of any knowledge. Logical order is not a form imposed upon what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: known; it is the proper form of knowledge as perfected. For it means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the statement of subject matter is of a nature to exhibit to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one who understands it the premises from which it follows and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusions to which it points (See ante, p. 190). As from a few bones
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the competent zoologist reconstructs an animal; so from the form of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement in mathematics or physics the specialist in the subject can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form an idea of the system of truths in which it has its place.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To the non-expert, however, this perfected form is a stumbling block.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Just because the material is stated with reference to the furtherance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowledge as an end in itself, its connections with the material of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everyday life are hidden. To the layman the bones are a mere curiosity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Until he had mastered the principles of zoology, his efforts to make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anything out of them would be random and blind. From the standpoint of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the learner scientific form is an ideal to be achieved, not a starting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point from which to set out. It is, nevertheless, a frequent practice to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: start in instruction with the rudiments of science somewhat simplified.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The necessary consequence is an isolation of science from significant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. The pupil learns symbols without the key to their meaning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He acquires a technical body of information without ability to trace
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its connections with the objects and operations with which he is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: familiar--often he acquires simply a peculiar vocabulary. There is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a strong temptation to assume that presenting subject matter in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perfected form provides a royal road to learning. What more natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than to suppose that the immature can be saved time and energy, and be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: protected from needless error by commencing where competent inquirers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have left off? The outcome is written large in the history of education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Pupils begin their study of science with texts in which the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is organized into topics according to the order of the specialist.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Technical concepts, with their definitions, are introduced at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outset. Laws are introduced at a very early stage, with at best a few
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indications of the way in which they were arrived at. The pupils learn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a "science" instead of learning the scientific way of treating the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: familiar material of ordinary experience. The method of the advanced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: student dominates college teaching; the approach of the college is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transferred into the high school, and so down the line, with such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: omissions as may make the subject easier.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The chronological method which begins with the experience of the learner
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and develops from that the proper modes of scientific treatment is often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: called the "psychological" method in distinction from the logical method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the expert or specialist. The apparent loss of time involved is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more than made up for by the superior understanding and vital interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: secured. What the pupil learns he at least understands. Moreover by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following, in connection with problems selected from the material of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ordinary acquaintance, the methods by which scientific men have reached
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their perfected knowledge, he gains independent power to deal with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material within his range, and avoids the mental confusion and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual distaste attendant upon studying matter whose meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is only symbolic. Since the mass of pupils are never going to become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific specialists, it is much more important that they should get
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some insight into what scientific method means than that they should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: copy at long range and second hand the results which scientific men have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reached. Students will not go so far, perhaps, in the "ground covered,"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but they will be sure and intelligent as far as they do go. And it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: safe to say that the few who go on to be scientific experts will have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a better preparation than if they had been swamped with a large mass of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purely technical and symbolically stated information. In fact, those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who do become successful men of science are those who by their own power
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manage to avoid the pitfalls of a traditional scholastic introduction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The contrast between the expectations of the men who a generation or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: two ago strove, against great odds, to secure a place for science
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in education, and the result generally achieved is painful. Herbert
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Spencer, inquiring what knowledge is of most worth, concluded that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from all points of view scientific knowledge is most valuable. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his argument unconsciously assumed that scientific knowledge could be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: communicated in a ready-made form. Passing over the methods by which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of our ordinary activities is transmuted into scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form, it ignored the method by which alone science is science.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Instruction has too often proceeded upon an analogous plan. But there is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no magic attached to material stated in technically correct scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form. When learned in this condition it remains a body of inert
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information. Moreover its form of statement removes it further from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitful contact with everyday experiences than does the mode of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement proper to literature. Nevertheless that the claims made for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction in science were unjustifiable does not follow. For material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so taught is not science to the pupil.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Contact with things and laboratory exercises, while a great improvement
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon textbooks arranged upon the deductive plan, do not of themselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suffice to meet the need. While they are an indispensable portion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of scientific method, they do not as a matter of course constitute
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific method. Physical materials may be manipulated with scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apparatus, but the materials may be disassociated in themselves and in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ways in which they are handled, from the materials and processes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: used out of school. The problems dealt with may be only problems of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science: problems, that is, which would occur to one already initiated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the science of the subject. Our attention may be devoted to getting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: skill in technical manipulation without reference to the connection of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: laboratory exercises with a problem belonging to subject matter. There
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is sometimes a ritual of laboratory instruction as well as of heathen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: religion. 1 It has been mentioned, incidentally, that scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statements, or logical form, implies the use of signs or symbols.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The statement applies, of course, to all use of language. But in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vernacular, the mind proceeds directly from the symbol to the thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: signified. Association with familiar material is so close that the mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not pause upon the sign. The signs are intended only to stand for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things and acts. But scientific terminology has an additional use. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: designed, as we have seen, not to stand for the things directly in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practical use in experience, but for the things placed in a cognitive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: system. Ultimately, of course, they denote the things of our common
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense acquaintance. But immediately they do not designate them in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: common context, but translated into terms of scientific inquiry. Atoms,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: molecules, chemical formulae, the mathematical propositions in the study
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of physics--all these have primarily an intellectual value and only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indirectly an empirical value. They represent instruments for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the carrying on of science. As in the case of other tools, their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance can be learned only by use. We cannot procure understanding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their meaning by pointing to things, but only by pointing to their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work when they are employed as part of the technique of knowledge. Even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the circle, square, etc., of geometry exhibit a difference from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: squares and circles of familiar acquaintance, and the further one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proceeds in mathematical science the greater the remoteness from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everyday empirical thing. Qualities which do not count for the pursuit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowledge about spatial relations are left out; those which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important for this purpose are accentuated. If one carries his study
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: far enough, he will find even the properties which are significant for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spatial knowledge giving way to those which facilitate knowledge of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other things--perhaps a knowledge of the general relations of number.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There will be nothing in the conceptual definitions even to suggest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spatial form, size, or direction. This does not mean that they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unreal mental inventions, but it indicates that direct physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities have been transmuted into tools for a special end--the end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of intellectual organization. In every machine the primary state of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material has been modified by subordinating it to use for a purpose.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Not the stuff in its original form but in its adaptation to an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is important. No one would have a knowledge of a machine who could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enumerate all the materials entering into its structure, but only he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who knew their uses and could tell why they are employed as they are. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like fashion one has a knowledge of mathematical conceptions only when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he sees the problems in which they function and their specific utility
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in dealing with these problems. "Knowing" the definitions, rules,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulae, etc., is like knowing the names of parts of a machine without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowing what they do. In one case, as in the other, the meaning, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual content, is what the element accomplishes in the system of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which it is a member.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Science and Social Progress. Assuming that the development of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct knowledge gained in occupations of social interest is carried
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to a perfected logical form, the question arises as to its place in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. In general, the reply is that science marks the emancipation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind from devotion to customary purposes and makes possible the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systematic pursuit of new ends. It is the agency of progress in action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Progress is sometimes thought of as consisting in getting nearer to ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already sought. But this is a minor form of progress, for it requires
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only improvement of the means of action or technical advance. More
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important modes of progress consist in enriching prior purposes and in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forming new ones. Desires are not a fixed quantity, nor does progress
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mean only an increased amount of satisfaction. With increased culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and new mastery of nature, new desires, demands for new qualities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of satisfaction, show themselves, for intelligence perceives new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities of action. This projection of new possibilities leads to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: search for new means of execution, and progress takes place; while the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovery of objects not already used leads to suggestion of new ends.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: That science is the chief means of perfecting control of means of action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is witnessed by the great crop of inventions which followed intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: command of the secrets of nature. The wonderful transformation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: production and distribution known as the industrial revolution is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruit of experimental science. Railways, steamboats, electric motors,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: telephone and telegraph, automobiles, aeroplanes and dirigibles are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conspicuous evidences of the application of science in life. But none
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of them would be of much importance without the thousands of less
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sensational inventions by means of which natural science has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rendered tributary to our daily life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It must be admitted that to a considerable extent the progress thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: procured has been only technical: it has provided more efficient means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for satisfying preexistent desires, rather than modified the quality of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human purposes. There is, for example, no modern civilization which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the equal of Greek culture in all respects. Science is still too recent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to have been absorbed into imaginative and emotional disposition. Men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: move more swiftly and surely to the realization of their ends, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their ends too largely remain what they were prior to scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlightenment. This fact places upon education the responsibility of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: using science in a way to modify the habitual attitude of imagination
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and feeling, not leave it just an extension of our physical arms and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: legs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The advance of science has already modified men's thoughts of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposes and goods of life to a sufficient extent to give some idea of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the nature of this responsibility and the ways of meeting it. Science
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taking effect in human activity has broken down physical barriers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which formerly separated men; it has immensely widened the area of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse. It has brought about interdependence of interests on an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enormous scale. It has brought with it an established conviction of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibility of control of nature in the interests of mankind and thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has led men to look to the future, instead of the past. The coincidence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the ideal of progress with the advance of science is not a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: coincidence. Before this advance men placed the golden age in remote
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: antiquity. Now they face the future with a firm belief that intelligence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: properly used can do away with evils once thought inevitable. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subjugate devastating disease is no longer a dream; the hope of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abolishing poverty is not utopian. Science has familiarized men with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the idea of development, taking effect practically in persistent gradual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: amelioration of the estate of our common humanity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The problem of an educational use of science is then to create an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence pregnant with belief in the possibility of the direction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of human affairs by itself. The method of science engrained through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education in habit means emancipation from rule of thumb and from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: routine generated by rule of thumb procedure. The word empirical in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ordinary use does not mean "connected with experiment," but rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: crude and unrational. Under the influence of conditions created by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: non-existence of experimental science, experience was opposed in all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ruling philosophies of the past to reason and the truly rational.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Empirical knowledge meant the knowledge accumulated by a multitude of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past instances without intelligent insight into the principles of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of them. To say that medicine was empirical meant that it was not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific, but a mode of practice based upon accumulated observations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of diseases and of remedies used more or less at random. Such a mode of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practice is of necessity happy-go-lucky; success depends upon chance. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lends itself to deception and quackery. Industry that is "empirically"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controlled forbids constructive applications of intelligence; it depends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon following in an imitative slavish manner the models set in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the past. Experimental science means the possibility of using past
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences as the servant, not the master, of mind. It means that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason operates within experience, not beyond it, to give it an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligent or reasonable quality. Science is experience becoming
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rational. The effect of science is thus to change men's idea of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature and inherent possibilities of experience. By the same token, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: changes the idea and the operation of reason. Instead of being something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beyond experience, remote, aloof, concerned with a sublime region
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that has nothing to do with the experienced facts of life, it is found
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indigenous in experience:--the factor by which past experiences are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purified and rendered into tools for discovery and advance.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The term "abstract" has a rather bad name in popular speech, being used
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to signify not only that which is abstruse and hard to understand,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but also that which is far away from life. But abstraction is an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indispensable trait in reflective direction of activity. Situations do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not literally repeat themselves. Habit treats new occurrences as if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they were identical with old ones; it suffices, accordingly, when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different or novel element is negligible for present purposes. But when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the new element requires especial attention, random reaction is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sole recourse unless abstraction is brought into play. For abstraction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberately selects from the subject matter of former experiences that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is thought helpful in dealing with the new. It signifies conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transfer of a meaning embedded in past experience for use in a new one.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is the very artery of intelligence, of the intentional rendering of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one experience available for guidance of another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Science carries on this working over of prior subject matter on a large
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scale. It aims to free an experience from all which is purely personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and strictly immediate; it aims to detach whatever it has in common with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the subject matter of other experiences, and which, being common, may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be saved for further use. It is, thus, an indispensable factor in social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progress. In any experience just as it occurs there is much which,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while it may be of precious import to the individual implicated in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the experience, is peculiar and unreduplicable. From the standpoint
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of science, this material is accidental, while the features which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: widely shared are essential. Whatever is unique in the situation, since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dependent upon the peculiarities of the individual and the coincidence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of circumstance, is not available for others; so that unless what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shared is abstracted and fixed by a suitable symbol, practically all the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value of the experience may perish in its passing. But abstraction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the use of terms to record what is abstracted put the net value of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual experience at the permanent disposal of mankind. No one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can foresee in detail when or how it may be of further use. The man of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science in developing his abstractions is like a manufacturer of tools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who does not know who will use them nor when. But intellectual tools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are indefinitely more flexible in their range of adaptation than other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mechanical tools.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Generalization is the counterpart of abstraction. It is the functioning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of an abstraction in its application to a new concrete experience,--its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extension to clarify and direct new situations. Reference to these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible applications is necessary in order that the abstraction may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitful, instead of a barren formalism ending in itself. Generalization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is essentially a social device. When men identified their interests
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exclusively with the concerns of a narrow group, their generalizations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were correspondingly restricted. The viewpoint did not permit a wide and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: free survey. Men's thoughts were tied down to a contracted space and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: short time,--limited to their own established customs as a measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of all possible values. Scientific abstraction and generalization are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equivalent to taking the point of view of any man, whatever his location
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in time and space. While this emancipation from the conditions and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: episodes of concrete experiences accounts for the remoteness, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "abstractness," of science, it also accounts for its wide and free
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: range of fruitful novel applications in practice. Terms and propositions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: record, fix, and convey what is abstracted. A meaning detached from a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: given experience cannot remain hanging in the air. It must acquire a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: local habitation. Names give abstract meanings a physical locus and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: body. Formulation is thus not an after-thought or by-product; it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: essential to the completion of the work of thought. Persons know many
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which they cannot express, but such knowledge remains practical,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct, and personal. An individual can use it for himself; he may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: able to act upon it with efficiency. Artists and executives often have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their knowledge in this state. But it is personal, untransferable, and,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as it were, instinctive. To formulate the significance of an experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a man must take into conscious account the experiences of others. He
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must try to find a standpoint which includes the experience of others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as well as his own. Otherwise his communication cannot be understood. He
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: talks a language which no one else knows. While literary art furnishes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the supreme successes in stating of experiences so that they are vitally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significant to others, the vocabulary of science is designed, in another
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fashion, to express the meaning of experienced things in symbols which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any one will know who studies the science. Aesthetic formulation reveals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and enhances the meaning of experiences one already has; scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulation supplies one with tools for constructing new experiences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with transformed meanings.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To sum up: Science represents the office of intelligence, in projection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and control of new experiences, pursued systematically, intentionally,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and on a scale due to freedom from limitations of habit. It is the sole
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumentality of conscious, as distinct from accidental, progress.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And if its generality, its remoteness from individual conditions, confer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon it a certain technicality and aloofness, these qualities are very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different from those of merely speculative theorizing. The latter are in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: permanent dislocation from practice; the former are temporarily detached
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the sake of wider and freer application in later concrete action.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is a kind of idle theory which is antithetical to practice; but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: genuinely scientific theory falls within practice as the agency of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expansion and its direction to new possibilities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Naturalism and Humanism in Education. There exists an educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tradition which opposes science to literature and history in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum. The quarrel between the representatives of the two interests
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is easily explicable historically. Literature and language and a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literary philosophy were entrenched in all higher institutions of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning before experimental science came into being. The latter had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: naturally to win its way. No fortified and protected interest readily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surrenders any monopoly it may possess. But the assumption, from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whichever side, that language and literary products are exclusively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanistic in quality, and that science is purely physical in import,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is a false notion which tends to cripple the educational use of both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies. Human life does not occur in a vacuum, nor is nature a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stage setting for the enactment of its drama (ante, p. 211). Man's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life is bound up in the processes of nature; his career, for success or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: defeat, depends upon the way in which nature enters it. Man's power of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate control of his own affairs depends upon ability to direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural energies to use: an ability which is in turn dependent upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insight into nature's processes. Whatever natural science may be for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialist, for educational purposes it is knowledge of the conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of human action. To be aware of the medium in which social intercourse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: goes on, and of the means and obstacles to its progressive development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to be in command of a knowledge which is thoroughly humanistic in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality. One who is ignorant of the history of science is ignorant of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the struggles by which mankind has passed from routine and caprice, from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superstitious subjection to nature, from efforts to use it magically,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to intellectual self-possession. That science may be taught as a set of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formal and technical exercises is only too true. This happens whenever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information about the world is made an end in itself. The failure of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such instruction to procure culture is not, however, evidence of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: antithesis of natural knowledge to humanistic concern, but evidence of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wrong educational attitude. Dislike to employ scientific knowledge as it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: functions in men's occupations is itself a survival of an aristocratic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture. The notion that "applied" knowledge is somehow less worthy than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "pure" knowledge, was natural to a society in which all useful work was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: performed by slaves and serfs, and in which industry was controlled by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the models set by custom rather than by intelligence. Science, or the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: highest knowing, was then identified with pure theorizing, apart from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all application in the uses of life; and knowledge relating to useful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arts suffered the stigma attaching to the classes who engaged in them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (See below, Ch. XIX). The idea of science thus generated persisted after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science had itself adopted the appliances of the arts, using them for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the production of knowledge, and after the rise of democracy. Taking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory just as theory, however, that which concerns humanity is of more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance for man than that which concerns a merely physical world.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In adopting the criterion of knowledge laid down by a literary culture,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aloof from the practical needs of the mass of men, the educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advocates of scientific education put themselves at a strategic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disadvantage. So far as they adopt the idea of science appropriate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to its experimental method and to the movements of a democratic and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial society, they have no difficulty in showing that natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science is more humanistic than an alleged humanism which bases its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational schemes upon the specialized interests of a leisure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class. For, as we have already stated, humanistic studies when set
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in opposition to study of nature are hampered. They tend to reduce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves to exclusively literary and linguistic studies, which in turn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tend to shrink to "the classics," to languages no longer spoken. For
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modern languages may evidently be put to use, and hence fall under the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ban. It would be hard to find anything in history more ironical than the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational practices which have identified the "humanities"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exclusively with a knowledge of Greek and Latin. Greek and Roman art and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: institutions made such important contributions to our civilization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that there should always be the amplest opportunities for making their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquaintance. But to regard them as par excellence the humane studies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involves a deliberate neglect of the possibilities of the subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is accessible in education to the masses, and tends to cultivate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a narrow snobbery: that of a learned class whose insignia are the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accidents of exclusive opportunity. Knowledge is humanistic in quality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not because it is about human products in the past, but because of what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it does in liberating human intelligence and human sympathy. Any subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter which accomplishes this result is humane, and any subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which does not accomplish it is not even educational.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Science represents the fruition of the cognitive factors in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. Instead of contenting itself with a mere statement of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what commends itself to personal or customary experience, it aims at a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement which will reveal the sources, grounds, and consequences of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a belief. The achievement of this aim gives logical character to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the statements. Educationally, it has to be noted that logical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: characteristics of method, since they belong to subject matter which has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reached a high degree of intellectual elaboration, are different from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the method of the learner--the chronological order of passing from a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cruder to a more refined intellectual quality of experience. When this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact is ignored, science is treated as so much bare information, which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however is less interesting and more remote than ordinary information,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being stated in an unusual and technical vocabulary. The function which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science has to perform in the curriculum is that which it has performed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the race: emancipation from local and temporary incidents of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, and the opening of intellectual vistas unobscured by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accidents of personal habit and predilection. The logical traits of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abstraction, generalization, and definite formulation are all associated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with this function. In emancipating an idea from the particular context
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which it originated and giving it a wider reference the results of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the experience of any individual are put at the disposal of all men.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Thus ultimately and philosophically science is the organ of general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social progress. 1 Upon the positive side, the value of problems arising
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in work in the garden, the shop, etc., may be referred to (See p.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 200). The laboratory may be treated as an additional resource to supply
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions and appliances for the better pursuit of these problems.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
