text: Chapter Eighteen: Educational Values
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The considerations involved in a discussion of educational values have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already been brought out in the discussion of aims and interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The specific values usually discussed in educational theories coincide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with aims which are usually urged. They are such things as utility,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture, information, preparation for social efficiency, mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discipline or power, and so on. The aspect of these aims in virtue of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they are valuable has been treated in our analysis of the nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of interest, and there is no difference between speaking of art as an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest or concern and referring to it as a value. It happens,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: however, that discussion of values has usually been centered about a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consideration of the various ends subserved by specific subjects of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum. It has been a part of the attempt to justify those subjects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by pointing out the significant contributions to life accruing from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their study. An explicit discussion of educational values thus affords
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an opportunity for reviewing the prior discussion of aims and interests
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on one hand and of the curriculum on the other, by bringing them into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with one another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Nature of Realization or Appreciation. Much of our experience is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indirect; it is dependent upon signs which intervene between the things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and ourselves, signs which stand for or represent the former. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one thing to have been engaged in war, to have shared its dangers and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hardships; it is another thing to hear or read about it. All language,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all symbols, are implements of an indirect experience; in technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language the experience which is procured by their means is "mediated."
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It stands in contrast with an immediate, direct experience, something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which we take part vitally and at first hand, instead of through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the intervention of representative media. As we have seen, the scope of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal, vitally direct experience is very limited. If it were not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the intervention of agencies for representing absent and distant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affairs, our experience would remain almost on the level of that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brutes. Every step from savagery to civilization is dependent upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the invention of media which enlarge the range of purely immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience and give it deepened as well as wider meaning by connecting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it with things which can only be signified or symbolized. It is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doubtless this fact which is the cause of the disposition to identify
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an uncultivated person with an illiterate person--so dependent are we on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: letters for effective representative or indirect experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At the same time (as we have also had repeated occasion to see) there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is always a danger that symbols will not be truly representative; danger
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that instead of really calling up the absent and remote in a way to make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it enter a present experience, the linguistic media of representation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will become an end in themselves. Formal education is peculiarly exposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to this danger, with the result that when literacy supervenes, mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bookishness, what is popularly termed the academic, too often comes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with it. In colloquial speech, the phrase a "realizing sense" is used
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to express the urgency, warmth, and intimacy of a direct experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in contrast with the remote, pallid, and coldly detached quality of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a representative experience. The terms "mental realization" and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "appreciation" (or genuine appreciation) are more elaborate names for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the realizing sense of a thing. It is not possible to define these ideas
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: except by synonyms, like "coming home to one" "really taking it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in," etc., for the only way to appreciate what is meant by a direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience of a thing is by having it. But it is the difference between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reading a technical description of a picture, and seeing it; or between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just seeing it and being moved by it; between learning mathematical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: equations about light and being carried away by some peculiarly glorious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: illumination of a misty landscape. We are thus met by the danger of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendency of technique and other purely representative forms to encroach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the sphere of direct appreciations; in other words, the tendency to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assume that pupils have a foundation of direct realization of situations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sufficient for the superstructure of representative experience erected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by formulated school studies. This is not simply a matter of quantity or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bulk. Sufficient direct experience is even more a matter of quality; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be of a sort to connect readily and fruitfully with the symbolic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material of instruction. Before teaching can safely enter upon conveying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts and ideas through the media of signs, schooling must provide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: genuine situations in which personal participation brings home the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: import of the material and the problems which it conveys. From the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standpoint of the pupil, the resulting experiences are worth while on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own account; from the standpoint of the teacher they are also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means of supplying subject matter required for understanding instruction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involving signs, and of evoking attitudes of open-mindedness and concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to the material symbolically conveyed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the outline given of the theory of educative subject matter, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: demand for this background of realization or appreciation is met by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the provision made for play and active occupations embodying typical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations. Nothing need be added to what has already been said except
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to point out that while the discussion dealt explicitly with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of primary education, where the demand for the available
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: background of direct experience is most obvious, the principle applies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the primary or elementary phase of every subject. The first and basic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: function of laboratory work, for example, in a high school or college in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a new field, is to familiarize the student at first hand with a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: range of facts and problems--to give him a "feeling" for them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Getting command of technique and of methods of reaching and testing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generalizations is at first secondary to getting appreciation. As
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regards the primary school activities, it is to be borne in mind that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fundamental intent is not to amuse nor to convey information with a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: minimum of vexation nor yet to acquire skill,--though these results
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may accrue as by-products,--but to enlarge and enrich the scope of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, and to keep alert and effective the interest in intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progress.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The rubric of appreciation supplies an appropriate head for bringing out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: three further principles: the nature of effective or real (as distinct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from nominal) standards of value; the place of the imagination in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciative realizations; and the place of the fine arts in the course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of study.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The nature of standards of valuation. Every adult has acquired, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the course of his prior experience and education, certain measures of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the worth of various sorts of experience. He has learned to look upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities like honesty, amiability, perseverance, loyalty, as moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: goods; upon certain classics of literature, painting, music, as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aesthetic values, and so on. Not only this, but he has learned certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rules for these values--the golden rule in morals; harmony, balance,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc., proportionate distribution in aesthetic goods; definition,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clarity, system in intellectual accomplishments. These principles are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so important as standards of judging the worth of new experiences that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parents and instructors are always tending to teach them directly to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: young. They overlook the danger that standards so taught will be merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: symbolic; that is, largely conventional and verbal. In reality, working
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as distinct from professed standards depend upon what an individual has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself specifically appreciated to be deeply significant in concrete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situations. An individual may have learned that certain characteristics
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are conventionally esteemed in music; he may be able to converse with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some correctness about classic music; he may even honestly believe that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these traits constitute his own musical standards. But if in his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past experience, what he has been most accustomed to and has most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enjoyed is ragtime, his active or working measures of valuation are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fixed on the ragtime level. The appeal actually made to him in his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal realization fixes his attitude much more deeply than what he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has been taught as the proper thing to say; his habitual disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thus fixed forms his real "norm" of valuation in subsequent musical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Probably few would deny this statement as to musical taste. But it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: applies equally well in judgments of moral and intellectual worth. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: youth who has had repeated experience of the full meaning of the value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of kindliness toward others built into his disposition has a measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the worth of generous treatment of others. Without this vital
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciation, the duty and virtue of unselfishness impressed upon him by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others as a standard remains purely a matter of symbols which he cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequately translate into realities. His "knowledge" is second-handed;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is only a knowledge that others prize unselfishness as an excellence,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and esteem him in the degree in which he exhibits it. Thus there grows
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up a split between a person's professed standards and his actual ones.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A person may be aware of the results of this struggle between his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inclinations and his theoretical opinions; he suffers from the conflict
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between doing what is really dear to him and what he has learned will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: win the approval of others. But of the split itself he is unaware;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the result is a kind of unconscious hypocrisy, an instability of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition. In similar fashion, a pupil who has worked through some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confused intellectual situation and fought his way to clearing up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obscurities in a definite outcome, appreciates the value of clarity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and definition. He has a standard which can be depended upon. He may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be trained externally to go through certain motions of analysis and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: division of subject matter and may acquire information about the value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of these processes as standard logical functions, but unless it somehow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comes home to him at some point as an appreciation of his own, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance of the logical norms--so-called--remains as much an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external piece of information as, say, the names of rivers in China. He
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may be able to recite, but the recital is a mechanical rehearsal.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is, then, a serious mistake to regard appreciation as if it were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confined to such things as literature and pictures and music. Its scope
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is as comprehensive as the work of education itself. The formation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of habits is a purely mechanical thing unless habits are also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tastes--habitual modes of preference and esteem, an effective sense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: excellence. There are adequate grounds for asserting that the premium
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so often put in schools upon external "discipline," and upon marks and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rewards, upon promotion and keeping back, are the obverse of the lack of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention given to life situations in which the meaning of facts, ideas,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principles, and problems is vitally brought home.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Appreciative realizations are to be distinguished from symbolic or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: representative experiences. They are not to be distinguished from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the work of the intellect or understanding. Only a personal response
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involving imagination can possibly procure realization even of pure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "facts." The imagination is the medium of appreciation in every field.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The engagement of the imagination is the only thing that makes any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity more than mechanical. Unfortunately, it is too customary to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identify the imaginative with the imaginary, rather than with a warm and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intimate taking in of the full scope of a situation. This leads to an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exaggerated estimate of fairy tales, myths, fanciful symbols, verse, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something labeled "Fine Art," as agencies for developing imagination and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciation; and, by neglecting imaginative vision in other matters,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leads to methods which reduce much instruction to an unimaginative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquiring of specialized skill and amassing of a load of information.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Theory, and--to some extent--practice, have advanced far enough to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognize that play-activity is an imaginative enterprise. But it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: still usual to regard this activity as a specially marked-off stage of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: childish growth, and to overlook the fact that the difference between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: play and what is regarded as serious employment should be not a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference between the presence and absence of imagination, but a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference in the materials with which imagination is occupied. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result is an unwholesome exaggeration of the phantastic and "unreal"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: phases of childish play and a deadly reduction of serious occupation to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a routine efficiency prized simply for its external tangible results.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Achievement comes to denote the sort of thing that a well-planned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: machine can do better than a human being can, and the main effect of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education, the achieving of a life of rich significance, drops by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: wayside. Meantime mind-wandering and wayward fancy are nothing but the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unsuppressible imagination cut loose from concern with what is done.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: An adequate recognition of the play of imagination as the medium of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization of every kind of thing which lies beyond the scope of direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical response is the sole way of escape from mechanical methods in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching. The emphasis put in this book, in accord with many tendencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in contemporary education, upon activity, will be misleading if it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not recognized that the imagination is as much a normal and integral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part of human activity as is muscular movement. The educative value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of manual activities and of laboratory exercises, as well as of play,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: depends upon the extent in which they aid in bringing about a sensing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the meaning of what is going on. In effect, if not in name, they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dramatizations. Their utilitarian value in forming habits of skill to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: used for tangible results is important, but not when isolated from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciative side. Were it not for the accompanying play of imagination,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there would be no road from a direct activity to representative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge; for it is by imagination that symbols are translated over
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into a direct meaning and integrated with a narrower activity so as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expand and enrich it. When the representative creative imagination is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made merely literary and mythological, symbols are rendered mere means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of directing physical reactions of the organs of speech.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. In the account previously given nothing was explicitly said about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the place of literature and the fine arts in the course of study. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: omission at that point was intentional. At the outset, there is no sharp
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: demarcation of useful, or industrial, arts and fine arts. The activities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mentioned in Chapter XV contain within themselves the factors later
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discriminated into fine and useful arts. As engaging the emotions and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the imagination, they have the qualities which give the fine arts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their quality. As demanding method or skill, the adaptation of tools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to materials with constantly increasing perfection, they involve the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: element of technique indispensable to artistic production. From the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standpoint of product, or the work of art, they are naturally defective,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: though even in this respect when they comprise genuine appreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they often have a rudimentary charm. As experiences they have both an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: artistic and an esthetic quality. When they emerge into activities which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are tested by their product and when the socially serviceable value of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the product is emphasized, they pass into useful or industrial arts.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When they develop in the direction of an enhanced appreciation of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediate qualities which appeal to taste, they grow into fine arts.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In one of its meanings, appreciation is opposed to depreciation. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: denotes an enlarged, an intensified prizing, not merely a prizing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much less--like depreciation--a lowered and degraded prizing. This
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enhancement of the qualities which make any ordinary experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appealing, appropriable--capable of full assimilation--and enjoyable,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes the prime function of literature, music, drawing, painting,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc., in education. They are not the exclusive agencies of appreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the most general sense of that word; but they are the chief agencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of an intensified, enhanced appreciation. As such, they are not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intrinsically and directly enjoyable, but they serve a purpose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beyond themselves. They have the office, in increased degree, of all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appreciation in fixing taste, in forming standards for the worth of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: later experiences. They arouse discontent with conditions which fall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: below their measure; they create a demand for surroundings coming up to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their own level. They reveal a depth and range of meaning in experiences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which otherwise might be mediocre and trivial. They supply, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, organs of vision. Moreover, in their fullness they represent the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concentration and consummation of elements of good which are otherwise
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scattered and incomplete. They select and focus the elements of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enjoyable worth which make any experience directly enjoyable. They are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not luxuries of education, but emphatic expressions of that which makes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any education worth while.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Valuation of Studies. The theory of educational values involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not only an account of the nature of appreciation as fixing the measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of subsequent valuations, but an account of the specific directions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which these valuations occur. To value means primarily to prize, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: esteem; but secondarily it means to apprise, to estimate. It means, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, the act of cherishing something, holding it dear, and also the act
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of passing judgment upon the nature and amount of its value as compared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with something else. To value in the latter sense is to valuate or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evaluate. The distinction coincides with that sometimes made between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intrinsic and instrumental values. Intrinsic values are not objects of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: judgment, they cannot (as intrinsic) be compared, or regarded as greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and less, better or worse. They are invaluable; and if a thing is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: invaluable, it is neither more nor less so than any other invaluable.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But occasions present themselves when it is necessary to choose, when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we must let one thing go in order to take another. This establishes an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: order of preference, a greater and less, better and worse. Things judged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or passed upon have to be estimated in relation to some third thing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some further end. With respect to that, they are means, or instrumental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: values.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We may imagine a man who at one time thoroughly enjoys converse with his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: friends, at another the hearing of a symphony; at another the eating of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his meals; at another the reading of a book; at another the earning of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: money, and so on. As an appreciative realization, each of these is an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intrinsic value. It occupies a particular place in life; it serves its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own end, which cannot be supplied by a substitute. There is no question
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of comparative value, and hence none of valuation. Each is the specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good which it is, and that is all that can be said. In its own place,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: none is a means to anything beyond itself. But there may arise a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: situation in which they compete or conflict, in which a choice has to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made. Now comparison comes in. Since a choice has to be made, we want
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to know the respective claims of each competitor. What is to be said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for it? What does it offer in comparison with, as balanced over against,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some other possibility? Raising these questions means that a particular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good is no longer an end in itself, an intrinsic good. For if it were,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its claims would be incomparable, imperative. The question is now as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to its status as a means of realizing something else, which is then the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: invaluable of that situation. If a man has just eaten, or if he is well
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fed generally and the opportunity to hear music is a rarity, he will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: probably prefer the music to eating. In the given situation that will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: render the greater contribution. If he is starving, or if he is satiated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with music for the time being, he will naturally judge food to have the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater worth. In the abstract or at large, apart from the needs of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particular situation in which choice has to be made, there is no such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing as degrees or order of value. Certain conclusions follow with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respect to educational values. We cannot establish a hierarchy of values
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: among studies. It is futile to attempt to arrange them in an order,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beginning with one having least worth and going on to that of maximum
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value. In so far as any study has a unique or irreplaceable function in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, in so far as it marks a characteristic enrichment of life,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its worth is intrinsic or incomparable. Since education is not a means
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to living, but is identical with the operation of living a life which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fruitful and inherently significant, the only ultimate value which can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be set up is just the process of living itself. And this is not an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to which studies and activities are subordinate means; it is the whole
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of which they are ingredients. And what has been said about appreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means that every study in one of its aspects ought to have just such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ultimate significance. It is true of arithmetic as it is of poetry that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in some place and at some time it ought to be a good to be appreciated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on its own account--just as an enjoyable experience, in short. If it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not, then when the time and place come for it to be used as a means or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumentality, it will be in just that much handicapped. Never having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been realized or appreciated for itself, one will miss something of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacity as a resource for other ends.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It equally follows that when we compare studies as to their values,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that is, treat them as means to something beyond themselves, that which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: controls their proper valuation is found in the specific situation in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they are to be used. The way to enable a student to apprehend the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumental value of arithmetic is not to lecture him upon the benefit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it will be to him in some remote and uncertain future, but to let him
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discover that success in something he is interested in doing depends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon ability to use number.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It also follows that the attempt to distribute distinct sorts of value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: among different studies is a misguided one, in spite of the amount of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time recently devoted to the undertaking. Science for example may have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any kind of value, depending upon the situation into which it enters
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as a means. To some the value of science may be military; it may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an instrument in strengthening means of offense or defense; it may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technological, a tool for engineering; or it may be commercial--an aid
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the successful conduct of business; under other conditions, its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: worth may be philanthropic--the service it renders in relieving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human suffering; or again it may be quite conventional--of value in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: establishing one's social status as an "educated" person. As matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact, science serves all these purposes, and it would be an arbitrary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: task to try to fix upon one of them as its "real" end. All that we can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be sure of educationally is that science should be taught so as to be an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end in itself in the lives of students--something worth while on account
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of its own unique intrinsic contribution to the experience of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Primarily it must have "appreciation value." If we take something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which seems to be at the opposite pole, like poetry, the same sort of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: statement applies. It may be that, at the present time, its chief value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the contribution it makes to the enjoyment of leisure. But that may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent a degenerate condition rather than anything necessary. Poetry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has historically been allied with religion and morals; it has served the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose of penetrating the mysterious depths of things. It has had an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enormous patriotic value. Homer to the Greeks was a Bible, a textbook
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of morals, a history, and a national inspiration. In any case, it may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be said that an education which does not succeed in making poetry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a resource in the business of life as well as in its leisure, has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something the matter with it--or else the poetry is artificial poetry.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The same considerations apply to the value of a study or a topic of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a study with reference to its motivating force. Those responsible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for planning and teaching the course of study should have grounds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for thinking that the studies and topics included furnish both direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increments to the enriching of lives of the pupils and also materials
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they can put to use in other concerns of direct interest. Since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the curriculum is always getting loaded down with purely inherited
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: traditional matter and with subjects which represent mainly the energy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of some influential person or group of persons in behalf of something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dear to them, it requires constant inspection, criticism, and revision
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to make sure it is accomplishing its purpose. Then there is always the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: probability that it represents the values of adults rather than those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of children and youth, or those of pupils a generation ago rather than
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: those of the present day. Hence a further need for a critical outlook
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and survey. But these considerations do not mean that for a subject to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have motivating value to a pupil (whether intrinsic or instrumental)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the same thing as for him to be aware of the value, or to be able to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tell what the study is good for.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the first place, as long as any topic makes an immediate appeal, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not necessary to ask what it is good for. This is a question which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can be asked only about instrumental values. Some goods are not good for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: anything; they are just goods. Any other notion leads to an absurdity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For we cannot stop asking the question about an instrumental good, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whose value lies in its being good for something, unless there is at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some point something intrinsically good, good for itself. To a hungry,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: healthy child, food is a good of the situation; we do not have to bring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: him to consciousness of the ends subserved by food in order to supply a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motive to eat. The food in connection with his appetite is a motive. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same thing holds of mentally eager pupils with respect to many topics.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Neither they nor the teacher could possibly foretell with any exactness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the purposes learning is to accomplish in the future; nor as long as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eagerness continues is it advisable to try to specify particular goods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are to come of it. The proof of a good is found in the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the pupil responds; his response is use. His response to the material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shows that the subject functions in his life. It is unsound to urge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that, say, Latin has a value per se in the abstract, just as a study, as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a sufficient justification for teaching it. But it is equally absurd
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to argue that unless teacher or pupil can point out some definite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assignable future use to which it is to be put, it lacks justifying
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value. When pupils are genuinely concerned in learning Latin, that is of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself proof that it possesses value. The most which one is entitled to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ask in such cases is whether in view of the shortness of time, there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are not other things of intrinsic value which in addition have greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumental value.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This brings us to the matter of instrumental values--topics studied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because of some end beyond themselves. If a child is ill and his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appetite does not lead him to eat when food is presented, or if his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appetite is perverted so that he prefers candy to meat and vegetables,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious reference to results is indicated. He needs to be made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious of consequences as a justification of the positive or negative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value of certain objects. Or the state of things may be normal enough,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and yet an individual not be moved by some matter because he does not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: grasp how his attainment of some intrinsic good depends upon active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concern with what is presented. In such cases, it is obviously the part
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of wisdom to establish consciousness of connection. In general what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desirable is that a topic be presented in such a way that it either have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an immediate value, and require no justification, or else be perceived
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be a means of achieving something of intrinsic value. An instrumental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value then has the intrinsic value of being a means to an end. It may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be questioned whether some of the present pedagogical interest in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of values of studies is not either excessive or else too narrow.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Sometimes it appears to be a labored effort to furnish an apologetic for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: topics which no longer operate to any purpose, direct or indirect, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the lives of pupils. At other times, the reaction against useless lumber
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seems to have gone to the extent of supposing that no subject or topic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be taught unless some quite definite future utility can be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pointed out by those making the course of study or by the pupil himself,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unmindful of the fact that life is its own excuse for being; and that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definite utilities which can be pointed out are themselves justified
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only because they increase the experienced content of life itself. 3.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The Segregation and Organization of Values. It is of course possible to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: classify in a general way the various valuable phases of life. In order
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to get a survey of aims sufficiently wide (See ante, p. 110) to give
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: breadth and flexibility to the enterprise of education, there is some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advantage in such a classification. But it is a great mistake to regard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these values as ultimate ends to which the concrete satisfactions of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience are subordinate. They are nothing but generalizations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more or less adequate, of concrete goods. Health, wealth, efficiency,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sociability, utility, culture, happiness itself are only abstract
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms which sum up a multitude of particulars. To regard such things as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standards for the valuation of concrete topics and process of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to subordinate to an abstraction the concrete facts from which the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abstraction is derived. They are not in any true sense standards of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: valuation; these are found, as we have previously seen, in the specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realizations which form tastes and habits of preference. They are,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: another of the various pursuits of life. The idea is prevalent that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: teaching, but chiefly by Greek and Latin poetry; observation by science
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work in the laboratory, though some training is to be got from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: earlier stages of Latin and Greek; for expression, Greek and Latin
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: composition comes first and English composition next; for abstract
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasoning, mathematics stands almost alone; for concrete reasoning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
