title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Latin, one modern language, some history, some English literature, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one science." There is much in the wording of this passage which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irrelevant to our point and which must be discounted to make it clear.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The phraseology betrays the particular provincial tradition within
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the author is writing. There is the unquestioned assumption
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of "faculties" to be trained, and a dominant interest in the ancient
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: languages; there is comparative disregard of the earth on which men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happen to live and the bodies they happen to carry around with them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But with allowances made for these matters (even with their complete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: abandonment) we find much in contemporary educational philosophy which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: parallels the fundamental notion of parceling out special values to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: segregated studies. Even when some one end is set up as a standard of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value, like social efficiency or culture, it will often be found to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: are comprised. And although the general tendency is to allow a greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: variety of values to a given study than does the passage quoted, yet the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attempt to inventory a number of values attaching to each study and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to state the amount of each value which the given study possesses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emphasizes an implied educational disintegration.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As matter of fact, such schemes of values of studies are largely but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unconscious justifications of the curriculum with which one is familiar.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: One accepts, for the most part, the studies of the existing course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and then assigns values to them as a sufficient reason for their being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taught. Mathematics is said to have, for example, disciplinary value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in habituating the pupil to accuracy of statement and closeness of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reasoning; it has utilitarian value in giving command of the arts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of calculation involved in trade and the arts; culture value in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its enlargement of the imagination in dealing with the most general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relations of things; even religious value in its concept of the infinite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and allied ideas. But clearly mathematics does not accomplish such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results, because it is endowed with miraculous potencies called values;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it has these values if and when it accomplishes these results, and not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: otherwise. The statements may help a teacher to a larger vision of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible results to be effected by instruction in mathematical topics.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But unfortunately, the tendency is to treat the statement as indicating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: powers inherently residing in the subject, whether they operate or not,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and thus to give it a rigid justification. If they do not operate, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: blame is put not on the subject as taught, but on the indifference and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recalcitrancy of pupils.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This attitude toward subjects is the obverse side of the conception of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience or life as a patchwork of independent interests which exist
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: side by side and limit one another. Students of politics are familiar
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a check and balance theory of the powers of government. There are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supposed to be independent separate functions, like the legislative,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: executive, judicial, administrative, and all goes well if each of these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: checks all the others and thus creates an ideal balance. There is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy which might well be called the check and balance theory of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. Life presents a diversity of interests. Left to themselves,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they tend to encroach on one another. The ideal is to prescribe a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: special territory for each till the whole ground of experience is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: covered, and then see to it each remains within its own boundaries.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Politics, business, recreation, art, science, the learned professions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: polite intercourse, leisure, represent such interests. Each of these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ramifies into many branches: business into manual occupations, executive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: positions, bookkeeping, railroading, banking, agriculture, trade and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commerce, etc., and so with each of the others. An ideal education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would then supply the means of meeting these separate and pigeon-holed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests. And when we look at the schools, it is easy to get the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impression that they accept this view of the nature of adult life, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: set for themselves the task of meeting its demands. Each interest is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acknowledged as a kind of fixed institution to which something in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course of study must correspond. The course of study must then have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some civics and history politically and patriotically viewed: some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: utilitarian studies; some science; some art (mainly literature of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: course); some provision for recreation; some moral education; and so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on. And it will be found that a large part of current agitation about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schools is concerned with clamor and controversy about the due meed of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognition to be given to each of these interests, and with struggles
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to secure for each its due share in the course of study; or, if this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not seem feasible in the existing school system, then to secure a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new and separate kind of schooling to meet the need. In the multitude of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educations education is forgotten.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The obvious outcome is congestion of the course of study, overpressure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and distraction of pupils, and a narrow specialization fatal to the very
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: idea of education. But these bad results usually lead to more of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same sort of thing as a remedy. When it is perceived that after all the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requirements of a full life experience are not met, the deficiency is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not laid to the isolation and narrowness of the teaching of the existing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subjects, and this recognition made the basis of reorganization of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: system. No, the lack is something to be made up for by the introduction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of still another study, or, if necessary, another kind of school. And
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as a rule those who object to the resulting overcrowding and consequent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superficiality and distraction usually also have recourse to a merely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quantitative criterion: the remedy is to cut off a great many studies as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fads and frills, and return to the good old curriculum of the three R's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in elementary education and the equally good and equally old-fashioned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum of the classics and mathematics in higher education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The situation has, of course, its historic explanation. Various epochs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the past have had their own characteristic struggles and interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Each of these great epochs has left behind itself a kind of cultural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deposit, like a geologic stratum. These deposits have found their way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into educational institutions in the form of studies, distinct courses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of study, distinct types of schools. With the rapid change of political,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific, and economic interests in the last century, provision had to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be made for new values. Though the older courses resisted, they have had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at least in this country to retire their pretensions to a monopoly. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have not, however, been reorganized in content and aim; they have only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been reduced in amount. The new studies, representing the new interests,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have not been used to transform the method and aim of all instruction;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have been injected and added on. The result is a conglomerate, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cement of which consists in the mechanics of the school program or time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: table. Thence arises the scheme of values and standards of value which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we have mentioned.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This situation in education represents the divisions and separations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which obtain in social life. The variety of interests which should mark
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any rich and balanced experience have been torn asunder and deposited in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separate institutions with diverse and independent purposes and methods.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Business is business, science is science, art is art, politics is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: politics, social intercourse is social intercourse, morals is morals,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recreation is recreation, and so on. Each possesses a separate and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: independent province with its own peculiar aims and ways of proceeding.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Each contributes to the others only externally and accidentally. All of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them together make up the whole of life by just apposition and addition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: What does one expect from business save that it should furnish money,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be used in turn for making more money and for support of self and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: family, for buying books and pictures, tickets to concerts which may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: afford culture, and for paying taxes, charitable gifts and other things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of social and ethical value? How unreasonable to expect that the pursuit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of business should be itself a culture of the imagination, in breadth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and refinement; that it should directly, and not through the money which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it supplies, have social service for its animating principle and be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conducted as an enterprise in behalf of social organization! The same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing is to be said, mutatis mutandis, of the pursuit of art or science
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or politics or religion. Each has become specialized not merely in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its appliances and its demands upon time, but in its aim and animating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spirit. Unconsciously, our course of studies and our theories of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational values of studies reflect this division of interests. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point at issue in a theory of educational value is then the unity or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: integrity of experience. How shall it be full and varied without losing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unity of spirit? How shall it be one and yet not narrow and monotonous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in its unity? Ultimately, the question of values and a standard of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: values is the moral question of the organization of the interests of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. Educationally, the question concerns that organization of schools,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: materials, and methods which will operate to achieve breadth and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: richness of experience. How shall we secure breadth of outlook without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sacrificing efficiency of execution? How shall we secure the diversity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of interests, without paying the price of isolation? How shall the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual be rendered executive in his intelligence instead of at the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cost of his intelligence? How shall art, science, and politics reinforce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another in an enriched temper of mind instead of constituting ends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursued at one another's expense? How can the interests of life and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies which enforce them enrich the common experience of men instead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of dividing men from one another? With the questions of reorganization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thus suggested, we shall be concerned in the concluding chapters.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Fundamentally, the elements involved in a discussion of value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been covered in the prior discussion of aims and interests. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: since educational values are generally discussed in connection with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: claims of the various studies of the curriculum, the consideration
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of aim and interest is here resumed from the point of view of special
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies. The term "value" has two quite different meanings. On the one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hand, it denotes the attitude of prizing a thing finding it worth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while, for its own sake, or intrinsically. This is a name for a full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or complete experience. To value in this sense is to appreciate. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to value also means a distinctively intellectual act--an operation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of comparing and judging--to valuate. This occurs when direct full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience is lacking, and the question arises which of the various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities of a situation is to be preferred in order to reach a full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realization, or vital experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We must not, however, divide the studies of the curriculum into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the appreciative, those concerned with intrinsic value, and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumental, concerned with those which are of value or ends beyond
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves. The formation of proper standards in any subject depends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon a realization of the contribution which it makes to the immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance of experience, upon a direct appreciation. Literature and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fine arts are of peculiar value because they represent appreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at its best--a heightened realization of meaning through selection and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concentration. But every subject at some phase of its development should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possess, what is for the individual concerned with it, an aesthetic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Contribution to immediate intrinsic values in all their variety
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in experience is the only criterion for determining the worth of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrumental and derived values in studies. The tendency to assign
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separate values to each study and to regard the curriculum in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: entirety as a kind of composite made by the aggregation of segregated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: values is a result of the isolation of social groups and classes. Hence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is the business of education in a democratic social group to struggle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: against this isolation in order that the various interests may reinforce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and play into one another.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Nineteen: Labor and Leisure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Origin of the Opposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The isolation of aims and values which we have been considering leads to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opposition between them. Probably the most deep-seated antithesis which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has shown itself in educational history is that between education in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preparation for useful labor and education for a life of leisure. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bare terms "useful labor" and "leisure" confirm the statement already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made that the segregation and conflict of values are not self-inclosed,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but reflect a division within social life. Were the two functions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of gaining a livelihood by work and enjoying in a cultivated way the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities of leisure, distributed equally among the different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: members of a community, it would not occur to any one that there was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any conflict of educational agencies and aims involved. It would be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-evident that the question was how education could contribute most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effectively to both. And while it might be found that some materials of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction chiefly accomplished one result and other subject matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other, it would be evident that care must be taken to secure as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much overlapping as conditions permit; that is, the education which had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leisure more directly in view should indirectly reinforce as much as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible the efficiency and the enjoyment of work, while that aiming at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter should produce habits of emotion and intellect which would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: procure a worthy cultivation of leisure. These general considerations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are amply borne out by the historical development of educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy. The separation of liberal education from professional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and industrial education goes back to the time of the Greeks, and was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulated expressly on the basis of a division of classes into those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who had to labor for a living and those who were relieved from this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessity. The conception that liberal education, adapted to men in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: latter class, is intrinsically higher than the servile training given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the latter class reflected the fact that one class was free and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other servile in its social status. The latter class labored not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for its own subsistence, but also for the means which enabled the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superior class to live without personally engaging in occupations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: taking almost all the time and not of a nature to engage or reward
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: That a certain amount of labor must be engaged in goes without saying.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Human beings have to live and it requires work to supply the resources
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life. Even if we insist that the interests connected with getting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a living are only material and hence intrinsically lower than those
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connected with enjoyment of time released from labor, and even if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were admitted that there is something engrossing and insubordinate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in material interests which leads them to strive to usurp the place
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: belonging to the higher ideal interests, this would not--barring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fact of socially divided classes--lead to neglect of the kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education which trains men for the useful pursuits. It would rather lead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to scrupulous care for them, so that men were trained to be efficient in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them and yet to keep them in their place; education would see to it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that we avoided the evil results which flow from their being allowed to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: flourish in obscure purlieus of neglect. Only when a division of these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests coincides with a division of an inferior and a superior social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class will preparation for useful work be looked down upon with contempt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as an unworthy thing: a fact which prepares one for the conclusion that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the rigid identification of work with material interests, and leisure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with ideal interests is itself a social product. The educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulations of the social situation made over two thousand years ago
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been so influential and give such a clear and logical recognition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the implications of the division into laboring and leisure classes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that they deserve especial note. According to them, man occupies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: highest place in the scheme of animate existence. In part, he shares
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the constitution and functions of plants and animals--nutritive,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reproductive, motor or practical. The distinctively human function is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason existing for the sake of beholding the spectacle of the universe.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence the truly human end is the fullest possible of this distinctive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: human prerogative. The life of observation, meditation, cogitation, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speculation pursued as an end in itself is the proper life of man. From
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason moreover proceeds the proper control of the lower elements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of human nature--the appetites and the active, motor, impulses. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves greedy, insubordinate, lovers of excess, aiming only at their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own satiety, they observe moderation--the law of the mean--and serve
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desirable ends as they are subjected to the rule of reason.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Such is the situation as an affair of theoretical psychology and as most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequately stated by Aristotle. But this state of things is reflected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the constitution of classes of men and hence in the organization of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society. Only in a comparatively small number is the function of reason
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capable of operating as a law of life. In the mass of people, vegetative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and animal functions dominate. Their energy of intelligence is so feeble
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and inconstant that it is constantly overpowered by bodily appetite and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: passion. Such persons are not truly ends in themselves, for only reason
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes a final end. Like plants, animals and physical tools, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are means, appliances, for the attaining of ends beyond themselves,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: although unlike them they have enough intelligence to exercise a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discretion in the execution of the tasks committed to them. Thus by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature, and not merely by social convention, there are those who are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: slaves--that is, means for the ends of others. 1 The great body of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: artisans are in one important respect worse off than even slaves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Like the latter they are given up to the service of ends external to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves; but since they do not enjoy the intimate association with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the free superior class experienced by domestic slaves they remain on a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lower plane of excellence. Moreover, women are classed with slaves and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: craftsmen as factors among the animate instrumentalities of production
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and reproduction of the means for a free or rational life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Individually and collectively there is a gulf between merely living and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: living worthily. In order that one may live worthily he must first live,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and so with collective society. The time and energy spent upon mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life, upon the gaining of subsistence, detracts from that available for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities that have an inherent rational meaning; they also unfit for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the latter. Means are menial, the serviceable is servile. The true life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is possible only in the degree in which the physical necessities are had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without effort and without attention. Hence slaves, artisans, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: women are employed in furnishing the means of subsistence in order that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, those adequately equipped with intelligence, may live the life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of leisurely concern with things intrinsically worth while.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To these two modes of occupation, with their distinction of servile and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: free activities (or "arts") correspond two types of education: the base
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or mechanical and the liberal or intellectual. Some persons are trained
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by suitable practical exercises for capacity in doing things, for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ability to use the mechanical tools involved in turning out physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commodities and rendering personal service. This training is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere matter of habituation and technical skill; it operates through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: repetition and assiduity in application, not through awakening and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nurturing thought. Liberal education aims to train intelligence for its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proper office: to know. The less this knowledge has to do with practical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affairs, with making or producing, the more adequately it engages
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence. So consistently does Aristotle draw the line between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: menial and liberal education that he puts what are now called the "fine"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arts, music, painting, sculpture, in the same class with menial arts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so far as their practice is concerned. They involve physical agencies,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assiduity of practice, and external results. In discussing, for example,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education in music he raises the question how far the young should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be practiced in the playing of instruments. His answer is that such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practice and proficiency may be tolerated as conduce to appreciation;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that is, to understanding and enjoyment of music when played by slaves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or professionals. When professional power is aimed at, music sinks from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the liberal to the professional level. One might then as well teach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cooking, says Aristotle. Even a liberal concern with the works of fine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: art depends upon the existence of a hireling class of practitioners who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have subordinated the development of their own personality to attaining
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: skill in mechanical execution. The higher the activity the more purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental is it; the less does it have to do with physical things or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the body. The more purely mental it is, the more independent or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-sufficing is it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: These last words remind us that Aristotle again makes a distinction of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superior and inferior even within those living the life of reason. For
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is a distinction in ends and in free action, according as one's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life is merely accompanied by reason or as it makes reason its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: medium. That is to say, the free citizen who devotes himself to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: public life of his community, sharing in the management of its affairs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and winning personal honor and distinction, lives a life accompanied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by reason. But the thinker, the man who devotes himself to scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inquiry and philosophic speculation, works, so to speak, in reason, not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply by *. Even the activity of the citizen in his civic relations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in other words, retains some of the taint of practice, of external or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely instrumental doing. This infection is shown by the fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: civic activity and civic excellence need the help of others; one cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engage in public life all by himself. But all needs, all desires imply,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the philosophy of Aristotle, a material factor; they involve lack,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: privation; they are dependent upon something beyond themselves for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: completion. A purely intellectual life, however, one carries on by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself, in himself; such assistance as he may derive from others is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accidental, rather than intrinsic. In knowing, in the life of theory,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason finds its own full manifestation; knowing for the sake of knowing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irrespective of any application is alone independent, or self-sufficing.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence only the education that makes for power to know as an end in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself, without reference to the practice of even civic duties, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: truly liberal or free. 2. The Present Situation. If the Aristotelian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conception represented just Aristotle's personal view, it would be a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more or less interesting historical curiosity. It could be dismissed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as an illustration of the lack of sympathy or the amount of academic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pedantry which may coexist with extraordinary intellectual gifts.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But Aristotle simply described without confusion and without that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insincerity always attendant upon mental confusion, the life that was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: before him. That the actual social situation has greatly changed since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his day there is no need to say. But in spite of these changes, in spite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the abolition of legal serfdom, and the spread of democracy, with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the extension of science and of general education (in books, newspapers,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: travel, and general intercourse as well as in schools), there remains
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enough of a cleavage of society into a learned and an unlearned class,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a leisure and a laboring class, to make his point of view a most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlightening one from which to criticize the separation between culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and utility in present education. Behind the intellectual and abstract
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distinction as it figures in pedagogical discussion, there looms a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social distinction between those whose pursuits involve a minimum of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: self-directive thought and aesthetic appreciation, and those who are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerned more directly with things of the intelligence and with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control of the activities of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Aristotle was certainly permanently right when he said that "any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupation or art or study deserves to be called mechanical if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: renders the body or soul or intellect of free persons unfit for the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exercise and practice of excellence." The force of the statement is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: almost infinitely increased when we hold, as we nominally do at present,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that all persons, instead of a comparatively few, are free. For when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mass of men and all women were regarded as unfree by the very nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their bodies and minds, there was neither intellectual confusion nor
