text: mind as purely receptive. The more passive the mind is, the more truly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects will impress themselves upon it. For the mind to take a hand, so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to speak, would be for it in the very process of knowing to vitiate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: true knowledge--to defeat its own purpose. The ideal was a maximum of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: receptivity. Since the impressions made upon the mind by objects were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generally termed sensations, empiricism thus became a doctrine of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sensationalism--that is to say, a doctrine which identified knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the reception and association of sensory impressions. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: John Locke, the most influential of the empiricists, we find this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sensationalism mitigated by a recognition of certain mental faculties,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like discernment or discrimination, comparison, abstraction, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generalization which work up the material of sense into definite and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organized forms and which even evolve new ideas on their own account,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such as the fundamental conceptions of morals and mathematics. (See
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ante, p. 61.) But some of his successors, especially in France in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: latter part of the eighteenth century, carried his doctrine to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limit; they regarded discernment and judgment as peculiar sensations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made in us by the conjoint presence of other sensations. Locke had held
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the mind is a blank piece of paper, or a wax tablet with nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engraved on it at birth (a tabula rasa) so far as any contents of ideas
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were concerned, but had endowed it with activities to be exercised upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the material received. His French successors razed away the powers and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: derived them also from impressions received.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As we have earlier noted, this notion was fostered by the new interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in education as method of social reform. (See ante, p. 93.) The emptier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mind to begin with, the more it may be made anything we wish by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bringing the right influences to bear upon it. Thus Helvetius, perhaps
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the most extreme and consistent sensationalist, proclaimed that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education could do anything--that it was omnipotent. Within the sphere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of school instruction, empiricism found its directly beneficial office
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in protesting against mere book learning. If knowledge comes from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impressions made upon us by natural objects, it is impossible to procure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge without the use of objects which impress the mind. Words,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all kinds of linguistic symbols, in the lack of prior presentations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects with which they may be associated, convey nothing but sensations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their own shape and color--certainly not a very instructive kind of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge. Sensationalism was an extremely handy weapon with which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to combat doctrines and opinions resting wholly upon tradition and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authority. With respect to all of them, it set up a test: Where are the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: real objects from which these ideas and beliefs are received? If such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects could not be produced, ideas were explained as the result of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: false associations and combinations. Empiricism also insisted upon a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first-hand element. The impression must be made upon me, upon my
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind. The further we get away from this direct, first-hand source of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge, the more numerous the sources of error, and the vaguer the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resulting idea.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As might be expected, however, the philosophy was weak upon the positive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: side. Of course, the value of natural objects and firsthand acquaintance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was not dependent upon the truth of the theory. Introduced into the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schools they would do their work, even if the sensational theory about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the way in which they did it was quite wrong. So far, there is nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to complain of. But the emphasis upon sensationalism also operated to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence the way in which natural objects were employed, and to prevent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: full good being got from them. "Object lessons" tended to isolate the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere sense-activity and make it an end in itself. The more isolated the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: object, the more isolated the sensory quality, the more distinct the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense-impression as a unit of knowledge. The theory worked not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the direction of this mechanical isolation, which tended to reduce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instruction to a kind of physical gymnastic of the sense-organs (good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like any gymnastic of bodily organs, but not more so), but also to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the neglect of thinking. According to the theory there was no need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking in connection with sense-observation; in fact, in strict
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory such thinking would be impossible till afterwards, for thinking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consisted simply in combining and separating sensory units which had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been received without any participation of judgment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As a matter of fact, accordingly, practically no scheme of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon a purely sensory basis has ever been systematically tried, at least
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: after the early years of infancy. Its obvious deficiencies have caused
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it to be resorted to simply for filling in "rationalistic" knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (that is to say, knowledge of definitions, rules, classifications, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modes of application conveyed through symbols), and as a device for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lending greater "interest" to barren symbols. There are at least
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: three serious defects of sensationalistic empiricism as an educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy of knowledge. (a) the historical value of the theory was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: critical; it was a dissolvent of current beliefs about the world and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: political institutions. It was a destructive organ of criticism of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hard and fast dogmas. But the work of education is constructive, not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: critical. It assumes not old beliefs to be eliminated and revised, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the need of building up new experience into intellectual habitudes as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: correct as possible from the start. Sensationalism is highly unfitted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for this constructive task. Mind, understanding, denotes responsiveness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to meanings (ante, p. 29), not response to direct physical stimuli. And
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning exists only with reference to a context, which is excluded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by any scheme which identifies knowledge with a combination of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense-impressions. The theory, so far as educationally applied, led
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: either to a magnification of mere physical excitations or else to a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: heaping up of isolated objects and qualities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (b) While direct impression has the advantage of being first hand, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also has the disadvantage of being limited in range. Direct acquaintance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the natural surroundings of the home environment so as to give
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reality to ideas about portions of the earth beyond the reach of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: senses, and as a means of arousing intellectual curiosity, is one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing. As an end-all and be-all of geographical knowledge it is fatally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: restricted. In precisely analogous fashion, beans, shoe pegs, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: counters may be helpful aids to a realization of numerical relations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but when employed except as aids to thought--the apprehension of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning--they become an obstacle to the growth of arithmetical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understanding. They arrest growth on a low plane, the plane of specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical symbols. Just as the race developed especial symbols as tools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of calculation and mathematical reasonings, because the use of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fingers as numerical symbols got in the way, so the individual must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progress from concrete to abstract symbols--that is, symbols whose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning is realized only through conceptual thinking. And undue
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absorption at the outset in the physical object of sense hampers this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growth. (c) A thoroughly false psychology of mental development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: underlay sensationalistic empiricism. Experience is in truth a matter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of activities, instinctive and impulsive, in their interactions with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things. What even an infant "experiences" is not a passively received
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality impressed by an object, but the effect which some activity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: handling, throwing, pounding, tearing, etc., has upon an object, and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequent effect of the object upon the direction of activities. (See
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ante, p. 140.) Fundamentally (as we shall see in more detail), the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ancient notion of experience as a practical matter is truer to fact that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the modern notion of it as a mode of knowing by means of sensations. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: neglect of the deep-seated active and motor factors of experience is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fatal defect of the traditional empirical philosophy. Nothing is more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uninteresting and mechanical than a scheme of object lessons which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ignores and as far as may be excludes the natural tendency to learn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the qualities of objects by the uses to which they are put through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: trying to do something with them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is obvious, accordingly, that even if the philosophy of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represented by modern empiricism had received more general theoretical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assent than has been accorded to it, it could not have furnished
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a satisfactory philosophy of the learning process. Its educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence was confined to injecting a new factor into the older
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum, with incidental modifications of the older studies and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods. It introduced greater regard for observation of things directly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and through pictures and graphic descriptions, and it reduced the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: importance attached to verbal symbolization. But its own scope was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so meager that it required supplementation by information concerning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matters outside of sense-perception and by matters which appealed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more directly to thought. Consequently it left unimpaired the scope of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: informational and abstract, or "rationalistic" studies.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Experience as Experimentation. It has already been intimated that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sensational empiricism represents neither the idea of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: justified by modern psychology nor the idea of knowledge suggested by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modern scientific procedure. With respect to the former, it omits the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: primary position of active response which puts things to use and which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learns about them through discovering the consequences that result from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use. It would seem as if five minutes' unprejudiced observation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the way an infant gains knowledge would have sufficed to overthrow the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: notion that he is passively engaged in receiving impressions of isolated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ready-made qualities of sound, color, hardness, etc. For it would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be seen that the infant reacts to stimuli by activities of handling,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reaching, etc., in order to see what results follow upon motor response
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to a sensory stimulation; it would be seen that what is learned are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated qualities, but the behavior which may be expected from a thing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the changes in things and persons which an activity may be expected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to produce. In other words, what he learns are connections. Even such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities as red color, sound of a high pitch, have to be discriminated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and identified on the basis of the activities they call forth and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences these activities effect. We learn what things are hard and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what are soft by finding out through active experimentation what they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respectively will do and what can be done and what cannot be done with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. In like fashion, children learn about persons by finding out what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsive activities these persons exact and what these persons will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do in reply to the children's activities. And the combination of what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things do to us (not in impressing qualities on a passive mind) in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: modifying our actions, furthering some of them and resisting and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: checking others, and what we can do to them in producing new changes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes experience. The methods of science by which the revolution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in our knowledge of the world dating from the seventeenth century, was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brought about, teach the same lesson. For these methods are nothing but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimentation carried out under conditions of deliberate control. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the Greek, it seemed absurd that such an activity as, say, the cobbler
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: punching holes in leather, or using wax and needle and thread, could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: give an adequate knowledge of the world. It seemed almost axiomatic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that for true knowledge we must have recourse to concepts coming from a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason above experience. But the introduction of the experimental method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: signified precisely that such operations, carried on under conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of control, are just the ways in which fruitful ideas about nature are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obtained and tested. In other words, it is only needed to conduct such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an operation as the pouring of an acid on a metal for the purpose of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting knowledge instead of for the purpose of getting a trade result,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in order to lay hold of the principle upon which the science of nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was henceforth to depend. Sense perceptions were indeed indispensable,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but there was less reliance upon sense perceptions in their natural or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: customary form than in the older science. They were no longer regarded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as containing within themselves some "form" or "species" of universal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kind in a disguised mask of sense which could be stripped off by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rational thought. On the contrary, the first thing was to alter and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extend the data of sense perception: to act upon the given objects of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense by the lens of the telescope and microscope, and by all sorts of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental devices. To accomplish this in a way which would arouse
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new ideas (hypotheses, theories) required even more general ideas (like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: those of mathematics) than were at the command of ancient science. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these general conceptions were no longer taken to give knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in themselves. They were implements for instituting, conducting,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interpreting experimental inquiries and formulating their results.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The logical outcome is a new philosophy of experience and knowledge,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a philosophy which no longer puts experience in opposition to rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge and explanation. Experience is no longer a mere summarizing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of what has been done in a more or less chance way in the past; it is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate control of what is done with reference to making what happens
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to us and what we do to things as fertile as possible of suggestions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (of suggested meanings) and a means for trying out the validity of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suggestions. When trying, or experimenting, ceases to be blinded by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impulse or custom, when it is guided by an aim and conducted by measure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and method, it becomes reasonable--rational. When what we suffer from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: things, what we undergo at their hands, ceases to be a matter of chance

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: justification.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: those results.

text: (i) Experience itself primarily consists of the active relations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsisting between a human being and his natural and social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surroundings. In some cases, the initiative in activity is on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: side of the environment; the human being undergoes or suffers certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: checkings and deflections of endeavors. In other cases, the behavior of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: surrounding things and persons carries to a successful issue the active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tendencies of the individual, so that in the end what the individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undergoes are consequences which he has himself tried to produce.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In just the degree in which connections are established between what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: happens to a person and what he does in response, and between what he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effect acquisition of those meanings which are so important that they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: become, in turn, instruments of further learnings. (ante, Ch. XI.) As
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has been repeatedly pointed out, activity out of school is carried on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the function of understanding and formation of effective intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dispositions. The results are vital and genuine as far as they go, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are limited by all kinds of circumstances. Some powers are left
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quite undeveloped and undirected; others get only occasional and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whimsical stimulations; others are formed into habits of a routine skill
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at the expense of aims and resourceful initiative and inventiveness. It
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is not the business of the school to transport youth from an environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of activity into one of cramped study of the records of other men's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning; but to transport them from an environment of relatively chance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities (accidental in the relation they bear to insight and thought)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into one of activities selected with reference to guidance of learning.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: intellectualizing of practical pursuits. It remains to grasp the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: principle with greater firmness.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and intercourse are instinct with applied science, the case stands

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct blow at the traditional separation of doing and knowing and at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

text: cannot be attained purely mentally--just inside the head. Men have to do

text: Summary. The Greeks were induced to philosophize by the increasing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: failure of their traditional customs and beliefs to regulate life. Thus
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they were led to criticize custom adversely and to look for some other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: source of authority in life and belief. Since they desired a rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standard for the latter, and had identified with experience the customs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which had proved unsatisfactory supports, they were led to a flat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opposition of reason and experience. The more the former was exalted,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the more the latter was depreciated. Since experience was identified
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with what men do and suffer in particular and changing situations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life, doing shared in the philosophic depreciation. This influence fell
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in with many others to magnify, in higher education, all the methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and topics which involved the least use of sense-observation and bodily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity. The modern age began with a revolt against this point of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: view, with an appeal to experience, and an attack upon so-called purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rational concepts on the ground that they either needed to be ballasted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the results of concrete experiences, or else were mere expressions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of prejudice and institutionalized class interest, calling themselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rational for protection. But various circumstances led to considering
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience as pure cognition, leaving out of account its intrinsic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: active and emotional phases, and to identifying it with a passive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reception of isolated "sensations." Hence the education reform effected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by the new theory was confined mainly to doing away with some of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the bookishness of prior methods; it did not accomplish a consistent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reorganization.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Meantime, the advance of psychology, of industrial methods, and of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental method in science makes another conception of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explicitly desirable and possible. This theory reinstates the idea of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ancients that experience is primarily practical, not cognitive--a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of doing and undergoing the consequences of doing. But the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ancient theory is transformed by realizing that doing may be directed so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to take up into its own content all which thought suggests, and so as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to result in securely tested knowledge. "Experience" then ceases to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: empirical and becomes experimental. Reason ceases to be a remote and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideal faculty, and signifies all the resources by which activity is made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: fruitful in meaning. Educationally, this change denotes such a plan
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: for the studies and method of instruction as has been developed in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: previous chapters.

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: ALLUSION has already been made to the conflict of natural science with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literary studies for a place in the curriculum. The solution thus far
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reached consists essentially in a somewhat mechanical compromise whereby
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the field is divided between studies having nature and studies having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man as their theme. The situation thus presents us with another instance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the external adjustment of educational values, and focuses attention
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the philosophy of the connection of nature with human affairs. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general, it may be said that the educational division finds a reflection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the dualistic philosophies. Mind and the world are regarded as two
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: independent realms of existence having certain points of contact with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each other. From this point of view it is natural that each sphere of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence should have its own separate group of studies connected with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it; it is even natural that the growth of scientific studies should be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: viewed with suspicion as marking a tendency of materialistic philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to encroach upon the domain of spirit. Any theory of education which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contemplates a more unified scheme of education than now exists is under
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the necessity of facing the question of the relation of man to nature.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Historic Background of Humanistic Study. It is noteworthy that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: classic Greek philosophy does not present the problem in its modern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form. Socrates indeed appears to have thought that science of nature was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not attainable and not very important. The chief thing to know is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature and end of man. Upon that knowledge hangs all that is of deep
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance--all moral and social achievement. Plato, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes right knowledge of man and society depend upon knowledge of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: essential features of nature. His chief treatise, entitled the Republic,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is at once a treatise on morals, on social organization, and on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: metaphysics and science of nature. Since he accepts the Socratic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doctrine that right achievement in the former depends upon rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge, he is compelled to discuss the nature of knowledge. Since he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accepts the idea that the ultimate object of knowledge is the discovery
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the good or end of man, and is discontented with the Socratic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conviction that all we know is our own ignorance, he connects the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discussion of the good of man with consideration of the essential good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or end of nature itself. To attempt to determine the end of man apart
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from a knowledge of the ruling end which gives law and unity to nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is impossible. It is thus quite consistent with his philosophy that he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subordinates literary studies (under the name of music) to mathematics
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and to physics as well as to logic and metaphysics. But on the other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hand, knowledge of nature is not an end in itself; it is a necessary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stage in bringing the mind to a realization of the supreme purpose of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence as the law of human action, corporate and individual. To use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the modern phraseology, naturalistic studies are indispensable, but they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are in the interests of humanistic and ideal ends.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Aristotle goes even farther, if anything, in the direction of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: naturalistic studies. He subordinates (ante, p. 254) civic relations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the purely cognitive life. The highest end of man is not human but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: divine--participation in pure knowing which constitutes the divine life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Such knowing deals with what is universal and necessary, and finds,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: therefore, a more adequate subject matter in nature at its best than in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the transient things of man. If we take what the philosophers stood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for in Greek life, rather than the details of what they say, we might
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: summarize by saying that the Greeks were too much interested in free
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inquiry into natural fact and in the aesthetic enjoyment of nature, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were too deeply conscious of the extent in which society is rooted in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature and subject to its laws, to think of bringing man and nature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into conflict. Two factors conspire in the later period of ancient
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life, however, to exalt literary and humanistic studies. One is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increasingly reminiscent and borrowed character of culture; the other is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the political and rhetorical bent of Roman life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Greek achievement in civilization was native; the civilization of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Alexandrians and Romans was inherited from alien sources. Consequently
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it looked back to the records upon which it drew, instead of looking
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out directly upon nature and society, for material and inspiration.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We cannot do better than quote the words of Hatch to indicate the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences for educational theory and practice. "Greece on one hand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had lost political power, and on the other possessed in her splendid
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literature an inalienable heritage. It was natural that she should turn

author: Dewey, John

text: to letters. It was natural also that the study of letters should be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflected upon speech. The mass of men in the Greek world tended to lay
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stress on that acquaintance with the literature of bygone generations,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and that habit of cultivated speech, which has ever since been commonly

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: fifteenth century which is variously termed the revival of learning

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dominant supernaturalistic interest. It is possible that the influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a return to classic Greek pagan literature in bringing about this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: changed mind has been overestimated. Undoubtedly the change was mainly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a product of contemporary conditions. But there can be no doubt that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educated men, filled with the new point of view, turned eagerly to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freedom, the sense of the order and beauty of nature, which animated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: untrammeled fashion. The history of science in the sixteenth century
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their points of departure from the new interest in Greek literature.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: (c) The natural sciences were themselves conceived in a way which

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
