text: important to mankind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. The Present Educational Problem. In truth, experience knows no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: division between human concerns and a purely mechanical physical world.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Man's home is nature; his purposes and aims are dependent for execution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon natural conditions. Separated from such conditions they become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: empty dreams and idle indulgences of fancy. From the standpoint of human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, and hence of educational endeavor, any distinction which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can be justly made between nature and man is a distinction between the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions which have to be reckoned with in the formation and execution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of our practical aims, and the aims themselves. This philosophy is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vouched for by the doctrine of biological development which shows that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man is continuous with nature, not an alien entering her processes from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without. It is reinforced by the experimental method of science which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shows that knowledge accrues in virtue of an attempt to direct physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energies in accord with ideas suggested in dealing with natural objects
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in behalf of social uses. Every step forward in the social sciences--the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies termed history, economics, politics, sociology--shows that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social questions are capable of being intelligently coped with only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the degree in which we employ the method of collected data, forming
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: hypotheses, and testing them in action which is characteristic of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural science, and in the degree in which we utilize in behalf of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the promotion of social welfare the technical knowledge ascertained by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physics and chemistry. Advanced methods of dealing with such perplexing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problems as insanity, intemperance, poverty, public sanitation, city
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: planning, the conservation of natural resources, the constructive use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: governmental agencies for furthering the public good without weakening
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal initiative, all illustrate the direct dependence of our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important social concerns upon the methods and results of natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: With respect then to both humanistic and naturalistic studies, education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should take its departure from this close interdependence. It should aim
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not at keeping science as a study of nature apart from literature as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a record of human interests, but at cross-fertilizing both the natural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sciences and the various human disciplines such as history, literature,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economics, and politics. Pedagogically, the problem is simpler than the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attempt to teach the sciences as mere technical bodies of information
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and technical forms of physical manipulation, on one side; and to teach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanistic studies as isolated subjects, on the other. For the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: procedure institutes an artificial separation in the pupils' experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Outside of school pupils meet with natural facts and principles in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with various modes of human action. (See ante, p. 30.) In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all the social activities in which they have shared they have had to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understand the material and processes involved. To start them in school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with a rupture of this intimate association breaks the continuity of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental development, makes the student feel an indescribable unreality in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his studies, and deprives him of the normal motive for interest in them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is no doubt, of course, that the opportunities of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should be such that all should have a chance who have the disposition to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advance to specialized ability in science, and thus devote themselves to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its pursuit as their particular occupation in life. But at present, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pupil too often has a choice only between beginning with a study of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results of prior specialization where the material is isolated from his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: daily experiences, or with miscellaneous nature study, where material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is presented at haphazard and does not lead anywhere in particular. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habit of introducing college pupils into segregated scientific subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter, such as is appropriate to the man who wishes to become an expert
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in a given field, is carried back into the high schools. Pupils in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: latter simply get a more elementary treatment of the same thing, with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulties smoothed over and topics reduced to the level of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: supposed ability. The cause of this procedure lies in following
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tradition, rather than in conscious adherence to a dualistic philosophy.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But the effect is the same as if the purpose were to inculcate an idea
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the sciences which deal with nature have nothing to do with man,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vice versa. A large part of the comparative ineffectiveness of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the teaching of the sciences, for those who never become scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialists, is the result of a separation which is unavoidable when one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: begins with technically organized subject matter. Even if all students
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were embryonic scientific specialists, it is questionable whether this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the most effective procedure. Considering that the great majority
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are concerned with the study of sciences only for its effect upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their mental habits--in making them more alert, more open-minded, more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inclined to tentative acceptance and to testing of ideas propounded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or suggested,--and for achieving a better understanding of their daily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: environment, it is certainly ill-advised. Too often the pupil comes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out with a smattering which is too superficial to be scientific and too
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical to be applicable to ordinary affairs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The utilization of ordinary experience to secure an advance into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific material and method, while keeping the latter connected with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: familiar human interests, is easier to-day than it ever was before.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The usual experience of all persons in civilized communities to-day is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intimately associated with industrial processes and results. These in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: turn are so many cases of science in action. The stationary and traction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: steam engine, gasoline engine, automobile, telegraph and telephone, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: electric motor enter directly into the lives of most individuals. Pupils
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at an early age are practically acquainted with these things. Not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does the business occupation of their parents depend upon scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: applications, but household pursuits, the maintenance of health,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the sights seen upon the streets, embody scientific achievements and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulate interest in the connected scientific principles. The obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pedagogical starting point of scientific instruction is not to teach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things labeled science, but to utilize the familiar occupations and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appliances to direct observation and experiment, until pupils have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arrived at a knowledge of some fundamental principles by understanding
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them in their familiar practical workings.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The opinion sometimes advanced that it is a derogation from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "purity" of science to study it in its active incarnation, instead of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in theoretical abstraction, rests upon a misunderstanding. AS matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact, any subject is cultural in the degree in which it is apprehended
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in its widest possible range of meanings. Perception of meanings depends
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon perception of connections, of context. To see a scientific fact or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: law in its human as well as in its physical and technical context is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to enlarge its significance and give it increased cultural value. Its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: direct economic application, if by economic is meant something having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: money worth, is incidental and secondary, but a part of its actual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections. The important thing is that the fact be grasped in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social connections--its function in life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On the other hand, "humanism" means at bottom being imbued with an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligent sense of human interests. The social interest, identical in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its deepest meaning with a moral interest, is necessarily supreme with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man. Knowledge about man, information as to his past, familiarity with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his documented records of literature, may be as technical a possession
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as the accumulation of physical details. Men may keep busy in a variety
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of ways, making money, acquiring facility in laboratory manipulation, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in amassing a store of facts about linguistic matters, or the chronology
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of literary productions. Unless such activity reacts to enlarge the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imaginative vision of life, it is on a level with the busy work of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: children. It has the letter without the spirit of activity. It readily
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degenerates itself into a miser's accumulation, and a man prides himself
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: on what he has, and not on the meaning he finds in the affairs of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Any study so pursued that it increases concern for the values of life,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any study producing greater sensitiveness to social well-being and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater ability to promote that well-being is humane study. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanistic spirit of the Greeks was native and intense but it was narrow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in scope. Everybody outside the Hellenic circle was a barbarian,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and negligible save as a possible enemy. Acute as were the social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observations and speculations of Greek thinkers, there is not a word in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their writings to indicate that Greek civilization was not self-inclosed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and self-sufficient. There was, apparently, no suspicion that its future
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was at the mercy of the despised outsider. Within the Greek community,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the intense social spirit was limited by the fact that higher culture
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was based on a substratum of slavery and economic serfdom--classes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessary to the existence of the state, as Aristotle declared, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: yet not genuine parts of it. The development of science has produced an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial revolution which has brought different peoples in such close
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contact with one another through colonization and commerce that no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter how some nations may still look down upon others, no country can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: harbor the illusion that its career is decided wholly within itself. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same revolution has abolished agricultural serfdom, and created a class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of more or less organized factory laborers with recognized political
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rights, and who make claims for a responsible role in the control of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industry--claims which receive sympathetic attention from many among the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: well-to-do, since they have been brought into closer connections with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the less fortunate classes through the breaking down of class barriers.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This state of affairs may be formulated by saying that the older
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: humanism omitted economic and industrial conditions from its purview.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Consequently, it was one sided. Culture, under such circumstances,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inevitably represented the intellectual and moral outlook of the class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which was in direct social control. Such a tradition as to culture is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as we have seen (ante, p. 260), aristocratic; it emphasizes what marks
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: off one class from another, rather than fundamental common interests.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Its standards are in the past; for the aim is to preserve what has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gained rather than widely to extend the range of culture.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The modifications which spring from taking greater account of industry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and of whatever has to do with making a living are frequently condemned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as attacks upon the culture derived from the past. But a wider
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational outlook would conceive industrial activities as agencies for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making intellectual resources more accessible to the masses, and giving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater solidity to the culture of those having superior resources.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In short, when we consider the close connection between science and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial development on the one hand, and between literary and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aesthetic cultivation and an aristocratic social organization on the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other, we get light on the opposition between technical scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: studies and refining literary studies. We have before us the need
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of overcoming this separation in education if society is to be truly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. The philosophic dualism between man and nature is reflected in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the division of studies between the naturalistic and the humanistic with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a tendency to reduce the latter to the literary records of the past.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This dualism is not characteristic (as were the others which we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: noted) of Greek thought. It arose partly because of the fact that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture of Rome and of barbarian Europe was not a native product,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: being borrowed directly or indirectly from Greece, and partly because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: political and ecclesiastic conditions emphasized dependence upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the authority of past knowledge as that was transmitted in literary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: documents.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At the outset, the rise of modern science prophesied a restoration of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the intimate connection of nature and humanity, for it viewed knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of nature as the means of securing human progress and well-being. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the more immediate applications of science were in the interests of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a class rather than of men in common; and the received philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formulations of scientific doctrine tended either to mark it off as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely material from man as spiritual and immaterial, or else to reduce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind to a subjective illusion. In education, accordingly, the tendency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was to treat the sciences as a separate body of studies, consisting of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical information regarding the physical world, and to reserve
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the older literary studies as distinctively humanistic. The account
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: previously given of the evolution of knowledge, and of the educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scheme of studies based upon it, are designed to overcome the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation, and to secure recognition of the place occupied by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of the natural sciences in human affairs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Twenty-two: The Individual and the World
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Mind as Purely Individual. We have been concerned with the influences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which have effected a division between work and leisure, knowing and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doing, man and nature. These influences have resulted in splitting up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the subject matter of education into separate studies. They have also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: found formulation in various philosophies which have opposed to each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other body and mind, theoretical knowledge and practice, physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mechanism and ideal purpose. Upon the philosophical side, these various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dualisms culminate in a sharp demarcation of individual minds from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the world, and hence from one another. While the connection of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophical position with educational procedure is not so obvious as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is that of the points considered in the last three chapters, there are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: certain educational considerations which correspond to it; such as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: antithesis supposed to exist between subject matter (the counterpart of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the world) and method (the counterpart of mind); such as the tendency to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: treat interest as something purely private, without intrinsic connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the material studied. Aside from incidental educational bearings,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it will be shown in this chapter that the dualistic philosophy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind and the world implies an erroneous conception of the relationship
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: between knowledge and social interests, and between individuality or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: freedom, and social control and authority. The identification of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind with the individual self and of the latter with a private psychic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciousness is comparatively modern. In both the Greek and medieval
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: periods, the rule was to regard the individual as a channel through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which a universal and divine intelligence operated. The individual was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in no true sense the knower; the knower was the "Reason" which operated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through him. The individual interfered at his peril, and only to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: detriment of the truth. In the degree in which the individual rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than reason "knew," conceit, error, and opinion were substituted for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: true knowledge. In Greek life, observation was acute and alert; and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking was free almost to the point of irresponsible speculations.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Accordingly the consequences of the theory were only such as were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequent upon the lack of an experimental method. Without such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method individuals could not engage in knowing, and be checked up by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results of the inquiries of others. Without such liability to test
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by others, the minds of men could not be intellectually responsible;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: results were to be accepted because of their aesthetic consistency,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: agreeable quality, or the prestige of their authors. In the barbarian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: period, individuals were in a still more humble attitude to truth;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important knowledge was supposed to be divinely revealed, and nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: remained for the minds of individuals except to work it over after
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it had been received on authority. Aside from the more consciously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophic aspects of these movements, it never occurs to any one to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identify mind and the personal self wherever beliefs are transmitted by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: custom.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In the medieval period there was a religious individualism. The deepest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concern of life was the salvation of the individual soul. In the later
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Middle Ages, this latent individualism found conscious formulation in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the nominalistic philosophies, which treated the structure of knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as something built up within the individual through his own acts, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental states. With the rise of economic and political individualism
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: after the sixteenth century, and with the development of Protestantism,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the times were ripe for an emphasis upon the rights and duties of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual in achieving knowledge for himself. This led to the view that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge is won wholly through personal and private experiences. As a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequence, mind, the source and possessor of knowledge, was thought
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of as wholly individual. Thus upon the educational side, we find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational reformers, like Montaigne, Bacon, Locke, henceforth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vehemently denouncing all learning which is acquired on hearsay, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: asserting that even if beliefs happen to be true, they do not constitute
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge unless they have grown up in and been tested by personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. The reaction against authority in all spheres of life, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the intensity of the struggle, against great odds, for freedom of action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and inquiry, led to such an emphasis upon personal observations and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas as in effect to isolate mind, and set it apart from the world to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be known.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This isolation is reflected in the great development of that branch
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of philosophy known as epistemology--the theory of knowledge. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identification of mind with the self, and the setting up of the self as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something independent and self-sufficient, created such a gulf between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the knowing mind and the world that it became a question how knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was possible at all. Given a subject--the knower--and an object--the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thing to be known--wholly separate from one another, it is necessary to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: frame a theory to explain how they get into connection with each other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so that valid knowledge may result. This problem, with the allied one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the possibility of the world acting upon the mind and the mind acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the world, became almost the exclusive preoccupation of philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The theories that we cannot know the world as it really is but only the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impressions made upon the mind, or that there is no world beyond the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual mind, or that knowledge is only a certain association of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the mind's own states, were products of this preoccupation. We are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directly concerned with their truth; but the fact that such desperate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: solutions were widely accepted is evidence of the extent to which mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had been set over the world of realities. The increasing use of the term
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "consciousness" as an equivalent for mind, in the supposition that there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is an inner world of conscious states and processes, independent of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any relationship to nature and society, an inner world more truly and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately known than anything else, is evidence of the same fact.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In short, practical individualism, or struggle for greater freedom of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought in action, was translated into philosophic subjectivism.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Individual Mind as the Agent of Reorganization. It should be obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that this philosophic movement misconceived the significance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the practical movement. Instead of being its transcript, it was a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perversion. Men were not actually engaged in the absurdity of striving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be free from connection with nature and one another. They were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: striving for greater freedom in nature and society. They wanted greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: power to initiate changes in the world of things and fellow beings;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: greater scope of movement and consequently greater freedom in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observations and ideas implied in movement. They wanted not isolation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the world, but a more intimate connection with it. They wanted to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: form their beliefs about it at first hand, instead of through tradition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: They wanted closer union with their fellows so that they might influence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another more effectively and might combine their respective actions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for mutual aims.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So far as their beliefs were concerned, they felt that a great deal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which passed for knowledge was merely the accumulated opinions of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past, much of it absurd and its correct portions not understood when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accepted on authority. Men must observe for themselves, and form their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own theories and personally test them. Such a method was the only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: alternative to the imposition of dogma as truth, a procedure which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reduced mind to the formal act of acquiescing in truth. Such is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning of what is sometimes called the substitution of inductive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental methods of knowing for deductive. In some sense, men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: had always used an inductive method in dealing with their immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practical concerns. Architecture, agriculture, manufacture, etc., had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be based upon observation of the activities of natural objects, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideas about such affairs had to be checked, to some extent, by results.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But even in such things there was an undue reliance upon mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: custom, followed blindly rather than understandingly. And this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observational-experimental method was restricted to these "practical"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matters, and a sharp distinction maintained between practice and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theoretical knowledge or truth. (See Ch. XX.) The rise of free cities,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the development of travel, exploration, and commerce, the evolution
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of new methods of producing commodities and doing business, threw men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definitely upon their own resources. The reformers of science like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Galileo, Descartes, and their successors, carried analogous methods into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ascertaining the facts about nature. An interest in discovery took the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: place of an interest in systematizing and "proving" received beliefs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A just philosophic interpretation of these movements would, indeed, have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emphasized the rights and responsibilities of the individual in gaining
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge and personally testing beliefs, no matter by what authorities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they were vouched for. But it would not have isolated the individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the world, and consequently isolated individuals--in theory--from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one another. It would have perceived that such disconnection, such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rupture of continuity, denied in advance the possibility of success in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their endeavors. As matter of fact every individual has grown up, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: always must grow up, in a social medium. His responses grow intelligent,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or gain meaning, simply because he lives and acts in a medium of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accepted meanings and values. (See ante, p. 30.) Through social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse, through sharing in the activities embodying beliefs, he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradually acquires a mind of his own. The conception of mind as a purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated possession of the self is at the very antipodes of the truth.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The self achieves mind in the degree in which knowledge of things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is incarnate in the life about him; the self is not a separate mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: building up knowledge anew on its own account.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Yet there is a valid distinction between knowledge which is objective
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and impersonal, and thinking which is subjective and personal. In one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sense, knowledge is that which we take for granted. It is that which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: settled, disposed of, established, under control. What we fully know,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we do not need to think about. In common phrase, it is certain, assured.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And this does not mean a mere feeling of certainty. It denotes not a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sentiment, but a practical attitude, a readiness to act without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reserve or quibble. Of course we may be mistaken. What is taken for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge--for fact and truth--at a given time may not be such. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everything which is assumed without question, which is taken for granted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in our intercourse with one another and nature is what, at the given
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time, is called knowledge. Thinking on the contrary, starts, as we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have seen, from doubt or uncertainty. It marks an inquiring, hunting,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: searching attitude, instead of one of mastery and possession. Through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its critical process true knowledge is revised and extended, and our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: convictions as to the state of things reorganized. Clearly the last few
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: centuries have been typically a period of revision and reorganization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of beliefs. Men did not really throw away all transmitted beliefs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerning the realities of existence, and start afresh upon the basis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of their private, exclusive sensations and ideas. They could not have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done so if they had wished to, and if it had been possible general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imbecility would have been the only outcome. Men set out from what had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: passed as knowledge, and critically investigated the grounds upon which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it rested; they noted exceptions; they used new mechanical appliances to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bring to light data inconsistent with what had been believed; they used
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their imaginations to conceive a world different from that in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their forefathers had put their trust. The work was a piecemeal, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: retail, business. One problem was tackled at a time. The net results
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of all the revisions amounted, however, to a revolution of prior
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceptions of the world. What occurred was a reorganization of prior
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual habitudes, infinitely more efficient than a cutting loose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from all connections would have been.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This state of affairs suggests a definition of the role of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual, or the self, in knowledge; namely, the redirection, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reconstruction of accepted beliefs. Every new idea, every conception of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things differing from that authorized by current belief, must have its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: origin in an individual. New ideas are doubtless always sprouting, but a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society governed by custom does not encourage their development. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contrary, it tends to suppress them, just because they are deviations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from what is current. The man who looks at things differently from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others is in such a community a suspect character; for him to persist
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is generally fatal. Even when social censorship of beliefs is not so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strict, social conditions may fail to provide the appliances which are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: requisite if new ideas are to be adequately elaborated; or they may fail
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to provide any material support and reward to those who entertain them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence they remain mere fancies, romantic castles in the air, or aimless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: speculations. The freedom of observation and imagination involved in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the modern scientific revolution were not easily secured; they had to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fought for; many suffered for their intellectual independence. But, upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the whole, modern European society first permitted, and then, in some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fields at least, deliberately encouraged the individual reactions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deviate from what custom prescribes. Discovery, research, inquiry in new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lines, inventions, finally came to be either the social fashion, or in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some degree tolerable. However, as we have already noted, philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theories of knowledge were not content to conceive mind in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual as the pivot upon which reconstruction of beliefs turned,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thus maintaining the continuity of the individual with the world of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature and fellow men. They regarded the individual mind as a separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: entity, complete in each person, and isolated from nature and hence from
