text: with others. That a child must work alone and not engage in group
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities in order to be free and let his individuality develop, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a notion which measures individuality by spatial distance and makes a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical thing of it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Individuality as a factor to be respected in education has a double
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning. In the first place, one is mentally an individual only as he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has his own purpose and problem, and does his own thinking. The phrase
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "think for one's self" is a pleonasm. Unless one does it for one's self,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it isn't thinking. Only by a pupil's own observations, reflections,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: framing and testing of suggestions can what he already knows be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: amplified and rectified. Thinking is as much an individual matter as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the digestion of food. In the second place, there are variations of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point of view, of appeal of objects, and of mode of attack, from person
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to person. When these variations are suppressed in the alleged interests
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of uniformity, and an attempt is made to have a single mold of method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of study and recitation, mental confusion and artificiality inevitably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result. Originality is gradually destroyed, confidence in one's own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality of mental operation is undermined, and a docile subjection to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the opinion of others is inculcated, or else ideas run wild. The harm
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is greater now than when the whole community was governed by customary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beliefs, because the contrast between methods of learning in school and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: those relied upon outside the school is greater. That systematic advance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in scientific discovery began when individuals were allowed, and then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: encouraged, to utilize their own peculiarities of response to subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter, no one will deny. If it is said in objection, that pupils
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in school are not capable of any such originality, and hence must be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confined to appropriating and reproducing things already known by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the better informed, the reply is twofold. (i) We are concerned with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: originality of attitude which is equivalent to the unforced response of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one's own individuality, not with originality as measured by product.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: No one expects the young to make original discoveries of just the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: facts and principles as are embodied in the sciences of nature and man.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But it is not unreasonable to expect that learning may take place under
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such conditions that from the standpoint of the learner there is genuine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovery. While immature students will not make discoveries from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the standpoint of advanced students, they make them from their own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: standpoint, whenever there is genuine learning. (ii) In the normal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process of becoming acquainted with subject matter already known to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, even young pupils react in unexpected ways. There is something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fresh, something not capable of being fully anticipated by even the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: most experienced teacher, in the ways they go at the topic, and in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the particular ways in which things strike them. Too often all this is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brushed aside as irrelevant; pupils are deliberately held to rehearsing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material in the exact form in which the older person conceives it. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result is that what is instinctively original in individuality, that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which marks off one from another, goes unused and undirected. Teaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then ceases to be an educative process for the teacher. At most he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learns simply to improve his existing technique; he does not get new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: points of view; he fails to experience any intellectual companionship.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence both teaching and learning tend to become conventional and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mechanical with all the nervous strain on both sides therein implied.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As maturity increases and as the student has a greater background of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: familiarity upon which a new topic is projected, the scope of more or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: less random physical experimentation is reduced. Activity is defined or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialized in certain channels. To the eyes of others, the student may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be in a position of complete physical quietude, because his energies are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confined to nerve channels and to the connected apparatus of the eyes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vocal organs. But because this attitude is evidence of intense
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mental concentration on the part of the trained person, it does not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: follow that it should be set up as a model for students who still have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to find their intellectual way about. And even with the adult, it does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not cover the whole circuit of mental energy. It marks an intermediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: period, capable of being lengthened with increased mastery of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject, but always coming between an earlier period of more general and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conspicuous organic action and a later time of putting to use what has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been apprehended.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: When, however, education takes cognizance of the union of mind and body
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in acquiring knowledge, we are not obliged to insist upon the need of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obvious, or external, freedom. It is enough to identify the freedom
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is involved in teaching and studying with the thinking by which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what a person already knows and believes is enlarged and refined. If
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention is centered upon the conditions which have to be met in order
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to secure a situation favorable to effective thinking, freedom will take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: care of itself. The individual who has a question which being really a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: question to him instigates his curiosity, which feeds his eagerness for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information that will help him cope with it, and who has at command
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an equipment which will permit these interests to take effect, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectually free. Whatever initiative and imaginative vision he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possesses will be called into play and control his impulses and habits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: His own purposes will direct his actions. Otherwise, his seeming
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attention, his docility, his memorizings and reproductions, will partake
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of intellectual servility. Such a condition of intellectual subjection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is needed for fitting the masses into a society where the many are not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expected to have aims or ideas of their own, but to take orders from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: few set in authority. It is not adapted to a society which intends to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. True individualism is a product of the relaxation of the grip
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the authority of custom and traditions as standards of belief. Aside
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from sporadic instances, like the height of Greek thought, it is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: comparatively modern manifestation. Not but that there have always been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual diversities, but that a society dominated by conservative
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: custom represses them or at least does not utilize them and promote
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. For various reasons, however, the new individualism was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interpreted philosophically not as meaning development of agencies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for revising and transforming previously accepted beliefs, but as an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assertion that each individual's mind was complete in isolation from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: everything else. In the theoretical phase of philosophy, this produced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the epistemological problem: the question as to the possibility of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cognitive relationship of the individual to the world. In its practical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: phase, it generated the problem of the possibility of a purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual consciousness acting on behalf of general or social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests,--the problem of social direction. While the philosophies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which have been elaborated to deal with these questions have not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affected education directly, the assumptions underlying them have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: found expression in the separation frequently made between study and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: government and between freedom of individuality and control by others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Regarding freedom, the important thing to bear in mind is that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: designates a mental attitude rather than external unconstraint of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements, but that this quality of mind cannot develop without a fair
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leeway of movements in exploration, experimentation, application, etc. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society based on custom will utilize individual variations only up to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a limit of conformity with usage; uniformity is the chief ideal within
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each class. A progressive society counts individual variations as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: precious since it finds in them the means of its own growth. Hence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a democratic society must, in consistency with its ideal, allow for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual freedom and the play of diverse gifts and interests in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational measures.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Twenty-Three: Vocational Aspects of Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. The Meaning of Vocation. At the present time the conflict of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophic theories focuses in discussion of the proper place and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: function of vocational factors in education. The bald statement that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significant differences in fundamental philosophical conceptions find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their chief issue in connection with this point may arouse incredulity:
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there seems to be too great a gap between the remote and general terms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in which philosophic ideas are formulated and the practical and concrete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: details of vocational education. But a mental review of the intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: presuppositions underlying the oppositions in education of labor and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leisure, theory and practice, body and mind, mental states and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world, will show that they culminate in the antithesis of vocational and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultural education. Traditionally, liberal culture has been linked to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the notions of leisure, purely contemplative knowledge and a spiritual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity not involving the active use of bodily organs. Culture has also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: tended, latterly, to be associated with a purely private refinement, a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultivation of certain states and attitudes of consciousness, separate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from either social direction or service. It has been an escape from the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: former, and a solace for the necessity of the latter.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So deeply entangled are these philosophic dualisms with the whole
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject of vocational education, that it is necessary to define the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning of vocation with some fullness in order to avoid the impression
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that an education which centers about it is narrowly practical, if not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely pecuniary. A vocation means nothing but such a direction of life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities as renders them perceptibly significant to a person, because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the consequences they accomplish, and also useful to his associates.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The opposite of a career is neither leisure nor culture, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aimlessness, capriciousness, the absence of cumulative achievement in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, on the personal side, and idle display, parasitic dependence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the others, on the social side. Occupation is a concrete term for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity. It includes the development of artistic capacity of any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: kind, of special scientific ability, of effective citizenship, as well
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as professional and business occupations, to say nothing of mechanical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: labor or engagement in gainful pursuits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: We must avoid not only limitation of conception of vocation to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations where immediately tangible commodities are produced, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: also the notion that vocations are distributed in an exclusive way, one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and only one to each person. Such restricted specialism is impossible;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nothing could be more absurd than to try to educate individuals with an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: eye to only one line of activity. In the first place, each individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has of necessity a variety of callings, in each of which he should be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligently effective; and in the second place any one occupation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: loses its meaning and becomes a routine keeping busy at something in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: degree in which it is isolated from other interests. (i) No one is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just an artist and nothing else, and in so far as one approximates that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: condition, he is so much the less developed human being; he is a kind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of monstrosity. He must, at some period of his life, be a member of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a family; he must have friends and companions; he must either support
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: himself or be supported by others, and thus he has a business career.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: He is a member of some organized political unit, and so on. We naturally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: name his vocation from that one of the callings which distinguishes him,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rather than from those which he has in common with all others. But we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should not allow ourselves to be so subject to words as to ignore and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: virtually deny his other callings when it comes to a consideration of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the vocational phases of education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) As a man's vocation as artist is but the emphatically specialized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: phase of his diverse and variegated vocational activities, so his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efficiency in it, in the humane sense of efficiency, is determined by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its association with other callings. A person must have experience,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he must live, if his artistry is to be more than a technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplishment. He cannot find the subject matter of his artistic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity within his art; this must be an expression of what he suffers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and enjoys in other relationships--a thing which depends in turn upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the alertness and sympathy of his interests. What is true of an artist
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is true of any other special calling. There is doubtless--in general
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accord with the principle of habit--a tendency for every distinctive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocation to become too dominant, too exclusive and absorbing in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialized aspect. This means emphasis upon skill or technical method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at the expense of meaning. Hence it is not the business of education to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: foster this tendency, but rather to safeguard against it, so that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific inquirer shall not be merely the scientist, the teacher
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely the pedagogue, the clergyman merely one who wears the cloth, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so on.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Place of Vocational Aims in Education. Bearing in mind the varied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and connected content of the vocation, and the broad background upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which a particular calling is projected, we shall now consider education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the more distinctive activity of an individual.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. An occupation is the only thing which balances the distinctive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capacity of an individual with his social service. To find out what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. An occupation is a continuous activity having a purpose. Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through occupations consequently combines within itself more of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: factors conducive to learning than any other method. It calls instincts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and habits into play; it is a foe to passive receptivity. It has an end
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in view; results are to be accomplished. Hence it appeals to thought; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: demands that an idea of an end be steadily maintained, so that activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot be either routine or capricious. Since the movement of activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must be progressive, leading from one stage to another, observation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and ingenuity are required at each stage to overcome obstacles and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to discover and readapt means of execution. In short, an occupation,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursued under conditions where the realization of the activity rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than merely the external product is the aim, fulfills the requirements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which were laid down earlier in connection with the discussion of aims,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest, and thinking. (See Chapters VIII, X, XII.)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A calling is also of necessity an organizing principle for information
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and ideas; for knowledge and intellectual growth. It provides an axis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which runs through an immense diversity of detail; it causes different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences, facts, items of information to fall into order with one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another. The lawyer, the physician, the laboratory investigator in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some branch of chemistry, the parent, the citizen interested in his own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: locality, has a constant working stimulus to note and relate whatever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has to do with his concern. He unconsciously, from the motivation of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupation, reaches out for all relevant information, and holds to it.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The vocation acts as both magnet to attract and as glue to hold. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organization of knowledge is vital, because it has reference to needs;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is so expressed and readjusted in action that it never becomes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stagnant. No classification, no selection and arrangement of facts,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which is consciously worked out for purely abstract ends, can ever
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: compare in solidity or effectiveness with that knit under the stress of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an occupation; in comparison the former sort is formal, superficial, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cold.

text: 3. The only adequate training for occupations is training through
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations. The principle stated early in this book (see Chapter VI)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the educative process is its own end, and that the only sufficient
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preparation for later responsibilities comes by making the most of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately present life, applies in full force to the vocational phases
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of education. The dominant vocation of all human beings at all times
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is living--intellectual and moral growth. In childhood and youth, with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their relative freedom from economic stress, this fact is naked and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unconcealed. To predetermine some future occupation for which education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to be a strict preparation is to injure the possibilities of present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development and thereby to reduce the adequacy of preparation for a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future right employment. To repeat the principle we have had occasion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to appeal to so often, such training may develop a machine-like skill in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: routine lines (it is far from being sure to do so, since it may develop
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: distaste, aversion, and carelessness), but it will be at the expense of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: those qualities of alert observation and coherent and ingenious planning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which make an occupation intellectually rewarding. In an autocratically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: managed society, it is often a conscious object to prevent the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of freedom and responsibility, a few do the planning and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ordering, the others follow directions and are deliberately confined to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: narrow and prescribed channels of endeavor. However much such a scheme
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: may inure to the prestige and profit of a class, it is evident that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limits the development of the subject class; hardens and confines the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunities for learning through experience of the master class, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in both ways hampers the life of the society as a whole. (See ante, p.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The only alternative is that all the earlier preparation for vocations
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be indirect rather than direct; namely, through engaging in those active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupations which are indicated by the needs and interests of the pupil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at the time. Only in this way can there be on the part of the educator
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and of the one educated a genuine discovery of personal aptitudes so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the proper choice of a specialized pursuit in later life may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: indicated. Moreover, the discovery of capacity and aptitude will be a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constant process as long as growth continues. It is a conventional and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: arbitrary view which assumes that discovery of the work to be chosen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for adult life is made once for all at some particular date. One has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovered in himself, say, an interest, intellectual and social, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things which have to do with engineering and has decided to make that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his calling. At most, this only blocks out in outline the field in which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: further growth is to be directed. It is a sort of rough sketch for use
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in direction of further activities. It is the discovery of a profession
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the sense in which Columbus discovered America when he touched
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its shores. Future explorations of an indefinitely more detailed and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: extensive sort remain to be made. When educators conceive vocational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: guidance as something which leads up to a definitive, irretrievable, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: complete choice, both education and the chosen vocation are likely to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rigid, hampering further growth. In so far, the calling chosen will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be such as to leave the person concerned in a permanently subordinate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: position, executing the intelligence of others who have a calling which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: permits more flexible play and readjustment. And while ordinary usages
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of language may not justify terming a flexible attitude of readjustment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a choice of a new and further calling, it is such in effect. If even
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adults have to be on the lookout to see that their calling does not shut
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: down on them and fossilize them, educators must certainly be careful
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the vocational preparation of youth is such as to engage them in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuous reorganization of aims and methods.

text: 3. Present Opportunities and Dangers. In the past, education has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: much more vocational in fact than in name. (i) The education of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: masses was distinctly utilitarian. It was called apprenticeship rather
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than education, or else just learning from experience. The schools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: devoted themselves to the three R's in the degree in which ability to go
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through the forms of reading, writing, and figuring were common elements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in all kinds of labor. Taking part in some special line of work, under
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the direction of others, was the out-of-school phase of this education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The two supplemented each other; the school work in its narrow and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: formal character was as much a part of apprenticeship to a calling as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that explicitly so termed.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) To a considerable extent, the education of the dominant classes was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: essentially vocational--it only happened that their pursuits of ruling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and of enjoying were not called professions. For only those things were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: named vocations or employments which involved manual labor, laboring for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a reward in keep, or its commuted money equivalent, or the rendering of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal services to specific persons. For a long time, for example, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: profession of the surgeon and physician ranked almost with that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: valet or barber--partly because it had so much to do with the body,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and partly because it involved rendering direct service for pay to some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definite person. But if we go behind words, the business of directing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social concerns, whether politically or economically, whether in war or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: peace, is as much a calling as anything else; and where education has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not been completely under the thumb of tradition, higher schools in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past have been upon the whole calculated to give preparation for this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: business. Moreover, display, the adornment of person, the kind of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: companionship and entertainment which give prestige, and the spending
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of money, have been made into definite callings. Unconsciously to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves the higher institutions of learning have been made to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contribute to preparation for these employments. Even at present, what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is called higher education is for a certain class (much smaller than it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: once was) mainly preparation for engaging effectively in these pursuits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In other respects, it is largely, especially in the most advanced work,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training for the calling of teaching and special research. By a peculiar
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superstition, education which has to do chiefly with preparation for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the pursuit of conspicuous idleness, for teaching, and for literary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: callings, and for leadership, has been regarded as non-vocational and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: even as peculiarly cultural. The literary training which indirectly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fits for authorship, whether of books, newspaper editorials, or magazine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: articles, is especially subject to this superstition: many a teacher and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: author writes and argues in behalf of a cultural and humane education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: against the encroachments of a specialized practical education, without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognizing that his own education, which he calls liberal, has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mainly training for his own particular calling. He has simply got into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the habit of regarding his own business as essentially cultural and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of overlooking the cultural possibilities of other employments. At
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the bottom of these distinctions is undoubtedly the tradition which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognizes as employment only those pursuits where one is responsible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for his work to a specific employer, rather than to the ultimate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employer, the community.

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There are, however, obvious causes for the present conscious emphasis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon vocational education--for the disposition to make explicit and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate vocational implications previously tacit. (i) In the first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: place, there is an increased esteem, in democratic communities, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whatever has to do with manual labor, commercial occupations, and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rendering of tangible services to society. In theory, men and women are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: now expected to do something in return for their support--intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and economic--by society. Labor is extolled; service is a much-lauded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moral ideal. While there is still much admiration and envy of those who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: can pursue lives of idle conspicuous display, better moral sentiment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: condemns such lives. Social responsibility for the use of time and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal capacity is more generally recognized than it used to be.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) In the second place, those vocations which are specifically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial have gained tremendously in importance in the last century
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and a half. Manufacturing and commerce are no longer domestic and local,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and consequently more or less incidental, but are world-wide. They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engage the best energies of an increasingly large number of persons. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manufacturer, banker, and captain of industry have practically displaced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a hereditary landed gentry as the immediate directors of social affairs.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The problem of social readjustment is openly industrial, having to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do with the relations of capital and labor. The great increase in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social importance of conspicuous industrial processes has inevitably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brought to the front questions having to do with the relationship of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schooling to industrial life. No such vast social readjustment could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occur without offering a challenge to an education inherited from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different social conditions, and without putting up to education new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: problems.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iii) In the third place, there is the fact already repeatedly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mentioned: Industry has ceased to be essentially an empirical,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rule-of-thumb procedure, handed down by custom. Its technique is now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technological: that is to say, based upon machinery resulting from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discoveries in mathematics, physics, chemistry, bacteriology, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The economic revolution has stimulated science by setting problems
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for solution, by producing greater intellectual respect for mechanical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: appliances. And industry received back payment from science with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: compound interest. As a consequence, industrial occupations have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: infinitely greater intellectual content and infinitely larger cultural
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities than they used to possess. The demand for such education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as will acquaint workers with the scientific and social bases and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bearings of their pursuits becomes imperative, since those who are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without it inevitably sink to the role of appendages to the machines
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they operate. Under the old regime all workers in a craft were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: approximately equals in their knowledge and outlook. Personal knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and ingenuity were developed within at least a narrow range, because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work was done with tools under the direct command of the worker. Now the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operator has to adjust himself to his machine, instead of his tool to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his own purposes. While the intellectual possibilities of industry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have multiplied, industrial conditions tend to make industry, for great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: masses, less of an educative resource than it was in the days of hand
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: production for local markets. The burden of realizing the intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possibilities inhering in work is thus thrown back on the school.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iv) In the fourth place, the pursuit of knowledge has become, in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: science, more experimental, less dependent upon literary tradition, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: less associated with dialectical methods of reasoning, and with symbols.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As a result, the subject matter of industrial occupation presents
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not only more of the content of science than it used to, but greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opportunity for familiarity with the method by which knowledge is made.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The ordinary worker in the factory is of course under too immediate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economic pressure to have a chance to produce a knowledge like that of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the worker in the laboratory. But in schools, association with machines
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and industrial processes may be had under conditions where the chief
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious concern of the students is insight. The separation of shop
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and laboratory, where these conditions are fulfilled, is largely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conventional, the laboratory having the advantage of permitting the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: following up of any intellectual interest a problem may suggest; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shop the advantage of emphasizing the social bearings of the scientific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle, as well as, with many pupils, of stimulating a livelier
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (v) Finally, the advances which have been made in the psychology of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning in general and of childhood in particular fall into line with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the increased importance of industry in life. For modern psychology
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: emphasizes the radical importance of primitive unlearned instincts of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exploring, experimentation, and "trying on." It reveals that learning is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not the work of something ready-made called mind, but that mind itself
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is an organization of original capacities into activities having
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance. As we have already seen (ante, p. 204), in older pupils
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work is to educative development of raw native activities what play is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for younger pupils. Moreover, the passage from play to work should be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gradual, not involving a radical change of attitude but carrying into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work the elements of play, plus continuous reorganization in behalf
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of greater control. The reader will remark that these five points
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practically resume the main contentions of the previous part of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work. Both practically and philosophically, the key to the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational situation lies in a gradual reconstruction of school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: materials and methods so as to utilize various forms of occupation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: typifying social callings, and to bring out their intellectual and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moral content. This reconstruction must relegate purely literary
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods--including textbooks--and dialectical methods to the position of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: necessary auxiliary tools in the intelligent development of consecutive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and cumulative activities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But our discussion has emphasized the fact that this educational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reorganization cannot be accomplished by merely trying to give a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical preparation for industries and professions as they now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operate, much less by merely reproducing existing industrial conditions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the school. The problem is not that of making the schools an adjunct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to manufacture and commerce, but of utilizing the factors of industry
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to make school life more active, more full of immediate meaning, more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connected with out-of-school experience. The problem is not easy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: solution. There is a standing danger that education will perpetuate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the older traditions for a select few, and effect its adjustment to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: newer economic conditions more or less on the basis of acquiescence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the untransformed, unrationalized, and unsocialized phases of our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: defective industrial regime. Put in concrete terms, there is danger that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocational education will be interpreted in theory and practice as trade
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education: as a means of securing technical efficiency in specialized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future pursuits. Education would then become an instrument of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perpetuating unchanged the existing industrial order of society,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instead of operating as a means of its transformation. The desired
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transformation is not difficult to define in a formal way. It signifies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a society in which every person shall be occupied in something which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes the lives of others better worth living, and which accordingly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: makes the ties which bind persons together more perceptible--which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: breaks down the barriers of distance between them. It denotes a state
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of affairs in which the interest of each in his work is uncoerced and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligent: based upon its congeniality to his own aptitudes. It goes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without saying that we are far from such a social state; in a literal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
