text: and quantitative sense, we may never arrive at it. But in principle, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality of social changes already accomplished lies in this direction.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There are more ample resources for its achievement now than ever there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been before. No insuperable obstacles, given the intelligent will
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for its realization, stand in the way.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Success or failure in its realization depends more upon the adoption of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational methods calculated to effect the change than upon anything
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: else. For the change is essentially a change in the quality of mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition--an educative change. This does not mean that we can change
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: character and mind by direct instruction and exhortation, apart from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a change in industrial and political conditions. Such a conception
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: contradicts our basic idea that character and mind are attitudes of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: participative response in social affairs. But it does mean that we may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: produce in schools a projection in type of the society we should like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to realize, and by forming minds in accord with it gradually modify the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: larger and more recalcitrant features of adult society. Sentimentally,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it may seem harsh to say that the greatest evil of the present regime is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not found in poverty and in the suffering which it entails, but in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact that so many persons have callings which make no appeal to them,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which are pursued simply for the money reward that accrues. For such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: callings constantly provoke one to aversion, ill will, and a desire
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to slight and evade. Neither men's hearts nor their minds are in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: work. On the other hand, those who are not only much better off in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: worldly goods, but who are in excessive, if not monopolistic, control of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the activities of the many are shut off from equality and generality of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social intercourse. They are stimulated to pursuits of indulgence and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: display; they try to make up for the distance which separates them from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others by the impression of force and superior possession and enjoyment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they can make upon others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It would be quite possible for a narrowly conceived scheme of vocational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education to perpetuate this division in a hardened form. Taking its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stand upon a dogma of social predestination, it would assume that some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are to continue to be wage earners under economic conditions like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the present, and would aim simply to give them what is termed a trade
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education--that is, greater technical efficiency. Technical proficiency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is often sadly lacking, and is surely desirable on all accounts--not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: merely for the sake of the production of better goods at less cost, but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the greater happiness found in work. For no one cares for what one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot half do. But there is a great difference between a proficiency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limited to immediate work, and a competency extended to insight into its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social bearings; between efficiency in carrying out the plans of others
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and in one forming one's own. At present, intellectual and emotional
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limitation characterizes both the employing and the employed class.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While the latter often have no concern with their occupation beyond the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: money return it brings, the former's outlook may be confined to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: profit and power. The latter interest generally involves much greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual initiation and larger survey of conditions. For it involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the direction and combination of a large number of diverse factors,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while the interest in wages is restricted to certain direct muscular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movements. But none the less there is a limitation of intelligence to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical and non-humane, non-liberal channels, so far as the work does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not take in its social bearings. And when the animating motive is desire
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for private profit or personal power, this limitation is inevitable. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact, the advantage in immediate social sympathy and humane disposition
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: often lies with the economically unfortunate, who have not experienced
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the hardening effects of a one-sided control of the affairs of others.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Any scheme for vocational education which takes its point of departure
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from the industrial regime that now exists, is likely to assume and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to perpetuate its divisions and weaknesses, and thus to become an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instrument in accomplishing the feudal dogma of social predestination.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Those who are in a position to make their wishes good, will demand a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: liberal, a cultural occupation, and one which fits for directive power
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the youth in whom they are directly interested. To split the system, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: give to others, less fortunately situated, an education conceived mainly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as specific trade preparation, is to treat the schools as an agency
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for transferring the older division of labor and leisure, culture and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: service, mind and body, directed and directive class, into a society
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nominally democratic. Such a vocational education inevitably discounts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the scientific and historic human connections of the materials and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: processes dealt with. To include such things in narrow trade education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: would be to waste time; concern for them would not be "practical." They
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are reserved for those who have leisure at command--the leisure due to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: superior economic resources. Such things might even be dangerous to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests of the controlling class, arousing discontent or ambitions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "beyond the station" of those working under the direction of others. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an education which acknowledges the full intellectual and social meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a vocation would include instruction in the historic background
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of present conditions; training in science to give intelligence and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: initiative in dealing with material and agencies of production; and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: study of economics, civics, and politics, to bring the future worker
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into touch with the problems of the day and the various methods proposed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for its improvement. Above all, it would train power of readaptation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to changing conditions so that future workers would not become blindly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject to a fate imposed upon them. This ideal has to contend not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the inertia of existing educational traditions, but also with the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opposition of those who are entrenched in command of the industrial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: machinery, and who realize that such an educational system if made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: general would threaten their ability to use others for their own ends.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: But this very fact is the presage of a more equitable and enlightened
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social order, for it gives evidence of the dependence of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reorganization upon educational reconstruction. It is accordingly an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: encouragement to those believing in a better order to undertake the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: promotion of a vocational education which does not subject youth to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the demands and standards of the present system, but which utilizes its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scientific and social factors to develop a courageous intelligence, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to make intelligence practical and executive.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. A vocation signifies any form of continuous activity which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: renders service to others and engages personal powers in behalf of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accomplishment of results. The question of the relation of vocation to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education brings to a focus the various problems previously discussed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarding the connection of thought with bodily activity; of individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious development with associated life; of theoretical culture with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practical behavior having definite results; of making a livelihood
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the worthy enjoyment of leisure. In general, the opposition to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognition of the vocational phases of life in education (except for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the utilitarian three R's in elementary schooling) accompanies the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conservation of aristocratic ideals of the past. But, at the present
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: juncture, there is a movement in behalf of something called vocational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training which, if carried into effect, would harden these ideas into
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a form adapted to the existing industrial regime. This movement would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continue the traditional liberal or cultural education for the few
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: economically able to enjoy it, and would give to the masses a narrow
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical trade education for specialized callings, carried on under the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: control of others. This scheme denotes, of course, simply a perpetuation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the older social division, with its counterpart intellectual and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moral dualisms. But it means its continuation under conditions where it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has much less justification for existence. For industrial life is now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so dependent upon science and so intimately affects all forms of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse, that there is an opportunity to utilize it for development
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind and character. Moreover, a right educational use of it would
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: react upon intelligence and interest so as to modify, in connection with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: legislation and administration, the socially obnoxious features of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present industrial and commercial order. It would turn the increasing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fund of social sympathy to constructive account, instead of leaving it a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: somewhat blind philanthropic sentiment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It would give those who engage in industrial callings desire and ability
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to share in social control, and ability to become masters of their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: industrial fate. It would enable them to saturate with meaning the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: technical and mechanical features which are so marked a feature of our
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: machine system of production and distribution. So much for those who now
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have the poorer economic opportunities. With the representatives of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more privileged portion of the community, it would increase sympathy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for labor, create a disposition of mind which can discover the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culturing elements in useful activity, and increase a sense of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility. The crucial position of the question of vocational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education at present is due, in other words, to the fact that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concentrates in a specific issue two fundamental questions:--Whether
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence is best exercised apart from or within activity which puts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature to human use, and whether individual culture is best secured
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: under egoistic or social conditions. No discussion of details is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undertaken in this chapter, because this conclusion but summarizes the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discussion of the previous chapters, XV to XXII, inclusive.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Chapter Twenty-four: Philosophy of Education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 1. A Critical Review. Although we are dealing with the philosophy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education, DO definition of philosophy has yet been given; nor has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there been an explicit consideration of the nature of a philosophy of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education. This topic is now introduced by a summary account of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: logical order implied in the previous discussions, for the purpose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of bringing out the philosophic issues involved. Afterwards we shall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undertake a brief discussion, in more specifically philosophical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms, of the theories of knowledge and of morals implied in different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational ideals as they operate in practice. The prior chapters fall
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: logically into three parts.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: I. The first chapters deal with education as a social need and function.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Their purpose is to outline the general features of education as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: process by which social groups maintain their continuous existence.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Education was shown to be a process of renewal of the meanings of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience through a process of transmission, partly incidental to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the ordinary companionship or intercourse of adults and youth, partly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberately instituted to effect social continuity. This process was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seen to involve control and growth of both the immature individual and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the group in which he lives.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This consideration was formal in that it took no specific account of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality of the social group concerned--the kind of society aiming at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its own perpetuation through education. The general discussion was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then specified by application to social groups which are intentionally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: progressive, and which aim at a greater variety of mutually shared
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests in distinction from those which aim simply at the preservation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of established customs. Such societies were found to be democratic in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quality, because of the greater freedom allowed the constituent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: members, and the conscious need of securing in individuals a consciously
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: socialized interest, instead of trusting mainly to the force of customs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: operating under the control of a superior class. The sort of education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appropriate to the development of a democratic community was then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explicitly taken as the criterion of the further, more detailed analysis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: II. This analysis, based upon the democratic criterion, was seen to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: imply the ideal of a continuous reconstruction or reorganizing of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience, of such a nature as to increase its recognized meaning or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social content, and as to increase the capacity of individuals to act as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: directive guardians of this reorganization. (See Chapters VI-VII.)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This distinction was then used to outline the respective characters of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter and method. It also defined their unity, since method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in study and learning upon this basis is just the consciously directed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: movement of reorganization of the subject matter of experience. From
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this point of view the main principles of method and subject matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning were developed (Chapters XIII-XIV.)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: III. Save for incidental criticisms designed to illustrate principles
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by force of contrast, this phase of the discussion took for granted the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic criterion and its application in present social life. In the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subsequent chapters (XVIII-XXII) we considered the present limitation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its actual realization. They were found to spring from the notion that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience consists of a variety of segregated domains, or interests,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: each having its own independent value, material, and method, each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: checking every other, and, when each is kept properly bounded by the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, forming a kind of "balance of powers" in education. We then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proceeded to an analysis of the various assumptions underlying this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: segregation. On the practical side, they were found to have their cause
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the divisions of society into more or less rigidly marked-off classes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and groups--in other words, in obstruction to full and flexible social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interaction and intercourse. These social ruptures of continuity were
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: seen to have their intellectual formulation in various dualisms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or antitheses--such as that of labor and leisure, practical and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual activity, man and nature, individuality and association,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture and vocation. In this discussion, we found that these different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: issues have their counterparts in formulations which have been made in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: classic philosophic systems; and that they involve the chief problems of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy--such as mind (or spirit) and matter, body and mind, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind and the world, the individual and his relationships to others, etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Underlying these various separations we found the fundamental assumption
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be an isolation of mind from activity involving physical conditions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bodily organs, material appliances, and natural objects. Consequently,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there was indicated a philosophy which recognizes the origin, place, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: function of mind in an activity which controls the environment. Thus we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have completed the circuit and returned to the conceptions of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: first portion of this book: such as the biological continuity of human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: impulses and instincts with natural energies; the dependence of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: growth of mind upon participation in conjoint activities having a common
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purpose; the influence of the physical environment through the uses made
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of it in the social medium; the necessity of utilization of individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: variations in desire and thinking for a progressively developing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: society; the essential unity of method and subject matter; the intrinsic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity of ends and means; the recognition of mind as thinking which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceives and tests the meanings of behavior. These conceptions are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consistent with the philosophy which sees intelligence to be the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposive reorganization, through action, of the material of experience;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and they are inconsistent with each of the dualistic philosophies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mentioned.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. The Nature of Philosophy. Our further task is to extract and make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: explicit the idea of philosophy implicit in these considerations. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have already virtually described, though not defined, philosophy in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terms of the problems with which it deals; and we have pointed out that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these problems originate in the conflicts and difficulties of social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. The problems are such things as the relations of mind and matter;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: body and soul; humanity and physical nature; the individual and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social; theory--or knowing, and practice--or doing. The philosophical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systems which formulate these problems record the main lineaments and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulties of contemporary social practice. They bring to explicit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciousness what men have come to think, in virtue of the quality of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their current experience, about nature, themselves, and the reality they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceive to include or to govern both.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As we might expect, then, philosophy has generally been defined in ways
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which imply a certain totality, generality, and ultimateness of both
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter and method. With respect to subject matter, philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is an attempt to _comprehend_--that is, to gather together the varied
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: details of the world and of life into a single inclusive whole, which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shall either be a unity, or, as in the dualistic systems, shall reduce
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the plural details to a small number of ultimate principles. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: side of the attitude of the philosopher and of those who accept his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusions, there is the endeavor to attain as unified, consistent,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and complete an outlook upon experience as is possible. This aspect is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expressed in the word 'philosophy'--love of wisdom. Whenever philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has been taken seriously, it has always been assumed that it signified
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: achieving a wisdom which would influence the conduct of life. Witness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fact that almost all ancient schools of philosophy were also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organized ways of living, those who accepted their tenets being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: committed to certain distinctive modes of conduct; witness the intimate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection of philosophy with the theology of the Roman church in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: middle ages, its frequent association with religious interests, and, at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: national crises, its association with political struggles.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This direct and intimate connection of philosophy with an outlook upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life obviously differentiates philosophy from science. Particular facts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and laws of science evidently influence conduct. They suggest things to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do and not do, and provide means of execution. When science denotes not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: simply a report of the particular facts discovered about the world but
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a _general attitude_ toward it--as distinct from special things to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: --it merges into philosophy. For an underlying disposition represents an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attitude not to this and that thing nor even to the aggregate of known
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things, but to the considerations which govern conduct.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Hence philosophy cannot be defined simply from the side of subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter. For this reason, the definition of such conceptions as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generality, totality, and ultimateness is most readily reached from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the side of the disposition toward the world which they connote. In any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: literal and quantitative sense, these terms do not apply to the subject
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: matter of knowledge, for completeness and finality are out of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: question. The very nature of experience as an ongoing, changing process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forbids. In a less rigid sense, they apply to science rather than to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy. For obviously it is to mathematics, physics, chemistry,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: biology, anthropology, history, etc. that we must go, not to philosophy,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to find out the facts of the world. It is for the sciences to say what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generalizations are tenable about the world and what they specifically
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are. But when we ask what sort of permanent disposition of action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: toward the world the scientific disclosures exact of us we are raising a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophic question.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: From this point of view, "totality" does not mean the hopeless task of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quantitative summation. It means rather consistency of mode of response
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in reference to the plurality of events which occur. Consistency does
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not mean literal identity; for since the same thing does not happen
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: twice, an exact repetition of a reaction involves some maladjustment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Totality means continuity--the carrying on of a former habit of action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the readaptation necessary to keep it alive and growing. Instead of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: signifying a ready-made complete scheme of action, it means keeping
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the balance in a multitude of diverse actions, so that each borrows and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gives significance to every other. Any person who is open-minded
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and sensitive to new perceptions, and who has concentration and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility in connecting them has, in so far, a philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition. One of the popular senses of philosophy is calm and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: endurance in the face of difficulty and loss; it is even supposed to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a power to bear pain without complaint. This meaning is a tribute to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence of the Stoic philosophy rather than an attribute of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy in general. But in so far as it suggests that the wholeness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: characteristic of philosophy is a power to learn, or to extract meaning,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from even the unpleasant vicissitudes of experience and to embody what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is learned in an ability to go on learning, it is justified in any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scheme. An analogous interpretation applies to the generality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and ultimateness of philosophy. Taken literally, they are absurd
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pretensions; they indicate insanity. Finality does not mean, however,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that experience is ended and exhausted, but means the disposition to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: penetrate to deeper levels of meaning--to go below the surface and find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: out the connections of any event or object, and to keep at it. In like
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: manner the philosophic attitude is general in the sense that it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: averse to taking anything as isolated; it tries to place an act in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: context--which constitutes its significance. It is of assistance to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connect philosophy with thinking in its distinction from knowledge.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Knowledge, grounded knowledge, is science; it represents objects which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have been settled, ordered, disposed of rationally. Thinking, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other hand, is prospective in reference. It is occasioned by an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unsettlement and it aims at overcoming a disturbance. Philosophy is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thinking what the known demands of us--what responsive attitude it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: exacts. It is an idea of what is possible, not a record of accomplished
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact. Hence it is hypothetical, like all thinking. It presents an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assignment of something to be done--something to be tried. Its value
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lies not in furnishing solutions (which can be achieved only in action)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but in defining difficulties and suggesting methods for dealing with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. Philosophy might almost be described as thinking which has become
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conscious of itself--which has generalized its place, function, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value in experience.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: More specifically, the demand for a "total" attitude arises because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is the need of integration in action of the conflicting various
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests in life. Where interests are so superficial that they glide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: readily into one another, or where they are not sufficiently organized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to come into conflict with one another, the need for philosophy is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perceptible. But when the scientific interest conflicts with, say, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: religious, or the economic with the scientific or aesthetic, or when the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conservative concern for order is at odds with the progressive interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in freedom, or when institutionalism clashes with individuality, there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is a stimulus to discover some more comprehensive point of view from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which the divergencies may be brought together, and consistency or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity of experience recovered. Often these clashes may be settled
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by an individual for himself; the area of the struggle of aims is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: limited and a person works out his own rough accommodations. Such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: homespun philosophies are genuine and often adequate. But they do not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: result in systems of philosophy. These arise when the discrepant claims
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of different ideals of conduct affect the community as a whole, and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: need for readjustment is general. These traits explain some things which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are often brought as objections against philosophies, such as the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: part played in them by individual speculation, and their controversial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: diversity, as well as the fact that philosophy seems to be repeatedly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupied with much the same questions differently stated. Without doubt,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: all these things characterize historic philosophies more or less. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are not objections to philosophy so much as they are to human
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature, and even to the world in which human nature is set. If there
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are genuine uncertainties in life, philosophies must reflect that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: uncertainty. If there are different diagnoses of the cause of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difficulty, and different proposals for dealing with it; if, that is,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the conflict of interests is more or less embodied in different sets of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persons, there must be divergent competing philosophies. With respect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what has happened, sufficient evidence is all that is needed to bring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: agreement and certainty. The thing itself is sure. But with reference
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to what it is wise to do in a complicated situation, discussion is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inevitable precisely because the thing itself is still indeterminate.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: One would not expect a ruling class living at ease to have the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy of life as those who were having a hard struggle for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: existence. If the possessing and the dispossessed had the same
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fundamental disposition toward the world, it would argue either
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insincerity or lack of seriousness. A community devoted to industrial
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursuits, active in business and commerce, is not likely to see the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: needs and possibilities of life in the same way as a country with high
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aesthetic culture and little enterprise in turning the energies of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nature to mechanical account. A social group with a fairly continuous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history will respond mentally to a crisis in a very different way from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: were present, they would be evaluated differently. But the different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sorts of experience attending different types of life prevent just the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same data from presenting themselves, as well as lead to a different
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: scheme of values. As for the similarity of problems, this is often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fundamental respects the same predicaments of life recur from time to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: time with only such changes as are due to change of social context,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: including the growth of the sciences.

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The fact that philosophic problems arise because of widespread and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: widely felt difficulties in social practice is disguised because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophers become a specialized class which uses a technical language,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: unlike the vocabulary in which the direct difficulties are stated. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where a system becomes influential, its connection with a conflict of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interests calling for some program of social adjustment may always be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discovered. At this point, the intimate connection between philosophy
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and education appears. In fact, education offers a vantage ground
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from which to penetrate to the human, as distinct from the technical,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance of philosophic discussions. The student of philosophy "in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself" is always in danger of taking it as so much nimble or severe
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual exercise--as something said by philosophers and concerning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them alone. But when philosophic issues are approached from the side
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the kind of mental disposition to which they correspond, or the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: artificial. The educational point of view enables one to envisage the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophic problems where they arise and thrive, where they are at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: home, and where acceptance or rejection makes a difference in practice.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education

text: Chapter Twenty-five: Theories of Knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
