author: Dewey, John

text: 1. Continuity versus Dualism. A number of theories of knowing have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criticized in the previous pages. In spite of their differences from one
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: another, they all agree in one fundamental respect which contrasts
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with the theory which has been positively advanced. The latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: assumes continuity; the former state or imply certain basic divisions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separations, or antitheses, technically called dualisms. The origin of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these divisions we have found in the hard and fast walls which mark off
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social groups and classes within a group: like those between rich and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: poor, men and women, noble and baseborn, ruler and ruled. These barriers
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mean absence of fluent and free intercourse. This absence is equivalent
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the setting up of different types of life-experience, each with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated subject matter, aim, and standard of values. Every such social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: condition must be formulated in a dualistic philosophy, if philosophy is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be a sincere account of experience. When it gets beyond dualism--as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: many philosophies do in form--it can only be by appeal to something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: higher than anything found in experience, by a flight to some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transcendental realm. And in denying duality in name such theories
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: restore it in fact, for they end in a division between things of this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world as mere appearances and an inaccessible essence of reality.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: So far as these divisions persist and others are added to them, each
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leaves its mark upon the educational system, until the scheme of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education, taken as a whole, is a deposit of various purposes and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: procedures. The outcome is that kind of check and balance of segregated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: factors and values which has been described. (See Chapter XVIII.)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The present discussion is simply a formulation, in the terminology of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: philosophy, of various antithetical conceptions involved in the theory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowing. In the first place, there is the opposition of empirical and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: higher rational knowing. The first is connected with everyday affairs,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: serves the purposes of the ordinary individual who has no specialized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pursuit, and brings his wants into some kind of working connection with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the immediate environment. Such knowing is depreciated, if not despised,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as purely utilitarian, lacking in cultural significance. Rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge is supposed to be something which touches reality in ultimate,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual fashion; to be pursued for its own sake and properly to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: terminate in purely theoretical insight, not debased by application
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in behavior. Socially, the distinction corresponds to that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence used by the working classes and that used by a learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: class remote from concern with the means of living. Philosophically, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference turns about the distinction of the particular and universal.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Experience is an aggregate of more or less isolated particulars,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acquaintance with each of which must be separately made. Reason deals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with universals, with general principles, with laws, which lie above the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: welter of concrete details. In the educational precipitate, the pupil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is supposed to have to learn, on one hand, a lot of items of specific
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: information, each standing by itself, and upon the other hand, to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: become familiar with a certain number of laws and general relationships.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Geography, as often taught, illustrates the former; mathematics, beyond
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the rudiments of figuring, the latter. For all practical purposes, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent two independent worlds.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Another antithesis is suggested by the two senses of the word
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "learning." On the one hand, learning is the sum total of what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: known, as that is handed down by books and learned men. It is something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: external, an accumulation of cognitions as one might store material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commodities in a warehouse. Truth exists ready-made somewhere. Study is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: then the process by which an individual draws on what is in storage. On
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other hand, learning means something which the individual does when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he studies. It is an active, personally conducted affair. The dualism
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: here is between knowledge as something external, or, as it is often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: called, objective, and knowing as something purely internal, subjective,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: psychical. There is, on one side, a body of truth, ready-made, and, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the other, a ready-made mind equipped with a faculty of knowing--if it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: only wills to exercise it, which it is often strangely loath to do. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation, often touched upon, between subject matter and method is the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational equivalent of this dualism. Socially the distinction has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do with the part of life which is dependent upon authority and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that where individuals are free to advance. Another dualism is that of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity and passivity in knowing. Purely empirical and physical things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are often supposed to be known by receiving impressions. Physical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things somehow stamp themselves upon the mind or convey themselves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into consciousness by means of the sense organs. Rational knowledge and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge of spiritual things is supposed, on the contrary, to spring
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from activity initiated within the mind, an activity carried on better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if it is kept remote from all sullying touch of the senses and external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: objects. The distinction between sense training and object lessons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and laboratory exercises, and pure ideas contained in books, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: appropriated--so it is thought--by some miraculous output of mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: energy, is a fair expression in education of this distinction. Socially,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it reflects a division between those who are controlled by direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concern with things and those who are free to cultivate themselves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Another current opposition is that said to exist between the intellect
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the emotions. The emotions are conceived to be purely private and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal, having nothing to do with the work of pure intelligence in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apprehending facts and truths,--except perhaps the single emotion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual curiosity. The intellect is a pure light; the emotions are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a disturbing heat. The mind turns outward to truth; the emotions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: turn inward to considerations of personal advantage and loss. Thus in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education we have that systematic depreciation of interest which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has been noted, plus the necessity in practice, with most pupils, of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recourse to extraneous and irrelevant rewards and penalties in order to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: induce the person who has a mind (much as his clothes have a pocket) to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: apply that mind to the truths to be known. Thus we have the spectacle
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of professional educators decrying appeal to interest while they uphold
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with great dignity the need of reliance upon examinations, marks,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: promotions and emotions, prizes, and the time-honored paraphernalia of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rewards and punishments. The effect of this situation in crippling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the teacher's sense of humor has not received the attention which it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deserves.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: All of these separations culminate in one between knowing and doing,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory and practice, between mind as the end and spirit of action and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the body as its organ and means. We shall not repeat what has been said
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about the source of this dualism in the division of society into a class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: laboring with their muscles for material sustenance and a class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which, relieved from economic pressure, devotes itself to the arts of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: expression and social direction. Nor is it necessary to speak again
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the educational evils which spring from the separation. We shall be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: content to summarize the forces which tend to make the untenability of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this conception obvious and to replace it by the idea of continuity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (i) The advance of physiology and the psychology associated with it have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shown the connection of mental activity with that of the nervous system.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Too often recognition of connection has stopped short at this point; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: older dualism of soul and body has been replaced by that of the brain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and the rest of the body. But in fact the nervous system is only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a specialized mechanism for keeping all bodily activities working
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: together. Instead of being isolated from them, as an organ of knowing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from organs of motor response, it is the organ by which they interact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsively with one another. The brain is essentially an organ
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for effecting the reciprocal adjustment to each other of the stimuli
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: received from the environment and responses directed upon it. Note that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the adjusting is reciprocal; the brain not only enables organic activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be brought to bear upon any object of the environment in response to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a sensory stimulation, but this response also determines what the next
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulus will be. See what happens, for example, when a carpenter is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at work upon a board, or an etcher upon his plate--or in any case of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consecutive activity. While each motor response is adjusted to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: state of affairs indicated through the sense organs, that motor response
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shapes the next sensory stimulus. Generalizing this illustration, the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: brain is the machinery for a constant reorganizing of activity so as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: maintain its continuity; that is to say, to make such modifications in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future action as are required because of what has already been done. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuity of the work of the carpenter distinguishes it from a routine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: repetition of identically the same motion, and from a random
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity where there is nothing cumulative. What makes it continuous,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consecutive, or concentrated is that each earlier act prepares the way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for later acts, while these take account of or reckon with the results
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: already attained--the basis of all responsibility. No one who has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realized the full force of the facts of the connection of knowing with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the nervous system and of the nervous system with the readjusting of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity continuously to meet new conditions, will doubt that knowing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has to do with reorganizing activity, instead of being something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolated from all activity, complete on its own account.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) The development of biology clinches this lesson, with its discovery
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of evolution. For the philosophic significance of the doctrine of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evolution lies precisely in its emphasis upon continuity of simpler
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and more complex organic forms until we reach man. The development of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: organic forms begins with structures where the adjustment of environment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and organism is obvious, and where anything which can be called mind is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: at a minimum. As activity becomes more complex, coordinating a greater
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: number of factors in space and time, intelligence plays a more and more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: marked role, for it has a larger span of the future to forecast and plan
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for. The effect upon the theory of knowing is to displace the notion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that it is the activity of a mere onlooker or spectator of the world,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the notion which goes with the idea of knowing as something complete in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself. For the doctrine of organic development means that the living
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: creature is a part of the world, sharing its vicissitudes and fortunes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and making itself secure in its precarious dependence only as it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectually identifies itself with the things about it, and,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forecasting the future consequences of what is going on, shapes its own
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activities accordingly. If the living, experiencing being is an intimate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: participant in the activities of the world to which it belongs, then
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge is a mode of participation, valuable in the degree in which it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is effective. It cannot be the idle view of an unconcerned spectator.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (iii) The development of the experimental method as the method of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting knowledge and of making sure it is knowledge, and not mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: opinion--the method of both discovery and proof--is the remaining great
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: force in bringing about a transformation in the theory of knowledge.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The experimental method has two sides. (i) On one hand, it means that we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have no right to call anything knowledge except where our activity has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: actually produced certain physical changes in things, which agree with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and confirm the conception entertained. Short of such specific changes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our beliefs are only hypotheses, theories, suggestions, guesses, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are to be entertained tentatively and to be utilized as indications of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiments to be tried. (ii) On the other hand, the experimental method
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of thinking signifies that thinking is of avail; that it is of avail in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: just the degree in which the anticipation of future consequences is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made on the basis of thorough observation of present conditions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Experimentation, in other words, is not equivalent to blind reacting.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Such surplus activity--a surplus with reference to what has been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: observed and is now anticipated--is indeed an unescapable factor in all
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: our behavior, but it is not experiment save as consequences are noted
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and are used to make predictions and plans in similar situations in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future. The more the meaning of the experimental method is perceived,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the more our trying out of a certain way of treating the material
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources and obstacles which confront us embodies a prior use of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intelligence. What we call magic was with respect to many things the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experimental method of the savage; but for him to try was to try his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: luck, not his ideas. The scientific experimental method is, on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the contrary, a trial of ideas; hence even when practically--or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately--unsuccessful, it is intellectual, fruitful; for we learn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from our failures when our endeavors are seriously thoughtful.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The experimental method is new as a scientific resource--as a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: systematized means of making knowledge, though as old as life as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a practical device. Hence it is not surprising that men have not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognized its full scope. For the most part, its significance is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarded as belonging to certain technical and merely physical matters.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It will doubtless take a long time to secure the perception that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: holds equally as to the forming and testing of ideas in social and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moral matters. Men still want the crutch of dogma, of beliefs fixed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by authority, to relieve them of the trouble of thinking and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility of directing their activity by thought. They tend to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: confine their own thinking to a consideration of which one among the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: rival systems of dogma they will accept. Hence the schools are better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adapted, as John Stuart Mill said, to make disciples than inquirers. But
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: every advance in the influence of the experimental method is sure to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aid in outlawing the literary, dialectic, and authoritative methods
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of forming beliefs which have governed the schools of the past, and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transfer their prestige to methods which will procure an active concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with things and persons, directed by aims of increasing temporal reach
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and deploying greater range of things in space. In time the theory of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowing must be derived from the practice which is most successful in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: making knowledge; and then that theory will be employed to improve the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: methods which are less successful.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 2. Schools of Method. There are various systems of philosophy with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: characteristically different conceptions of the method of knowing. Some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of them are named scholasticism, sensationalism, rationalism, idealism,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realism, empiricism, transcendentalism, pragmatism, etc. Many of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them have been criticized in connection with the discussion of some
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: educational problem. We are here concerned with them as involving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deviations from that method which has proved most effective in achieving
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge, for a consideration of the deviations may render clearer
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the true place of knowledge in experience. In brief, the function
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of knowledge is to make one experience freely available in other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences. The word "freely" marks the difference between the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle of knowledge and that of habit. Habit means that an individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undergoes a modification through an experience, which modification forms
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a predisposition to easier and more effective action in a like direction
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the future. Thus it also has the function of making one experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: available in subsequent experiences. Within certain limits, it performs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this function successfully. But habit, apart from knowledge, does not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: make allowance for change of conditions, for novelty. Prevision of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: change is not part of its scope, for habit assumes the essential
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: likeness of the new situation with the old. Consequently it often leads
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: astray, or comes between a person and the successful performance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his task, just as the skill, based on habit alone, of the mechanic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will desert him when something unexpected occurs in the running of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: machine. But a man who understands the machine is the man who knows what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he is about. He knows the conditions under which a given habit works,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and is in a position to introduce the changes which will readapt it to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: new conditions.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In other words, knowledge is a perception of those connections of an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: object which determine its applicability in a given situation. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take an extreme example; savages react to a flaming comet as they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accustomed to react to other events which threaten the security of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their life. Since they try to frighten wild animals or their enemies by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: shrieks, beating of gongs, brandishing of weapons, etc., they use the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: same methods to scare away the comet. To us, the method is plainly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: absurd--so absurd that we fail to note that savages are simply falling
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: back upon habit in a way which exhibits its limitations. The only reason
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we do not act in some analogous fashion is because we do not take
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the comet as an isolated, disconnected event, but apprehend it in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: its connections with other events. We place it, as we say, in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: astronomical system. We respond to its connections and not simply to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the immediate occurrence. Thus our attitude to it is much freer. We may
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: approach it, so to speak, from any one of the angles provided by its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections. We can bring into play, as we deem wise, any one of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habits appropriate to any one of the connected objects. Thus we get at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a new event indirectly instead of immediately--by invention, ingenuity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resourcefulness. An ideally perfect knowledge would represent such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: network of interconnections that any past experience would offer a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: point of advantage from which to get at the problem presented in a new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. In fine, while a habit apart from knowledge supplies us with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a single fixed method of attack, knowledge means that selection may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: made from a much wider range of habits.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Two aspects of this more general and freer availability of former
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experiences for subsequent ones may be distinguished. (See ante, p. 77.)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (i) One, the more tangible, is increased power of control. What cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be managed directly may be handled indirectly; or we can interpose
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: barriers between us and undesirable consequences; or we may evade them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if we cannot overcome them. Genuine knowledge has all the practical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: value attaching to efficient habits in any case. (ii) But it also
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increases the meaning, the experienced significance, attaching to an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. A situation to which we respond capriciously or by routine
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has only a minimum of conscious significance; we get nothing mentally
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from it. But wherever knowledge comes into play in determining a new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience there is mental reward; even if we fail practically in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting the needed control we have the satisfaction of experiencing a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meaning instead of merely reacting physically.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: While the content of knowledge is what has happened, what is taken
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as finished and hence settled and sure, the reference of knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is future or prospective. For knowledge furnishes the means of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understanding or giving meaning to what is still going on and what is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to be done. The knowledge of a physician is what he has found out by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: personal acquaintance and by study of what others have ascertained and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recorded. But it is knowledge to him because it supplies the resources
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: by which he interprets the unknown things which confront him, fills out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the partial obvious facts with connected suggested phenomena, foresees
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: their probable future, and makes plans accordingly. When knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cut off from use in giving meaning to what is blind and baffling,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it drops out of consciousness entirely or else becomes an object of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aesthetic contemplation. There is much emotional satisfaction to be had
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from a survey of the symmetry and order of possessed knowledge, and the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: satisfaction is a legitimate one. But this contemplative attitude is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: aesthetic, not intellectual. It is the same sort of joy that comes from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: viewing a finished picture or a well composed landscape. It would make
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no difference if the subject matter were totally different, provided
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it had the same harmonious organization. Indeed, it would make no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: difference if it were wholly invented, a play of fancy. Applicability to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the world means not applicability to what is past and gone--that is out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the question by the nature of the case; it means applicability to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is still going on, what is still unsettled, in the moving scene in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which we are implicated. The very fact that we so easily overlook
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this trait, and regard statements of what is past and out of reach as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge is because we assume the continuity of past and future. We
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cannot entertain the conception of a world in which knowledge of its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past would not be helpful in forecasting and giving meaning to its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: future. We ignore the prospective reference just because it is so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irretrievably implied.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Yet many of the philosophic schools of method which have been mentioned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: transform the ignoring into a virtual denial. They regard knowledge as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something complete in itself irrespective of its availability in dealing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with what is yet to be. And it is this omission which vitiates them
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and which makes them stand as sponsors for educational methods which an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adequate conception of knowledge condemns. For one has only to call to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mind what is sometimes treated in schools as acquisition of knowledge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to realize how lacking it is in any fruitful connection with the ongoing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience of the students--how largely it seems to be believed that the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mere appropriation of subject matter which happens to be stored in books
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: constitutes knowledge. No matter how true what is learned to those who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: found it out and in whose experience it functioned, there is nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which makes it knowledge to the pupils. It might as well be something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about Mars or about some fanciful country unless it fructifies in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: individual's own life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At the time when scholastic method developed, it had relevancy to social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions. It was a method for systematizing and lending rational
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sanction to material accepted on authority. This subject matter meant
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so much that it vitalized the defining and systematizing brought to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: bear upon it. Under present conditions the scholastic method, for most
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persons, means a form of knowing which has no especial connection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with any particular subject matter. It includes making distinctions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: definitions, divisions, and classifications for the mere sake of making
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them--with no objective in experience. The view of thought as a purely
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physical activity having its own forms, which are applied to any
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: material as a seal may be stamped on any plastic stuff, the view which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: underlies what is termed formal logic is essentially the scholastic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method generalized. The doctrine of formal discipline in education is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the natural counterpart of the scholastic method.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The contrasting theories of the method of knowledge which go by the name
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of sensationalism and rationalism correspond to an exclusive emphasis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: upon the particular and the general respectively--or upon bare facts on
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: one side and bare relations on the other. In real knowledge, there is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particularizing and a generalizing function working together. So far as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a situation is confused, it has to be cleared up; it has to be resolved
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into details, as sharply defined as possible. Specified facts and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: qualities constitute the elements of the problem to be dealt with, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is through our sense organs that they are specified. As setting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: forth the problem, they may well be termed particulars, for they are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fragmentary. Since our task is to discover their connections and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recombine them, for us at the time they are partial. They are to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: given meaning; hence, just as they stand, they lack it. Anything which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to be known, whose meaning has still to be made out, offers itself as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particular. But what is already known, if it has been worked over with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a view to making it applicable to intellectually mastering new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: particulars, is general in function. Its function of introducing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection into what is otherwise unconnected constitutes its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generality. Any fact is general if we use it to give meaning to the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: elements of a new experience. "Reason" is just the ability to bring the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: subject matter of prior experience to bear to perceive the significance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the subject matter of a new experience. A person is reasonable in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the degree in which he is habitually open to seeing an event which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: immediately strikes his senses not as an isolated thing but in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connection with the common experience of mankind.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Without the particulars as they are discriminated by the active
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responses of sense organs, there is no material for knowing and no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intellectual growth. Without placing these particulars in the context of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the meanings wrought out in the larger experience of the past--without
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the use of reason or thought--particulars are mere excitations or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: irritations. The mistake alike of the sensational and the rationalistic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schools is that each fails to see that the function of sensory
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulation and thought is relative to reorganizing experience in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: applying the old to the new, thereby maintaining the continuity or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consistency of life. The theory of the method of knowing which is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: advanced in these pages may be termed pragmatic. Its essential feature
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to maintain the continuity of knowing with an activity which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purposely modifies the environment. It holds that knowledge in its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strict sense of something possessed consists of our intellectual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: resources--of all the habits that render our action intelligent. Only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that which has been organized into our disposition so as to enable us to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adapt the environment to our needs and to adapt our aims and desires
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to the situation in which we live is really knowledge. Knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not just something which we are now conscious of, but consists of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dispositions we consciously use in understanding what now happens.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Knowledge as an act is bringing some of our dispositions to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciousness with a view to straightening out a perplexity, by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conceiving the connection between ourselves and the world in which we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: live.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. Such social divisions as interfere with free and full
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: intercourse react to make the intelligence and knowing of members of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the separated classes one-sided. Those whose experience has to do
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: with utilities cut off from the larger end they subserve are practical

text: Chapter Twenty-six: Theories of Morals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John
