text: 1. The Inner and the Outer.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Since morality is concerned with conduct, any dualisms which are set
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: up between mind and activity must reflect themselves in the theory of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: morals. Since the formulations of the separation in the philosophic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory of morals are used to justify and idealize the practices employed
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in moral training, a brief critical discussion is in place. It is a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commonplace of educational theory that the establishing of character is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a comprehensive aim of school instruction and discipline. Hence it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: important that we should be on our guard against a conception of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: relations of intelligence to character which hampers the realization
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the aim, and on the look-out for the conditions which have to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: provided in order that the aim may be successfully acted upon. The first
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obstruction which meets us is the currency of moral ideas which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: split the course of activity into two opposed factors, often named
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: respectively the inner and outer, or the spiritual and the physical.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This division is a culmination of the dualism of mind and the world,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: soul and body, end and means, which we have so frequently noted. In
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: morals it takes the form of a sharp demarcation of the motive of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action from its consequences, and of character from conduct. Motive and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: character are regarded as something purely "inner," existing exclusively
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in consciousness, while consequences and conduct are regarded as outside
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of mind, conduct having to do simply with the movements which carry out
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: motives; consequences with what happens as a result. Different schools
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identify morality with either the inner state of mind or the outer act
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and results, each in separation from the other. Action with a purpose is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: deliberate; it involves a consciously foreseen end and a mental weighing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of considerations pro and eon. It also involves a conscious state of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: longing or desire for the end. The deliberate choice of an aim and of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a settled disposition of desire takes time. During this time complete
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: overt action is suspended. A person who does not have his mind made up,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not know what to do. Consequently he postpones definite action
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: so far as possible. His position may be compared to that of a man
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considering jumping across a ditch. If he were sure he could or could
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not make it, definite activity in some direction would occur. But if
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he considers, he is in doubt; he hesitates. During the time in which a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: single overt line of action is in suspense, his activities are confined
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to such redistributions of energy within the organism as will prepare
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a determinate course of action. He measures the ditch with his eyes;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: he brings himself taut to get a feel of the energy at his disposal; he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: looks about for other ways across, he reflects upon the importance of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: getting across. All this means an accentuation of consciousness; it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means a turning in upon the individual's own attitudes, powers, wishes,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: etc.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Obviously, however, this surging up of personal factors into conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognition is a part of the whole activity in its temporal development.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: There is not first a purely psychical process, followed abruptly by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a radically different physical one. There is one continuous behavior,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proceeding from a more uncertain, divided, hesitating state to a more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: overt, determinate, or complete state. The activity at first consists
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: mainly of certain tensions and adjustments within the organism; as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these are coordinated into a unified attitude, the organism as a whole
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: acts--some definite act is undertaken. We may distinguish, of course,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the more explicitly conscious phase of the continuous activity as mental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or psychical. But that only identifies the mental or psychical to mean
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the indeterminate, formative state of an activity which in its fullness
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involves putting forth of overt energy to modify the environment.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Our conscious thoughts, observations, wishes, aversions are important,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: because they represent inchoate, nascent activities. They fulfill their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: destiny in issuing, later on, into specific and perceptible acts. And
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these inchoate, budding organic readjustments are important because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they are our sole escape from the dominion of routine habits and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: blind impulse. They are activities having a new meaning in process
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of development. Hence, normally, there is an accentuation of personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciousness whenever our instincts and ready formed habits find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: themselves blocked by novel conditions. Then we are thrown back upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ourselves to reorganize our own attitude before proceeding to a definite
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and irretrievable course of action. Unless we try to drive our way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through by sheer brute force, we must modify our organic resources to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: adapt them to the specific features of the situation in which we find
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ourselves. The conscious deliberating and desiring which precede overt
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: action are, then, the methodic personal readjustment implied in activity
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in uncertain situations. This role of mind in continuous activity is not
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: always maintained, however. Desires for something different, aversion to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the given state of things caused by the blocking of successful activity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stimulates the imagination. The picture of a different state of things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does not always function to aid ingenious observation and recollection
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to find a way out and on. Except where there is a disciplined
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition, the tendency is for the imagination to run loose. Instead
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of its objects being checked up by conditions with reference to their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: practicability in execution, they are allowed to develop because of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the immediate emotional satisfaction which they yield. When we find the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: successful display of our energies checked by uncongenial surroundings,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: natural and social, the easiest way out is to build castles in the air
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and let them be a substitute for an actual achievement which involves
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the pains of thought. So in overt action we acquiesce, and build up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an imaginary world in, mind. This break between thought and conduct is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflected in those theories which make a sharp separation between mind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as inner and conduct and consequences as merely outer.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: For the split may be more than an incident of a particular individual's
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience. The social situation may be such as to throw the class
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: given to articulate reflection back into their own thoughts and desires
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without providing the means by which these ideas and aspirations can
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be used to reorganize the environment. Under such conditions, men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take revenge, as it were, upon the alien and hostile environment by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultivating contempt for it, by giving it a bad name. They seek refuge
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and consolation within their own states of mind, their own imaginings
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and wishes, which they compliment by calling both more real and more
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideal than the despised outer world. Such periods have recurred in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: history. In the early centuries of the Christian era, the influential
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: moral systems of Stoicism, of monastic and popular Christianity and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other religious movements of the day, took shape under the influence of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such conditions. The more action which might express prevailing ideals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was checked, the more the inner possession and cultivation of ideals was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: regarded as self-sufficient--as the essence of morality. The external
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world in which activity belongs was thought of as morally indifferent.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Everything lay in having the right motive, even though that motive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was not a moving force in the world. Much the same sort of situation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recurred in Germany in the later eighteenth and early nineteenth
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: centuries; it led to the Kantian insistence upon the good will as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the sole moral good, the will being regarded as something complete in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: itself, apart from action and from the changes or consequences effected
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the world. Later it led to any idealization of existing institutions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as themselves the embodiment of reason.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The purely internal morality of "meaning well," of having a good
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition regardless of what comes of it, naturally led to a reaction.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: This is generally known as either hedonism or utilitarianism. It was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: said in effect that the important thing morally is not what a man is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: inside of his own consciousness, but what he does--the consequences
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which issue, the charges he actually effects. Inner morality was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: attacked as sentimental, arbitrary, dogmatic, subjective--as giving men
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: leave to dignify and shield any dogma congenial to their self-interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or any caprice occurring to imagination by calling it an intuition or an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: ideal of conscience. Results, conduct, are what counts; they afford
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the sole measure of morality. Ordinary morality, and hence that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: schoolroom, is likely to be an inconsistent compromise of both views.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: On one hand, certain states of feeling are made much of; the individual
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must "mean well," and if his intentions are good, if he had the right
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sort of emotional consciousness, he may be relieved of responsibility
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for full results in conduct. But since, on the other hand, certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: things have to be done to meet the convenience and the requirements of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others, and of social order in general, there is great insistence upon
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the doing of certain things, irrespective of whether the individual has
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: any concern or intelligence in their doing. He must toe the mark; he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: must have his nose held to the grindstone; he must obey; he must form
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: useful habits; he must learn self-control,--all of these precepts being
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: understood in a way which emphasizes simply the immediate thing tangibly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done, irrespective of the spirit of thought and desire in which it is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: done, and irrespective therefore of its effect upon other less obvious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: doings.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is hoped that the prior discussion has sufficiently elaborated the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: method by which both of these evils are avoided. One or both of these
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: evils must result wherever individuals, whether young or old, cannot
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engage in a progressively cumulative undertaking under conditions which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: engage their interest and require their reflection. For only in such
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cases is it possible that the disposition of desire and thinking should
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be an organic factor in overt and obvious conduct. Given a consecutive
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity embodying the student's own interest, where a definite result
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is to be obtained, and where neither routine habit nor the following of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: dictated directions nor capricious improvising will suffice, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there the rise of conscious purpose, conscious desire, and deliberate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reflection are inevitable. They are inevitable as the spirit and quality
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of an activity having specific consequences, not as forming an isolated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: realm of inner consciousness.
