text: 2. The Opposition of Duty and Interest. Probably there is no antithesis
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more often set up in moral discussion than that between acting
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from "principle" and from "interest." To act on principle is to act
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disinterestedly, according to a general law, which is above all personal
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerations. To act according to interest is, so the allegation runs,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to act selfishly, with one's own personal profit in view. It substitutes
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the changing expediency of the moment for devotion to unswerving moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: law. The false idea of interest underlying this opposition has already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: been criticized (See Chapter X), but some moral aspects of the question
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: will now be considered. A clew to the matter may be found in the fact
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: that the supporters of the "interest" side of the controversy habitually
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: use the term "self-interest." Starting from the premises that unless
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there is interest in an object or idea, there is no motive force, they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end with the conclusion that even when a person claims to be acting from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle or from a sense of duty, he really acts as he does because
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: there "is something in it" for himself. The premise is sound; the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conclusion false. In reply the other school argues that since man is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capable of generous self-forgetting and even self-sacrificing action, he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is capable of acting without interest. Again the premise is sound, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the conclusion false. The error on both sides lies in a false notion of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the relation of interest and the self.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Both sides assume that the self is a fixed and hence isolated quantity.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: As a consequence, there is a rigid dilemma between acting for an
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest of the self and without interest. If the self is something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fixed antecedent to action, then acting from interest means trying to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: get more in the way of possessions for the self--whether in the way
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of fame, approval of others, power over others, pecuniary profit, or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: pleasure. Then the reaction from this view as a cynical depreciation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of human nature leads to the view that men who act nobly act with no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest at all. Yet to an unbiased judgment it would appear plain that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a man must be interested in what he is doing or he would not do it. A
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: physician who continues to serve the sick in a plague at almost certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: danger to his own life must be interested in the efficient performance
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of his profession--more interested in that than in the safety of his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: own bodily life. But it is distorting facts to say that this interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is merely a mask for an interest in something else which he gets by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuing his customary services--such as money or good repute or
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: virtue; that it is only a means to an ulterior selfish end. The moment
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: we recognize that the self is not something ready-made, but something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in continuous formation through choice of action, the whole situation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: clears up. A man's interest in keeping at his work in spite of danger to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life means that his self is found in that work; if he finally gave up,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and preferred his personal safety or comfort, it would mean that he
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: preferred to be that kind of a self. The mistake lies in making a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation between interest and self, and supposing that the latter
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the end to which interest in objects and acts and others is a mere
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: means. In fact, self and interest are two names for the same fact;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the kind and amount of interest actively taken in a thing reveals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and measures the quality of selfhood which exists. Bear in mind that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest means the active or moving identity of the self with a certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: object, and the whole alleged dilemma falls to the ground.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Unselfishness, for example, signifies neither lack of interest in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: what is done (that would mean only machine-like indifference) nor
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: selflessness--which would mean absence of virility and character. As
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: employed everywhere outside of this particular theoretical controversy,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the term "unselfishness" refers to the kind of aims and objects which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: habitually interest a man. And if we make a mental survey of the kind
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of interests which evoke the use of this epithet, we shall see that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: they have two intimately associated features. (i) The generous self
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously identifies itself with the full range of relationships
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: implied in its activity, instead of drawing a sharp line between itself
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and considerations which are excluded as alien or indifferent; (ii)
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it readjusts and expands its past ideas of itself to take in new
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences as they become perceptible. When the physician began
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his career he may not have thought of a pestilence; he may not have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consciously identified himself with service under such conditions. But,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: if he has a normally growing or active self, when he finds that his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: vocation involves such risks, he willingly adopts them as integral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: portions of his activity. The wider or larger self which means inclusion
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: instead of denial of relationships is identical with a self which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: enlarges in order to assume previously unforeseen ties.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: In such crises of readjustment--and the crisis may be slight as well
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as great--there may be a transitional conflict of "principle" with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: "interest." It is the nature of a habit to involve ease in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: accustomed line of activity. It is the nature of a readjusting of habit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to involve an effort which is disagreeable--something to which a man
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has deliberately to hold himself. In other words, there is a tendency to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identify the self--or take interest--in what one has got used to, and to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: turn away the mind with aversion or irritation when an unexpected thing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which involves an unpleasant modification of habit comes up. Since
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in the past one has done one's duty without having to face such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disagreeable circumstance, why not go on as one has been? To yield to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this temptation means to narrow and isolate the thought of the self--to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: treat it as complete. Any habit, no matter how efficient in the past,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which has become set, may at any time bring this temptation with it. To
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: act from principle in such an emergency is not to act on some abstract
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle, or duty at large; it is to act upon the principle of a course
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of action, instead of upon the circumstances which have attended it. The
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: principle of a physician's conduct is its animating aim and spirit--the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: care for the diseased. The principle is not what justifies an activity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: for the principle is but another name for the continuity of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity. If the activity as manifested in its consequences is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: undesirable, to act upon principle is to accentuate its evil. And a man
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: who prides himself upon acting upon principle is likely to be a man who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insists upon having his own way without learning from experience what
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the better way. He fancies that some abstract principle justifies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: his course of action without recognizing that his principle needs
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: justification.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Assuming, however, that school conditions are such as to provide
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: desirable occupations, it is interest in the occupation as a whole--that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is, in its continuous development--which keeps a pupil at his work in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: spite of temporary diversions and unpleasant obstacles. Where there is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: no activity having a growing significance, appeal to principle is either
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: purely verbal, or a form of obstinate pride or an appeal to extraneous
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: considerations clothed with a dignified title. Undoubtedly there are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: junctures where momentary interest ceases and attention flags, and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: where reinforcement is needed. But what carries a person over these hard
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: stretches is not loyalty to duty in the abstract, but interest in his
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: occupation. Duties are "offices"--they are the specific acts needed for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the fulfilling of a function--or, in homely language--doing one's job.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: And the man who is genuinely interested in his job is the man who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is able to stand temporary discouragement, to persist in the face of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: obstacles, to take the lean with the fat: he makes an interest out of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meeting and overcoming difficulties and distraction.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 3. Intelligence and Character. A noteworthy paradox often accompanies
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: discussions of morals. On the one hand, there is an identification of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the moral with the rational. Reason is set up as a faculty from which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: proceed ultimate moral intuitions, and sometimes, as in the Kantian
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: theory, it is said to supply the only proper moral motive. On the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: other hand, the value of concrete, everyday intelligence is constantly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: underestimated, and even deliberately depreciated. Morals is often
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought to be an affair with which ordinary knowledge has nothing to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: do. Moral knowledge is thought to be a thing apart, and conscience is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thought of as something radically different from consciousness. This
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: separation, if valid, is of especial significance for education.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Moral education in school is practically hopeless when we set up the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: development of character as a supreme end, and at the same time treat
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the acquiring of knowledge and the development of understanding, which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of necessity occupy the chief part of school time, as having nothing
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to do with character. On such a basis, moral education is inevitably
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reduced to some kind of catechetical instruction, or lessons about
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: morals. Lessons "about morals" signify as matter of course lessons
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in what other people think about virtues and duties. It amounts to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: something only in the degree in which pupils happen to be already
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: animated by a sympathetic and dignified regard for the sentiments of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others. Without such a regard, it has no more influence on character
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than information about the mountains of Asia; with a servile regard, it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: increases dependence upon others, and throws upon those in authority the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: responsibility for conduct. As a matter of fact, direct instruction in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: morals has been effective only in social groups where it was a part of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the authoritative control of the many by the few. Not the teaching as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such but the reinforcement of it by the whole regime of which it was
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: an incident made it effective. To attempt to get similar results from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lessons about morals in a democratic society is to rely upon sentimental
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: magic.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: At the other end of the scale stands the Socratic-Platonic teaching
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which identifies knowledge and virtue--which holds that no man does evil
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowingly but only because of ignorance of the good. This doctrine is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: commonly attacked on the ground that nothing is more common than for a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: man to know the good and yet do the bad: not knowledge, but habituation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: or practice, and motive are what is required. Aristotle, in fact, at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: once attacked the Platonic teaching on the ground that moral virtue is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: like an art, such as medicine; the experienced practitioner is better
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: than a man who has theoretical knowledge but no practical experience of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disease and remedies. The issue turns, however, upon what is meant by
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge. Aristotle's objection ignored the gist of Plato's teaching to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the effect that man could not attain a theoretical insight into the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good except as he had passed through years of practical habituation and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: strenuous discipline. Knowledge of the good was not a thing to be got
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: either from books or from others, but was achieved through a prolonged
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education. It was the final and culminating grace of a mature experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life. Irrespective of Plato's position, it is easy to perceive that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the term knowledge is used to denote things as far apart as intimate
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and vital personal realization,--a conviction gained and tested in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experience,--and a second-handed, largely symbolic, recognition that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persons in general believe so and so--a devitalized remote information.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: That the latter does not guarantee conduct, that it does not profoundly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: affect character, goes without saying. But if knowledge means something
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the same sort as our conviction gained by trying and testing that
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: sugar is sweet and quinine bitter, the case stands otherwise. Every time
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a man sits on a chair rather than on a stove, carries an umbrella when
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it rains, consults a doctor when ill--or in short performs any of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thousand acts which make up his daily life, he proves that knowledge of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a certain kind finds direct issue in conduct. There is every reason to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: suppose that the same sort of knowledge of good has a like expression;
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in fact "good" is an empty term unless it includes the satisfactions
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: experienced in such situations as those mentioned. Knowledge that other
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: persons are supposed to know something might lead one to act so as to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: win the approbation others attach to certain actions, or at least so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to give others the impression that one agrees with them; there is no
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reason why it should lead to personal initiative and loyalty in behalf
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the beliefs attributed to them.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: It is not necessary, accordingly, to dispute about the proper meaning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of the term knowledge. It is enough for educational purposes to note
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the different qualities covered by the one name, to realize that it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is knowledge gained at first hand through the exigencies of experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which affects conduct in significant ways. If a pupil learns things
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from books simply in connection with school lessons and for the sake of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: reciting what he has learned when called upon, then knowledge will have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effect upon some conduct--namely upon that of reproducing statements at
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the demand of others. There is nothing surprising that such "knowledge"
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: should not have much influence in the life out of school. But this is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not a reason for making a divorce between knowledge and conduct, but for
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: holding in low esteem this kind of knowledge. The same thing may be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: said of knowledge which relates merely to an isolated and technical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: specialty; it modifies action but only in its own narrow line. In truth,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the problem of moral education in the schools is one with the problem of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: securing knowledge--the knowledge connected with the system of impulses
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and habits. For the use to which any known fact is put depends upon its
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: connections. The knowledge of dynamite of a safecracker may be identical
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in verbal form with that of a chemist; in fact, it is different, for it
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is knit into connection with different aims and habits, and thus has a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: different import.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Our prior discussion of subject-matter as proceeding from direct
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: activity having an immediate aim, to the enlargement of meaning found in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: geography and history, and then to scientifically organized knowledge,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: was based upon the idea of maintaining a vital connection between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: knowledge and activity. What is learned and employed in an occupation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: having an aim and involving cooperation with others is moral knowledge,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: whether consciously so regarded or not. For it builds up a social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest and confers the intelligence needed to make that interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effective in practice. Just because the studies of the curriculum
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: represent standard factors in social life, they are organs of initiation
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: into social values. As mere school studies, their acquisition has only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a technical worth. Acquired under conditions where their social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: significance is realized, they feed moral interest and develop moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: insight. Moreover, the qualities of mind discussed under the topic
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of method of learning are all of them intrinsically moral qualities.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Open-mindedness, single-mindedness, sincerity, breadth of outlook,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thoroughness, assumption of responsibility for developing the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: consequences of ideas which are accepted, are moral traits. The habit
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of identifying moral characteristics with external conformity to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: authoritative prescriptions may lead us to ignore the ethical value of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: these intellectual attitudes, but the same habit tends to reduce morals
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: to a dead and machinelike routine. Consequently while such an attitude
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: has moral results, the results are morally undesirable--above all in a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: democratic society where so much depends upon personal disposition.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: 4. The Social and the Moral. All of the separations which we have been
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: criticizing--and which the idea of education set forth in the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: previous chapters is designed to avoid--spring from taking morals too
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: narrowly,--giving them, on one side, a sentimental goody-goody turn
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: without reference to effective ability to do what is socially needed,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and, on the other side, overemphasizing convention and tradition so
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as to limit morals to a list of definitely stated acts. As a matter of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact, morals are as broad as acts which concern our relationships with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: others. And potentially this includes all our acts, even though their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social bearing may not be thought of at the time of performance. For
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: every act, by the principle of habit, modifies disposition--it sets up
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a certain kind of inclination and desire. And it is impossible to tell
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: when the habit thus strengthened may have a direct and perceptible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: influence on our association with others. Certain traits of character
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: have such an obvious connection with our social relationships that we
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: call them "moral" in an emphatic sense--truthfulness, honesty, chastity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: amiability, etc. But this only means that they are, as compared with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: some other attitudes, central:--that they carry other attitudes with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: them. They are moral in an emphatic sense not because they are isolated
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and exclusive, but because they are so intimately connected with
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: thousands of other attitudes which we do not explicitly recognize--which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perhaps we have not even names for. To call them virtues in their
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolation is like taking the skeleton for the living body. The bones
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are certainly important, but their importance lies in the fact that they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: support other organs of the body in such a way as to make them capable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of integrated effective activity. And the same is true of the qualities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of character which we specifically designate virtues. Morals concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: nothing less than the whole character, and the whole character is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identical with the man in all his concrete make-up and manifestations.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: To possess virtue does not signify to have cultivated a few namable
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and exclusive traits; it means to be fully and adequately what one is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: capable of becoming through association with others in all the offices
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of life.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The moral and the social quality of conduct are, in the last analysis,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: identical with each other. It is then but to restate explicitly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the import of our earlier chapters regarding the social function of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: education to say that the measure of the worth of the administration,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: curriculum, and methods of instruction of the school is the extent to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which they are animated by a social spirit. And the great danger which
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: threatens school work is the absence of conditions which make possible
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a permeating social spirit; this is the great enemy of effective moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: training. For this spirit can be actively present only when certain
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: conditions are met.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (i) In the first place, the school must itself be a community life
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in all which that implies. Social perceptions and interests can be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: developed only in a genuinely social medium--one where there is give and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: take in the building up of a common experience. Informational statements
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: about things can be acquired in relative isolation by any one who
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: previously has had enough intercourse with others to have learned
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: language. But realization of the meaning of the linguistic signs is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: quite another matter. That involves a context of work and play in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: association with others. The plea which has been made for education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: through continued constructive activities in this book rests upon the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: fact they afford an opportunity for a social atmosphere. In place of a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school set apart from life as a place for learning lessons, we have
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a miniature social group in which study and growth are incidents of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: present shared experience. Playgrounds, shops, workrooms, laboratories
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not only direct the natural active tendencies of youth, but they
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: involve intercourse, communication, and cooperation,--all extending the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: perception of connections.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: (ii) The learning in school should be continuous with that out of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: school. There should be a free interplay between the two. This is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: possible only when there are numerous points of contact between the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: social interests of the one and of the other. A school is conceivable in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: which there should be a spirit of companionship and shared activity,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: but where its social life would no more represent or typify that of the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: world beyond the school walls than that of a monastery. Social concern
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and understanding would be developed, but they would not be available
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: outside; they would not carry over. The proverbial separation of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: town and gown, the cultivation of academic seclusion, operate in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: this direction. So does such adherence to the culture of the past as
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: generates a reminiscent social spirit, for this makes an individual feel
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: more at home in the life of other days than in his own. A professedly
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: cultural education is peculiarly exposed to this danger. An idealized
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: past becomes the refuge and solace of the spirit; present-day concerns
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are found sordid, and unworthy of attention. But as a rule, the absence
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of a social environment in connection with which learning is a need and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: a reward is the chief reason for the isolation of the school; and this
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: isolation renders school knowledge inapplicable to life and so infertile
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in character.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: A narrow and moralistic view of morals is responsible for the failure to
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: recognize that all the aims and values which are desirable in education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: are themselves moral. Discipline, natural development, culture, social
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: efficiency, are moral traits--marks of a person who is a worthy member
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: of that society which it is the business of education to further. There
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is an old saying to the effect that it is not enough for a man to be
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: good; he must be good for something. The something for which a man must
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: be good is capacity to live as a social member so that what he gets from
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: living with others balances with what he contributes. What he gets and
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: gives as a human being, a being with desires, emotions, and ideas, is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not external possessions, but a widening and deepening of conscious
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life--a more intense, disciplined, and expanding realization of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: meanings. What he materially receives and gives is at most opportunities
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and means for the evolution of conscious life. Otherwise, it is neither
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: giving nor taking, but a shifting about of the position of things in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: space, like the stirring of water and sand with a stick. Discipline,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: culture, social efficiency, personal refinement, improvement of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: character are but phases of the growth of capacity nobly to share in
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: such a balanced experience. And education is not a mere means to such a
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: life. Education is such a life. To maintain capacity for such education
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: is the essence of morals. For conscious life is a continual beginning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: afresh.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: Summary. The most important problem of moral education in the school
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: concerns the relationship of knowledge and conduct. For unless the
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: learning which accrues in the regular course of study affects character,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: it is futile to conceive the moral end as the unifying and culminating
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: end of education. When there is no intimate organic connection between
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the methods and materials of knowledge and moral growth, particular
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: lessons and modes of discipline have to be resorted to: knowledge is
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: not integrated into the usual springs of action and the outlook on life,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: while morals become moralistic--a scheme of separate virtues.
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: The two theories chiefly associated with the separation of learning
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: from activity, and hence from morals, are those which cut off inner
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: disposition and motive--the conscious personal factor--and deeds
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: as purely physical and outer; and which set action from interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in opposition to that from principle. Both of these separations are
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: overcome in an educational scheme where learning is the accompaniment of
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: continuous activities or occupations which have a social aim and utilize
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the materials of typical social situations. For under such conditions,
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: the school becomes itself a form of social life, a miniature community
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: and one in close interaction with other modes of associated experience
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: beyond school walls. All education which develops power to share
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: effectively in social life is moral. It forms a character which not only
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: does the particular deed socially necessary but one which is interested
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in that continuous readjustment which is essential to growth. Interest
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: in learning from all the contacts of life is the essential moral
title: Democracy and Education: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
author: Dewey, John

text: interest.
